properties.text: 2. VI. Monday.  Morning absorbed in reading the Newspapers of the last Night’s Mail and the Globe of Saturday evening upon my table— It contains the speech of John C. Calhoun in the Senate of the United States last August in favour of advising and consenting to the ratification of the Webster and Ashburton Treaty— Calhoun is the High Priest of Moloch— The embodied Spirit of Slavery— He has resigned his Seat in the Senate of the United States to take effect from the close of the present Congress the 3d. of March next—and immediately upon the acceptance of his resignation by the Legislature of South-Carolina, they unanimously nominated him as a Candidate for election, as President of the United States for four years from the 4th. of March 1845. His speech is remarkable for one of those glaring, unblushing dare-devil inconsistencies, which as far as I know are peculiar to the doctrinal school of Slavery— He begins by a broad, explicit, unqualified declaration that he has always believed the claim of Maine upon the North-eastern boundary question just; and then proceeds with an elaborate argument to prove, that on that same identical boundary question the title of Great-Britain is clear, to more than she has ever claimed— On the subject of Slavery and the Slave-trade, the negotiation itself was a Scapinade— A struggle between the Plenipotentiaries to outwit each other, and to circumvent both countries by a slippery compromise between freedom and Slavery— Calhoun crows about his own success in imposing his own bastard Law of Nations upon the Senate by his preposterous Resolutions, and chuckles at Websters appealing to those Resolutions now after dodging from the duty of refuting and confounding them then— Calhoun concludes upon the whole to put up with the ticklish truce, patched up between the Treaty and the correspondence; and this was what in fact reconciled him to the ratification— There is a temperance in his manner obviously aiming to conciliate the Northern political sopranos who abhor slavery, and help to forge fetters for the Slave— My wife is still confined to her bed, and was more unwell this day than yesterday— There were however none the less of female visitors, who were well received by Mrs John Adams— Our late minister to France Lewis Cass, was among them; and told me that shortly before he left France he had a conversation with my old friend the king, concerning me, which he wished to tell me; and he was beginning to do so, when other visitors came up and interrupted him— He said he would call again some evening and tell me— They say the crowd at the President’s this day was unexampled— I did not go out. Walter Hellen dined with us. Campbell dined at the President’s and came in after dinner, and gave us some music with Isaac Hull.— Mr Greenough left with me a Memorial to Congress; and poor Hassler was raving about the treatment of him in the house—

3. V:30. Tuesday.  Mr Kurtz, and Mr Barcroft of Georgetown called on me this morning, and stated that they were members of the Society of Friends, and Mr Kurtz had a Letter from Philadelphia, recommending Mrs Lucretia Mott, who is desirous of obtaining the use of the Hall of the house of Representatives for a religious exercise—and without coming directly to the point, Mr Kurtz gave me to understand that it was desired that I should make the motion in the house; that she might have the use of the hall— I desired Mr Kurtz to say to Mrs Motte, that I remembered with much pleasure the hospitality which I had once, some years since enjoyed at her house, and the social intercours with which I had at other times been favoured by her husband, and other friends— That I should be happy to see her at my house, and if she desired it would make the motion in the house that she should have the use of the hall— But I observed to Mr Kurtz that Mrs Motte was known as a distinguished abolitionist of Slavery, that there was little difference between her opinions upon the subject of Slavery and mine: but he knew how obnoxious I was here both in and out of Congress for that very thing: and he would consider whether the application for the use of the hall would not be more likely to succeed if made by another member— I added that Speaker White told me last Saturday that application had been made to him, for the use of the hall by Mrs Motte, and that he had granted it— Mr Kurtz thought as I did that if there should be a necessity for asking the leave of the house for the use of the hall, it would be more likely to succeed if moved by some other member than by me—and said he would deliver faithfully my message to Mrs Motte. I attended the meeting of the Committee of foreign affairs—present Cushing, Everett, Granger, Caruthers, Stuart, Meriwether—absent Shepperd and Holmes— The Letter from the Secretary of State asking an appropriation of 20000 dollars, for running the boundary line under the Ashburton Treaty, was referred to Mr Cushing, and the President’s Message relating to the Sandwich Islands and China, were referred to the Chairman to report two bills— At the house, Slade moved a suspension of the 21st rule, for him to introduce a preamble and Resolution against the Slave trade in the District of Columbia. Suspension of the rule refused by yeas and nays 73 to 111. Morgan offered a Resolution to repeal a Florida negro-law—laid on the table 113 to 80— Bowne moved that the judiciary committee be instructed to report next Thursday at 12. O’Clock a given bill in totidem verbis—previous question lost. Bankrupt repeal bill. T. F. Marshall, withdraws from the field on the plea of ill health— Greenough here, and read his memorial.

4. V:30. Wednesday.  The weather yesterday morning was so mild that I rode to the capitol, without taking an outer garment—but in walking home I found it severely cold and as evening came on, I found the Catarrh upon me, I fear for the residue of the Winter— This morning I went to the general Post-Office, with a Letter of remonstrance froma minister at South Dedham, against the establishment of the Post-Office at that place, for which I had applied, with the Petition of Isaac Ellis and others and a Letter from William Ellis of Dedham— Mr Wickliffe promised to suspend the establishment of the Post-Office petitioned for, till further information shall be obtained— At the house Bowne’s Resolution to instruct the Committee on the judiciary to report a prescribed bill to refund General Jackson’s fine, with interest, to morrow, was debated through the morning hour, a motion to lay it on the table having been lost by yeas and nays—91 to 107 There is already a Bill on the Calendar, reported by the judiciary Committee at the last Session, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, but Bowne wants to signalize himself by the combustion of his zeal for the old hero. This has got to be a mere party foot-ball; and Bowne is attempting to carry the measure by storm.— And it is quite probable he will succeed— The speaker against all principle decided that Bowne’s motion to instruct the judiciary Committee to report another Bill, while there is already one reported by the same Committee now in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, was in order, has prostrated all rule upon the subject, and a succession of previous questions, stifling all discussion of the principles involved in the bill is probably the only way by which it can be carried— The expiration of the hour however, put off the decision again for this day; and Bowne took the floor again for the immediate repeal of the Bankrupt Law— He was followed by Meriwether—he by Pickens, and he by Proffit, with intermediate interruptions, and defiances of Cushing till past 3. O’Clock when Gordon took the floor, and the house adjourned— Cushing’s national venom was ransacked and held up to scorn by Meriwether and Pickens, notwithstanding his vehement disclaimers and challenges as for specifications— Proffit did all he could to help him out of his trouble, and piteously implored the house to allow Cushing an hour to explain the real meaning of his speech— But it was too bare-faced and flagrant; and if had an hour for explanation he would need a week to explain the explanation itself— Isaac Hull dined abroad— Walter Hellen was here and I had a long evening visit from Mr Sedgwick.

5. V:30— Thursday  My business encroaches on my Diary— At the house this morning John Campbell of South-Carolina, upon leave introduced a bill to suspend the operation of the second Section of the apportionment bill (the second which prescribes the elections by single districts) in all elections for the 28th. Congress— Campbell is the man who introduced that section into the bill itself. He now flinches from his own purpose— His bill was read twice—he wanted to pass it at once—but Barnard moved its reference to the Committee of elections—and Briggs that it should be printed, which was carried— Halsted introduced on leave and after notice the bill to regulate the taking of testimony in cases of contested elections and for other purposes, which passed both houses at the last Session, and was pocketed by the President— It was referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— W. W. Irwin moved a resolution instructing the judiciary committee to enquire into the expediency of repealing a section of one of the retrenchment acts of the last Session, prohibiting the publication by the Secretary of State of the Laws of Congress in Newspapers except in the city of Washington—adopted— Everett intreated the house to take up, and act upon his bankrupt act repeal bill— But Gwin, insisted upon taking up Bowne’s Resolution to instruct the judiciary Committee to report this day the Bill, first introduced into the Senate on the 10th. of last March by Dr Linn of Missouri— Barnard had moved an amendment, to instruct the Committee to report the facts and principles of the case; and Arnold had moved to refer the Resolution to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Gwin’s speech was a rancorous and malignant party invective upon the whigs for a sneaking desire to give the bill the go-by, and spurring them to take it into consideration: Cushing made a bombastic speech, about the glories of the victory of New-Orleans and in order to pass the bill in anticipation of the anniversary, which will be on Sunday he moved that all debate should cease on the bill in committee of the whole to-morrow at two O’Clock and the questions be taken on the bill and amendments— The Speaker decided the motion to be not in order; the bill in Committee of the whole not having been debated at all— I then rose and addressed the Speaker— Cushing who had moved the previous question claimed to hold the floor against me for another motion; but the Speaker told him he could not have the floor on two motions at once— I spoke about half an hour, till the expiration of the morning hour when Everett called for the orders of the day and his bankrupt act repeal bill— C. J. Ingersoll moved to go into Committee of the whole to get at the Jackson fine-bill lost by yeas and nays 100 to 106— Then followed on the bankrupt repeal bill an amusing snarl between Gordon and Bowne, New-York Democrats— M’Keon commenced a Speech, but the house soon adjourned— Mr Hackett, the comedian was here this Evening.

6. V:30. Friday—  It was the day before yesterday, that Mr Parker called on me, and announced himself as the agent of the bond holders of the debts of the several States of this Union; and he came here to solicit the interposition of the Government to enforce the punctuality of the States in the payment of their debts, interest and principal. And he asked my opinion as to the right of the bond holders to demand this interposition, and as to the duty of the federal government to extend it— I told him that I had no doubt on either point— That the bond holders have the right to demand, and the duty of the federal government to grant their interposition to compel the States to pay their honest debts— But that the President of the United States held a different opinion, and that he had nothing to do with the debts of the States— And that a vast majority of both houses of Congress held in this respect the same opinion as the President— That of course nothing will or can be done at present here, on the subject, and I therefore shall attempt nothing, having repeatedly expressed my opinion as to the result. He said he had written to the President to claim the interposition of the Government, and had not received an answer. That he would write to him again; and if he should receive no answer he would recommend to the bond holders to apply to their own Governments for their interposition— This morning Mr Lewis Johnson came to enquire, if I had examined certain papers relating to his administration of the estate of William Otis, and to his recovery of Otis’s claim against the Government, but I had not found time to read them; and I promised to read them as soon as possible— Mr Leavitt, who has been quite unwell came and borrowed a file of the Richmond Whig. He has published in the Emancipator only a part of my address at Braintree, and for omitting other parts of it alledged that he did not approve them— I asked him, what were the parts which he disapproved. He said the parts which had a political party aspect. I said they all had indirect reference to the Slavery questions— At the house Bowne’s resolution to instruct the judiciary committee, to report on yesterday, Linn’s old Senate bill, with Barnard’s amendment, and Arnold’s motion to refer the Resolution to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union were taken up— I moved an amendment to the Resolution, as a substitute for Barnard’s, and Arnold withdrew his motion. I spoke about half an hour when C. J. Ingersoll claimed the floor and the Speaker gave it to him— I claimed a whole hour upon my own motion but the Speaker refused it and I submitted— Ingersoll spoke about 30 minutes when the morning hour expired— He begged hard to be allowed to proceed but was not indulged— Nor could Everett get up the Bankrupt repeal bill. The rest of the day was devoted to private Bills— Campbell dined and spent the Evening with us.

7. VI. Saturday.  I sit up so late at Night reading the Newspapers and Letters, which come by the Mail from 9. to 10 in the evening, that I seldom reach my bed before midnight, which necessarily delays for two hours at least that of my rising— Sex horas somno—says Lord Coke, quoting from I know not whom—and that has been for more than forty years my rule of life—and the six hours are from ten at night to four in the morning— But the rule of life must be modified, by external causes, and by social relations with others— If I sit up till Midnight I cannot rise before six, and that irregularity leads to the laxity of the rule itself—to indulging in morning laziness encroaching upon the best hours of the day— Lieutenant Wilkes was here this morning—extremely solicitous about his promotion. A law of the last Session of Congress limits the number of Officers of each rank in the Navy that may be appointed, and that number is full— On the list of Lieutenants there are only four seniors to Mr Wilkes, and the appointment of him as a Commander would require the appointment of those also to the same rank— Mr Barnard has been preparing a resolution to repeal the restriction upon the number of officers, so as to allow the appointment of five more commanders than are now commissioned— And he and Mr Wilkes are urgent with me to offer the resolution, which I have consented to do; though I told Mr Barnard that I could seldom consent to offer a Resolution prepared by any other than myself. Mr John C. Clark a member of the house from Bainbridge, Chenango County, New-York called on me with a constituent of his, whose name escaped me, and whose only motive for coming was of curiosity to see me. At the house after the interloping intrusions one of which was Arnold’s attempt to get up his retrenchment bill N. 568. Bowne’s Resolution to instruct the judiciary Committee to report last Thursday Linn’s bill to refund with interest from March 1815 General Jackson’s fine, with my amendment yesterday proposed; came up, and Charles J. Ingersoll was delivered of his long treasured philippic upon me and glorification of himself and of Jackson— He spoke till the close of his hour; and then by a suspension of the rules, a half hour more, to vent the whole volume of his spleen upon me— When he closed, half a dozen members started up for the floor, which the Speaker gave to William O. Butler of Kentucky who was one of Jackson’s aids at New-Orleans. But the house passed to the consideration of private business till the adjournment— Dr Thomas was here this Evening, and Mr Hassler full of his grievances—and his hopes— Hull and Campbell dined at the Russian Minister Bodisco’s.

8. VII. Sunday  My catarrhal cough is upon me, I fear for the rest of the winter— The weather is so warm and sultry that great part of this day passed without requiring a fire in my cabinet— But it was damp and showery like an April day I attended the morning public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where a Baptist clergyman named Anderson, said to be a professor at a College in Maine, but now endeavouring to drum up a new baptist church in this city by preaching at the Apollo Hall, preached in the Speaker’s chair from 2. Corinthians 5.17. “Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold all things are become new.” The discourse was so confined to the first part of the verse; and it was the most ingenious exposition of the Christian doctrine of regeneration or the new birth. It was altogether argumentative and ingeniously metaphysical— It was evident that the preacher has been a close student of the school of Edwards. In handling his subject he laid down his positions—then stated the objections of the unbeliever; and answered them successively.— He presented a formal division of the motives to human action—external and internal,—and argued that regeneration or the new birth— As conclusive evidence of the efficacy of vicarious punishment and thereby of the atonement of Christ, he said the truth of any affirmative position, must be tested by its effects— Then he averred that whenever the process of regeneration took place, it was by a change of the influence of the external over the internal motives to action; which he exemplified by allusion to the treasury of Benedict Arnold, produced by the influence of the external motive of temptation over the inner man—and by supposing what would have been the effect of the same external motive if it had been applied to General Washington— The internal motive would have rejected the influence of the external one and so it is whenever by divine grace and the atonement of Christ the inner man is turned from sin to holiness.— Mr Anderson was introduced to me after the service by Mr Briggs— Neither of the chaplains of Congress was present. Joseph H. Adams dined with us— He and Campbell, and Richard D Cutts, and Walter Hellen were here all this Evening— Campbell is going off to-morrow morning for New-Orleans.— After dinner, I went to St John’s Church where the bell rung but there was no service; a shower of rain intervening— I called to see Mr T. B. Johnson, who is slowly reviving from a third shock of palsy, and looks all but dead— I then attended at the Presbyterian Church, where the new supplier of the pulpit preached to twenty hearers from 2. Corinthians 10.12: [“]For we dare not make ourselves of the number, or compare ourselves with some that commend themselves— But they measuring themselves by themselves and comparing themselves among themselves are not wise.”

9. III.45. Monday.  No visitors. Before going to the house this morning, I called on the Secretary of State at his Office, to confer with him upon the Message of the President relating to the Sandwich Islands and to China, referred by the House to the Committee of foreign Affairs, and by them to me— Mr Webster referred me to the correspondence between the Commissioners from the Sandwich Islands Richards and Haa-li-lio, and himself, for the views of the administration favourable to the recognition of the Government of those Islands—with which I concurred— I concurred also with the recommendations of the message, respecting the expediency of instituting a diplomatic mission to China; but enquired what was the amount of appropriation desired for both objects— Mr Webster thought a salaried Consul, like those maintained at the Barbary States would require about 3000 dollars and after some conversation on the probable details of expenditure he thought an appropriation of 40,000 dollars, would be adequate for the mission to China. He said he would send me an estimate in the course of the day; together with a despatch from Edward Everett containing some indications of the present views of the British Government concerning their intercourse with China— He accordingly sent me the papers in the course of the day, to the House— This conference delayed me so that the house had been a quarter of an hour in Session, when I reached my seat— I found new game was started. Cushing was vapouring against the Committee of Ways and Means, from which Fillmore the Chairman had reported an unanimous Resolution that the exchequer plan reported by the Secretary of the Treasury (Forward) at the last Session, and recommended by the President ought not to be adopted (Webster’s.) Cushing insisted that the Committee should have reported a positive measure— The minority of the Committee consisted of Atherton and Pickens, did report an amendment instructing the Committee to report a positive bill; in substance the sub treasury— Here was a perfect snarl, which brought out after Cushing, Everett, Arnold, Pickens, Wise W. Cost Johnson, Botts Fillmore, Granger, Joseph R. Ingersoll, Turney, John Campbell, Thomas F. Marshall, and at last Proffit, who only took the floor— Irwin moved to adjourn and refused to withdraw it merely to take the question on printing the reports— Fillmore called the yeas and nays on the adjournment, and Irwin finding the vote going against him, withdrew his motion till the question to print was taken and carried. Botts had given notice that he would to-morrow move his charges for the impeachment of President Tyler. When Marshall’s speech was cut off by the expiration of his hour he said he would take it up again, upon any other question that may come before the house, and make his whole speech right through. Hull went to a Ball at Major Kearney’s.

10. IV:30. Tuesday  A person by the name of Hoover came and enquired if I had received some time last Summer a sample of ink from his brother with a request that I would use it, and give under my hand a certificate of its superior qualities— I told him I had received a box with twelve bottles of ink, part I believe black and part red, with a Letter from Mr. Hoover requesting my acceptance of the ink, and a certificate of its good properties.— I had used one bottle of the black ink, and had a second ready to be opened— It was very good ink; though rather pale at the first writing. I was well satisfied with it for use; but I never gave recommendatory certificates of articles for sale, and would prefer paying for the bottles of ink that I have taken, and to return the box with the rest— He said if I made it a rule to give no certificates, he could not expect me to make an exception for him, and left me, expecting that he will send for the box— Mr Sweetser consul at Guayaquil, but who has a claim for diplomatic services, and going to Quito and exchanging the ratifications of a Treaty with the Republic of Equador called this morning to urge the speedy decision upon his claim by the Committee of foreign Affairs, to whom it has been referred— I attended the Meeting of that Committee—present Cushing, Stuart, Meriwether, Caruthers and Holmes— Absent Everett, Granger and Shepperd— Cushing had prepared a Bill making appropriations for carrying into execution the Ashburton Treaty— This was discussed— Meriwether thought an additional section was necessary, appropriation of a squadron of eighty guns to be kept for five years on the coast of Africa for the suppression of the Slave trade— I concurred in this opinion which was partially discussed, and postponed for further consideration— So was the claim of Mr Sweetser after some examination of its merits— So was my report of my conference with Mr Webster on the Chinese, and Sandwich Islands concerns— At the House, John M. Botts moved a select Committee of 9, with power to send for persons and papers, to report upon nine specific charges of misdemeanours against John Tyler, Vice-President of the United States acting as President, with a view to his impeachment.— After a good deal of skirmish fighting, this motion was rejected by yeas and nays 83 to. I had strongly urged Botts against this movement, and positively refused to support him in it or to serve upon his Committee if appointed— I voted however for the appointment of a Committee to examine and report upon his charges— After this matter was disposed of, Proffit made his hour speech of scolding and railing at the whigs about the exchequer plan—and the house adjourned.

11. IV:30. Wednesday.  Mr John Spear Smith, the son of the late General Samuel Smith of Baltimore, and heretofore one of the attachés to the legation, when I was minister at St. Petersburg, was here this morning. I had not seen him for many years, and since our residence in Russia, time has scarified his face with wrinkles. He is now here in attendance upon the proceedings of Congress relating to the claims on France prior to 1800— I spent four hours of last evening in a running perusal of the trial of James H Peck, judge of the U.S. District Court in Missouri, for punishing by imprisonment and suspension from practice a Lawyer named Luke Edward Lawless for a contempt, by publishing in a newspaper a critical review of an opinion delivered by the judge and also published in a newspaper— I found in it a uniform series of opinions as to the power of judicial courts to punish for contempt, directly in the face of position impudently assumed by Charles J. Ingersoll, that judicial Courts have no lawful power to punish for contempt— At the house Mr John Pope, chairman of the Committee on the Territories moved, and after some discussion carried a resolution to devote the 2d. 3d. and 4th. of February, to the consideration of business relating to the Territories— The Committees were called, and the Jackson Fine was taken up— William O. Butler of Kentucky, one of Jackson’s aids, in the New-Orleans campaign, and perhaps the most distinguished member from Kentucky now in the house, discoursed nearly an hour and a half in glorification of Jackson, and in malignant Slander upon me— When the morning hour closed the Speaker’s hammer fell, but Mr Butler wanted more time and the Speaker said that by general consent he might have it— No objection was made and he went on till he had emitted all his venom upon me When I spoke the other day, I was allowed only two half hours, upon two totally distinct questions, and when I claimed a full hour upon the amendment proposed by myself it was denied— Winthrop insisted on my right; but it was of no avail— But Ingersoll and Butler have been allowed each an extra half an hour for the pleasure of reviling me— After Butler closed Hiram Hunt of New-York took the floor; but the morning hour was gone; and the report of the Committee of ways and means against Tyler and Webster’s exchequer was taken up— Underwood made an hour speech, chiefly in defence of H. Clay against an insidious, and base insinuated charge against him in Proffit’s speech of yesterday— Everett made a speech and moved the previous question; but the house adjourned— I dined at Mr Webster’s with a diplomatic party of 18. And attended an Evening party at B. O. Tayloe’s.

12. V:30. Thursday  I give the list of the company at Mr Webster’s dinner party yesterday, chiefly for the sake of preserving the names of the diplomatic agents now here— But neither the British Minister Fox nor the French Pageot nor the Austrian Hultzman was there— Van Zandt has just arrived as Chargé d’Affaires from Texas— Almonte is of a mixed breed of Spaniard and Indian, of which his face is highly characteristic— General Cass came in last evening after dinner at Mr Websters, and told me what he had spoken of at my house on the second of this month— General Cass said that shortly before he left France, the king Louis Philippe asked him what in nature had got into Mr Adams, with whom he recollected to have formed a very pleasing acquaintance in England; and whom he had ever since considered as a friend. Mr Cass said he was surprized, and asked the king to what he alluded— Why—says Louis Phillipe—he denies my title— The General said he knew not what to say in reply— I told him that in a lecture delivered before a literary Society, speaking of the dangerous and convulsed condition of Europe, and referring to France, I said that its king held his crown neither by the monarchical title of hereditary succession, nor by the republican title of popular election. but I spoke it as of a historical fact without evil intention to him, and without imagining that it would have been remembered by any one the next day— Well, said Mr Cass—but it was true.— This morning Dr Mayo called here with a couple of pamphlets, one of which was the War in Texas, and of which he asked me if I knew the author, and I told him it was the late Benjamin Lundy. The other was a publication of the recent correspondence between this, and the Mexican Government—published by the Mexican Minister here.— At the house, Giddings chairman of the Committee of Claims, reported without amendment a joint Resolution from the Senate to establish a new rule, to reject in future all claims against which reports have been made at former Sessions. A debate sprung up which absorbed the morning hour, and closed by a motion of Hopkins to lay the Resolution on the table—lost by yeas and nays 86 to 129. Cushing moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union to take up the exchequer bill, lost by yeas and nays 101 to 104— Holmes to take up the French claim bill—lost without a count— Bankrupt repeal bill— M’Keon finished a flat speech and Rayner gave a deadly blast of an hour.

13. IV:30. Friday.  Mr Leavitt was here this morning and read to me an article which he has prepared to publish in the Emancipator explanatory of the charge by him in a former number of that paper of not having supported me, upon my trial Six of the members of the delegation, Briggs, Hudson, Burnell, Winthrop, Baker and Saltonstall, with a concurring signature of Calhoun have written me a Letter requesting me to furnish a statement relative to their votes on the motions to lay the resolutions on the table, to repel the imputation in the Emancipator that they did not support me— At the house, Weller presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Ohio, demanding the repeal of the Bankrupt Law— Wise presented a Memorial from Baltimore the City and County of Baltimore praying Congress to pass the exchequer bill recommended by the President, and he moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; with a view to take up that bill—lost by yeas and nays, 53 to 128—and that vote was an index to the present condition of Wise’s influence in the house— Everett moved to suspend the rules to take up his bankrupt repeal law—yeas and nays 119 to 70. lost for want of two thirds. The joint Resolution from the Senate proposing a new rule to abridge the right of petition. Parmenter opposed it to my surprize. for he yesterday voted against laying it on the table— Giddings equally to my surprize supported it. He is chairman of the Committee of claims; much annoyed by their multitude, and does not see the lurking stab to the right of petition— I made a short speech against it, on several grounds; and to my astonishment Holmes of S.C. declared he had been convinced by me and strenuously opposed it— Botts moved one amendment; and Stanly another— The last clearly not in order—but the Speaker decided that it was—both the amendments were carried; but the resolution itself as amended was rejected by yeas and nays 95 to 103.— When private business was taken up, the debate was on the reconsideration of a bill which passed at the last Session for the relief of the heirs of Philip Renaut; but the reconsideration was then moved and now debated and carried 86 to 49. John Young said he wished to speak upon the bill, and the house adjourned— The Count de Menou called on me this evening, and as agent for the Renaut claim, put into my hands sundry papers; convinced me that the claim was just and solicited my assistance which I promised. Menou himself is a worthy and honourable man, under beclouded fortune, and whom it would delight me to be able to serve— Mr Borden came with Jonathan Hodges, who brought with him a recommendatory Letter from Mr Hodges, heretofore a Member of the House from Bristol District.

14. V. Saturday.  A black man named Moses Bell came this morning, and sent me a paper narrative of gross personal abuse by whipping and cobbing with which he has been treated by a white man claiming him as a Slave; In March 1841. Bell sued the white man, named Rhodes in the circuit Court for his freedom— The trial was procrastinated about 18 months, till last August. on the 20th. of August he was adjudged on the special verdict of a white jury to be free from this sentence. Rhodes appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court now in Session— Mr Hoban and Mr Wallach have been Bell’s lawyers in the Circuit Court, and he said he had been advised to apply to me to assist him in the Supreme Court— I promised to do for him what I could— Mr Hodges came with a model of his invention to be deposited in the Patent Office— It is a metallic bed for the end of the axEltreee of a railway locomotive; but he did not explain to me it operation or its use— But he renewed the request, which he, and Mr Borden for him had made last evening that I would furnish him with a Letter to some person in England who might help him in his pursuit. I accordingly wrote, and in the evening sent to his lodging at the Washington Hotel a Letter of introduction to Edward Everett. On my way to the Capitol, I stop’d at the general Post-Office and delivered to the second Assistant post-master general Bryan a packet sealed, addressed to him and enclosed to me by William Ellis of Dedham. Mr Bryan said it contained the answers to the enquiries which had been forwarded from the Department.— At the house, the day being devoted to the consideration of private business, numerous interloping resolutions were palmed upon the house and the committees—a most disorderly and mischievous practice which has grown out of the 21st. rule— Hiram P. Hunt made a silly hour speech upon Bowne’s fine refunding resolution and my amendment. The bill for the relief of the heirs of Philip Renaut was at the request of Mr Moore of Louisiana postponed till next Friday as was also desired by me— A bill for the relief of the inhabitants of West Florida was opposed in a spirited Speech by Mr Giddings, and supported with so much overbearing insolence by Black of Georgia, reinforced by the squeaking of the Jew Delegate from Florida Levy, that I was provoked to speak, and moved to adjourn which was carried without opposition, though Levy had moved the previous question. I went into the Supreme Court room; where Richard Peters gave me a printed Statement of the appeal of Rhodes against Moses Bell— The Senate did not sit. Mr George T. Curtis of Boston, Greenough the sculptor and Joseph Blunt here this Evening—

15. IV:30. Sunday  I attended public worship in the hall of the house of representatives where Mr Tustin, the chaplain of the Senate preached from Daniel 5.27. “TEKEL. Thou art weighed in the balances, and art found wanting.” This is a formidable text for a preacher to manage—and especially for a chaplain to a house of Congress. It is in itself the key to a discourse of keen and searching reproof to the auditory— It is the solemn duty of a Christian clergyman to administer reproof to his hearers; and it is the duty of the hearers to listen to reproof without taking offence— This is the great practical obstacle to the faithful and useful discharge of the preacher’s duty. If he probes the sinner to the soul, he kindles hatred against himself; and loses his hold upon the conscience. If he forbears he neglects his holiest duty and betrays the cause of his master.— When Louis 14. told Massillon, that he had often admired the splendid eloquence of other preachers but that he always made him discontented with himself, he testified the admirable address, as well as the rare virtue of the bishop of Clermont. Read his Petit Carême preached before Louis 15 in his childhood, and during the regency of the profligate duke of Orleans, and you will see the consummate art with which the pulpit orator had reproved without offending; and made the vain glorious royal sinner ashamed of himself without incurring his displeasure— Mr Tustin told us all that we had been weighed in the balances and found wanting—but this is reproach and not reproof like the wild goose Satire of Jaques, flying unclaimed of any man. After the morning service I called at M’Daniels to visit Briggs, Winthrop and Hudson who lodge there, but neither of whom was at home. I went next to Clements’s and visited Isaac E. Holmes, member of the house from Charleston South-Carolina, specially elected to Congress as a wrangler against me, but has always treated me with marked civility— I found with him Walter Coles an icy member from Virginia, and George M’Duffie, recently arrived, a Senator from South-Carolina, in the place of Preston resigned— He looks feeble and emaciated, but of the same impenetrable stuff as of old— My wife this day was able to come down to dinner—the first time since she returned here from Quincy. After dinner at St. John’s church prayers for the second Sunday after Epiphany were read by Mr Stringfellow, rector of Trinity church in this city, and a sermon was preached by Mr Slaughter of Alexandria, from 2. Corinthians 5.17. “If any man be in Christ he is a new creature,” the same text, preached from by Mr Anderson last Sunday morning at the Capitol— We had long evening visits from a young man named Smith—a friend of Isaac Hull, from Mr Benjamin Rush, and from John Connell.

16. V. Monday  Mr Benjamin Rush was here this morning— Somewhat apprehensive of the fate in the Senate of the bill for the relief of his father, which has passed the house— I promised to speak to one of the Senators in his behalf— I went to the Senate chamber for that purpose on Saturday; but they were not in Session— I went again this day, but they had adjourned. Mr. Sedgwick came again this morning; to urge me on to call up the French claims bill; and to talk generally upon the political topics of the day— He listens with much attention to what I say, and tempts me to talk too much—all from vanity. At the house it was the day for offering Resolutions, and no sooner did the Speaker name the State of Maine than Clifford started with a Resolution to instruct the Committee on the judiciary, to report forthwith the following bill— Be it enacted &c that the Bankrupt act &c, be and the same is hereby repealed— There was a bill already in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union reported by the same judiciary Committee— Nothing can be more explicit than the rule of the house than forbids this duplication of bills on the same subject— Objection was made by Barnard to the reception of Clifford’s resolution—and the rule was cited; but the Speaker decided that Clifford was in order, and he moved the previous question.— This petty by-play to overreach one another, by a war of posts on points of order which would disgrace a court of pie-powder, is the ordinary practice of all the leading members of the house—a motion was made to lay Clifford’s resolution on the table—lost by yeas and nays—81 to 110. The motion for the previous question was seconded by tellers 90 to 79. and carried by yeas and nays 116 to 88. The Resolution itself was carried 128 to 78. Then Barnard referred to the rule of the house that Committees cannot sit while the house is in Session, without a special order of leave— Wise moved a resolution that the committee have leave to sit during the Session of the house, to bring in the bill— Barnard objected that this motion was not in order, and the speaker so decided— Wise appealed and his appeal was laid on the table 104 to 91. The Speaker called Maine again for Resolutions and Lowell offered again the Resolution which had slumped in the hand of Wise—motion to lay it on the table lost by yeas and nays 87 to 105.— Main question ordered 116 to 88. Resolution carried 128 to 78— Barnard went out and soon returned— No Quorum of the Committee had been formed, and no bill was reported— Fessenden for Toland moved a resolution of enquiry of the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning the removal of Jonathan Roberts as Collector of the Customs at Philadelphia—yeas and nays 103 to 76. not two thirds Resolution lost. Tillinghast offered a proviso to the bankrupt repeal bill which was finally carried— In the evening James Mott and is wife Lucretia were here; and after them Charles A King the painter, infatuated with Mesmerism.

17. IV:30. Tuesday.  The hours of the morning lamp were consumed in commencing the preparation of a report of the Committee of foreign affairs upon the Message relating to the Sandwich Islands, and China— I could not finish it; and feel in its composition the decay of my faculties more than in any thing that I ever before attempted— Joseph Blunt came this morning, and gave me a small volume of his Speeches, Reviews and Reports, which he had just published— Blunt is a man of fine talents and excellent principles, blunted by an over-familiarity of deportment, and a good-natured over-estimate of himself—repulsive because appulsive. Meeting of the Committee of Foreign Affairs— I was tardy, 15 minutes— Present Adams, Cushing, Everett, Granger, Stuart, Meriwether, Shepperd, Caruthers and Holmes.—the whole Committee— I read the Letter from Mr Webster to me, proposing the appropriation, and the part of the despatch from Edward Everett of 29. November 1842. relating to China— I mentioned that I had begun but not finished a report, and would read to them what I had written or ask them for time till the next meeting to finish it— They took up Cushing’s bill of appropriations, for carrying into execution the Ashburton Treaty— He wished, and had expressed the wish to me in a conversation at my seat last Saturday after the adjournment of the house, to present an argumentative report in defence of the Treaty, and particularly of the Article stipulating for the squadron of 80 guns to be kept on the coast of Africa— There was some objection in committee to his making this report, because it must be debatable in Committee and must occasion delay— Meriwether’s motion to add a Section with a specific appropriation for the African Squadron was rejected, but Everett renewed it in another form—further consideration postponed to the next meeting, fixed for Thursday morning the 19th. at 11. At the house, I have no room for details, but nearly the whole day was consumed like yesterday in trapping with yeas and nays for the repeal of the bankrupt act— The first and second bills were so jumbled together that inextricable confusion was the result— T. F. Marshall instead of making a speech moved the previous question upon Everett’s bill with Cushing’s amendment which were at last carried by yeas and nays 140 to 71. after several intermediate votes. The house then went into committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hopkins in the chair, and took up the army appropriation bill— Committee soon rose, and the house adjourned. Revd Mr Danforth—Count de Menou—Messrs. Murray and Van Wagenen were here.

18. V. Wednesday.  The Revd. Mr Danforth’s visit to me yesterday was to urge me with great importunity to deliver a Lecture at Alexandria which I assured him would be absolutely impossible during the Session of Congress— He still teized me with inquiries whether I would deliver one in March or April—to which I could only promise an answer when the time should come— The object is to raise a hundred dollars contribution to pay the debt of a beggarly presbyterian church, which he has spurred them on to build without means to pay for it—just as he did here— This morning Alpheus Packard, and his brother Joseph came with a letter of introduction, from their father my old classmate Hezekiah Packard now 81. years of age. His eldest Son, Alpheus with whom he lives, is a professor of Rhetoric Oratory and classical literature at Bowdoin College, comes now on a visit to his brother Joseph the youngest son at the theological seminary near Alexandria— He has seven children living.— Mrcomes from the territory of Ioway, about which he has written a book— He is now going to Boston, and thence to England; and he wants a Letter of introduction to Edward Everett— He sent me his book upon Ioway last fall. I received it in Quincy; but had not time to read it— I promised him a Letter to my Son at Boston.— At the house I moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union with a view to call up the bill for providing indemnity for the sufferers by French spoliations, before 1801.— The house went into Committee, but twice refused to take up my French claims bill, both times by tellers first 78 to 80 and the second time 68 to 78.— The army appropriation bill was then taken up, and the nibblers of Economists began upon it— I heard them till I was tired out, and then went into the Senate chamber and spoke to Mr Huntington asking his favour to the bills for the relief of Richard Rush and of Joseph Holmes— Huntington said that in the case of Holmes there was a shipping paper wanted, and said he would speak in behalf of Mr Rush to the Senator from North-Carolina, Graham, with whom the bill labours.— I found Mr Choate speaking with great power in answer to one of T. H. Benton’s numberless pugnacious attacks upon the Ashburton Treaty— I heard Choate for about half an hour, and he had been speaking an hour and a half before— When I returned to the representative hall I found the house had adjourned— Evening visits from Joseph Blunt, and from Messrs. Murray and van Wagenen, much disappointed at the failure of the attempts to get up the french claims bill— I was occupied much of the Evening in examining the Kentuckian Samuel Smith Nicholas upon martial Law.

19. III.30. Thursday.  I finished this morning the report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs, to accompany two bills, in compliance with the Message of the President of the United States, relating to the Sandwich Islands and China— Then attended the meeting of the Committee— Present Adams, Cushing, Everett, Granger, Stuart, Meriwether, Caruthers, Holmes— Absent Shepherd— Cushing’s bill to carry into execution the Ashburton Treaty was amended by an additional section requiring that the cost of the stipulated squadron, on the coast of Africa, should be paid from the annual naval appropriations— By a report from the Secretary of the Navy, in answer to a Resolution of the Senate his estimate of the cost of the African Squadron is 440000 dollars for the vessels 40000 dollars for repairs, wear and tear and 240000 dollars a year for maintaining it— Half a million of first cost, and 300000 dollars a year for the five years stipulated will fall short of the real cost— Mr Cushing repeated his wish to prepare a report in justification of the Treaty with the bill— There was some reluctance in the Committee; from apprehension of delay and perhaps final dissent of a majority of the Committee—but I urged the fair claim of the Treaty to be defended by a report, and Mr Cushing was authorised to prepare one— I read my report on the Sandwich island and China Message, and was authorised to present it to the house, with an amendment suggested by Mr Everett.— The bills are not yet prepared.— The Committee adjourned to next Tuesday. In the house after the usual quantity of miscellaneous trifles, Cushing in the process of the call of the Committees, reported the bill of appropriations for carrying into execution the Ashburton Treaty, and bustled about with explanations speech, like to attract notice.— The bill was referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— The Jackson-fine Resolution offered by Bowne, with Barnard’s amendment and mine (the immediate question in debate[)] came up next— Hiram P. Hunt finished his speech, and dealing this day only with C. J. Ingersoll’s preposterous pretension that the Courts of Law have no power to punish summarily for contempt, completely demolished it— The morning hour expired and Botts took the floor for the next debatable day— And now came Proffit’s motion to reconsider the repeal of the bankrupt Law, made to give Cushing an hour for reply— He took the hour, and made his case worse by his use of the hour— He assailed furiously Fessenden, and Thompson of Indiana, who had severely handled him— Fessended replied gently, but keenly— Thompson agonized to get the floor but failed— Garrett Davis and Thomas F. Marshall followed, each an hour till near 5. O’Clock. The Count de Menou was here this evening.

20. IV. Friday  Isaac Hull Adams, and Walter Hellen went yesterday to Alexandria, and returned this morning— Mr Connell was here, very urgent with me, to get the house to take up the bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton— He said there was but one bill on the calendar before it; and Mr Cowen of the committee of claims who had charge of it was willing to postpone it, and take that up— I was pledge to take part in the debate on them both, and also on a bill for the relief of the inhabitants of West Florida and on that for the relief of the heirs of Philip Renaut, which superseded both the others.— John Spear Smith was again here, lamenting that the house, after going into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union at my motion, with notice that my object was to take up the French claims bill twice refused to take it up— He told me that Samuel Smith Nicholas, the Kentuckian author of the pamphlet on martial Law—was a relation of his—(maternal first cousin) He said he had written to him of his principles about martial Law, but he did not agree with him; and mentioned that his father in the defence of Baltimore in 1814 had burnt sundry houses of individuals— At the house, on the call for Reports from Committees Robert C. Winthrop from the Committee of commerce presented a report on the memorial of Benjamin rich andothers of Boston, remonstrating against the practise of imprisoning coloured mariners in South-Carolina, and other Southern States, which report he said was agreed by seven out of the nine members of the Committee— That of the two others Mr Rayner of North Carolina had prepared a minority report, and the chairman of the Committee John P. Kennedy, dissenting from both reports would probably present his views separately— Winthrop’s report closed with several resolutions which were read. He moved that both reports be printed and laid on the table for consideration hereafter, and to avoid debate called for the previous question. The Slave representation were instantly in a flame— Rayner’s report closed with a Resolution that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of the subject— Kennedy moved that 5000 copies of both reports be printed. Jacob Thompson objected and Kennedy withdrew his motion but Rayner himself renewed it— By the rule of the house, the motion must lie over one day— Black of Georgia objected to the printing of the majority report at all, and moved to lay the motion to print on the table—lost by yeas and natys 72 to 114— Fillmore moved to cease debate and take the question on the army appropriation bill to-morrow at 2. O’Clock lost— Private bills till the adjournment. Franklin Whitney here— Evening and supper at John L. Kerr’s.

21. IV. Saturday.  Franklin Whitney brought with him last evening a long petition to the House of Representatives complaining against Henry L. Ellsworth Commissioner of Patents for official misconduct, and asking for the appointment of a select committee with power to send for persons and papers to investigate the charge— I told him that I would read the petition, and if he insisted on it would present it, but if a Committee should be appointed it would be impossible for me to serve upon it— The party at Mr Kerr’s last evening was of Gentlemen—members of Congress and others— Mrs Kerr was there—and Mrs Greenough the sculptor’s wife—no other Lady.— I was none the better this morning for the supper of last evening— Major Fauntleroy of the second regiment of dragoons came this morning, most urgently to remonstrate against the conversion of that regiment into a dismounted rifle regiment which by the act of the last Session of Congress is to take effect on the next 4th. of March. This was one of the Southern compromises screwed by the Senate upon the house, which had directed the regiment to be disbanded; and there is now before the house a resolution moved by Gwin of Mississippi, to repeal the provision for dismounting the regiment— The major says that if they are to be dismounted they had better be disbanded at once— He gave me much useful information concerning the character of that western population, of which the yankee nation do not even dream—but it thoroughly convinces me that the regiment ought to be disbanded; and that it will not even be dismounted— At the house, on the call for reports from Committees, several of them were upon subjects of deep interest, but of which little notice was taken owing to the transcendent influence of the Slave representation— Cave Johnson with the aid of Gilmer, and of Granger drove through a bill prohibiting any extra allowance to any public officer for any service whatever. I spoke against it, and so did Joseph R. Ingersoll and Holmes, but it was carried by yeas and nays 151 to 15. Arnold moved a reconsideration and struggled hard to get in his bill 548 by way of amendment, but failed— Rayner’s motion to print 5000 extra copies of the two reports from the committee of commerce on the imprisonment of Southern coloured Seamen in South-Carolina was called up by me, and adopted without opposition: Rayner himself was not in the house— The bill for the relief of the inhabitants of West Florida came up— I spoke about half an hour against it and concluded by moving to lay it on the table. Levy, the delegate asked me to withdraw the motion, to give him the opportunity of reply— I withdrew the motion and the house adjourned. I dined at the Russian Minister Bodisco’s with a company of 34. Allen, Barrow, Benton, Conrad, Crittenden, Dickins, Gales, Greenoug Henderson, Hill, Huston, Jessup, Jones, Kemble—King, Mangum, Saltonstall, Scott, Seaton, Stuart, Tallmadge, Tayloe, White,

22. IV. Sunday  (continued from yesterday) Wise, Woodbury, and 7 more whom I did not know—34 at table—and two missing. Cushing and Irwin— Mr Bodisco told me that he made it a rule to give four dinners of 36 every year, and two smaller of 18. This morning at the hall of the house of Representatives Mr Tiffany read a small portion of the episcopal morning service, without the litany or any part of the communion—no singing— He read the chapter from the old Testament of the first lesson, and preached a very short Sermon, from Hebrews 12.22 “But ye are come unto mount Sion, and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an innumerable company of Angels, 23. To the general Assembly of the church of the first born, which are written in heaven, and to God, the Judge of all, and to the Spirits of just men made perfect.” The whole service was performed in less than an hour, and Mr Tiffany’s exposition of his text was very superficial— In commenting upon any passage in the Scriptures, taken for a text, it seems to me that the preacher should consider it, in its relations with the context, and the general scope of the whole chapter from which it is selected— This chapter for example contains a most solemn and fervid exhortation to steadfastness, endurance, patience, perseverance, under every persecution and every affliction— It appeals to the example of patient endurance given by the saviour himself—he likens the afflictions of the faithful to the chastisement of an affectionate parent to this child, and in exquisitely beautiful imagery paints the Christian in his pilgrimage as arriving, not at the terrific mountain of the wilderness Sinai, whence amid terrific thunder and lightening, and the sound of the trumpet, which mortal man could not abide, but at the mild and cheering foot of mount Sion, the permanent immovable seat of the holy temple, in the city of Jerusalem—then passing on to heaven, to the innumerable company of angels, to God, to the Spirits of just men made perfect—and afterwards to Jesus, the mediator of the new covenant—what a lesson of more than Roman fortitude!— After dinner at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the prayers for the third evening after the Epiphany, and preached from Isaiah 60.19. “The sun shall be no more thy light by day; neither for brightness shall the moon give light unto thee: but the Lord shall be thine everlasting light, and thy God thy glory.”— I had heard Mr Hawley on this text before— After Church I went over to see Mr T. B. Johnson’s to see him; but Mrs Smith who came to the door told me that he was asleep, and I declined having him waked— Mr Richard Rush took tea, and spent the evening with me; and had long conversation with me, on the Oregon territory, and T. H. Benton’s speeches.

23 III— V:15 Monday  The racking catarrhal cough which afflicts and oppresses me, abridges the little sleep which I am able to obtain when relieved from it.— I awoke this morning before 3. and upon lighting my lamp, finding myself dispirited, drowsy and lethargic I extinguished it, and took to my bed again, and by mercy got two hours more of sleep which refreshed me for the labours of the day; but I had on my table a mass of newspapers and pamphlets which had come by the mail last Evening; and upon once looking into them absorbed hour after hour leaving me scarce ten minutes for breakfast, till meridian day summoned me to the capitol— My record of yesterday was untouched—several indispensable tasks of business were procrastinated— Mr Newhall of Ioway came and reminded me of his projected disinterested literary expedition to England to enlighten the European world, upon the beauties and glories of our western Paradise, and of my promise to furnish him with a Letter of recommendation to my son at Boston, for one from him to Edward Everett, and Franklin Whitney besieged me at the house to know if I had presented his petition of impeachment against Henry L Ellsworth the Commissioner of Patents— I had from forgetfulness left it at home— At the house Fillmore, chairman of the Committee of Ways and means, read an editorial article in the New-York Union, the Tyler paper there, and a Letter from New-York in the Madisonian of this morning charging the Committee of Ways and Means, with having reported against the Tyler-Webster exchequer contrary to the opinion and disposition of the moderate whigs and democrats, which was sufficient to have passed the exchequer, but for a caucus held the night before at which a Letter from Henry Clay was read forbidding the passage of any bill for settling the currency and restoring the credit of the country— Fillmore declared the whole statement an absolute falsehood; and he called upon every member of the house, and particularly upon every member of the guard, if he knew of any such caucus to declare it in his place— Wise took the call to himself and ferociously demanded if Fillmore meant to insinuate that he knew any thing of the articles in the Union and Madisonian— Fillmore disclaimed and Wise said he did know of a Caucus last Summer which did send a deputy to Mr Tyler to accommodate the President with a fiscal corporation instead of a Bank— Botts moved a reconsideration of the vote of Saturday to print 5000 copies of the two reports from the Committee of Commerce on the coloured seaman case, and the reconsideration was carried by yeas and nays: and the motion laid on the table— Walter Hellen, Dr. Thomas and Mr Smith were here—

24. IV. Tuesday.  Franklin Whitney came again this morning; and took his petition of impeachment against Henry L. Ellsworth Commissioner of patents as he belongs to New-Bedford in Mr Burnell’s district. I advised him to get him to present it, and have it referred to the committee on the judiciary— He said he had wished me to present it and have it referred to a select Committee, of which I should be chairman; but I told him that would be impossible; but if Mr Burnell should decline to present his petition, I would present it— He is bitterly resentful against the commissioner of patents Ellsworth, and believes him to have been in this case venally corrupt, which I cannot.— I attended the meeting of the Committee of foreign affairs— Present Adams, Granger, Stuart, Caruthers, Shepherd, Meriwether—and absent Cushing, Everett and Holmes— I presented two Bills of appropriation, one for the compensation of a Consul or Commissioner to the Hawaian or Sandwich Islands—3000 dollars; and the other of 40000 dollars, to enable the President of the United States to establish the future commercial relations of the United States with China, on terms of equal reciprocity— I was authorised by the unanimous vote of the members present to report to the house the two bills as I had prepared them, which I did on the call of the Committee for reports— The Bills were read twice, referred to the committee of the whole house on the state of the Union, and with the report ordered to be printed— In Committee Granger made a verbal report on the claim of Commodore Ridgely, that two members thought it should not only be rejected, but that a report should be made to the house, exposing the conduct of the Commodore to severe censure, for daring to present such a claim. I prevailed on the majority however to consent to a simple report that Commodore Ridgely have leave to withdraw his petition— In the house, William Russell of Ohio offered a Resolution that the hour of meeting of the house after next Monday should be 11. O’Clock till further order. Barnard objected— Russell moved a suspension of the rules, but the speaker declared that not in order— Russell shook his finger at Barnard, and said I’ll mark you— Botts made his hour speech against the bill to refund the Jackson fine— Moore of Louisiana took the floor on that question for to-morrow— Cushing made his hour speech against the Committee of Ways and Means and the whigs, for rejecting the Tyler Webster Exchequer— Adjourned at 3. I rode home— Dusty gale— Mr Newhall came, and I gave him a Letter to Edward Everett. R. Rush took tea and spent the Evening here— Hull went to Alexandria.

25— IV.15 Wednesday.  John Davies, a coloured man, came this morning with a Letter from himself to me—asking my advice in behalf of his wife’s son, named Joseph Clark, sold some years since by Mrs Hellen to someone, who sold him to the Senator Berrien, who sold him to a Coll. Curry; an agent or subagent employed in the removal of the Cherokee Indians. Currey took him to the state of Arkansas, employed him as an interpreter, and pomised him his freedom— Currey afterwards died, and by his Will, declared Clark free, after 3 years service to his brother— The rascal brother sold him for 900 dollars, and he is now in irredeemable Slavery for life— The mother of this poor man, Jenny lived sometime with us, and at her instance her husband Davies came to ask my advice what can be done for him.— But he has neither means to sue for his freedom, nor evidence to prove the Will— He is now living with a Dr. Davis Flint, Cherokee Nation, and is acting as interpreter— Can I not possibly do something for this man?— Mr Coleman, late Commissioner of Agriculture in Massachusetts, came with a subscription book to defray the expence of his going to England and France as a Commissioner at large to make and publish discoveries in Agriculture— I subscribed for one copy of his book, which is to appear in numbers; but he declined receiving the dollar in advance required by his prospectus. I called a second time at the Treasury Department, and enquired of Mr M’Clintock Young, the Chief Clerk the amount paid, to certain inhabitants of East-Florida, under the Act of 1834. and the amount claimed by the inhabitants of West-Florida, and for which the bill now before the house is intended to provide— Mr Young said there would not be time to the end of this Session of Congress to report upon such an enquiry; but he shewed me the papers of one claim on Amelia Island upon which between 5 and 6000 dollars have been allowed and paid; a mere transient glance at which opened to me a dungeon of fraud and swindling claims.— At the house, Fillmore, chairman of the Committee of Ways and means succeeded in screwing at once into consideration the Resolution against the Tyler Webster Forward exchequer bill. Three one hour speeches were successively delivered by D. D. Barnard—R. C. Winthrop, and T. F. Marshall, all of the highest order of eloquence, though with irreconcileable dissent of opinions. Pendleton took the floor at the adjournment— The house nearly deserted during great part of Barnard’s and Winthrop’s speeches, by members slinking away to hear the new Senator from South-Carolina, M’Duffie— We had sundry evening visitors among whom J. Connell, who has purchased a Carriage for me at Philadelphia— Isaac Hull Adams, and Walter Hellen went yesterday to Alexandria, and returned this day.

26. IV:30. Thursday.  At the house this morning, the Speaker announced the select committee on the resolution moved on theby W. Cost Johnson to consider the Memorials calling on Congress to make some provision for relief to the States from the embarrassment of their debts. The Committee are William Cost Johnson of Maryland, Meredith P. Gentry of Tennessee, J. Q. Adams of Massachusetts Zadok Casey of Illinois, James Cooper of Pennsylvania, Thomas F. Marshall of Kentucky, Calvary Morris of Ohio Jacob M Howard of Michigan, and James H. Cravens of Indiana.— Johnson came to my seat, and told me that he had given in my name to the Speaker on the motion of John P. Kennedy chairman of the Committee of Committee of Commerce. Tuesday the 7th. of February was specially assigned for the consideration of a joint resolution concerning reciprocity Treaties— Kennedy reported also a bill to establish a warehousing system, with a report of which he moved then an extra number of 5000 copies should be printed— Cave Johnson objected; but at the earnest intreaty of Kennedy withdrew his objection— Payne of Alabama has the floor on the Jackson fine Resolution, but he has two days successively allowed it to be overridden— Fillmore moved to take up immediately the Negative Resolution of the Committee of Ways and Means on the Presidential Exchequer Bill the paternity of which was assumed by Daniel Webster in his too celebrated Faneuil Hall speech— Nathaniel G. Pendleton of Cincinnati Ohio a member of the Committee of Ways and Means, made an hour speech against the executive exchequer, followed by Wise in an hour speech of reply to Marshall’s paper kite of yesterday— Marshall was not in the house—a grievous lamentation to Wise, excessively sore under Marshall’s flagellation, and with his usual vindictive malignity eager to score Marshall return— Marshall was I suppose purposely absent, and Wise’s hot shot fell short of their object— He was cut short in a ludicrous attitude, with his arms expanded in the very delivery of a magnificent trope as he thought, by Charles G. Atherton, minority chairman of the Committee of ways and means, who spun out his hour in a dull laudatory exposition of the sub-treasury— Proffit, of the guard then pounced upon the sub-treasury and the democracy—scolding like a Poissarde; and repeating one hundred and one times that under the Sub treasury Law not one dollar had ever been paid in specie— Adjourned at half past 3— I had gone during the debate for a few minutes into the Supreme Court room where 7 judges, (Story and M’Kinley absent from indisposition) were listening to an argument of John Sergeant— The hall was nearly empty— After the adjournment Stanly gave me a pamphlet appeal, written he told my by R. B. Rhett to the democratic party about a national convention of the party to fix upon candidates for the presidential election— M’Duffie made a speech yesterday in Senate against the Oregon Territory Bill— Hull went this evening to the assembly

27. III— IV. Friday  Mr John Spear Smith was again here this morning; anxious about the French claim Bill, and enquiring whether it would not be expedient for me to give notice this day that I would call it up to morrow. I thought it would be waste of time and influence, and would surely fail— Mr Smith told me that the judges of the Supreme Court had yesterday without a word of previous notice removed Richard Peters from the Office of Reporter and appointed Ben C. Howard, heretofore a member of Congress from Baltimore, and a relative of Chief Justice Taney in his place— The Count de Menou called, and said he had received a duly authenticated genealogy of the heirs of Philip F Renaut, which he would have certified by Mr Pageot, and transmit to the house— I called again at the Treasury Department, and obtained from Mr Young the chief Clerk, a schedule of the claims of the inhabitants of West Florida, to be paid on the passage of the Bill now before the house and he afterwards sent me to the house a statement of the amount actually paid to the certain inhabitants of East-Florida, under the act of 1834.—upwards of 700000 dollars! While I was at the Treasury department our coachman Philip came round with the carriage to the door, and hearing that I was not in the house concluded I had walked on, drove to the Capitol thinking to overtake me on the way; and finding I was not there turned round and came back still in pursuit of me— When I returned home from the Treasury the Carriage was gone—and I set out trudge it on foot. going out from my door I met Mr Allen; member of the house from Maine, returning from one of the public offices and walked with him till in the Pennsylvania avenue we met my carriage coming back from the capitol. Mr Allen then went with me; and I found the house in Session, and Fillmore chairman of the Committee of ways and means, in final replication, chiefly to the charges of Cushing upon the resolution of the Committee that the President’s Exchequer ought not to be adopted— Giddings moved the previous question— Cushing withdrew his motion to strike out the word not. Thompson of Mississippi moved to lay the whole subject on the table, lost 66 to 141— Atherton’s amendment was rejected 105 to 115— The resolution of the majority of the Committee not to adopt the Webster exchequer carried 191 to 18 (remark 11. skulking votes—) Burnell moved a reconsideration, made a speech; and withdrew his motion. Charles J. Ingersoll, renewed the motion for reconsideration made an ambidexter speech, full of sense and nonsence, of wisdom and of knavery— Wise was one of the skulkers—and then bristled up—brag’d that what he abhorred above all things was dodging, and ordered the reporters to state that he would have voted for Atherton’s amendment and against Fillmore’s Resolution.— Adjourned— Lieutenant Wilkes here this evening—

28. IV:30 Saturday.  The Count de Menou and Mr Connell were here successively this morning very anxious, the Count, that the bill for the relief of the heirs of Philip Francis Renaut, and Connell that the bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton should be taken up and acted on by the house this day; but they were both disappointed— At the house a confused mass of intrusive business was admitted or rejected according to the humour of the house and the Speaker— Gilmer offered a Resolution calling on the President for any information about a negotiation for the cession of California, by Mexico to Great Britain—adopted without opposition— Giddings and Cowen alternate chairmen of the Committee of claims insisted upon the observance of the rule devoting the day for private business. Cushing moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up his exchequer bill—he said he had been reproached for not calling it up—moved to suspend the rules and called for the yeas and nays— Then withdrew the call for the yeas and nays, but said he would renew the motion to go into Committee and take up that bill every day till he should succeed— William W. Payne of Gainesville, Sumter County—Alabama, was big with his hour speech on the Jackson fine Resolution and demanded the opportunity to be delivered of it; in which the Speaker indulged him— His speech was a brawling declamation upon necessity—invective upon judge Hall upon me—upon Louaillier and the Legislature of Louisiana—at the time of the declaration of Martial Law— He read from Martin’s history of the War and from Eaton’s life of Jackson, and puffed and spouted himself out of breath— As his hour closed Dawson of Louisiana took the floor for the next fighting day.— Charles J. Ingersoll gave notice that he would on Monday ask leave to introduce a bill to amend the act organizing the Treasury Department— The house then went into the consideration of private business, and passed sundry bills but rejected by yeas and nays 55 to 92 that for the relief of the Petersburg Rail-road company— Then in Committee of the whole, Thomas M T. M’Kennon in the chair numerous other bills were reported to the house, all those against which any objection was made being set aside— I offered the joint resolution, drawn up by Mr Barnard, to authorise the appointment of 4 additional commanders in the navy, for the purpose of promoting lieutenant Wilkes— Meriwether and Mallory objected but finally consented to receive the resolution and refer it to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. The Bill for the relief of the inhabitants of West Florida, was postponed and made the special order of the day for next Friday— Burke objected to the bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton, and it was overlaid. Mr Rush took tea, and spent the evening with us—

29. V. Sunday  Public worship at the Representative hall. The service performed by the Revd. Mr Tiffany. He read a very small portion of the morning prayer—omitting, the portion of the Psalms, the lesson from the old Testament—the litany, the portion of the communion, and even the reading of a psalm or hymn to be sung— The whole ceremony occupied not more than 50 minutes, and I thought was too much hurried over. The Sermon was from Hebrews 11.6. [“]But without Faith it is impossible to please him”— The subject was Faith; and having discoursed upon it myself, Mr Tiffany seemed to me to handle the subject superficially and feebly. The auditory was thin; not more than half the seats of the members being filled— My nephew the passed midshipman Joseph H dined with us.— After dinner at St. John’s, the Revd. Mr Smith of Smithfield, Virginia, brother to the member of Congress, William Smith, read the Evening prayers for the 4th Sunday after the Epiphany, and preached from Proverbs 23.26. [“]My Son, give me thy heart.”— The reverend gentleman appeared not to understand his text, for he commented upon it as if the speaker was God—whereas it was Solomon— The whole chapter is an affectionate paternal exhortation to temperance from sensuality—from eating—from drinking—from women— Temperance and moderation in the pursuit of wealth thriftiness and industry, benevolence and charity to the orphan poor, filial affection and observance of paternal precepts and example are all enjoined in this chapter—and the pathetic apostrophe, my Son give me thy heart is more impressive from the lips of the earthly parent, than in the gratuitous transfer of it to the Lord Jehovah himself. Mr Smith’s manner is cold and artificially emphatic— After church I went over and passed half an hour with Mr Thomas B. Johnson who recovers very slowly from his last paralytic shock—confined to the sopha in his bed-chamber—his speech almost unintelligible—his countenance cadaverous, and his spirits drooping in despondency. Richard D. Cutts and his sister Mary took tea with us, and I had a long evening visit from Mr Kerr, one of the Senators from the State of Maryland, and one of those whom I am accustomed to respect as among the best and worthiest of men— He is in politics a whig—with principles as pure as in a land of Slavery can be held: and of unsullied honour. We had much conversation on the aspect of our public affairs, with a great preponderance of discouragement.

30. V. Monday.  Gideon Morris is one of the western pioneers who told me he had a Cherokee family, and has some interest in a bill now before the house for carrying into effect a Treaty with the Cherokees— He came to ask my influence to get it through, and referred me to Joseph L. Williams of Tennessee, for information concerning it— Williams spoke to me about it; but the confusion in the house was so great, and I was so much absorbed in the business before it, that I knew just as much of the Cherokee Treaty and Gideon Morris’s claim after he finished as before he began. I must wait till the bill comes up— Mr George Brown came with two gentlemen from Lowell named Bixby, and whom he introduced to me, and with whom I was talkative— At the house, this was the day to call the States for Resolutions, and I had prepared two—calling on the President for information respecting the exploit of Commodore Thomas ap Catesby Jones, at Monterey in California—but Wise and Cushing immediately moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up their exchequer bill— The house taking no heed to my remonstrance, went floundering into Committee Hopkins in the chair.
