The House of Representatives at my motion passed a Resolution calling on the President for a return of the aggregates by Counties and Cities— I called at the Department of State, where Weavers work as far as it was finished was shewn to me by Mr Webster’s order, and I said that was what I wanted and I was told it was nearly finished— But no answer to the Resolution was returned by the President, at that Session, nor until the 4th. of January 1842. when a Report from the Secretary of State, with a totally different document was sent to the House— Weems had told me that Weaver was secretly bargaining with Blair and Rives to give the printing of the document unlawfully to Blair and Rives, and wished me to insist with the Secretary of State that the printing should be done by Gales and Seaton the Printers of the house; but not chusing to meddle with that question I declined speaking to Mr Webster about it— Weaver succeeded in his bargain of plunder with Blair and Rives— Thomas Allen the Printer of the Senate screwed out of Webster another bargain for printing the same document—and counter memorials and a select Committee of investigation, and scurrilous counter pamphlets will, terminate by payment of all the printers bills, and the complete fleecing of the public— Weems says that Weaver has falsified the printing of his testimony before the investigating committee and then presented his own falsification as evidence to support a charge against Weems of perjury before the grand jury.— He asked me again for a certificate, which I promised to write, and to have ready for him to-morrow— I called at the Department of State, and returned to Mr Webster his Letter of Instructions to Edward Everett—the Instructions of Secretary Upshur to Commodore Mattew C. Perry, and the Office copy of Mr Guizot’s Letter to General Cass in answer to his Protest— A very short further conversation with Mr Webster— He wishes another Negotiation with Great-Britain— But they keep Mr Fox here; only to make him pensionable— He has a private Letter from Everett, and one from Lord Ashburton— They will take the line of the Columbia river, and let us stretch South at the expence of Mexico— Mr Fox came in and I went into Mr Hunter’s chamber, where he brought several of the Archives of the Departme and among the rest the correspondence of Anthony Butler. His Letter to Forsyth of 17. June 1835 must be read again.

28. IV— V:15. Tuesday  Mr Connell called on me this morning and requested of me a Letter of introduction to Mr Pageot the Chargé d’Affaires from France— His purpose is to request Mr Pageot to forward for him a Memorial to Louis Philippe the king of the French, setting forth certain services of relief, kindness and humanity which in the year 1813 to numerous French Officers returning from the wreck of Napoleon’s army which invaded Russia.— He had a volume of Niles Register published in 1820. containing a narrative of these transactions and bearing the most authentic and unqualified testimony to Mr Connell’s services at that time, at considerable inconvenience and expence to himself— He said that he had recently met with so many misfortunes in his private concerns that he was reduced to great distress, and had been advised by some of his friends, particularly by Mr John Spear Smith, to address this memorial to the king of France, who upon this state of facts would feel himself under obligations to remunerate those services.— I told him that I would very cheerfully give him a Letter to Mr Pageot; but that I could scarcely say I was acquainted with him— There was no personal intercourse between him and me, and had been none between his predecessor Bacourt and me, since I questioned in a public Lecture, Louis Philippe’s title to the crown— This fact I knew had been reported to the king, and therefore a Letter of recommendation from me would do him harm rather than good— Connell did not seem to be satisfied, but did not insist— My morning wasted away till it was near 2. O’Clock P.M before I reached the Department, and immediately went into Hunter’s chamber. I made an abstract of the Letter from William A. Slacum a purser in the Navy, (since deceased,) to the Secretary of State Forsyth, dated Alexandria 1. August 1835.— This was the Letter which kindled the passion of Andrew Jackson for the 37th. line of Latitude from the river Arkansas to the South Sea—to include the river and Bay of San Francisco—and was the foundation of Forsyth’s instruction to Butler of 6. Augt. 1835. authorizing him to offer 500000 dollars more, than he had received authority to offer before.— There is another long Letter from Slacum, relating to the commerce of the several South American States— Both prove him to have been an observing man— I had not time to begin the abstract of Butler’s Letter to Forsyth of 17 June 1835— The substance of which is a proposal to purchase the cession of Texas by bribing a priest named Ygnacio Hernandez with 500000 dollars, and he encloses a note signed Hernandez assuring him that with 500000 (he says not what) he will certainly obtain his object— There is an endorsement on this Letter signed A. J. forbidding bribery or corruption— Walter Hellen was here this afternoon, and we had as evening visitors Mr King the Painter, Greenough the Sculptor, and John Connell.

29. IV.20. Wednesday  The months of January and March for the present year 1843. changed places in the atmosphere, the first having been so springlike, that the buds on the fruit trees were bursting into blossom, and I remember no month of January at Washington so frost benumbed and snow clad as has been this expiring month of March— This day however it relented, and seems preparing according to its proverbial character to go out like a lamb. My cough is apparently subsiding, but my plan of occupation is broken up, and I am irretrievably spellbound in idleness— The day was fair and the temperature mild; but my vis inertiae so insuperable that it was near one when I got to Mr Hunter’s chamber at the Department of State— I took up again the Volume of Anthony Butler’s despatches to the Department of State and to President Jackson during his mission to Mexico, and began the abstract of his Letter to Forsyth of 17. June 1835.— But I made little progress, my attention being diverted from that Letter to other parts of the correspondence, and to the reading of numerous other Letters— I found that I could not understand the subject thoroughly but by a rigorous chronological examination of all the documents— The appetite for Texas was from the first a Western passion, stimulated by no one more greedily than by Henry Clay.— He had denounced the Florida Treaty for fixing the boundary at the Sabine; and held and preached the doctrine that we should have insisted upon our shadow of a claim to the Rio del Norte— President Monroe actually preferred the line of the Sabine, thinking that the extension of the boundary woaken us for defence— And Jackson expressly approved the line of the Sabine— The first act of the Mexican Government after declaring their Independence was to claim the boundary as settled by the Florida Treaty and we had consented to it. But with the commencement of my administration I appointed Poinsett Minister to Mexico and Mr Clay instructed him to propose the purchase of Texas— This they declined but two years after the proposition was renewed— They then rejected it resentfully.— But Jackson was so sharp set for Texas, that from the first year of his administration, he set his double engines to work of negotiating to buy Texas with one hand and instigating the people of that province to revolt against Mexico with the other Houston was his Agent for the rebellion, and Anthony Butler, a Mississippi Land-jobber in Texas, for the purchase— Butler kept him five years on the tenter hooks of expectation—negotiating, wheedling, promising and finally boasting that he had secured the bargain by bribing a priest with half a million of dollars— Jackson at last found him out and dismissed him rather abruptly. But he carried off some of the most important documents of the negotiation— They exchanged the ratifications of a new convention this day at the Department of State. D. L. Child spent the Evening here—

30. IV:30 Thursday  The change of the Season has been this day completed, by the substitution rather of Summer than of Spring, for the Winter which has ruled supreme over the month of March— My cough has very much subsided but has left in its place a listless languid incapacity of action, which operates upon me as a palsy, and baffles all my good purposes—  I walked this morning to the Capitol, and on my way met Joseph L. Williams, a member of the last Congress from Tennessee, who is yet here. He told me that Henry A. Wise, who has offered himself as a Candidate for re-election to Congress, in a stump speech at Louisa last week qualified Henry Clay as a sot and a liar.  At the capitol I obtained two copies of the Message of the President of 18. Feby last, relating to the seizure by Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones of the Mexican town of Monterey in California; and several other Documents concerning Mexico and Texas of which I had made a list, In the Resolution of the house, calling for the Monterey document, I had called for all the Instructions to Commodore Jones, and all his communications to the Navy Department—purposely omitting the usual exception of such as the President might deem it improper to communicate— I had moved the Resolutions by direction of the Committee of foreign affairs though it is not so stated on the journal of the house— Cushing voted against the Resolutions in Committee and was at his request excused from voting on them in the house because they did not contain the exception. The Message adverting to the omission of the exception, assumes a discretionary power in the executive to with hold any documents called for by Resolution of the house, but says that in this case all are given because he sees no necessity for withholding any.— I believe that at the next Session of Congress, it will be my duty to move some action of Congress on this document, though I have no hope of succeeding in that or in any thing else— Never in my life was there such an array of discouragement before— Never despair!— Returning from the capitol I stop’d at the National Intelligencer Office and obtained from W. W. Seaton the four papers containing the correspondence relating to Cass’s protest against the ratification of the Quintuple Treaty; and the subsequent controversy between Cass and Webster about the Ashburton Treaty— After my return home, a dull headache, and overpowering lassitude disabled me for the rest of the day, till late in the evening when I made out to finish a statement for Jesse E. Weems, about my call for the aggregates of the census returns, and the rascally job, perpetrated between William A. Weaver and Blair and Rives for the printing of the compendium.— I received a Letter from Mr Frye, with a note from the Miller Speakman, informing me that the snow and rainstorm of Tuesday Night carried away the milldam, and that of course the rent from that day ceases— My wife received also a Letter from our Son dated that same Tuesday Evening at Stonington where he had been with his wife since the Evening before, detained by the storm— She was coming here—but from fear of embarking on the Sound, they concluded to return the next morning to Boston.

31. III.30— Friday.  A person by the name of Russell, an inventor of some astronomical instrument came and requested of me a certificate of its usefulness. He had some time last year brought it to my house and exhibited it to me, but I did not understand its mechanism or its operation sufficiently to judge of its usefulness— I declined giving him a certificate upon my general rule— He had one from the Revd. Dr Ezra Stiles Ely.— Mr Child was here this morning; and I gave him a copy of the reprinted Executive Documents N. 40 and 42 of the 1st. Session of the 25th. congress 1837. containing the most important papers of our relations with Mexico and Texas. I desired him to ascertain from Genl Almonte whether the paper delivered by Anthony Butler to Lucas Alaman, on the 15th. of July 1832, and another paper afterwards delivered by Butler to Santa Anna, and never answered by him are not among the Archives of the Mexican Government, and if they are to obtain copies of them— I requested him also to endeavour to procure the St. Louis Newspapers containing Benton’s Essays under the signatures of Americanus and La Salle in 1829. which he promised to do. I called to see Mr T. B. Johnson, who is afflicted with a paralytic disease; the issue of which may occur from hour to hour, and yet may linger along for years— Thence I went to the Department of State, and put into the hands of Mr Webster the last Letter received from Dr Flügel of 25. November last, imploring my aid to obtain an allowance of his charges in an account for expences not authorised by Law, but which he was ill able to bear, and had incurred without knowing that they were not allowable.— I told him that Dr Flügel was an entire Stranger to me, but that Mr Wheaton had recommended him to me, as a very poor but respectable man of Letters— Mr Webster took the papers and said he would see what he could do for the Doctor— He sent me also the London Globe and Times Newspapers received down to the 3d. of this Month— We said something about the North eastern boundary maps, and I mentioned one to him as being in the Department which he had not seen. I then passed into Hunter’s chamber, and made a short further abstract from Anthony Butler’s Letter to John Forsyth of 17. June 1835— Hunter had the first number of a Texan Newspaper Feby last. containing a list of the members of the Executive Government— Also a list of the Masonic Government— A Royal Arch Chapter, of which Anthony Butler is the Grand High Priest. Without finishing my abstract, I came home at 4 O’Clock in the Rain which continued steadily all the afternoon and evening. Joseph H. Adams was here, and also Miss Cutts— This afternoon Mr Richard I. Morsell came and made his annual payment of 300 dollars for the purchase of the house and lot in square 214— In the Evening Isaac Hull and Mary and her daughter read for me in the London Globe of 1. March a curious debate in the house of Commons on the subject of education.

1. IV:30 Saturday.  Brisk Northwestern gale, and winter cold— I went to the Pension Office, and left with the Commissioner James L. Edwards a Letter of Enquiry from Jonathan Parker of Plympton relating to the act passed at the late session of Congress granting an additional pension for one year to certain widows of Revolutionary Officers and Soldiers— Mr Edwards gave me several printed copies of the Act, with a form of application by the widow to obtain the benefit of it, and promised to write me an answer to Mr Parker’s enquiries— I then went to Mr Hunter’s chamber at the Department of State, and finished the extracts from Anthony Butler’s Letter to the Secretary of State Forsyth of 17. June 1835— Neither this Letter, nor that of W. A. Slacum of 1. August 1835 was ever communicated to Congress; but in them originated the project of enlarging the encroachment upon Mexico from the mere acquisition of Texas, to embrace all New-Mexico, to the 37th parallel of Latitude, and thence across the continent to the South-Sea— Butler’s Letter connects with it a project for a commercial line of communication between the Arkansas river and the Colorado of California, uniting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans— The Texian expedition of last year to Santa Fe, must have been a sucker from the same root— Ap Catesby Jones’s occupation of Monterey— Dr Linn’s bill for the organization of the Oregon territory: and above all the tampering of Webster with the Mexican Minister here, Almonte, by a proposition that Mexico should cede to the United States the Port of San Francisco, and the parallel 36 of North Latitude across the continent to buy the consent of Great Britain with a cession to her from 49 to the Columbia river present altogether a spectacle and prospect truly appalling.— The root of the danger is in the convulsive impotence of Mexico to maintain her own integrity, geographical, political or moral, and the inflexible perseverance of rapacity of our South and West, under the spur of Slavery, to plunder and dismember her.— Butler’s bribe of half a million of dollars to the confessor of Santa Anna’s sister was too gross even for Jackson’s stomach to allow him to give it his official sanction—but even while ostensibly disapproving it, he sent him back to Mexico with liberty to try it in his own way; and it failed. Hamilton of South Carolina tried it upon Santa Anna himself and failed— Mr Hunter brought me the volume of secret instructions to agents of foreign intercourse, and there I found a despatch of 14. January 1843. to the present Consul at the HavanaCampbell full of the most combustible matter, putrid with Slavery and the Slave trade— It announces the receipt of information from the Havana, and a highly respectable source, charging the English abolitionists and Government with a deliberate project to occupy and ruin the Island of Cuba— And the Consul is instructed to collect and transmit all possible information on the subject— Matter for more enquiry and deep meditation. The instructions promise that we will not permit Great-Britain to occupy the Island of Cuba— Mr J. J. Greenough was here this Evening.

2— VI— Sunday—  Morning service at the second Presbyterian church by the Revd. Mr M’Carer of Philadelphia. He supplies the pulpit until the return of Dr Ezra Stiles Ely from Missouri— When he rose in the pulpit I was struck with his resemblance to Robert Barnwell Rhett, the member of Congress from South Carolina.— He read the 16th. chapter of Luke, and commented shortly upon the parable of the unjust Steward, noticing the objections taken to the forms of expression importing that the Lord commended the unjust steward for the perpetration of an atrocious fraud, upon the general principle that the children of this world are wiser in their generation than the children of light— The words commended and wiser must be understood in an ironical sense; and yet it seems incongruous that the Lord, plundered by his faithless steward should commend him for the worldly wisdom of his device to indemnify himself for the loss of his place. Mr M’Carer’s text was from Revelation 22.11. [“]He that is unjust, let him be unjust still: and he which is filthy, let him be filthy still:” omitting the remainder of the verse:—“and he that is righteous, let him be righteous still: and he that is holy, let him be holy still.”— The doctrine inferred from the text was that the retributions of the world to come will be eternal— A brief account of the composition of this book by Saint John in the island of Patmos was given— That is a prophesy of coming events till the end of the world— That this sentence in the closing chapter of the book has direct reference to the final consummation of all things— That it is equivalent to a positive declaration, that the wicked cannot change their nature after death—that they will continue wicked in the next world as they were in this, and their crimes and of course their punishments will endure, for endless ages— This is presbyterian creed, but very defective logic— The premises do not warrant the conclusion— Though it cannot be denied that the context gives countenance to the reasoning— Mr Stephen D. Smith dined with us— Afternoon at St. Johns Church. Mr Hawley read the evening prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent; and preached from Zechariah 4.10. “For who hath despised the day of small things?” Half a verse— A sentiment applicable to all human affairs; but here specially applied to the rebuilding of the temple of Jerusalem by Zerubbabel— Mr Hawley generalizes, and did not explain why the rebuilding of the Temple should be called the day of small things— The prophet Haggai had announced The glory of the latter house shall be greater than of the former, saith the Lord of hosts: and in this place will I give peace saith the Lord of hosts— Bishop Whittingham was to have come to administer the rite of confirmation to many; but was detained by indisposition— After church I visited Mr T. B. Johnson—

3. IV:30. Monday  North-east wind—chill—damp—snow.  Morning call from Mr Heman Lincoln— He is connected with the Baptist missions, and has been on an excursion into Virginia— He was inquisitive upon the prospects of the approaching Presidential election— He asked my opinion of the chances and agreed with me that the prospects were in favour of Martin van Buren. He thought the prospects of Henry Clay as irretrievably gone: as I have no doubt they are— Those of Tyler, Calhoun, Cass, are equally desperate— Buchanan is the shadow of a shade, and General Scott is a Daguerrotype likeness of a candidate—all sunshine, through a camera obscura. Mr Lincoln’s partiality was for Theodore Frelinghuysen or judge John M’Lean I had never heard the name of Frelinghuysen as a candidate before; and M’Lean, is but a second edition of John Tyler—vitally democratic, double-dealing and hypocritical— They will all go into the democratic convention, and all melt into the Corinthian brass of Kinderhoek. Mr. Lincoln urged me warmly to publish my Lecture upon Faith. I told him I had promised a copy of it for publication; but I supposed they had forgotten it, to the Trustees of the Warren Street Chapel Boston where it had been first delivered— I gave Mr Lincoln copies of my jubilee of the Constitution—of my speech of 14 and 15. April 1842 on War with Mexico and England—and of my Lecture on the social compact— I went to the Department of State, and saw Fletcher Webster the chief clerk— The Secretary his father left the City last Night for a visit of ten days to Boston— I gave the son a Letter from Plymouth for reference to the Secretary of the Navy, and went into Hunter’s chamber where I spent three hours in examining the instructions to Poinsett and Anthony Butler, and their correspondence relating to the boundary with Mexico and to Texas— The enquiry deepens as I proceed; and I shall as usual be obliged to break it short off for want of time to find its sounding. The Chronology of the Negotiations for the acquisition of Texas and California would of itself be a labour of weeks, and yet without it I cannot master the subject for any useful result— Upon enquiry of Mr Hunter for the Essays of Americanus and La Salle, he brought me a thin volume of Missouri, and other Western Newspapers of the year 1829. forming a complete collection of those documents, none of which had I ever before seen— The first instructions under the Jackson administration on this subject was from Van Buren to Poinsett 25. August 1829—precisely at the time, when Benton was publishing Americanus and La Salle at St. Louis. I have reading for at least a month opened to me by the cursory perusals of this day— I made up the minutes of the Committee of foreign Affairs.

4. V:15. Tuesday.  Snow— Rain— Snow.  My cough has much abated, but has not wholly disappeared; nor can I expect that it ever will; but I am now confined almost entirely to the house by the weather—an easterly wind with alternate snow and rain having chilled and darkened the whole of this day— At home I took up the Message and documents relating to the seizure of Monterey by Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones.— There is no warrant for it in any of his written instructions from the Navy Department— But I remark, with no small concern 1. the special charge of exploring the coast within the gulph of California and as high as the Port of San Francisco—one of the reasons of which is the weakness of the local authorities, and their irresponsibility to the distant government of Mexico. 2. The tone of intercourse both military and diplomatic, bearing upon Mexico— It would never have entered into the head of Jones to commit such an outrage upon a Nation whom he believed able to resent it— Waddy Thompson’s diplomacy is in perfect keeping with this temper— Even his apologies are insolent, insulting, and contemptuous; and there is far too much of the same spirit in the notes of our Secretary of State— The spirit of encroachment upon Mexico, is stimulated and nourished by this settled and but too well founded conviction of her helpless weakness in conflict with the gigantic energy of our national avarice and ambition— When I contemplate the prospect before us, my heart sinks within me for the cause of human freedom—and for our own— At the Department of State too I found matter for gloomy anticipations in the instructions of 13 Jany last to the Consul at the Havana Robert B. Campbell which discloses great alarm at the Havana and thence instigated here, at the supposed design of the British Government to take possession of the island of Cuba; and a real design at the Havana to urge us to be before hand with Britain, by taking it ourselves. The Secretary of State tells the Consul in a very trenchant tone that we shall not permit Great-Britain to take possession of Cuba— The real fact I suppose to be that the British Government are turning the screws upon the importation of Slaves into the island and that they can no longer in defiance of all Law, and all Treaty, openly gorge their markets with 25000 bozal negroes every year— The Havana has been and is one of the last inexpugnable haunts of the African Slave trade pirates. I received Letters this day—one from B. R. Curtis, reminding me of my conditional engagement to deliver next August the anniversary discourse to the alumni of Harvard University, and one from James Savage, for the anniversary of 29. May—

5. V. Wednesday.  The Snow has disappeared, but there is yet no symptom of Spring. Coll. Freeman was again here this morning. He went to Norfolk, but remained there only a few days— Since he came back he has had a long interview with the President, and has written a tart Letter to the Secretary of the Navy. He has preferred charges against Coll. Henderson, which the Secretary refuses to entertain— Freeman says that Wise advised Upshur to sustain Henderson because he was a Virginian against Freeman who was nothing but a Yankee. The Colonel has obtained an informal permission to be absent for an indefinite time from his station at Norfolk, but no encouragement to expect a resto-rastoration to Boston— He is brooding over a memorial to Congress, against Henderson, and perhaps against the Secretary of the Navy, Upshur. He asked me, if he could depend upon Mr Parmenter to present his memorial. I said any member from Massachusetts could present the memorial if he insisted upon it; but I could not advise the measure, for he would have all the Executive, and all the Virginia influence against him, besides that of Henderson himself and of his family, which was very great— Coll. Freeman seemed to believe that Congress would easily be persuaded to abolish the Office of Colonel of the Marine Corps, which he believed to be altogether useless; but then the Office would devolve upon the Lieutenant Colonel—that is, upon himself— Mr Beck came with a subscription paper, for the purchase of a collection of coins or medals, of sundry kings of England and France, from Dr Wyatt, for the National Institute. I spent again about 3 hours at the Department of State, examining the correspondence of Anthony Butler with the Department concerning his Negotiation for the purchase of Texas— He was himself a speculator in Texian lands.— First despatched with the Instructions of Van Buren to Poinsett of 29. Augt. 1829. His first Letter is from Attakapas 17. Octr. 1829. complaining of having been delayed on the road by sickness— On that same day, Poinsett’s Letter of recall was signed and a long jesuitical Letter of Instructions to himself as Chargé d’Affaires, to which Office he had been appointed on the 12th. of October— There is some mystification in these dates; probably explainable.— Butlers second Letter is from Bexar, near the river Nueces, in TexasNovember 1829. and the third 31. December 1829 from the City of Mexico. Poinsett departed immediately after loaded with execrations, and Guerrero’s government was in the agonies of dissolution— I enquired of Mr Hunter, if any answer had been received from Robert Campbell, the Consul at the Havana to the secret instructions of 14. Jany last and he brought me the answer dated 9. Feby 1843.— He discredits entirely the secret informer’s tale about the intention of the British Government to take possession of the Island of Cuba: but joins in holy horror of the English abolitionists, and is in full confidential communication with General Valdez the present Governor General— R. D. Cutts was here this Evening, but I did not see him—

6. V. Thursday.  Mr Lincoln called on me this morning, and mentioned to me that Mr Barker Burnell, member of the 11th. Congressional district of Massachusetts in the last Congress, and member elect of the 10th Congressional district of the present Congress has been detained here by severe indisposition since the close of the last Session and is yet confined to his chamber, and intimated a wish that I would visit him. I told him it was but two days since that I heard of Mr Burnell’s being yet here; and I was then on the point of going out to see him. I went accordingly and found him with his wife at Mrs M Daniel’s, under a cough worse than mine, and expectoration of blood, which he says comes not from the lungs but from the throat— He thinks himself convalescent and almost wholly recovered. But he shewed me a respirator which he had sent for to New-York, an invention of which I had never before heard, but to be used by personals with pulmonary complaints for breathing fresh air, softened by the medium through which it passes— Dr Sewall came in while I was there and Mrs Heman Lincoln who with her husband lodges at the same house— I thence prolonged my walk to the capitol; meeting on my way the members of the late Congress, Sumter, Proffit, and Joseph L. Williams, who says that Proffit is going as Chargé d’Affaires to Sardinia— I went into the Congress Library and for about 5 minutes looked into the first Volume of Hazard’s State papers, for some account of the New England Colonial confederacy of the 16th century, but I had no time for examination.— In the Clerk’s office, I asked of Mr Burche an explanation of an entry on the printed journal of the House, of 22d. February last, p. 437. that the great Latimer petition, and five others when presented by me, under the order of the house of 29. March 1842 “The reception of these petitions was objected to; and the question of reception was laid on the table”— This entry was false— They were all referred to the Committee on the judiciary; of which I furnished to Mr Burche the written proof in my own list of the petitions presented by me, which I had given to him with the petitions, and which he had returned to me— Burche admitted the facts, and after some titubation, said that Kingman had made the entry, and that he had overlooked it by inadvertence in his revisal of the journal—and he promised to have the error corrected which I fear he will not do— I had a search to be renewed for some other Documents— Mr Frye, Mr King the painter, with Miss Eliza Johnson, and Mr and Mrs Horatio Greenough spent the evening with us.

7. V:15. Friday  Spring is at last setting in; the sky is clear, and the atmosphere balmy; but the effect on the bodily frame relaxing into extreme lassitude and imbecility— I awoke about 3 this morning with a fit of severe coughing, and a muddy head-ache which passed off before breakfast, but left me drowsy and torpid throughout the day— Mr Child called on me, and gave me the first sheet of a pamphlet which he is publishing on the Texan Revolution, and the late outrage in California.— I had a long conversation with him on this and other consanguineous subjects, and I advised him to keep his eye steadily fixed on occuring events in the island of Cuba— He told me, that Webster had within a few day renewed his propositions to General Almonte, for a cession by Mexico of six degrees of Latitude along the shores of the pacific, and the parallel of 36 across the continent.strike the Arkansas river. This would include Monterey of California and Santa Fe of New-Mexico— I called upon General Almonte himself and he told me that Mr Webster had renewed the proposal for the cession, the other day, when they exchanged the ratifications of the recent Convention for the payment of the adjudicated claims— There are rumours coming from New Orleans that Santa Anna had released a judge Robinson, one of the Texian prisoners taken in their late predatory expedition, and through him had made overtures towards the recognition of the Independence of Texas— Almonte said he had no doubt that judge Robinson had been released, but he believed not a word of his being charged with any proposal for recognizing the independence of Texas— For he knew that Santa Anna considered the recovery of Texas as vital to the existence of the Mexican Republic, and he had the day before yesterday received Letters from Santa Anna, of very recent date which gave no intimation of any such proposed negotiation; which he thinks there must have been if it had been contemplated— Especially as he himself had been a prisoner in Texas with Santa-Anna, and was perfectly acquainted with all his views concerning that territory— I spoke of the rumours that Great Britain had offered her mediation between Texas and Mexico— He said the British Consul had made an informal tender of such a mediation—but it had been rejected with an expression of surprize that Great Britain should undertake to negotiate for the Independence of Texas, knowing as she did that the revolt of that Province had originated and was to be consummated solely for the reinstitution of Slavery which had been abolished by Mexico.— There is now a rumour that Great Britain has offered Texas, to mediate for her Independence with Mexico, on condition that Texas shall abolish Slavery. Almonte said he knew nothing of that— He promised to call on me before I leave the City— I went to the Department of State and looked again for about an hour into Anthony Butler’s correspondence, but could not command my own attention and came home. Joseph H. Adams dined with us. Afternoon walk. Walter Hellen here— My wife confined to her bed.

8. V. Saturday.  I finished the reading of the Message of 22d Feby 1843—on the taking possession of Monterey Doct. 166. 27. Congress 3d Session, in answer to two Resolutions, offered by me on the 1st. of February under instruction of the Committee of foreign Affairs, though not so noted on the journal of the house— On the 31st. of Jany I moved the Resolutions in Committee— Cushing alone voted against them on the ground that they called for all the instructions to Captain Jones and all his correspondence, without the usual exception of such as the President might deem it improper to communicate— When I moved the Resolutions in the house Granger immediately moved the previous question Wise shuffled it off for that day by calling at the expiration of the morning hour, for the orders of the day.— The next day, the previous question was carried— The yeas and nays were taken upon the resolutions. ay 116. of whom 23 democrats, and only two Virginia whigs, Stuart and Summers. Nay 69. of whom 11. Virginians, Barton and Powell, whigs, of the number— Cushing asked to be and was excused from voting— The Message notices the omission of the usual exception in the Resolutions; asserts the right of the executive to withhold the communication of papers which he deems improper for publication; but says he has in this case communicated all, perceiving no necessity to withhold any— Tyler’s arbitrary Spirit, and his flinching practice, have been signally manifested throughout this whole transaction— The document itself is full of matter for future consideration and commentary— I spent again three hours at the Department of State, hurrying over Anthony Butler’s correspondence, especially on the negociations for Texas—with regard to which there are three classes of papers—Public despatches and private Letters to the Secretary of State, and private Letters to President Jackson— There is no record of the President’s Letters to him— It was one of Jackson’s practices to hold private and secret correspondences upon the most important public affairs, without leaving any copies of his own Letters or instructions in the Departments. A most irregular, mischievous and imminently dangerous exercise of power, for which the Constitution provides no remedy.— One of its effects is that there is no trace of Anthony Butler, till his appointment in August 1829 as bearer of despatches to Poinsett instructing him to open without delay a negotiation for the purchase of as much of the province of Texas as could be obtained— How he came to be at Washington in August 1829. does not appear, but the Negotiation was evidently instigated by him, and I have no doubt that he was deeply involved in Texian land jobbing.— On returning home I found the card of Mr George Brown. Walk before and after dinner— Richard D. Cutts and his Sister here— Cry of fire close by.

9. V. Sunday.—  Palm Sunday.  At the second presbyterian church this morning, Mr M’Carer preached from Psalm 84–11. [“]For the Lord God is a sun and shield: The Lord will give grace and glory; no good thing will he withhold from them that walk uprightly.” The Sermon began with the usual clerical rather than critical sweeping assertion of the immense superiority for sublimity of the Psalms over every merely human composition— A matter about which after a rigorous comparison with the Odes of Pindar and of Horace, especially the carmen saeculare, I have some doubts— The preacher said further that this 84th. psalm was very beautiful, as it is in the asiatic or oriental Stile— That it was believed to be from the pen of David written at the time of his expulsion from Jerusalem by the revolt of his unnatural, and rebellious son Absalom— Of which I perceive no evidence external or internal— The Psalmist pours out his Soul in extasies of desire to enjoy the privilege of devotion in the tabernacles of the Lord of Hosts— There is no allusion direct or indirect to the rebellion of Absalom; nor to a calamitous condition as the source of inspiration— There was then some comment upon the aptitude of illustration in the imagery representing God, as at once a Sun and a shield— A Sun—the idolatry of Nature— The Sun—of all the visible creation, the object of the greatest beneficence to man.— The source of light and heat—all splendour to the eye— The Parent of all production for nourishment and subsistence believed by the antient Parsees and the modern Parsees to be God himself or the abode of the deity— Then a shield. In those antient day the emblem of protection from all danger, because an effectual guard against every weapon of assault whether of sword, falchion, arrow, javelin or spear, before the invention of firearms— Then the comforting promise of the gifts of grace and glory; and the delightful assurance that he will withhold no good thing, from them that walk uprightly.— The good hearted presbyterian seemed for the moment to have forgotten the atonement by the blood of the lamb— Joseph H. Adams dined with us— After dinner at St. John’s church Mr Hawley read the evening service for the sixth Sunday in Lent and preached from 1. Peter 4.17.—what shall the end be, of them that obey not the gospel of God? He gave notice that during the coming Passion week, there would be service every morning at the Church, and on Thursday Bishop Whittingham would confer the rite of confirmation at 1/2 past 4 p.m.— On Good Friday—service morning and afternoon— After Church, I called and saw Mr T. B. Johnson— And then visited by request Mrs Tudor and Mrs Stuart—

10. IV.45. Monday  The purpose of Mrs Tudor, and her daughter Mrs Stewart in sending for me was to request me, to write to Washington Irving, Minister of the United States at Madrid, in behalf of Frederic Tudor, the inventor of the commerce in ice— He has had for 30 years a special privilege to supply the City of the Havana with that article; but at the last renewal of his patent, a man by the name of Damon, who for many years his agent in the business and grown rich in the agency, took out the patent in his own name, and grasped at the whole profits of the trade for himself— This has involved Tudor in a Lawsuit— Tudor has recovered three sentence in his favour in the tribunals of the Island; but Damon has appealed to the Supreme Court at Madrid— This Court they say cannot reverse the decisions of the Colonial Courts, but may delay their execution, and in the meantime Mr Tudor’s privilege is suspended— Mrs Stewart gave me a Letter to her from her brother Henry Tudor at the Havana, dated 20. March last, urging her to write to General Rodil, minister of War at Madrid, with whom she is acquainted; soliciting his influence as a friend at Court; and she and her mother requested me to enclose the Letter for Rodil, to Mr Irving, with a recommendation of the case to Irving himself, and to forward the Letters with the despatches from the department of State, by the Steam packet, to sail on the 16th. from New-York— This morning I groped again three hours into the despatches of Anthony Butler at the Department of State— The three-fold and double dealing line of negotiation 1. for a commercial Treaty 2. indemnity for all sorts of claims and 3. to strip Mexico of Texas, Santa Fe, and California, and annex them all to this union, runs into the most curious details of Jackson and Tyler duplicity. Butler’s Letter of 17. June 1835 to Forsyth, suppressed in the communication of 4 July 1838 to the House of Representatives is the Passe par tout of the whole system pursued with inflexible perseverance down to this hour— I met at the Department, Mr George Brown, who is going out as Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands— As I was returning home from the Department, I met Dr Mayo, who asked me for a copy of my address of 17 September 1842 at Braintree which I gave him— I received at 4. p.m. a note of invitation from Dr Sewall to attend the wedding of his niece at his house this day at 1/2 past 3— Sent of course an excuse— At 1/2 past 7 this evening I attended a stated meeting of the National Institute at the Patent Office building— Peter Force, a Vice President was in the Chair. I presented the allegorical napkin, and specimens of Saxon Silks from Dr. Flügel Consul of the United States at Leipzig, for which a vote of thanks was adopted— Among the other proceedings was the offer of a Resolution by the revd. Mr Bulfinch for the appointment of a Committee to enquire and report how the meetings of the Institute may be made more interesting and instructive; which after some discussion he withdrew— Home at 1/2 past 10.

11. IV:15. Tuesday  Lieutenant Hunter of the Navy, called on me this morning and asked me to examine his new invented war steamer Union now at the Navy-yard, and of which he has a small model at his lodgings at Fuller’s hotel— I promised to call there and see it at 11. O’Clock to-morrow morning— He gave me Senate document 244. of the 3d of March last, the last day of the last Session—being a Report made by him to the Naval Committees of the two houses, after examination by them of his Steamer on the 26th. of February— The report was presented to the Senate by Mr Bayard the chairman of their naval committee. The invention of Lieutenant Hunter, is of a submerged horizontal propeller of the boat, substituted, for the paddlewheels of Fultons invention;—but with paddlewheels under the water. I walked to and from the capitol; and met in the Clerk’s Office Edward Stanly who since the close of the Session has been home and has come back— In the document chamber, Mr Elmore, heretofore a member of Congress from South-Carolina, and in the Capitol-yard Horace Everett, who told me that he expected to remain here about a fortnight longer— I was desirous of completing a file of Documents concerning our relations with Mexico and Texas: and had made out a list from the Index to the House Documents from 1831 to 1839— I obtained a considerable number of them; but of several of the most important there are no spare copies left— Returning home, I stop’d to visit Mr Burnell, who is yet confined to his chamber, though convalescent— The assortment of my pamphlets to have them bound up in volumes, not only absorbs an enormous quantity of time, but consumes the labour of the mind, which should be devoted to productive thought, and terminates in distraction—day after day passes off and the time is gone— To concentrate my reflections upon one of the numerous projects floating in my brain I began yesterday an address to my late constituents of the 12th late, and my future constituents of the present 8th. congressional districts of Massachusetts, which if I have the courage and perseverance to finish it, I may deliver as a Lecture before the commencement of the next Session of Congress. I know not how this may succeed—the time is not propitious for me to speak to my countrymen unpalatable truths—but I wish to leave behind me something which may keep alive the flame of liberty and preserve it in that conflict between Slavery and freedom which is drawing to its crisis and which is to brighten or to darken the condition of the human race upon earth— I wrote this Evening a short Letter to Washington Irving at Madrid, and received one from Mrs Stewart, to General Rodil; and requesting that her mother might see my Letter to Mr Irving before I send it—

12. V. Wednesday  The work upon which I have at length undertaken to concentrate the employment of my leisure time and the result of my meditations, in the form of an address to my constituents past and future deepens in interest as I proceed; and widens in the list of topics which I propose to discuss— Already I perceive that one discourse of two hours duration will not suffice to unburden my heart of the sentiments and opinions which I believe vital to the happiness, peace and future liberty of this great people— Whether any thing that I can do or say, will avail to save and preserve them from the dangers with which they are beset; or to avert the Catastrophe impending over them, an all wise Providence will decide— The prospect of the future is deeply discouraging; but despondency would surrender the cause; and exertion even if fruitless will be sanctified by the motive for using it— I called at 11. this morning at Fuller’s hotel, and examined the model Steamer of Lieutt. Hunter’s invention, in which the paddlewheels are under water on the two sides and close to the bottom of the boat—with a horizontal instead of a perpendicular rotation, an unincumbered deck, and noiseless machinery— I agreed to go with him to-morrow morning at 11. if fair, and visit the Union Steamer itself at the Navy-yard. Thence I went and smothered three hours more at the Department of State in rapid survey of Anthony Butler’s correspondence— This man was in the last War with Great Britain Lieutenant Coll. and then Coll. of the 28th. Regiment of infantry; appointed as a citizen of Kentucky— He says in one of his Letters that he is a native of South-Carolina; and that he was many years an intimate and confidential friend of Jackson under whom he served in the New-Orleans campaign.— His appointment in 1829 as bearer of despatches to Poinsett, and afterwards as chargé d’Affaires to Mexico, was as a Citizen of Mississippi, and he was at that very time a jobber in Texian Lands— His looseness of moral principle, and political profligacy as disclosed in several of his Letters— His vanity and self sufficiency in others— He boasts of his address in managing Lucas Alaman, by mystifing a little, and while under the shield of diplomatic privilege, brutally insulted the Mexican Minister of War, General Tornel, by scurrilous and insolent Letters challenging him to fight a duel— Tornel’s conduct in return was rather tame than spirited— Santa Anna demanded Butler’s recall; but Jackson had already dismissed him— Mr Hunter shewed me also a despatch from Joseph Eve, Chargé d’Affaires in Texas, telling strange and incredible stories of suspicions and distrust among the Texians of their President Houston. Stanly and Childs were here when I was out.

13. V. Thursday.  Rainy day— At my request my nephew Hull Adams went to Lieutenant Hunter and proposed to postpone to a fair day my visit with him to his Steamer Union at the Navy Yard—to which he readily assented— I received this morning from Jeremiah Hughes of Baltimore, the present publisher of Niles National Register the missing numbers of the 62 and 63 volumes which I had written to him to obtain— I took them to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and left them there to be bound— I saw Mr Gales there somewhat perplexed by the publication of Mr Webster’s letter to Edward Everett, recently despatched and which he is instructed to read to Lord Aberdeen, and give him a copy of it, if desired— Gales asked me if it was usual in negotiation to publish in the newspapers controversial notes, before they have been received by the parties to whom they are addressed— I told him it was not usual heretofore; but that of late years all negotiation is little more than a perpetual appeal to public opinion, and the negotiators little more than advocates before the tribunal of the civilized world— I referred him to the case of the Spanish Minister Pizarro who in 1818 addressed to George W. Erving Minister of the U.S. in Spain a manifesto against General Jackson’s invasion of Florida, equivalent to a declaration of War, and before waiting for our reception of it; published it in a Hamburg Gazette whence it was circulated all over Europe. In return for which my answer of Instructions to Erving, was communicated to Congress, and published all over the Union, before it could reach the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, as the Counterpart to his manifesto— Other instances of more recent occurrence were referred to in the case of Gorostiza’s pamphlet published here in 1836. of General Cass’s publication of his preposterous protest against the ratification by France of the Quintuple Treaty, and the triangular debates between the British Parliament the French Legislative chambers, and the North American Congress like a game of Chess played by correspondence between the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Horn, or between Nova Zembla and New-Zealand— I visited Edward Stanly, Timothy Childs, and John C. Clark at Mrs Owner’s on the Capitol hill— Met them at their own door, just returned from a visit with Lieutenant Hunter to his Steamer Union, with which they are much pleased— Clark has just buried his lovely daughter Josephine, in her 15th year, a school companion of our Mary-Louisa— Stanly starts for home to-morrow morning—still uncertain whether he will be nominated for re-election to the 28th. Congress or not. Childs is still detained here by sickness but looks convalescent— At the document room of the house I obtained two copies of the Message of 14 July 1842. containing part of the peppery correspondence between Webster and Bocanegra

14. IV.30. Friday.  Another day of solitude; rain and gloom with the exception of a three hours visit to the Department of State— There, the progress of my enquiries into the biography of Anthony Butler, and of Andrew Jackson’s projected dismemberment of Mexico, is disturbed and protracted by the daily occurrence of new incidents which consume the time and divert my attention from the main object of my pursuit— I found at the Office this day four different weekly newspapers in the month of March down to the 29th.— 1. The Civilian and Galveston City Gazette, published at Galveston. 2 The Telegraph and Texas Register, at Houston— 3. The Texian and Brazos farmer, at Washington; and 4. The western Advocate, at the City of Austin—a new paper of which I had before seen the first number.— These papers are of opposite political parties are highly excited partizans for and against their President Samuel Houston; all passionately devoted to the lone star of Texas; all of the Catonian school, exterminating War upon Mexico; and all panting for annexation to the United States— T. W. Gilmer’s Letter is in one of them with a warm commendation of its object and argument; an earnest exhortation to the Texians to gather up their forces for a renewed application to our Congress at their next long Session, with assurance of kind support from our amiable President, and an easy disposal of the opposition of Johny Q— Dr Robinson was at Galveston, with the compromise propositions of Santa Anna which will be rejected with disdain—and Rusk, the appointed Major General, was breathing blood and slaughter for the invasion of Mexico, if he could but get hold of the Law for his own appointment— Mr Hunter furnished me a new Map of Texas—Austin’s, published by Tanner in 1840. and shewed me another despatch from Joseph Eve, dated at Galveston 29. March— In the midst of all her vices, difficulties and troubles, Texas is swelling with incredible rapidity into a formidable Slave State which Mexico can never recover, and from the contamination of whose Slavery nothing can save this Union, short of a special interposition of Providence— Mr Hunter produced to me also this day a private note dated 25 July 1835. signed A. J. and directed to the then Secretary of State Forsyth—proposing additional Instructions to Butler to offer half a million more, for the line of the Rio del Norte from its mouth to the 37th. degree of Latitude and thence straight to the pacific— This note was the seminal principle of the Instruction from Forsyth to Butler of 6. August 1835—published in Doct. 42. p. 18. of Message 3. Octr. 1837.— In the regular examination of Butler’s despatches I have only reached his Letter of 25. May 1831. refering to and answering one from him of 24 March 1831. which is not at the Department. I continue to write morning and evening on the proposed address to my constituents, but begin to shrink from the task.

15. IV:30. Saturday.  Come—gentle Spring! etherial mildness! come. She is here! and brings to me uninterrupted leisure, instead of which this daily record, my brooding address to my Constituents, and my researches at the Department of State, fill to the brim every vacant hour, and keep me on the rack of overplied occupation as laborious as at the busiest period of the Session of Congress— Meanwhile my correspondence runs into irredeemable arrears and my private affairs and impending duties are neglected— One thing at a time was the maxim of John de Witt— Too many irons in the fire at once is the fatal flaw in my economy of time. It was past one O’Clock this afternoon when I reached my table in Mr Hunter’s chamber at the Department of State— He was not there— In pursuing the correspondence of Anthony Butler I find a Letter from him to President Jackson of 25. May 1831. extracts only from which were communicated to H.R.U.S. in document 351. p 382—where a line of stars represent two most important pages of the despatch— Jackson, in a Letter to him of 24. March 1831 had complained of not hearing from him later than the preceding November— This despatch is a long and laboured apology for delay in the Texian Negotiation, but he proves 1. that this delay had been expressly enjoined by Van Buren’s instructions to him, as well as by his own convictions of expediency, and 2. he proves the shortness of Jackson’s memory in pretending that he had received nothing from him of later date than November, by referring to a publication in the Washington Telegraph of a paper transmitted by Butler to him with a despatch dated in January— This is one of the numberless instances of Jackson’s reckless disregard to truth, when the impatience of his temper betrays the frailty of his memory— Jackson’s passion for the acquisition of Texas was intense. Butler was a Texian land-jobber, who treated Jackson, as he boasts of having treated Alaman, the Mexican Secretary of State and negotiator with him— “Mystified a little so as to leave him not without hope.” Alaman and Butler played a game of tame cheating in which each intended to overreach the other— Butler mystified with Alaman and Alaman mystified with Butler.— Alaman was the shrewdest knave of the two— When Butler wrote this despatch he had just discovered that Alaman had made him his dupe; and he with ludicrous gravity discloses his first doubts of Mexican sincerity He advises Jackson to insult Montoya who coming out to supersede Tornel as the Mexican charge d’Affaires, and give him to understand that Mexico was of very little account with us— Edward Livingston took the place of Martin Van Buren as Secretary of State on the 27th. of May 1831. and his correspondence with Butler began with a sharp altercation about some irregularity in Butler’s accounts. The Galveston civilian of 29. March the comment on Robinson’s mission, and on T. W. Gilmer’s Letter are to be remembered— Short walks before and after dinner. Walter Hellen was here this morning, and Miss Cutts took tea and spent the Evening here— Isaac Hull dined abroad

16. VI. Sunday.  Easter. No fire in my chamber—  Fahrenheit 70. No fire in my chamber— Heard at the second Presbyterian church Mr M’Carer, from Isaiah 57.21. [“]There is no peace, saith my God, to the wicked.” The discourse began with a dissertation upon the disposition natural to all mankind to seek for peace or happiness, in which he prosified Pope’s invocation— O! happiness our beings end and aim—or Horace’s Otium divos rogat impotente, Prensus AEgeo.— This is a hacknied commonplace. He then adduced as instances of the torture of remorse suffered by the wicked in the cases of Cain—of Saul—and of Judas Iscariot— He then described the distress and uneasiness always experienced by vicious persons specifying only the Miser and the sensualist— This list might have been much enlarged, and sharply pointed to exhibit the real wicked intended by the text— The preacher finally addressed his very scanty auditory and enquired whether among them there were not some who felt themselves included within this denunciation—exhorting them with great earnestness to work out their own salvation, by the consciousness of their own depravity, and of their own inability to save themselves— The main difficulty for this text is to affix a precise idea to the word wicked. In the general doctrine of human depravity, I concur, I hope in humility and sincerity, with fervent prayer for divine aid in self chastisement and correction— But I was not much disturbed by this malediction upon the wicked, by the fear that it includes me— I confess my unworthiness, and labour to redeem myself from it—relying only upon the mercy of my maker— The house was nearly empty, and from the urgency of his prayer that God would provide a pastor after his own heart for this people, I inferred that the Reverend Dr Ely has finally declined their invitation to him to come to them I attended the afternoon service at St. John’s Church, where the Revd Mr Oliver Abbot Shaw, of Philadelphia, read prayers for the evening of Easter day and preached from John 11.25. “Jesus said unto her ‘I am the resurrection and the life.[’]” The preacher observed that this day being devoted to the celebration of Christs own resurrection, this saying of his on the occasion of his raising Lazarus from the dead seemed appropriate to the devotion of the day; and remarked upon the peculiar energy of the words, being at the third demonstration given of his power to raise the dead—the first being in the case of Jairus’s daughter and the second in that of the widow’s Son at Nain. And here he claimed to be the resurrection itself because as Adam in his fall had represented the whole human race, so Christ in his own resurrection equally reprented that of all mankind.

17. V. Monday. Easter Monday— Fahrenheit 70.  Rain again no inconsiderable part of the day. The address to my constituents, and my investigations daily at the Department of State, into our public relations with Mexico and Texas, all have one object, the contribution of my last public labours to the cause of human freedom, in its present and impending conflict with Slavery. The field is too vast for me: An address of two hours which I am proposing to prepare will scarcely skim the surface of the subject; and the dangers of the undertaking are more appalling than its toils— But I must pass on— Sursum corda! The preacher whom I heard at Saint John’s church yesterday afternoon, Mr Shaw, called on me this morning, and had with me a conversation of more than two hours. He is a native of Lexington, Massachusetts, and is now a settled minister of the episcopal church at Philadelphia and a professor at the high school in that city— His grandfather was an inhabitant of Lexington, when the revolutionary War commenced with the bloody conflict of that spot and shared in it. He was also at the battle of Bunker’s hill, and an ardent patriot of the Revolution, and lived and died a country farmer at Lexington.— He had always a strong and bitter prejudice against England and every thing English, and once in riding down to Cambridge with his grandson when a boy, and pointing out to him the university buildings as they passed along, the boy seeing the episcopal church on the other side of the square enquired what that was, and he answered that is the tory meeting house— Mr Shaw told me other anecdotes of his own life, and made numerous enquiries relating to mine which I readily answered— He said it was so dark yesterday afternoon that he could not see to read a written sermon which he had in his pocket, and was obliged to extemporize which he did— He enquired much as to my practice of extempore speaking, which I acknowledged was wretchedly imperfect, but which yet was such as anxious labour and unwearied pains have been able to make it— I considered it as an art for the gift of which the seeds of which are given by nature to be cultivated by intense study and matured by frequent practice and long experience.— My own original portion of the seed being next to nothing, my cultivation of it inadequate— My experience much interrupted and my practice like every thing about me unsystematic, confused and drowsy.— At the department of State my progress with Anthony Butler is provokingly slow.— Hunter shewed me a Letter from the Sandwich Island Commissioners Halilio and Richards to D. Webster, of 3. March 1843. who say Lord Aberdeen declined to acknowledge the Independence of the Islands, because we had not acknowledged it, and were endeavouring to obtain exclusive privileges for ourselves— Also a Letter from St. Louis Missouri, claiming to be recognized as Consul from Texas at that place. Joseph H. Adams who has just received his Commission of Lieutenant came and took leave, going home on a furlough for 3 weeks; and then ordered to the coast of Africa. David L. Child spent the evening here.

18. IV:30. Tuesday  Dull weather and chilly atmosphere— Dr. Sewall called upon me, and informed me that he proposed to leave the city next Monday to embark in the Steamer at Boston for Liverpool for the purpose of visiting the medical schools in England, Scotland and Ireland— Then those of the continent of Europe, Holland, France, Germany, including Hamburg, Berlin, Vienna, and Italy, and to return home by next October— He repeated a request he had heretofore made that I would furnish him with a Letter, and I promised him one to Edward Everett— In the course of my address I find occasion every now and then to state a fact, for the authentication of which I must have recourse to a document; and that puts me upon a chase which always consumes hours, and often leaves me disappointed, having found every thing that I did not, want, and failed to find precisely what I did. At the department of State this day I was disconcerted in the examination of Anthony Butlers negotiations from the condition of his correspondence— The negotiation for the commercial treaty was open and ostensible Poinsett had on the 12th. of January 1828. concluded with the then Mexican Government two separate Treaties one of Commerce and one of limits— From the time of the Mexican Declaration of Independence, she had assumed the boundary agreed upon by us with Spain in the Florida Treaty, as the existing boundary between her and us, to which we had assented in 1824. Poinsett, under Instructions from H. Clay, approved by me had proposed and urged the purchase of Texas for one million of dollars, which Mexico had rejected and refused to conclude a Treaty of Commerce unless with another, confirming the Florida Treaty line boundary.— The two Treaties were to be ratified, and their ratifications exchanged within four months from their date, but they were not. When Jackson came in, after some time the Negotiations were renewed to revise the commercial Treaty, but Jackson proposed anew the purchase of Texas for which he authorised the offer of 5. millions of dollars, while at the same time Sam Houston went into Texas to kindle an internal insurrection and separate Texas from Mexico— Poinsett Was recalled and Butler was charged with the double negotiation— Poinsett’s Treaty of limits was reconcluded, and his commercial Treaty revised and altered— The two new Treaties were signed by Butler, and on the part of Mexico by Alaman and Manjino on the 5th. of April 1831. They were to be ratified and the ratifications exchanged within one year from the date and on the 5th. of April 1832. Jackson issued his proclamation declaring that the ratifications of both Treaties had been exchanged. (more to morrow). David L. Child here—this Eve.

19. V:15. Wednesday  Mr George Brown the Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands was here this morning, and I had a long conversation with him, upon public affairs. He is a speaking example of the chemical affinities between power, patronage, place and political opinions— He came here two years ago, a flaming Harrison whig, devoted soul and body to Daniel Webster, and shaping all his opinions to the pattern held up before him by Webster. He was then also a great admirer of me, and expected perhaps some aid to obtain a place which might be suitable for him— He commenced reporter and Letter-writer for sundry Northern whig Newspapers, and has adhered faithfully to Webster through all the events; vicissitudes of men and things—and disappointments of the late years— He clings faithfully too to Caleb Cushing, and insists that if he would offer himself as a Candidate for election in the third district he would be elected by a large majority.— Mr Samuel Crepps of Fayette County Pennsylvania came and had some conversation with me— I received a Letter from Seth M. Gates explaining the address to the People of the free States against the annexation of Texas— Mr Seaton sent me also a manuscript sent to him for publication in the Intelligencer by Mr Horace Everett, but without signature, on the controversy concerning the right of search— Mr Everett requested it might be perused by me before publication, and in the piece itself there is a call rather earnest upon me, without naming me to give to the public my opinions on the subject. I called at the Intelligencer Office, and returned to Mr Seaton, Everett’s manuscript, and gave him also the Liberty Press extra sent to me by Mr Gates, and requested him to publish in the Intelligencer, the joint address to the people of the free States against the annexation of Texas; which he promised— I could not reach the Department of State this day— It was on the 15th. of July 1832 that Butler delivered to Alaman the paper of proposals for the purchase of Texas, of which he never transmitted any copy to his own Government— Within a week after Alaman was removed from Office, and a revolution took place in the Government of Mexico—on the 25th. of July 1832 Butler addressed a note to Monasterio, chief Clerk in the Mexican Department of foreign Affairs, announcing that President Jackson had proclaimed the Treaty of limits as the law of the Land and was ready to appoint a Commissioner on the part of the U.S. to run jointly the boundary line with a Mexican Commissioner but that he thought a revisal and new line of boundary was very desirable. Mary, and her daughter and Hull went to the Missouri Steamer Ball, and came home at 2 in the morning—

20. VI. Thursday.  Peach blossoms.  Coll. Croghan called on me this morning to borrow 250 dollars of his want of which I had no reason to doubt; but which I had not the means to supply; subsisting as I do with my family on the annual payment for my dwelling house sold to Morsell part of my real Estate, which I cannot reinvest but must consume in my current household expenses— I declined therefore with suitable civility. Going to the Department of State, I met Mr Caleb Cushing, who has returned here, after a short visit to his late constituents— Before he went he gave out that he would offer himself as a candidate for re-election—but after he got home his heart failed him, and he requested his friends not to put him in nomination— But he still considers himself a public man, and though thrice rejected by the Senate on the nomination for Secretary of the Treasury; he evidently still relies upon the fixed fact as the open Sesame, to the precious vaults. He told me, he expected to remain here about ten days.— Mr Webster returned from his short visit to Marshfield last evening. At the Department, Mr Hunter gave me to read a late despatch from Mr Picket Chargé d’Affaires at Lima in Peru, written in September last, communicating the fact of Captain Jones’s departure from Lima, and of his intention to take San Francisco if Mexico and U.S should prove to be at War or if it should burn out as was rumoured that Mexico had ceded California to Great-Britain. All which Mr Picket approves— Another Letter from Allen A. Hall, written last December at Caraccas mentions the arrival there of a Mexican Commissioner bound to Lima in Peru where a Congress of South Americans were convening, said to be to form a league of defence against the grasping designs of the United States upon Mexico— Hall is Chargé d’Affaires of the United States to the Republic of Venezuela—and thinks this league against our usurpations very ridiculous— He says it is not at all approved in Venezuela and they certainly will not seen a Commissioner to the Assembly. Lieutenant Hunter came and said he was ordered with his Steamer Union to Norfolk and must go on Saturday. He invited me to visit her at 4 O’Clock this afternoon, which I did, with Isaac Hull— We rode down to the Arsenal. Lieutenant Hunter came in the Steamer’s barge, and took us to her, in the channel at the mouth of the Eastern Branch. We spent about an hour on board and inspected her organization, arrangements and machinery. Lieutenant Hunter then landed us in the same boat and we got home before Sunset.

21. V:30. Friday.  Vernal vegetation.  I received this morning, under cover from my son at Boston, to whom it was addressed for me a Letter from Edward Everett, in London, answering mine to him of 13. March on the 40th. day from that on which it was written— My Letter was acceptable to him—but whether available is left for after consideration— He sends me a printed copy of his answer to Mr Schofield and the American Bond-holders— Mrs Wirt, with her daughter Mrs Randall and her infant boy were here this morning— Mr and Mrs Campbell dined and spent the Evening with us— Mrs Campbell was Mary daughter of Charles Harrod of New-Orleans— Campbell was here and left the city on theof January last—since which he has been to New Orleans—married her, and brought her back thus far.— Our evening visitors came from various social impulses— Mr Hawley to explain and reconcile me to a total evisceration of the pews and reorganization of them to raise money for paying off the debt of the church, excellently well calculated to aggravate it— At the Department of State, I crept along with the pace of snail in the examination of Anthony Butler’s correspondence— In 1833 Santa Anna broke up the federal Constitution, and with the aid of his bayonets was elected President. Mr Butler is consulted by persons whom he does not name to know if the Government or capitalists in the United States will make a loan to Mexico, he says not for how much— He advises to turn it into a bargain for the sale of Texas, or a loan upon mortgage which they will certainly never redeem.— He addresses this in a private Letter to Jackson, who instrucks Livingston to reject at once the loan, and to write forthwith to Butler, to bring his negotiation to a close; for that on the 1st. of April the American Colonists in Coahuila; are to hold a convention and declare their Independence,—after which he says it will be useless to treat with Mexico for Texas— Livingston instructs Butler accordingly, but Butler hangs on— This precise knowledge of Jackson to a day of the intended design of the Colonists to declare their independence as early as April 1833. was suppressed in the document communicated to the House in 1833— I walked before dinner. left my watch chain at Keyworth’s to be repaired; and examined at Taylor’s a new invented inkstand—a humbug.

22. V:15. Saturday.  Mr D. D. Barnard of Albany was here yesterday with his father in Law, Mr Stevenson; but I was out and did not see them— They have been since the close of the Session of Congress to Savannah in Georgia and Mr Barnard is quite delighted with his tour.— My address to my constituents absorbs three fourths of my time—and I have reached three fourths of a two hours address, and have yet scarcely entered upon my subject. I should have laid out for an address of three hours, and even then my stream would have overflow’d its banks— It spreads and widens before me, though I am constantly labouring to dam it in— It is much the same with Anthony Butler’s Negotiation for Texas— For six long years he was mistifying Jackson with the positive assurance that he was within a hairs breadth of the object and sure of success, while Jackson was all the time wriggling along and snapping at the bait like a mackrel after a red rag, and there is not one line to show that Butler ever made to any one in Mexico the specific proposal that he was instructed to make, at first; or the enormous stride upon it, authorised by Forsyth’s Letter of 6. August 1835— The most impressive conclusion that I draw from the comparison between the manuscript and the printed documents is the unscrupulous suppression, upon a call from the house for all the correspondence at a crisis when the President had actually asked of Congress authority to wage war, of every scrap of paper, which it did not suit to make public— It proves how utterly inefficient, the reservation of the power of declaring War, to Congress is, as a check upon the will of the President to wage it—is— My progress in examining Butler’s correspondence at the Department of State is so slow that I shall be obliged to break it up without getting half through— The Steamer Britannia which brought Edward Everett’s answer to my letter of 13 March, brought also the reports of a long and searching debate in the British Parliament upon the Ashburton Treaty—terminated after a pitched battle between Lord Palmerston and Sir Robert Peel, by the failure of a Quorum in the house That historical blunderhead Jared Sparks had made serious mischief by one of his spurious discoveries, of latent correspondence and a map countenancing the British claim of boundary; but the production of Mr Jay’s map at New-York and simultaneously of Mr Oswald’s map at London have prostrated that vile imposture— I walked out towards evening to seek Mr D. L. Childs’s lodgings, and was overtaken by a shower— Met Mr M. Poor at his door in 6th. Street: He lent me his umbrella, which sheltered me from the rain while returning home— Mr and Mrs Campbell dined with us.

23. V.30. Sunday.  At the second Presbyterian Church Mr M’Carer preached, taking for his text the whole first Psalm—[“]1. Blessed is the man that walketh not in the counsel of the ungodly, nor standeth in the way of sinners, nor sitteth in the seat of the scornful: 2. But his delight is in the Law of the Lord; and in his laws, doth he meditate day and night. 3. And he shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season: his leaf also shall not wither: and whatsoever he doeth shall prosper. 4. The ungodly are not so: but are like the chaff which the wind driveth away 5. Therefore the ungodly shall not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the congregation of the righteous. 6. For the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous: but the way of the ungodly shall perish.”— The preacher first observed the peculiar appropriateness of this Psalm as introductory to the whole collection— That it was commencing with a contrasted portraiture of the characters and destination of the righteous man and the Sinner. He said there were various opinions with regard to the author of this Psalm.— It might perhaps have been David; but it was more generally believed by the learned in biblical Literature to be the production of Ezra, the Priest, who formed the collection of the canonical books after the return from the Babylonian captivity— The style of the Book of Ezra, and that of this Psalm have it would seem to me no congeniality to indicate the same hand.— The Psalm is sublime poetry. The narrative of Ezra is rather beneath the elevation of historic prose.—but Mr M’Carer said that by whomsoever composed it was dictated by divine inspiration— The beauties of the imagery, the tree by the riverside, and the chaff driven before the wind form beautiful pictures of the Oriental pencil— And the Sermon closed with a warm exhortation to the auditory so to order their ways as to be like the trees by the side of the rivers— Mr and Mrs Campbell dined and spent the Evening with us— And while we were at dinner a very heavy thunder gust came over us, an incident which reminded us, that according to the Miller prophesies this was the day for the final conflagration of the world— At St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the first Sunday after Easter and preached from John 3.17. “For God sent not his Son into the world, to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved.”— Cutts’s and Walter Hellen here—

24. V.30. Monday.  Universal blossoming.—  Mr and Mrs Campbell went off this morning by the Baltimore Cars for Philadelphia. Dr Heap entered the service in 1804. as a surgeon in the Navy, continued in that station till after the close of the last War with Great-Britain when he was appointed Consul at Tunis; where he remained till the change of administration brought in General Harrison— Captain Tyler seems to have determined, from the moment of his accession to cast off the Heap, and without consulting him he was displaced from his consulate, which was given to W. B. Hodgson, and Heap as if in mockery was appointed Dragoman of Commodore Porter at Constantinople— When he reached Constantinople he found that Porter was a wreck to whom no dragoman could be of any use, and besides had a dragoman of his own—his nephew—and Heap was soon after displaced there too.
