He came home and is now with a large family; without employment and without subsistence. He left a quire of papers with me to read, and promised to call again to-morrow— Mr Whipple from St. John, New Brunswick, is the gentleman who was so obliging and attentive to us, when in September 1840 we were there— He comes now to solicit the appointment of Consul of the United States in that City, and wished a commendation from me to Mr. Webster— I called at the Department of State and saw him, and told him the answer that I had received from Edward Everett to my Letter of 13. March— I spoke of the recent debates in Parliament on the Ashburton Treaty, terminating in the house of Commons, by the Speaker’s adjourning the house for lack of a Quorum— I spoke of the lucky discovery of Mr Oswald’s map together with that of Mr Jay at New-York, and of their blowing up Jared Sparks’s impostures in mousing among the papers of that old juggler Vergennes.— Mr Webster lent me some Morning Chronicle containing reports of the debate in the Commons—and a despatch and a confidential Letter from Edward Everett about the maps, the debate and that gibbet-bird United States Geologist Featherstonhaugh. I spoke to Mr Webster about Whipple, but he said they had had his application before them these six months and last week had appointed a Mr Anderson of Maine, recommended by Mr Evans Consul at St. John. I spoke of Heap, but he said John Howard Payne had been appointed Consul at Tunis and he thought there was no occasion for any consul at Tunis; and that the Office ought to be abolished— I said I hoped the case of Mr Heap would be considered separately from that of the usefulness of the Consulate— I called to see Mr Burnell, still confined to his chamber.— Genl. Almonte was here when I was out—and Fendall in the Evening.

25. V. Tuesday.  Dr Heap was here again this morning; very anxious about the prospect of his obtaining some appointment for subsistence in his old age— He has been shabbily treated—removed from his quiet sinecure at Tunis, to make way for W. B. Hodgson, and appointed Dragoman at Constantinople—that is translator from and to the Turkish Language, of which he never unstood one single word; still he went to Constantinople with his family, and at Malta on his way learnt that he was superseded, and a young man a nephew of Commodore was appointed in his place.— He came home leaving his family at Constantinople, and now must go again to fetch them thence. I told him I had spoken of him and recommended his case to Mr Webster, though I knew not with what success— He said Mr Webster had received him with coldness and Mr Tyler with much more and upon his representing the unceremonious manner in which he had been displaced from his office at Tunis, Mr Tyler in a tone of fretful uneasiness had said I cannot remove my friend—Payne—meaning John Howard Payne, the histrionic parasite, who was here all the summer of 1841. currying favour by writing niminy piminy, meretricious letters of courtly adulation of John Tyler to be published in the New-York Herald.— This was the sycophant and this the service for which my friend Mr Payne was appointed Consul at Tunis instead of an old public servant of forty years with a large family to linger about the world for a beggarly subsistence— After drudging all the morning upon the sickening task of my proposed address, I staggered to the Department of State and enquired of Mr Derrick for several notes of remonstance of the former French Minister Pontois. He gave me to read three of his Letters to the Secretary of State in 1837.38.39. and of Forsyth’s answers to them— With the last of which there was a list of all the Laws in the Slave-holding States, proscriptive of free coloured mariners— I asked Mr Derrick for a copy of this List which he promised to have made out and to give me to-morrow— Returned to the chronology of Anthony Butler’s negotiation for Texas—my progress exceedingly slow.— I took no morning walk, but sallied out just before the Evening twilight Walk with extreme pain, and feet excessively sore— Richard D. Cutts was here a few minutes, and David L. Child till near One O’Clock of the Morning— He is publishing a pamphlet on Mexico—

26. V.30. Wednesday  The pressure upon my brain to conclude the address to my Constituents, before I depart to return home continues with increasing gravity; and the day is now at hand when I must depart from the performance of a different and yet more arduous task. I have concluded to go home next Tuesday, and wrote accordingly to Mr Richard Rush who has insisted on a visit from me at Sydenham on my way home— I wrote also to my son, enclosing a Letter from Ellis Gray Loring about stock in the United States Hotel company, and notifying him that he may expect me at Boston next Wednesday or Thursday. Dr Heap called on me again this morning anxiously hoping for some cheering news from me. I could give him nothing but some cold vague indefinite promise to remember him from Mr Webster— He was specially desirous of being re instated in his office of Surgeon in the Navy, and solicitous for my opinion whether he might hope to obtain it— The chance is a caprice of Captain Tyler, who I suspect has a grudge against Heap for having been too much delighted with the Bey’s abolition of Slavery Mr Heap said he must go in two or three days to embark for Constantinople to fetch his family home— At the Department of State, Mr Derrick gave me the list of unconstitutional State Laws against free coloured Seamen— I copied Jackson’s endorsement upon Anthony Butlers project of purchasing Texas, with a bribe of half a million of dollars to the Confessor of Santa-Anna’s sister— Jackson seems to have seen that this might be a bait thrown out by Santa Anna himself to get into his hands to impute offers of corruption by Jackson— There is colour for this suspicion from the fact that Hamilton the Texian diplomatist did secretly as he thought make the same identical offer of half a million, to Santa-Anna himself who immediately published the Letter and divulged the fact— I find also in Butlers correspondence also that the Mexican Minister Tornel after his return home from his mission here published a pamphlet in which he stated expressly that on his landing at New-York, the Agent of Coll. Thomas Benton came twice to him with numberless other speculators, to treat with him for Texian Lands.— In my walk this afternoon I stop’d to see Mr Burnell who thinks himself convalescent, but I fear is not. We had evening visits from Captain Newton of the Steamer Missouri, and Dr Buck, commander at the arsenal—

27. V:45 Thursday  Dr Buck who called upon me last Evening gave me to read a Letter from John S. Barbour heretofore a member of Congress from Virginia to a young man named Francis Hume, now a barkeeper at Gadsby’s hotel, but who has some claim to a large Estate in England, by a supposed collateral consanguinity with David Hume the historian, and descent from an Earl of Marchmont, in which Letter Mr Barbour advises the young man to consult me, and take my advice, and he requested leave to send Mr Hume to me this morning, to which I very cheerfully agreed— He came accordingly and asked my advice, but knew absolutely nothing about the nature or justice of his own claim— He said that a Mr Jeremiah Morton a lawyer of Virginia had been to England in pursuit of this claim in 1825, and had had made of it a suit in chancery, and that was all he knew about it, and he understood there were two difficulties in the way—one, evidence to establish the genealogy; and the other the Statute of Limitations— I asked him through whom the claim of consanguinity with David Hume, and through him with the earl of Marchmont was averred— He did not know— I asked him if he had a copy of the proceedings in the Court of Chancery, when left there by Mr Morton— He had not, but he presumed Mr. Morton had— I advised him to procure the copy of those proceedings, and upon seeing them I might perhaps be enabled to advise him further— I overreached the space I had allotted to myself for the address to my Constituents, which absorbed the leisure of the morning— I then rode with Mrs John Adams and Mary Cutts to the Capitol after stopping at Keyworth’s and taking my repaired watchchain— At the Office of the Clerk of the House, I enquired for many documents but found only the Message of 28. Feby last enclosing the correspondence of the Spanish Minister Argaiz, with the Secretary of State Webster, relating to the case of the Schooner Amistad— It was referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs, but the papers were referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs, sent immediately to the Printers and the Committee never saw them— The correspondence is a fire-brand, over which Tyler casts a bucket of cold water by recommending to congress to refund the salvage claimed by Lieutt Gedney: but Gedney’s claim supposes that the Schooner was Spanish property when taken by him— It was the property of the Mendi captors and ought to have been restored to them— When will the whole truth be told concerning this case?— If I dare to tell it—I shall be arrested before I have proceeded 3 steps on the way—perhaps charged with treason—perhaps expelled from the house— Mr Child was here this Evening.

28— IV.30. Friday.  I finished at last the address to my constituents, and am so much dissatisfied with it, that I very much doubt whether I shall ever make any use of it— There is not more than one fourth part of the matter that should be included in it— There should be unity of purpose, symmetry of parts, concentration of argument, sharpness of conclusion, and impulse to action, in such a discourse. Of all this there is a lamentable deficiency in my address.— If I had time, perseverance and energy to write four such; and then methodize and abridge the four into one, it might be of some use. But I have neither time—nor strength—nor health—nor Spirits—nor manhood—to go through that process— I must now turn my thoughts and my remnant of my life to other objects— I am engaged to deliver a discourse to the historical Society of Massachusetts, on the 29th. of next month, on the New England confederation of the 17th. century—half bound to address the Society of Alumni of Harvard University, the last week in August next—and invited by a Letter received yesterday from Peter S. Du Ponceau, Thomas Sergeant, William B. Reed, W. Duck and A Langdon Elwyn, a Committee of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, to deliver a Historical Discourse before that institution at any time during the present year that may be agreeable to me— In the decay of body and mind growing upon me with inexorable speed I lack Resolution to say No! to all these propositions, and to retire from the world of business to that of repose— Mr Frye was here this morning and I had much conversation with him with respect to his management of my concerns of property in this City. I ought and intended to have settled them up to the present time since the close of this last Session of Congress—but it has been neglected— I requested of him however; and he promised me a statement of his accounts shewing his receipts and expenses on my account— He explained to me also the project for reorganizing Saint John’s Church, which led me to the determination to relinquish my pew in it. I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer and saw Mr Gales of whom I enquired concerning the address to the People of the Free States signed by me, and 12 other members of the late house, which I gave some time since to Mr Seaton to publish, as he promised— Gales said he did not know that Seaton had promised to publish it— I said if they did not publish it I wished the paper might be returned to me— Mr Childs was twice here. Going to morrow, under a threat of prosecution from Greenhow. Miss Cutts took tea, and spent the evening here.

29. V. Saturday.  Summer heat— Lassitude and 76.  I walked out this morning to the meeting of the Pennsylvania and Louisiana avenues, and sat to Mr West for two Daguerrotype likenesses; one of which he took for David L. Child, and one for himself— I did not see either of them, nor do I feel any curiosity to see them— They are resemblances too close to the reality and yet too shadowy to be agreeable— I had once before been painted by Mr Charles in the same chamber— Childs left the City this morning— Not without danger of being Lynched I hear for his pamphlet on the Texan Revolution— The pamphlet smacks of abolition— I received at the Bank of Washington the Quarter’s interest of 1. April—on 3500 on Washington Corporation 6 per Cents 52.50 and 48.75. The 1. Jany interest on 3250 of the Stock, which I left for the payment of household expenses— For the quarter due 1. Jany. I was obliged to get an order from the Register’s Office at the City Hall— I came home overpowered by the Summer heat, and rested for the remainder of the day.— Mr T. B. Johnson has been very unwell for the last three or four days. My wife was with him great part of the day yesterday, and with Mary this afternoon and evening— Mary Louisa’s Music Master was here to give a lesson in singing, and I had a visit from Mr M’Carer the minister who at present supplies the pulpit of the second presbyterian church— He reminded me that Mr John Campbell had introduced him to me about two years ago in the house of which I have no recollection— He said he had resided some years in South-Carolina— He thought it very doubtful whether Dr. Ely would accept the invitation of this church to settle with them as their Pastor, though I have no doubt he took no small pains to obtain the invitation— The Doctor is an able theologian; but has the reputation well earned of being a worldly minded man Mr M’Carer professe to be and I have no doubt is liberal in principle; and he lamented the divisions between the old and new schools of the Presbyterian church— I began my preparation for departure with the attempt to assort and endorse my files of Letters—at all times a heavy labour, but more and more aggravated every time I pass between this city and my home.— The work is always imperfectly done, and in assorting the files I find many Letters which ought long since to have been answered, which ought to be answered now, but which for want of time I could not answer when received, cannot answer now, and never shall find time to answer. A deep mortification—

30. V:30. Sunday.  Heard Mr M’Carer this morning at the second Presbyterian Church, from Hosea 6.1. [“]Come and let us return unto the Lord; for he hath torn and he will heal us: he hath smitten and he will bind us up.”— Upon this text the preacher gave a summary account of the Assyrian captivity which he considered as it is represented in the Scriptures, as a judgment of Heaven upon the sins of the People— And this is the remarkable characteristic of all the scriptural history of the old Testament— The creation of one pair of human beings from whom all mankind are descended is the foundation of the doctrine of human rights— The forfeiture of Paradise for disobedience to the will of God is a second moral principle teeming with a multitude of principles.— The Destruction of the whole human race by a flood with the exception of one family still exhibits the same feature— The vocation of Abraham—the assignment of the land of Canaan to his descendants, and all their adventures in it from the crossing of the Jordan by Joshua to the Assyrian and Babylonian captivities, all the prosperous events are attributed to the favour of Jehovah propitiated by repentance for their sins, and obedience to his will, and all their calamities and disasters as punishment for their transgressions and breaches of their covenants with him— The Sin the most severely reproved, and yet that to which they were most addicted was idolatry— Jehovah is declared in the dialogue to be a jealous God visiting the iniquities the fathers upon the children to the third and fourth generation; and the most aggravated reproaches are cast upon those who bow the knee to Baal, or pass their children through the fire to Moloch— This exhortation of Hosea to the Israelites was addressed to them in the time of the Assyrian captivity, and the tenor of the whole book is to call on the people to return to the God of their allegiance, with a promise of his favour in reward for their repentance. Mr M’Carer made the applica of instructions to his hearers with some allusion as it seemed to me with his yesterday’s conversation with me. He deplored the calamitous condition of the Church, but admonished his auditory that it is as owing to their own sins before God, and that if they would return to him he would return to them— After dinner Mr Hawley read evening prayers for the second Sunday after Easter, and preached but I could not gather from what text— After church I visited Mr Thomas B. Johnson, had half an hour’s conversation with him and took leave of him. Evening busy in preparing for departure—

1. VI. Monday  The last day before departure  Always busy, agitating, anxious, and as years advance every time it happens more confusing than the last— As I am this time to travel alone I concluded to take with me but one trunk and an umbrella— Hesitating about the last article, so often needed for shelter from rain or sun; but so liable to be lost, stolen or broken by the way, that about twice out of three times mine is missing at my journey’s end— This days occupation with aid of my wife and nephew was packing up my chest of books and pamphlets and my files of Letters for the last two years to be shipped by the first coaster to Boston, and my strong trunk to be taken with me— Mr Heap called on me this morning, and I returned him his papers, but partly read: He told me he was going by the Cars to-morrow morning, without prospect of any further public employment, and equally unwilling to seek and hopeless to obtain further personal access to President Tyler or Secretary Webster— I received a note from Mr Page the Daguerrotype artist requesting me to call again this day as he was not satisfied with the shades taken on Saturday— I did call accordingly twice, and he took my similitude twice but neither time with much success. At one time he and Mr West took two impressions of me at one sitting, upon two camera obscura’s standing side by side, and shewing the face as by two different angles of refraction. I stop’d at Keyworth’s and took my old silver sleeve buttons relinked after fifteen years of wear— I paid my last visit to Mr Burnell with whom I found as usual his faithful wife and Nurse— They think him convalescent and I hope he is so— While I was there Mr George Brown came in; going to-morrow to Norfolk, Virginia to embark in the Vandalia Sloop of War to be landed at Chagres thence to traverse by land the Isthmus to Panama, and thence to proceed in some vessel of our Pacific Squadron to the seat of his mission to the Hawaÿan Islands. I walked on to the Capitol and there received from Mr Burche, the last sheet of the House journal of the recent Session, and from young Cutts two or three other Documents; but neither the Senate Journal of the last Session; nor the collective house documents of the preceding Session the 2d. of the 27th. Congress were ready for distribution— After dinner Mr Hawley Rector of St. John’s Church called to take leave of me, and enquired if I should incline to rent a pew in the renovated Church having concluded to relinquish that which I now hold. I said I should. Mr Frye came, and gave me a statement of his accounts with me, and Mr Morsell made me an offer of 100 dollars for the lot adjoining the house I sold to him— In both these cases, I procrastinated settlement most neglectfully— Richard D. Cutts and his Sister came and took leave— Up till midnight.

2— IV.30. Tuesday  At 6. O’Clock this morning I left the City of Washington in the train of Cars for Baltimore— My nephew Isaac Hull Adams accompanied me to the Railway depot; remaining here to come on with my wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa in June. At the Cars I met Mr Heap who came on only as far as Baltimore Captain Williams of the army. Mr Newhall of Lynn, and sundry others who claimed I have no doubt justly, old acquaintance, but whom I do not even now recollect— The morning was clear and fine but cold and there was a white-frost on the ground till we had passed beyond Bladensburg— We reached Baltimore, about a quarter past 8.—and alighting from the Cars, walked immediately to the Steam boat wharf and step’d on board the Steamer Constitution, Captain Chaytor. I think it was over 6. years since I had seen him, and his skin hung about him like an old lady’s loose gown— I asked him if he had been sick—he said no—he was drying up— He had within the last four years, dried off sixty pounds of flesh and I have no doubt he weighs that much less than he did the last time I made a passage in his boat— I scarcely ever saw such a change; and his face looks like a wet cloth ill laid up. In the steamer I saw for a moment the Secretary of the U.S. Senate Asbury Dickens, but he was about to return to Washington; Mr Russell of the interior of the State of New-York; a member of two or three Congresses including the 26th. now returning home from Washington, where he told me he saw yesterday Mr Webster at the Department of State—and he told him he intended to retire from the Department within ten days. Mr Sanderson the first publisher of the biography of the signers of the declaration of Independence; a work of which the first expense was very heavy upon him, and which he was upwards of 5 years in getting through, but of which he afterwards sold the property and the plates, and of which more than twenty Editions have now been published, and the plates have been four times renewed. The last edition is in one octavo volume— Sanderson, said he now kept a public house, in Chesnut Street Philadelphia—the Franklin house, where he would be glad to see me— There was also in the boat Captain Payne of the Navy and his Sister—and a Mr Fessenden, who said he lived at Jamaica Plains, and was now a constituent of mine— We reached French-town at half past 1. then came in the railway cars in 50 minutes to Newcastle, and thence in the Steamer Robert Morris to Philadelphia—at half past 4. I took chamber N. 16. at Jones’s Union Hotel Chesnut Street— In a quarter of an hour more in Mr Richard Rush’s carriage, with his Son Benjamin, I came out to Sydenham, his residence, dined with him and a party of his friends, and agreed at his kind and hospitable invitation to pass the Night here— I retired soon after 11. O’Clock.

2— IV.30. Tuesday  At 6. O’Clock this morning I left the City of Washington in the train of Cars for Baltimore— My nephew Isaac Hull Adams accompanied me to the Railway depot; remaining here to come on with my wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa in June. O’Clock.

3. V. Wednesday  After a good night’s rest I rose at five, and having with me this Diary, a steel pen and my small tin-boxed inkstand, wrote the journal of May-day— I then breakfasted with Mr and Mrs. Rush and their two daughters, I suppose about 20 and 18 years old— Their three sons Benjamin, Samuel and Murray were at the dinner last evening, but neither of them at breakfast this morning— Of the company at dinner yesterday were Mr James Smith Wilcocks, Dr Chapman, Mr Petre, the English Consul, Mr White a son of the late Bishop, a Dr Mitchell, a young man named Chew, and one or two others, strangers to me— Mr Wilcocks invited me to dine with him this day; and Mr Rush urged me so cordially to stay and pass the night at his house that I consented,—and accepted Mr Wilcocks’s invitation to dine with him this day. After breakfast, Mr Rush took me in his Carriage and landed me at the door of the Bank of North America in Philadelphia, where I received in Bills of that bank 120 dollars for 4 coupons of 30 dollars each, a half year’s interest on 4. Cincinnati city bonds. Mr Rush then left me, and I went in search of Mr George Rundle Treasurer of the Schuykill permanent Bridge Company. Two or three years since the Legislature of the State nullified the Charter of that company and made the bridge free; a sample of democratic pillage of property just like that of the Legislature of Massachusetts with Charles river Bridge— So Sovereigns, Monarchical or popular always will deal with corporation property— The dividends now made are only the proceeds of sales of the Company’s property— The Legislature gave them the alternative of having another bridge built close at the side of their own, or of surrendering their charter for a compensation of about 75 per cent of the par value of their stock which was at 30 per cent advance in the market, that is they gave them about half the value of their stock, as a consideration for not taking away the whole, by another parallel bridge— After long search I found Mr Rundles house in Locust Street 101. but he was at his office— Another long search for that which I found at last with the help of a young Quaker whom I met in the Street, and after all it was the old Office which I had visited at least ten times.— He paid me three dividends amounting to 96. dollars, by a check on the Philadelphia Bank— Another search for that, which I found with George W. Toland whom I met twice in the street; first with S. D. Ingham, whom I did not recognize; and afterwards withPotts— The President of the Bank J. B. Trion gave me a draft on the Globe Bank at Boston— At 1/2 past 10. Mr Rush came and took me to the house ofRidgway, to attend his funeral; that is to have my name announced as one of the mourners— I then returned to Jones’s Hotel—wrote the Journal of yesterday— Mr Rush called for me again at 1/2 past 4 visited his mother and Sister Mrs. Williams— Took up his two daughters; dined at Mr Wilcocks’s— About 10 in the Evening he took me to the door of Jones’s hotel where I took leave of him and his daughters—

3. V. Wednesday  After a good night’s rest I rose at five, and having with me this Diary, a steel pen and my small tin-boxed inkstand, wrote the journal of May-day— I then breakfasted with Mr and Mrs. Rush and their two daughters, I suppose about 20 and 18 years old— Their three sons Benjamin, Samuel and Murray were at the dinner last evening, but neither of them at breakfast this morning— Of the company at dinner yesterday were Mr James Smith Wilcocks, Dr Chapman, Mr Petre, the English Consul, Mr White a son of the late Bishop, a Dr Mitchell, a young man named Chew, and one or two others, strangers to me— Mr Wilcocks invited me to dine with him this day; and Mr Rush urged me so cordially to stay and pass the night at his house that I consented,—and accepted Mr Wilcocks’s invitation to dine with him this day. After breakfast, Mr Rush took me in his Carriage and landed me at the door of the Bank of North America in Philadelphia, where I received in Bills of that bank 120 dollars for 4 coupons of 30 dollars each, a half year’s interest on 4. Cincinnati city bonds. Mr Rush then left me, and I went in search of Mr George Rundle Treasurer of the Schuykill permanent Bridge Company. Two or three years since the Legislature of the State nullified the Charter of that company and made the bridge free; a sample of democratic pillage of property just like that of the Legislature of Massachusetts with Charles river Bridge— So Sovereigns, Monarchical or popular always will deal with corporation property— The dividends now made are only the proceeds of sales of the Company’s property— The Legislature gave them the alternative of having another bridge built close at the side of their own, or of surrendering their charter for a compensation of about 75 per cent of the par value of their stock which was at 30 per cent advance in the market, that is they gave them about half the value of their stock, as a consideration for not taking away the whole, by another parallel bridge— After long search I found Mr Rundles house in Locust Street 101. but he was at his office— Another long search for that which I found at last with the help of a young Quaker whom I met in the Street, and after all it was the old Office which I had visited at least ten times.— He paid me three dividends amounting to 96. dollars, by a check on the Philadelphia Bank— Another search for that, which I found with George W. Toland whom I met twice in the street; first with S. D. Ingham, whom I did not recognize; and afterwards withPotts— The President of the Bank J. B. Trion gave me a draft on the Globe Bank at Boston— At 1/2 past 10. Mr Rush came and took me to the house ofRidgway, to attend his funeral; that is to have my name announced as one of the mourners— I then returned to Jones’s Hotel—wrote the Journal of yesterday— Mr Rush called for me again at 1/2 past 4 visited his mother and Sister Mrs. Williams— Took up his two daughters; dined at Mr Wilcocks’s— About 10 in the Evening he took me to the door of Jones’s hotel where I took leave of him and his daughters—

properties.dateline: Philadelphia Thursday 4. May 1843. New-York— Steamer Cleopatra.
properties.text: 4. V. Thursday.  There are two lines of daily conveyance— One, departing at 7. in the morning, which after crossing the river to Camden proceeds to Amboy by the Railway to Amboy, and thence in a Steamboat to New-York—arriving there between 2 and 3 O’Clock P.M. The other, crossing the river at 9. and proceeding by the Railway to the Ferry at Powle’s hook, or Jersey city, and arriving at New-York between 3 and 4 P.M— I had determined to take the early line, and for that purpose rose at 5. and wrote till past 6. then breakfasted alone; but being visited while at breakfast by an old ex member of Congress whose name I did not remember was delayed till I had scanty time to reach the wharf— My trunk carried in a hand cart by a man from the hotel but I missed my way, and going first to the chesnut Street and thence to the market street wharf, finally returning to the true walnut street wharf saw the ferry-boat move off from it and lost my passage to Camden— The carrier from Jones’s had just turned round with his cart and was taking my trunk back to the hotel, when by a short race I overtook him, and made him lodge my trunk in the corner room where the ticket office is kept, and it being a public house, engaged a chamber till the next boat should go. had my trunk taken up in the chamber; and there finished writing the journal of yesterday.— I thus avoided the ennui and waste of two lost hours of time and how many such hours I might have saved had I throughout my life resorted to similar expedients— Nine O’Clock came and I had lost no time, and made no arrears of journal— Crossing the river to Camden I met Mr Furness the Unitarian Minister escorting two of his nieces named Osborne, who were returning from a visit of some weeks to him, to their home in Connecticut—he introduced them to me, and recommended them to my attentions.— He left them seated in the Cars, and I took a seat near them. I met too in the boat a man by the name of Bradshaw a native of Massachusetts, who claimed old acquaintance with me, and charged me with having forgotten him, which was true, but which I promised him, should not happen again— In the Cars also there was Mrs. Whitney, wife of one of my neighbours going home from a visit to her daughter— The cars rolled steadyly and smoothly on to the ferry boat at Jersey city, on crossing which to New-York, a young man a brother of the two young Ladies met them and escorted them to the Steamer Cleopatra bound to Norwich, in which I also engagement? was finally to embark— My trunk had been first shipped in the Steamer Rhode Island bound to Stonington, lying on the other side of the wharf I walked round the battery and to the exchange, where I paid a visit to Lewis Tappan, who introduced to me the Revd Mr Raymond returned from the Mendian Mission.

properties.dateline: New London. Norwich. Friday 5. May 1843. Boston
properties.text: 5. I.30. Friday.  From my visit to Mr Lewis Tappan yesterday afternoon I returned to the Steamer Cleopatra, Captain Dustin at Pier N. 1. adjoining the Battery New-York— At 5. O’Clock precisely she loosened from her moorings at the same time, with the Steamer Rhode-Island from the other side of the Pier, bound to Stonington; whom we soon left astern at least a mile an hour. The two young Ladies nieces of Mr Furness on embarking had retired to the Ladies Cabin, and I saw them no more.— Mrs Whitney had concluded to rest for the Night at New York— I saw her no more; but as fellow passengers I met Mr Thomas W. Williams, a member of the last two Congresses from Connecticut, with his son, a boy about 12 years of age— A Mr Lee of Philadelphia claiming old acquaintance which I remembered not, and a Mr John G. Parker who introduced himself to me, as thankful for very great obligations which I had equally forgotten— He said he was a native of Massachusetts but had resided many years in Canada— That in 1838 he had been arrested on groundless suspicion of being actively concerned in the insurrection against the British Government and sent to England for trial. That a number of Gentlemen here had signed a representation in his favour, to Mr Fox the British Minister at Washington; which he had transmitted to his Government, and in consequence of which he Parker had been discharged— My name he said was signed among others to the representation, and he was happy to have this opportunity to thank me for the favour.— Un bienfait n est jamais perdu— How delightful it is to discover that you have rendered happy grateful hearts, by good offices, not even remembered by yourself— The weather was so fine, and the sea so smooth that the motion of the boat was scarcely perceptib while she was going at least 12 miles an hour. Supper came, which I made to answer for my dinner, and about 8. O’Clock I turned in to my berth N. 69, which the Captain had assigned to me as one of the best in the boat.— After about 5 hours of sound and quiet sleep I awoke soon after one this morning, arose, dressed, washed and was shaved, and went on the deck where I found Mr Williams just ready to land with his son at New London— He took leave of me with a kind invitation, to his house, if I should ever come there again— The sky was cloudless, and the Great and Little Bear, the Scorpion, Balance and Sagittary, the Lyre, Eagle and Dolphin all splendid overhed, but when we landed at Norwich at 1/2 past 2—it was already beclouded. We had barely time to enter the cars and be seated when they started. passed through Worcester just after 6. landed at the depot in Boston a quarter past 8 took a cab and at 1/2 past 8 was greeted by my Son at his house 57 Mount Vernon Street Boston— Wrote to my wife— Called on Mr Leavitt but he was gone to Malden— Evening visit from Mr P. C. Brooks.

6. V. Saturday.  I have accepted an invitation from the Massachusetts historical Society, to deliver on the 29th of this month a discourse before them, on the second centennial anniversary of the confederation of the New-England Colonies, and I have come here without and before my family, for the purpose of preparing it— I have paid so little attention to that portion of our history that I scarcely knew the sources at which the principal facts relating to it were to be found—nor have I any clue to the aspect in which it should be viewed for any useful purpose at the present time— Pope makes it a point of self-glorification, that not in fancy’s maze he wander’d long, but stoop’d to truth and moraliz’d his song— I believe that moral principle should be the alpha and omega, of all human composition—poetry or prose scientific or literary written or spoken—and emphatically of every discourse An Epic Poem, a Drama, Pastoral, Georgic or Fable, Ode, Sonnet or epigram should alike spring from one vital seminal principle of morals and so should every History Dissertation, Treatise, Discourse or epistle— Pen should never be put to paper, but for the discharge of some duty to God or man— How then shall I best discharge the duty which I have undertaken of discoursing to my co-associates of the historical Society, and to my fellow Citizens on the New-England Confederation of 1643? What was that confederation—its uses, its origin, its history, its termination—its influence upon the colonies, between whom it was formed; upon their relations with the Indians, with the other English Colonies, with England the mother Country, with the neighbouring Colonies of other Countries; and with the rest of mankind?—and from the result of all these enquiries what sound and useful moral principle can be deduced for the entertainment and instruction of a listening auditory, and of readers here after.— I called at the chambers of the Historical Society. The outer door was locked, with a notice that the Librarian might be found at N 15. Warren street— It was the residence of Mr Joseph B. Felt, whom I found at home where I also saw his wife. He accompanied me to the chambers of the historical Society, and found for me Mather’s Magnalia; the 2d. Volume of Hazard’s collection of State Papers, and three folio volumes of manuscripts which he supposed might assist me in my enquiries. He lent me the keys of the chambers, and promised to call and see me there on Monday. I paid a visit to Mrs Abbott Lawrence: her husband was not at home— I dined with Charles at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s. Walk after dinner. Met Degrand— Evening at home with Charles.

7. IV.15. Sunday.  Thunder and Lightening— Rain  Dr Frothingham preached this morning, from 1. Corinthians 1.18—The whole verse reads “For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness: but unto us which are saved, it is the power of God”— But the text was only “The preaching of the cross, is the power of God,” and the sermon was a most ingenious and deeply pathetic declamation upon the power of the cross, as a symbol of the sufferings of Christ, and of the doctrines of Christianity— The use of this symbol, has been of the sharpest points of controvery between the Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches.— It has been heretofore a source of much internal dissension in the episcopal church of England, and is even now revived with ominous agitation both in England and here— It extends even beyond the bounds of the episcopal church, and I was somewhat surprised at the vivacity and zeal with which Dr Frothingham seems to have entered into it— Certain it is that the writings of St. Paul, from which the Dr cited several most impressive passages, countenance a reverence for the cross, which endangers the indulgence of idolatry, as all substitution of attachment to the symbol for the love of the object represented, is prone to do— Of these trappings of Roman Catholic worship the Church of England has discarded many and retained more than enough— She has retained the sign of the cross only in the administration of the rite of baptism, where it is made by the finger of the priest over the forehead of the infant, leaving no trace of it behind— But there is at this very moment a bitter struggle in the episcopal church of England to return to the emblematic worship of popery— There was a passage at the close of the Doctor’s discourse, which alluded without censure to the Roman Catholic worship of the virgin mother of Christ, which belongs to the same School of the adoration of the cross— After the morning service, Dr Frothingham administered the communion with admirable and affecting solemnity— I came home through a shower of heavy thunder and sharp Lightening with a mere sprinkling of rain— After dinner Dr Frothinghams text was from the words “whose seed was in itself” from Genesis 1.11. The discourse as usual; ingenious, fanciful, and copious of analogies with a touch of gentle interrogation, as to the value or efficiency of religious missions to distant foreign lands— After church I had a visit from Mr Abbott Lawrence, who invited me to dine with him on Tuesday. Miss Harriet Welsh took tea here— And with Charles and his wife I spent the Evening at Mr P. C. Brooks’s.

8. IV:45 Monday.  On awaking this morning I found my sore throat, hoarseness and catarrh returned upon me in all its severity, and in sitting down to write my hand shaking so that it was with extreme difficulty that I could hold my pen; yet my only labour under the sun is writing, as I have little time to spare in preparation for the 29th. I devoted all the early morning to Hazard’s collection of the records of the United Colonies of New-England— They extend from the 19th. of May 1643 to the 24th of March 1678—35 years—including the Colonies of Massachusetts, Plymouth, Connecticut and New-Haven. Rhode Island applied for admission to the confederacy but was refused. During its continuance New-Haven was merged into the Colony of Connecticut; after which the Confederate Colonies were but 3.— From the beginning there were only two Commissioners for each Colony; at first annually chosen, for yearly meetings; but of later time meeting only once in three years— The records occupy three fourths of a large quarto volume; but as I have to consult many other sources of information, I skimmed over the whole surface of this compilation, and could of course pry deep into nothing— Yet the morning was gone, and I had yesterday’s journal yet to write; which I nevertheless did accomplish— I then sallied forth and at N. 220. Washington Street found my old shaver of last fall, by the name of Cadmus, after passing through whose hands, I went to the Emancipator Office, and had a long conversation with Mr Leavitt— He is to embark next Tuesday in the Steamer for Liverpool, to attend as a delegate from the American, Anti-Slavery Society the second triennial meeting of the World’s convention, for the promotion of the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade throughout the Earth— I urged him very earnestly to observe with unremitting care the movements of the British Government with regard to Mexico and Texas— I told him I distrusted them altogether— I believed their real policy far from desiring to favour the abolition of Slavery either in our Southern States, or in Texas. I suspect on the contrary, that for a suitable equivalent they will readily acquiesce both in the annexation of Texas to this Union, and to the perpetuation of Slavery here to weaken and to rule us.— Mr P. C. Brooks and his Son, dined with us at my Sons house, and I began at a perfect hazard to write my discourse.

9. V. III. V. Tuesday  The Catarhh has become feverish, and cruelly torturing— I was twice up in the Night before the time for rising came; and this whole day I have been upon the rack— I find it difficult to sustain my Spirits and have concluded to go out to Quincy next Monday— As my first and most indispensable object is to be prepared for the discourse of the 29th. I find it necessary to begin the day with writing upon it— I wrote accordingly and wasted the morning until Noontide without coming to any point upon which I can dilate, to fill up the time necessary for the delivery The confederacy of the New-England Colonies was a system of concert between the several jurisdictions, for the common defence against the French colonial establishments at the North—the Dutch at the South but especially, and above all against the Indians— Shortly before noon, I went locked myself up in the chambers of the historical Society, and searched for notices of Indian wars and the New England confederacy— I soon found abundance of materials for enquiry, and spent nearly three hours in search, rather for the sources of information than in the examination of what I found— I had no time for that— It was some time before I detected the history of the War with Philip—Sachem of Mount Hope— It forms the 7th. book of Mather’s Magnalia— This work deserves great consideration as a sample of the literary, political, moral and religious condition of the New-England colonies at that time— It is a collection of biographical anecdotes; a nauseous panegyric upon all the principal founders civil and ecclesiastical of the New England colonial settlements. With a history of Harvard College, and a narrative of Indian wars, down to the close of the 17th century— The Style is pedantic; motley coloured with perpetual allusions to the bible, and to the Hebrew, Greek, Latin and English Poets— Among the rest, I was surprised to meet a quotation from the Paradise Lost— I found also numerous articles relating to the Pequot, Mohegan, and Narragansett tribes of Indians—upon all which my discourse should have been preceded by a regular and systematic six months course of reading, for which I have less than three weeks— After 2 I came home and went and dined with Mr Abbott Lawrence. Besides his family, there were his Sister Mrs Green, Miss Leslie the painter’s Sister, and Mr Thacher of Bangor— I came home immediately after dinner, and found Mr Kinnicutt and Mr John T. Bigelow with my Son. Mr Felt came in afterwards, and I agreed to go with him at 11. to-morrow morning to the State-house.

10. I. III. IV.30. Wednesday.  A much disturbed night succeeded by an uncomfortable and unprofitable day— After a visit to Mr Cadmus the barber, I called at Mr James H. Foster’s and saw Mrs Foster and her three daughters Elizabeth, Louisa and Mary— Mr Foster was not at home, and Louisa C. Smith was gone to Medford.— Mr Felt had agreed to meet me at 11. O’Clock this morning at the Secretary’s Office in the State house— But I had misunderstood him that he would call at my Son’s house for me, and would go with me.— After waiting for him till near noon I went to the State house to the room which he formerly occupied, when employed in collecting in volumes, and indexing the records of the general Courts, and the archives of the State. But this office has been suppressed since the first of March.— He was not there and I came home. He was at the same time in the Secretary’s Office where I neglected to call and enquire for him— He was informed that I had been to the other office after him and he then came to Charles’s and accompanied me to the Secretary’s Office— I examined the volume of Records containing the proceedings of the Commissioners of the United Colonies of New-England— Mr Felt made two extracts for me; but I found little, other than what is printed in Hazard’s collections, and the manuscript writing of that age is so difficult for me to read that I shall obtain little or no assistance from these original records— One of the extracts is a vote of the general Court of 8. Septr. 1642. appointing a numerous Committee of Magistrates and deputies, to treat with any Commissioners from Plymouth, Connecticut or New-Haven [“]about the Union and concerning avoiding any danger of the Indians—and to have power to do herein what they shall find needful for common safety and peace, so as they enter not into an offensive War without order of this Court.”— So that the primary object of the Union was the common defence against the Indians— I was able to write only a few lines of my address this day; and at one O’Clock with my Son and his wife with their son John we took up Mr P. C. Brooks at his Office, and went out and dined with Mr Gorham Brooks and his wife at Medford— This day was pleasant, but with an easterly wind, and its cold bath temperature, peculiar to this region at this Season of the year— After dinner we walked round Mr P. C. Brooks’s garden, just beginning to give signs of vegetable life— The desolation of winter still heavy upon it— About Sunset we returned to the City and received notes of invitation from Mrs. Abbott Lawrence, for this Evening— We had engagements already at M Samuel D. Parker’s my Son’s next door neighbour; but I was so unwell that an excuse was sent into Mr Parker’s, and I wait for to morrow to apologize to Mrs Lawrence.

11. I. III. IV:30. Thursday  We had received cards of invitation to dine this day with Mr Francis C. Gray; but on Tuesday evening a second note came announcing that by the death of a near relative, Mr Gray would be deprived of the pleasure of receiving his friends this day— It was great relief to me being in a condition utterly unfit to meet any one in company— The night was again quite oppressive and I was twice in the course of it awaked with a racking cough— Mrs Charles finally prevailed on me to see Dr Bigelow— He came and I gave him a history of my case; which he said was the peripneumona notha, and prescribed for it, medicine, ale and a generous diet— I went with Mrs. Charles to visit Mrs Abbott Lawrence who was not at home, and Miss Leslie who was engaged.— We then parted, and I returned the visit of Mr George Tickner— He lives in a large and elegant house a life of ease and indolence, without seeming to take part in any thing that concerns this world, talking with indifference about men and things. I returned also the visits of Mr James Savage, and Mr Robert C. Winthrop, neither of whom was at home— The Revd Mr Lunt of Quincy called to see me and spoke of the very sudden decease in the course of the late winter of his aged Colleague Peter Whitney— I passed the day as with a mill-stone about my neck, working invita Minerva upon my address for the historical Society, unable even to get through with my daily task of two pages, and seeing as yet no point of departure for the discourse. hitherto I stumble one after another upon preliminary points of doubtful propriety to the occasion and more doubtful adaptation to the taste and prejudices of the day.— I find continual occasion to resort to books which I have not at hand— In discussing a confederacy of New England Colonies the subject leads to remarks upon the propriety of the name upon the special sympathies with the condition and characteristic properties of the mother Country old England and to a comparative notice of the elementary composition of the other colonies which now constitute jointly with us the North American Union. This has already brought me upon debatable ground, and upon the accursed domain of Slavery. What shall I do with it? I am upon the breakers, and know not how to draw off from them— The relations of the Colonies with the Indians also constitute another shoal which I have not yet reached but upon which I shall be in imminent danger of stranding.— I can scarcely express how in my weakened condition these thoughts weigh me down.

12. II. IV.30. Friday  I was awaked only once in the Night, by a fit of coughing, and slept again till the dawn was far advanced— I had engaged to dine with Mr P. C. Brooks and my Son, at Dr Frothingham’s but my cough was this morning so troublesome that I thought it more prudent to decline dining in company, and was excused— Mr Quincy President of Harvard University, and his eldest daughter called to visit us, and the day was assiduously, but very unsatisfactorily occupied in search reading and writing upon my task— I am still on the preliminaries of my subject—still struggling for some heart of argument, not already fagged into common-place— My first spring of thought has been to discriminate between the Colonies of New-England, and the others which constitute our present confederate Government— In commenting upon this I meet the necessity of knowing, exactly the primitive titles of the several New-England Colonies— Mr Felt has lent me a volume published at Hartford in 1836. by R. R. Hinman Secretary of the State of Connecticut, consisting of Letters from the kings and Queens of England, to the Governors of the Colony of Connecticut, with their answers from 1635. to 1749— Much of this day was consumed in turning over the leaves of this book, to trace the origin of the colony of Connecticut, which is yet left to be accomplished— I found it also necessary to examine the first Volume of Hazard’s State Papers, but had not time to look into it— After labouring till close upon one O’Clock in this alternation of reading and writing, I went to Mr Felts N. 15. Warren Street, and borrowed the keys of the historical Society’s chambers. I found Mr Felt’s dinner smoking on the table, though he had not sitten down to it. I had scarcely reached the Society’s chambers when I was obliged to return home to dinner. Charles dined at Dr Frothingham’s— After dinner I wrote the journal of yesterday— Then read the remainder of Lord Brougham’s great Speech in the British house of peers, on his motion that the thanks of this house be given to Lord Ashburton for his treaty concluded last August with Mr Webster— It must be very imperfectly reported— The National Intelligencer of last Tuesday, announces that on the preceding day Mr Daniel Webster resigned the office of Secretary of State, and that the charge of the Department ad interim was taken by the attorney General Legare— And that on the same day Caleb Cushing was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to China, in the place of Edward Everett who has declined the appointment. The reason of Mr Webster’s resignation is not explained— Dr and Mrs Frothingham spent part of the evening here.

13. IV. Saturday—  There is no abatement of my Catarrhal cough, although there is some of the symptoms of other diseases with which it is complicated— I slept last night till the crepuscular dawn, which is now about half past 3 in the morning, and then awoke under a load which the racking cough of half an hour could only lighten but not cast off— It continued through the day without sign of mollification. I wrote with heavy heart and drooping spirits the journal yesterday—and then a Letter to my wife, which I could not even enliven with fancies to please her, as a man ought always to do in writing to his wife— Dr Bigelow paid me a second visit and I gave him the diagnostics of my present condition— His advice is still, ale and good living. I had a long visit from Mr Joshua Leavitt— Long conversation with him. He is to embark next Tuesday in the Steamer Britannia, to attend the second triennial world’s convention to promote the abolition of Slavery throughout the world to be held next month in London— I urged him to make close observations, so far as he should have opportunity, to ascertain the real policy of the British Government on this subject; entertaining as I do strong doubts of a compromise between their commercial and their moral policy, much too obsequious to the cause of Slavery for real fidelity to the cause of justice and of man— I desired him to say to Arnold Buffum, and to Joseph Sturge from me, that I intended to have written to each of them by him; but am prevented by my indisposition— And I intreated him as long as he should be there to keep his eye fixed upon Texas, Mexico, California, and especially on the Island of Cuba. He intimated to me that he intended as appropriate to his character he intended to bring before the Convention for consideration certain primary principles asserting the personal rights of men as always transcending the corporate right of Sovereignty— As I was going out I met at the door Commodore and Mrs Downes coming to visit my Son and daughter— Downes told me he did not know I was in the City. After shaving I went to the chambers of the historical Society where I found neither Church’s history of Philip’s War, nor Adair’s history of the Indians which I wanted, but I did find an original edition of John Smith’s history—and a collection of Old Colony Documents recently published by Dr Alexander Young. I had but a short hour at the Rooms, and on coming home, found Lieutt. Joseph H. Adams who dined with us— Under orders for Norfolk and is to go on Monday— Visits also from Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks— He, just returned from Brattleborough Vermont, where he went to see his sick brother Horatio. Mr P. C Brooks spent the Evening here

14. III:45 Sunday.  An uncommonly beautiful day— Summer like, but for a dash of East-wind—cool without being chilly. But not the least abatement of my Catarrh. Rather a heavy aggravation. Heard Dr Frothingham this morning. From 1. Timothy 2.4. “Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth”— The universality of the Christian faith was the subject but the sense in which the words should be used was to be understood To be saved in this passage, meant evidently to be converted to Christianity, and thereby come to the knowledge of the truth— But what was meant by all? very few— All included neither the inhabitants of Africa nor of Asia, the greater or the less, nor of a great portion of the rest of the earth nor even Palestine where Christ himself was born— But all in this text referred to the various classes and conditions of men, and its object was to shew how the blessings and promises of the gospel were adapted to every age, to either sex, to every class of human kind, and in that consisted the universality of christianity whereby the knowledge of the truth is obtained— The doctrine deduced from the discourse was the obligation upon all to devote themselves to the purposes which the gospel is destined to report. There was a notice read by Dr Frothingham of a meeting to be held by the Society next Thursday for considering a plan to alter and repair the Church— Immediately after the service, I called with Mrs Charles on Mrs Edward Brooks, whom we saw with her Son and daughter— The house belongs to Edward Everett, and is that in which he lived while he was Governor of the Commonwealth. When he went to Europe, it was occupied by Sidney Brooks who with his wife has a passion for elegant furniture, and when they also embarked last November for England, they left all their splendid furniture in the house which Edward Brooks took with more costly articles of his own, and now they all constitute the joint display of the lower rooms. They are monuments of the vanity of riches— They look like a cabinet makers shop in a Sculptor’s studion, and a painter’s gallery. Crimson satin sophas and curtains, easy and rocking chairs. Statues from a Colossal Apollo Belvidere to a naked woman on her knees, modern portraits and Italian paintings— Engravings of the Transfiguration and Guido’s Aurora, with Durand’s Declaration of Independence, and Trumbull’s Bunker hill were all clustered together but well disposed by the taste of Mrs Edward Brooks— After dinner, a very young man preached from Ecclesiastes. 1.–2 “All is vanity.” Soon after that services a succession of visitors— Closed the day— Harriet Welsh. Degrand at tea— Then Mr P. C. Brooks—and Edward Brooks’s Son.

15. V.30— IV. Monday—  Mr Savage, President of the Massachusetts historical Society called and I had a long conversation with him; chiefly upon a question fit only to make a learned body ridiculous by forming a subject for divided opinions and even of controversy. That is, on the day for the ceremony.— The day of the confederation was 19. May 1643— The day chosen for the celebration is the 29th. of May because at that time the difference between the Calenders was only ten days— But the difference is now two days more, and I told Mr Savage that as the 19th. of May of old Style of the present year is the 31st. of the new Style, I thought they should take the 31st. for the celebration— But he and judge Davis, have settled the point between themselves upon principle— He argued it with me astronomically and politically with such lucid illustration, that I lost the thread of his syllogism, and finally did not understand him at all. I went to visit Dr Frothingham, who was not at home, and I called on George Bancroft. I found Robert C. Winthrop with him, and of course we talked history— They were endeavouring to ascertain the relation between Sir John Temple, Winthrops grand-father and the Grenville family—of which I was surprized to see, Winthrop apparently not at all informed— Mr Bancroft had a number of manuscript Letters, which Edward Everett has collected for him, from Burke, Fox, Champion, Dr Franklin, Arthur Lee &c written in 1774—and among the rest a copy of Thomas Hutchinson’s account of his private interview, with King George the 3d. in July 1774. on Hutchinson’s first arrival from this country— He was introduced by Lord Dartmouth, and was upwards of two hours long with the king— Much of the dialogue, was upon the detection and exposure by Dr Franklin of Hutchinson’s Letters, upon which the king said that there was not a word in them at which any just exception could be taken— Bancroft told me that from this paper and all the other disclosures to which he has obtained of the real character of Hutchinson, he had come to the same conclusion that my father did—that he was a bad man.— This afternoon I had again a long professional visit from Dr Bigelow, and a discussion upon the proper regimen and treatment of the incurable disease with which I am afflicted, and for which I believe great abstemiousness and he thinks good living the appropriate, and only appropriate palliative remedy— He still persists in his opinion, and I shall conform myself to it, as long, and as well as I can— Dr George Parkman came to see me. He did not know that I was in the city till this morning— My intercourse with him is always friendly without alloy, and nothing more— At close of day I went with Charles’s wife in to their next door neighbour’s Mr Samuel D. Parker, and saw him—his daughter—niece and two sons, the youngest of whom is a student at the University. Visit afterwards from Mr Schuyler—of New-York.

16. II. IV. Tuesday.  My catarrh gives me not the slightest encouragement to expect relief from its visitation— The weather of yesterday and this day has been unusually fine, with a bright Sun and a balmy breeze— My daughter received last Night the intelligence of the death of her brother Horatio Brooks, at Brattleborough, Vermont— His life has been unfortunate, and yet his decease is afflictive— I packed up my trunk and sent it out at Noon by the Stage to Quincy.— Then wrote my journal for yesterday—and had written one page of my address, for the anniversary day—after a call on Cadmus, I took the last turn to the chamber’s of the historical Society where I found at last Adair’s History of the Indians— I could not take it out— But I did take out a copy of the 8th. volume of the 3d. series of the publications of the Society the volume recently published, and for which I left with my Son directions to pay. Louisa C. Smith was here great part of the morning. Shortly before noon, one of the black men concerned in publishing the Emancipator, brought me a note from Mr Joshua Leavitt, taking an affectionate leave of me, and enquiring of the state of my health, being on the point of departure in the Steamer Hibernia for Liverpool to attend the Meeting of the World’s Convention— I wrote on a small scrap of paper a few words, bidding him God speed and praying for him a happy return— A man by the name of John Howard from Springfield in this Commonwealth; came and made some enquiries about the Land in Guysborough Nova-Scotia, belonging to the Estate of the late Mr Ward N. Boylston, which land Mr Howard said he was told last year, when he was there, belonged to John Quincy Adams.— I told him I had no other interest in it than as an Executor and Trustee of Mr Boylston’s last Will; and referred him for further enquiries to Mr Nathaniel Curtis; but this incident reminded me that I have yet much to do for the settlement of that estate, and probably only the season now before me for doing it— Immediately after dinner, at 1/2 past 3. my son took me in his Gig out to my own residence at Quincy, where I found John Kirk and his wife ready to receive me— I have returned once at least every year for the last 15 years, to this calm retreat from public labours and boisterous passions with extasy of delight— Now dashed with a presentiment that it may probably be for the last time, and that the most imperious of my duties now is to set my household in order, and prepare for my last change. Charles returned to Boston— I walked round my Garden, Nursery and Seminary where I found a few of my young seedling trees which will still deserve my attention— The Rev’d Mr Lunt called and spent an hour of the Evening with me— I easily found occupation till 10. O’Clock and then with a severe fit of coughing retired to bed

16. II. IV. Tuesday.  My catarrh gives me not the slightest encouragement to expect relief from its visitation— The weather of yesterday and this day has been unusually fine, with a bright Sun and a balmy breeze— My daughter received last Night the intelligence of the death of her brother Horatio Brooks, at Brattleborough, Vermont— His life has been unfortunate, and yet his decease is afflictive— I packed up my trunk and sent it out at Noon by the Stage to Quincy.— Then wrote my journal for yesterday—and had written one page of my address, for the anniversary day—after a call on Cadmus, I took the last turn to the chamber’s of the historical Society where I found at last Adair’s History of the Indians— I could not take it out— But I did take out a copy of the 8th. volume of the 3d. series of the publications of the Society the volume recently published, and for which I left with my Son directions to pay.
