O’Clock and then with a severe fit of coughing retired to bed

17. II. IV.15. Wednesday.  No Relaxation of my disease— The repose of the Night broken as it has been every night since the return of my complaint.— But I rose this morning at 4. and was on my way to see the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house; when I found half his disk above the horizon— His first ray appeared 4:37.— I wrote upon my address for the anniversary—without any satisfaction, and under a deep impression of dulness beyond all redemption— The day was fair and the weather on the whole warm—though I had a small fire made. I visited my seedling trees— For these fifteen years I have seen, every year sowing in confusion which I have often and vainly endeavoured to methodize, the seeds of many fruit and forest trees— I have been here only a part of every year, and I have never paid due scientific regard to them— I have neglected all the instructions of Du Hamel, Forsyth, Loudon, and the other writers upon planting and dendrology— The result is that after numberless disappointments and the thorough failure of about 9/10ths. of my experiments I have perhaps one hundred trees growing from seeds sown by my own hands, and which if left unmolested where they now stand may survive me a full century and bear fruit for those who shall come after me— Of these, the only ones in which I now take much interest, are young apple trees, some just beginning to bear and others fit stocks for engrafting good fruit upon them.— About half a dozen pear stocks—one red oak 12 feet high and one foot in circumference, a dozen or more other Oaks, black, white and chesnut all neglected— Sundry elms and ash of which I might have a forest. Sundry cherries, most of them in bloom, but not having yet born fruit— Three maples the seeds of which I brought from Philadelphia in May 1836. and sowed on the first of June of that year. It is a comfort to me to leave these growing upon my grounds, and the sight of my trees bursting into bloom gives me the solitary pleasure that I enjoy in returning to this peaceful abode. I dined alone; and this afternoon my Son came out from Boston, with all his family to keep house with me, till he can get his own house upon the hill prepared for their reception— I got through my daily task of yesterday’s journal, and two pages of my address for the centennial— But this last sickens me to the heart and must prove a grievous failure— I am now wading through a comparative statement of the democratic ingredients of the four New-England Colonies which united in the confederacy of 1643. and find it hard to labour through.

18. I.15. III. IV.  I took last Night before going to bed by way of experiment a tumbler of wine whey, and it did not succeed— It aggravated my cough, and heated me without producing a perspiration— I rose in time to go over and see the sun rise from the corner of Charles’s house at 4.36. The restlessness of the Night somewhat dispirited me for punctuality to my labours so that I did not complete the two pages of my address for the day, nor finish my diary for yesterday, but by writing this evening till my bed time. But I spent between two and three of the best hours of the day, in going with John Kirk round my Garden and Nursery—trimming some of my trees, plucking up others, and preparing for clearing off the useless trees now stunting the growth of the precious ones—those for which I anticipate the longest lives are the shagbark walnuts of which I have about 20 from 12 to 2 years old, and the sight of which is a reward for all the labour I have wasted in raising tree, from the seed— In making up my summary of the 4 New-England Colonies which formed the confederacy of 1643. I have to consult numerous writers as well those nearly cotemporaneous as of later ages— Hutchinson is my standing leader, and often after finding, a very brief notice of my special object of enquiry, in him, with a reference to others for further enquiry, I stroll off to Hazard’s State papers, to Hinman’s Connecticut Antiquities, to Farmer’s Registers to Chalmers of Holmes Annals, to sundry volumes of the Collections of the Historical Society—and to others which I have not yet been able to gather. I return to the short notice in Hutchinson, and perceive not that I have much enlarged my stock of knowledge— Dr Holmes’s Annals are copious of facts—and they are what I want to know with most precision— I seek particularly the why and the when the Colonies of Connecticut and of New-Haven were organized and established— There is much modification of the history caused by the various phases of the revolution and restoration in of the Stuart family in England— I took up this day the Volume of Bancroft’s history recently published, and find a new colouring given to every incident, and a new gloss to every character— There is in every line of Bancroft a struggle to magnify the importance of events and of persons giving an air of pomposity to his whole Story— This afternoon I took a ride in the Carriage with Mrs Charles and her baby Arthur, to Braintree, where she finally found Miss Sampson, and engaged her to come, and work for her, the second week in June— Evening visit from Mr Beale— Short for I was drowsy.

19. IV. Friday  Having no time to spare for the composition of my address for the Massachusetts historical Society, and deeming it necessary for the filling of the time allotted to the discourse, that it should consist of 32 pages, occupying two pages or thereabouts I begin the day with that labour, and prescribing to myself to write two pages each day till I get through— I began therefore this morning as soon after rising dressing and making my fire was practicable, and with the interval of half an hour for breakfast kept incessant alternate reading and writing, till the village bell rung for noon before my task for the day was completed— In the course of my treatment of the subject I was this day brought to the consideration of the character of Roger Williams and the establishment of the Colony of Rhode-Island— It has in recent times become a sort of literary fashion to extol the character of Roger Williams, by disparaging those of the Massachusetts with whom he contended. I have suspected that there is in this much injustice; and the more minutely I examine his controversy with them, the more firmly this opinion fixes itself in my mind— Roger Williams was a Welshman— He came sharpened for controversy, a polemical porcupine from Oxford, an extreme puritan quilled with all the quarrelsome metaphysical divinity of the age— He arrived eight months after Winthrop and his company and began by preaching at Salem that the Charter was of no avail, because the king had no power to grant the lands because they belonged to the Indians, and that the Church was no true Church because she had not proclaimed her repentance for having held Communion with the Church of England before the Emigration— These doctrines struck at the vitals of the Massachusetts Colony, civil and ecclesiastical— If there is any thing surprizing in their treatment of him, it was their lenity towards him— His principle of liberty of conscience admirable in itself, was utterly at variance with itself in his excommunication of the colonial church for not excommunicating the episcopal church of England— Altogether he was a mere boute-feu and they were amply justified in getting rid of him. I see that Bancroft tells his Story with extreme partiality to puff him up—not only to a Saint and Hero; but to a transcendent Genius— A Newton, Kepler, or Copernicus. His principle of Toleration was the inspiration of a strong mind, and his success in settling a small colony where it was carried into practise gives lustre to his name— The recent revolution in Rhode-Island, is the Euthanasia of his system— My son, took his daughter Louisa to Boston with him to Boston and returned to dine. And after dinner I took a ride in the Carriage with his wife and youngest son Arthur.

20. III.45. Saturday.  My nightly cough begins to subside and I am encouraged with a hope of temporary relief from the peripneumona notha which I suppose is to finish me upon earth—for the respite I desire to bless the name of God, and with it I must pray for a good deliverance from my tedious task of the 29th.— I am still entangled with the character and history of Roger Williams and his democracy of the Providence Plantations.— I fear to do him injustice in the anxious desire to do justice to his adversaries— I cannot but think him the aggressor against the Massachusetts Colony from the day of his arrival— I cannot acquit him of the ambition of supplanting John Cotton as the high priest of the Colony— He shuffled and equivocated in apologizing to the general Court for his first Treatise against the Charter and in offering it to them to be burnt— His excommunications were all intolerant. his refusal to take the oath of allegiance was factious—his preaching against it seditious— He appears to have prevaricated on the subject of his conversion to the anabaptist denomination.— And his last controversial writings against the Quakers might as well have been omitted— Yet his inflexible and finally triumphant principles of universal toleration makes him a name and a praise for all future time— I see sharp points shooting out from every side of the subject— I received this day 1. A Letter from R. F. Barnard President of the Berkshire County Agricultural Society, dated Sheffield May 18. inviting me to prepare and deliver an address before them at their annual Fair to be held on the first Wednesday and Thursday of next October. 2. A Letter from Charles Sedgwick, Daniel N. Dewey, George N. Briggs, and Franklin Sturgis dated 17. May, referring to the above Letter of Mr Barnard and adding their very earnest solicitations to me, to visit that part of the Country. 3. A Letter from Revd. Charles Lowell D.D. Secretary of the Massachusetts Historical Society, dated Boston 18. May, requesting me to write an hymn or ode for the celebration of the 29th. 4. A further printed circular Letter from Ellis Gray Loring dated 13. May, as Treasurer of the United States Hotel company, apprizing me of some new arrangements to be made by the Stock holders— All these Letters require answers— They should be immediate answers; but I have no time to write them— I wrote and despatched a short Letter to my wife— Mr and Mrs Lunt were here on a visit this afternoon— I took a ride with my daughter and her baby Arthur this Evening— We left Mrs Lunt at the door of her house, and came out where the Quarry railway crosses the road in Milton—

21. IV. Sunday  My cough has very much subsided, and I went to bed last Night without a fit of coughing, and awoke this morning with a very light one— Mr Lunt preached this morning from Luke 12.15—[“]for a man’s life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth”—and Romans 8.6.—“to be spiritually minded is life and peace.”— Mr Lunt considered the second of these texts as an exposition of the first— The life of man he said was different from that of all merely material beings— The life of beasts and birds and fishes and all the animated creation consisted of the circulation of material elements—and in this sense there was a life in plants—perishable by the lapse of time but life in man was the conscious existence of the immortal soul, and therefore could not consist in the abundance of a man’s earthly possessions.— Mr Lunt gave notice that the afternoon service would be performed by a blind person named Bowen—who had been earnestly recommended to him by several of his professional brethren at the South, as every way, worthy of encouragement and kindness. He said that Mr Bowen, had been admitted to the pulpits of many churches in this neighbourhood, and had preached as he was informed to general acceptance.— He had thought it his duty to give him the same opportunity, and as Mr Bowen had no other means of providing for his subsistence, after his discourse a collection would be taken up for his benefit— Mr E. Price Greenleaf walked home with me— After dinner, Mr Bowen, the blind man preached from John 9.2. “And his disciples asked him, saying, Master, who did sin, this man, or his parents, that he was born blind? 3. Jesus answered, neither hath this man sinned, nor his parents: but that the works of God should be made manifest in him.”— Is there not in this answer an explicit declaration that the phyical infirmities and diseases of men are not to be considered as visitations of heaven upon them in punishment for transgression— Yet it is scarcely to be denied that there are punishments inflicted by heaven for sins upon earth— Mr Bowen’s discourse was intellectual as much as might be expected from one habitually living with knowledge at one entrance quite shut out.— Mr Bowen gave some statistics of blindness in different countries, and presented their plea for compassion without overcharge or exaggeration.— In thanking the auditory for their patience he repeated the notice given this morning by Mr Lunt, that he had no other means of obtaining his subsistence, but his preaching, and a liberal contribution was taken up for his benefit—

22— IV. Monday.  I find myself with the most unremitting labour unable to accomplish the daily task of writing two pages of my address, and equally so of fixing any point of view, in which the New England Colonial confederacy can be made interesting.— My acquaintance with the details of the original settlement of New England is very slender, and being now under the obligation to look them up, the streams of information are so copious, that they absorb all my time— The confederacy of 1643 was a defensive league against the Indians—my first duty was to trace the separate origin of the five New-England Colonies, including that of Rhode-Island and Providence plantations, which was not admitted into the league— Then I was cast upon the controversy concerning the life and character of Roger Williams. Next I came to the investigation of the Colonial Wars with the Indians— This plunges me into the historical collections of the Massachusetts, and of the Rhode Island historical Societies—of the Massachusetts Collections there are 28 volumes already published and of the Rhode Island collections 4: The Massachusetts collections are rich in original publications respecting the New England Indians, and the Wars of the European Colonists with them. In the first volume there is a work by Daniel Gookin, entitled Historical collections of the Indians of New-England of which I made this day the discovery, and which occupied hours of my time— The work is dedicated in December 1674. to Charles the 2d with an Epistle to Robert Boyle and the Society in London for propagating the gospel among the Indians, and another epistle to the reader— In the second Chapter of this work there is an enumeration of five tribes embracing all the tribes inhabiting New England when the English colonies were first settled, and continuing to exist half a century afterwards when Gookin wrote— This Daniel Gookin was father to Elizabeth Gookin, second wife of the second Edmund Quincy, ancestor of President Josiah Quincy. His first wife was Joanna Hoare, mother of Daniel Quincy and thereby my ancestor— I am yet to explore the narratives of the Indian Wars as originating causes of the New-England confederacy, and in the mean time, my address drags its slow length along. I took a ride this afternoon round through Braintree with my daughter and her baby Arthur.— Elizabeth C. Adams took tea here. They came from Medford on Saturday. We have the melancholy tidings of the death of Mr Whittemore the husband of Louisa De Wint, leaving two infant children.

23. IV. Tuesday.  Morning showery. Cleared off after Breakfast. Charles went to Boston with his daughter Louisa, and returned to dine— Mr Robinson the Minister of the episcopal church in this town called on me this morning and requested me to attend the Fair, at the vestry under the Church this afternoon, and to address the company who might be there. After dinner I rode with Mrs Charles and Arthur to Mrs T. B. Adams’s; left them there— Took up Elizabeth C. Adams and went to the Church vestry Fair— There were about twenty women there with tables before them covered with small articles for sale, and five or six men, and sundry children— The Fair is a small device for taxing the pockets of visitors for contributions— An expedient of beggary humble enough but growing stale— I purchased two or three petty articles; Mr Robinson who had formally announced me when I entered asked me again to let the ladies hear my voice— My voice was in no condition to speak, and I declined— I had in truth nothing to say; and knew not what to say— I returned with Elizabeth to Mrs T. B. Adams’s Took up Mrs Charles and the baby, and rode down to the Mount Wollaston beach where I am always reminded of the barge into which I enteredFebruary 1778 to embark in the Boston Frigate for France, and of my landing on the 2d. of August 1779 from the pinnace of the French frigate La Sensible on the same beach—65 years have passed away since the first of those events— Nearly 64 since the second— What changes of the globe and of man in that interval— The beach seems to be the same— We took Elizabeth home, and then came home. Evening call from Benjamin Owen Tyler—coming now from Duxbury where he has been varnishing for Gershom B. Weston— I was benumbed—and torpid, and fell asleep while Mr Tyler was talking, and slept till after he went away— I had been labouring all day, at the New-England confederacy of 1643. and made very little progress. See Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society 3. 203 Abstract of Roger Williams’s Key in to the Language of the Indians of New-England. 5. Genl. B. Lincoln’s Observations on the Indians— Report of Jeremy Belknap and Jedidiah Morse about Indians and Missionaries— Letter from Stephen Badger about Natick Indians—p 6–45— Roger Williams, Vocabulary of the Narraganset Language p. 80— Brief account of Settlements in and about Narraganset Bay. p. 216–252. 6. Specimen of Indian languages. p. 16. Letter of Instructions from Leonard Hoar to Josiah Flint 27. March 1661. p. 100— Letters relating to the Natick Indians and Philip 1671. p. 196–211.— Dedications to Eliot’s Indian Bible 7. 222. Ecclesiastical History of Massachusetts and the old Colony of Plymouth— p. 262–280— I propose to continue this list, through the subsequent volumes of the Historical Collections—

24. V. Wednesday  Disastrous fire in Quincy—  Mr Benjamin Owen Tyler was again here this morning with his century of inventions for raising the wind— His principal project now is an engraved print for a temperance pledge certificate, ornamented with the portraits of sundry reformed drunkards, or according to the latest vocabulary, inebriates— He also convinced me by dint of persuasion, to let him varnish some of my old pictures. A person by the name of Alexander Wolcott Stow, formerly of Connecticut, now of Milwaukie, in the territory of Wiskonsin, came to see me and to have some conversation with me; as he said merely for the pleasure of it— A friend of Liberty Deacon Spear called also, and proposed to me at some future day to visit my territories, to which I agreed without naming a day. There was a fire in the Town this day, between Noon and One O’Clock, which consumed several dwelling houses, at some distance from each other— First caught from a foul chimney, and then carried by the wind in burning cinders from house to house.— Clift Rogers and Cotton Pratt, a Carpenter are two of the sufferers who lost their houses— After dinner I rode to Milton with my daughter and her boy Arthur—stop’d on our return at Mrs T. B. Adams’s to enquire how they were— Barely recovering from their fright— The fire was close in their neighbourhood, and their house was in imminent danger of being kindled— My progress to the completion of my Address to the Massachusetts Historical Society was suspended by my examination of the volumes of the Collections of the Society, for publications relating to the subject. The notice of which I now continue— First Series Vol. 8. p 5–35. Memoir of the Life of Rev’d John Eliot, called the Apostle of the Gentiles, who translated the Bible into an Indian Language, and was part author of the New-England Metrical version of the Psalms— p 203–239. 25. IV.45 Thursday.  Horse Chesnut in full blossom.  Mr White came with a subscription paper for the sufferers by the fire yesterday besides Pratt. The fire broke out in the Faxon house, property of the late Benjamin Faxon nearly opposite the orthodox Church, occupied by several Irish families— Crossed the street to the stable of Clift Rogers Currier. Sparks blown by the gale, kindled Henry Gardiner Pratt’s carpenter’s shop, and thence to his dwelling house—both burnt, and also the next adjoining dwelling house of Peter Brackett— Three houses, one stable, two shops—all consumed within the space of one hour— Loss about 3000 dollars. Seven families burnt out— Blessed be God—no lives lost— Wooden buildings stubble. Mr Tyler was here nearly all day, varnishing everything upon which he could lay his hand— I went to Boston with my Son, and we both attended a monthly Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society— There were about 20 members in attendance; and the arrangements were made for the delivery of my discourse next Monday— It is to be a religious ceremony with prayers and singing. At Dr Frothingham’s Church— There was a debate whether it should be in the morning or after dinner— Finally voted, that the Society shall meet at their chambers at half past 10. A.M.— Go from thence in procession to the church so as to commence the performances at 11.—so I hope it will be all over by half past one.— We returned home to Quincy to dine and I was occupied all the afternoon upon the diary and the Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society— I had written and despatched this morning a Letter to my wife— And received one from Mr Frye, with enclosures which must not be neglected— My cough has almost subsided, but leaves me, in a condition of sluggishness and torpidity such as I never before experienced— I cannot rouse my self to exertion, and I returned to my paper and dropped away from it in helpless impotence ten times in the course of this afternoon— Collections of Massachusetts Historical Society—Second Series Vol. 1. 26. V. Friday. After Sunrise.  Mr Tyler continues his varnishing atchievements and this day dined with us— An Irish woman of one of the families burnt out of the Faxon house came to plead her own cause with all the eloquence of distress, but she could not pronounce her own name so that I could remember it.— After dinner I rode with Charles and his wife to Roxbury to the garden of an Englishman named Walker at Roxbury, where he has sundry beds of tulips after the fashion of those at Haerlem in Holland— In one bed under a glass-frame there were 1200 bulbs with the stalk and cups, in every variety of colouring and of cost— We met there Mr Edward Brooks with his mother in Law, Mrs Boott, his wife and daughter— There was a printed advertisement of a sale at auction of all these plants one day next week— In one part of the bed Mr Brooks was noticing two of the tulips near together, as being remarkably handsome, when Mr Walker observed that the difference in value between them was of fifty cents and fifty dollars— I thought the fifty cent one the handsomest of the two— The wild and extravagant and most capricious taste for tulips is not yet extinct— Returning home just after crossing Neponsett Bridge, my fingers were so pinched with cold that I alighted from the carriage and walked two miles home; Charles’s son John Quincy came down from the Coachman’s box, and walked with me— The day for the delivery of my address is now so near at hand that I am excessively pressed for time to conclude. I have come at last to an abstract of the Articles of the New England confederacy with the view of closing by a parallel between them and the present North American confederation of the United States—but the attempt has brought me to a conviction of failing faculties so exquisitely painful, that I am tempted to wish that a return of my habitual disease may totally disqualify me for the performance on Monday and save me from the mortification of self exposure. 27. V.15 Saturday.  The Sun rose clear, but I was yet in bed. And the sky soon clouded up for a Northeaster with showers of rain through the day— I came in my address to the parallel between the New-England confederacy of 1643. and the North-American confederacy of 1774.— I had some hopes on approaching this topic to bring up some interest with it—but it sinks under me— Not one of the motives which stimulated the puritans of 1643 to their confederacy of 1643 had the slightest influence in actuating the confederacy of 1774. The parties to the New-England Union were homogeneous— Those of the North-American Union were not only of heterogeneous but of hostile elements; and in the latter there was the ingredient of Slavery which poisoned the whole composition— I have touched upon it in this address; but on revisal propose to strike out all that I have written relating to it— This afternoon I rode with my daughter and her son Charles to Weymouth to enquire of the state of Mrs Mercy Tufts who has been very dangerously ill with the Erisypelas— We saw her two daughters Mercy and Susan, who told us she was somewhat better, though still confined to her bed— We rode home with a sprinkling rain and the evening was wintry cold— This family of Tufts are all that now remain of my childhood’s remembrance of Weymouth— Some of the earliest of my recollections are there, and the localities which remain unchanged bring them back, with a pungency for which I scarcely know how to account— I have no such reminiscences in Boston, because every thing there is changed; but spots of the old road through Braintree and Weymouth are precisely as they were seventy years ago—and a return to them seems to sweep away the interval of time, and to make me again a child— But there is not one individual of my grandfather Smith’s blood now living in Weymouth— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society— Second Series Vol. 9. 28. V. Sunday  Heard this morning Mr Lunt from Hebrews. 1.1. [“]God, who at sundry times, and in divers manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets.”— A Dissertation upon the Hebrew prophets. This subject has perhaps not been fully explored— Mr Lunt noticed the division made by the Jews of their sacred books into the historical, the poetical and the prophetical— The latter including only the books of Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel Daniel and the twelve minor prophets— But the term prophet is of much more extensive signification in the old testament than to include the authors of the sixteen prophetical books.— The Patriarchs Abraham Isaac and Jacob were prophets— The kings Saul and David and Solomon were prophets. During the time of the judges the prophets were called Seers; and in the case of Balaam, there is a description of the manner of their visions (Numbers 24.16) The prophet fell into a trance, but had his eyes open—and then he saw visions, and heard voices—and what he heard he was obliged to repeat— In the days of the kings there were schools of the prophets whence it would seem it was considered as an art or Science to be taught by human instruction. But the word of the Lord came indiscriminately to persons of all conditions, and the prophet Amos was among the herdmen of Tekoa— One of the greatest prophets was Elijah, of whom there are now no writings left and it is remarkable that the 16. prophets whose writings are included in the Bible, all lived very shortly before or during the Babylonian captivity. By the Law of Moses, (Deuteronomy 13 and 18) a false prophet if he spoke in the name of the Lord—and a true prophet if he spoke in the name of any other God were to be put to death— The test of a true prophet who spoke in the name of the Lord was that his predictions should come to pass— And there was a promise that the Lord would raise up a prophet, like unto Moses; but it was not said when and the modern Christian commentators have concluded that this promise was fulfilled by the advent of Jesus Christ— But he, and by his declaration even John the Baptist was more than a prophet. Mr Lunt gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday. Mr Edward Brooks junr came out from Boston and dined with us. After dinner Mr Hall of Dorchester preached from Acts 16.30. “what must I do to be saved?” There was something startling in the text, but Mr Hall thought it a question, which every Christian ought to put to himself, every day and every hour of his life.— But he did not very distinctly define what he understood by being saved— He is no believer of eternal damnation— I this day painfully brought to a conclusion my address, to be delivered to-morrow before the Massachusetts Historical Society.

29. V. Monday  New England confederacy of 1643.  At 9 this morning I went with Charles into Boston and we stop’d at Dr Frothingham’s. There by a mistake rather ludicrous I was shown into his study where were assembled a number of persons, who I supposed were the Massachusetts historical Society though I could not conceive how they came there— Mr Peter C. Brooks was presiding, and they settled their Treasurer’s Accounts, made all their annual elections, and chose the Revd. Ezra Stiles Gannett as a member of their corporation in the place of the late Doctor William E. Channing before I discovered that it was a meeting of the Massachusetts Congregational charitable Society— When they had finished their business President Quincy who was there took me in his barouche to the chambers of the historical Society, where a meeting well attended was held— The President James Savage moved that the meeting should adjourn to his house at 8 O’Clock this evening and gave a general invitation to all the members present to attend there— A Procession was then formed in which I walked with President Savage to the first Church in Chauncey Place where I delivered the address to the Massachusetts Historical Society, in celebration of the second centennial anniversary of the New-England colonial confederacy of 1643.— The performances began precisely at 11. O’Clock, with an appropriate prayer by Dr Frothingham the Minister of the Church— Then the Psalm 107. of the New England version of 1640. was sung— I then delivered my address, beginning at 20 minutes past 11. and closing at 5 minutes past 1.— One hour and three quarters; omitting about one eighth of what I had written— It was very well received; and there was no manifestation of what I most dreaded, a sense of weariness on the part of the auditory— The attention was general and unremitting to the last— The house was well filled but not crowded— Excepting the members of the Society about as many women as men— After the Address, Psalm 44 of the New England version was sung, and the benediction was pronounced by Dr Frothingham.— Mr William Beach Laurence, Mr John Jay, and several other gentlemen were introduced to me as delegates from the historical Societies of New-York, Connecticut and Maine. I went with Charles and dined at Dr Frothingham’s— Charles’s wife dined at her brother Edward Brooks’s. At 4 in the afternoon we left Dr. Frothingham’s, and returned immediately to Quincy. Mr Buckingham’s son; part Editor of the Courier asked the loan of my manuscript to report an abstract from it—but I had promised to reserve it for the Society— My voice held out better than I expected, but I excused myself from attendance at the President’s evening party.

30. III.45 Tuesday.  Mr Thomas Greenleaf called on me this morning, with a copy of a lease executed in 1839 of a lot of land belong to the Adams temple and school corporation for 20 years on a ground lent of 6. dollars a year— There was a condition inserted in the draught of the deed that at the termination of the lease, if the parties could not agree upon its renewal the corporation should take the buildings erected by the lessee, at an equitable apprizement— The supervisors of the fund disapproved of this condition; and directed that another should be done. But from the loose and careless manner in which the business of this corporation, and indeed of most others is transacted the conclusion of the deed has been neglected and protracted to this day—once signed and sealed by the selectmen, and acknowledged before a justice of the peace; but by unaccountable negligence without signature of witnesses; so that it must be done all over again— An admonition which ought not to be overlooked— Charles went into Boston to attend a Collation furnished by the Unitarian laymen of Boston to the Clergy of their denomination. This is a yearly festival; at which there were this day 815 persons of both sexes present— Charles presided as a delegate from Dr Frothingham’s Society at one of 8 tables.— The entertainment consisted of cold meats, tea and coffee— No wine or Spirits, but addresses and songs— I rode this afternoon with Mrs Charles, her Sons Charles, Henry and Arthur with his Nurse Becca—we stop’d at Mr John Greenleaf’s; and saw him and Mrs Greenleaf and their two daughters Mrs Lucy Dawes and Mrs Mary Dawes—after which we rode round the Braintree square, and when we reached home found Charles returned from Boston— I visited my garden, Nursery and seminary, and examined my seedling trees, many of which exhibit appearances, for which I cannot account— Almost all my peach-trees are winter killed; and among them several of two and three years old; and till now of the fairest promise— On the other hand the cherries all flourish more than I have ever known them to do before— The black walnuts often before blighted are uncommonly thrifty now: and the oaks and Shagbark walnuts differ so much that numbers of them have put forth a vigorous growth, while others after opening a beautiful foliage have already withered and are irretrievably blasted— The apples make as yet the fairest show.

31. IV. Wednesday  Sun 4:26. rose—  Mr Lewis Tappan and Mr Andrews visited me this morning. Mr Tappan had with him the New-Orleans Bee of 15 and 16. May containing several long Articles, sounding the trumpet of alarm at the symptoms recently manifested in Texas of a strong party with a fixed design to abolish Slavery— The Bee has the name of Henry Clay on its first page nominated as its candidate for the presidency but its groans at the prospect of abolition in Texas are agonizing.— Mr Andrews is a native of Massachusetts, but at present an inhabitant of Texas— He is the person mentioned in the Letter from Joseph Eve, to the Secretary of State shewn to me by Mr Hunter on the 14th. of April— Eve related that this person had come from Austin to Galveston to make a speech in public urging the expediency and necessity of abolishing Slavery. But that an assemblage of people had gone to him at his lodgings, taken him by force and landed him at Virginia point on the opposite bank of the river. Mr Andrews says this was true; but that the men who committed this outrage upon him were a gang of not more than 20 persons; not at all authorised or supported by the People—and that he afterwards returned to Galveston, openly avowing his abolition opinions without meeting any ill treatment or opposition— He says he knows that the Texan President Houston is in favour of the abolition— He is now about to embark in the Steamer Caledonia to morrow for England, with a view to obtain the aid of the British Government to the cause— Mr Tappan asked me if I would furnish him with Letters of recommendation, which I declined having no correspondent in England with whom I could take the Liberty: but I bade him God speed and told him, that I believed the freedom of this country and of all mankind depended upon the direct, formal, open and avowed interference of Great-Britain to accomplish the abolition of Slavery in Texas. But that I distrusted the Sincerity of the present British Administration in the Anti-slavery cause. Mr Andrews offered to write to me, to inform me how his propositions may be received, which I accepted— Mr Tappan told me he had himself been urged to go to England and asked my advice what he should do— I declined advising; but said I wished he would go; were it only for the possibility that he might contribute to advance the cause— Edward and Mrs Brooks, with their daughter and Mrs Frothingham came out this afternoon and took tea with us.

1. IV. Thursday.  Sun rose 4:26. Sharp frost.  I find myself already falling into idleness as always happens after I have completed a compulsive task, and am left without another bearing upon me— The luxury of my life is desultory reading, and my library furnishes irresistible temptation to variety of enjoyment— My first duty now is to answer Letters of invitation to deliver Orations, Lectures and Addresses, and I began with that of B. R. Curtis for an Address to the Alumni of Harvard University on the day before the next Commencement— The next was from R. F. Barnard President of the Berkshire County Agricultural Society, inviting me to deliver an Address to that Society at their annual meeting next October—to both these I wrote and despatched declining answers—but in addition to the Berkshire invitation there is a Letter from Charles Sedgwick and 49 others dated at Lenox, and another from Thaddeus Pomeroy and 22 others at Stockbridge which I ought to have answered this day but postponed till to-morrow— A man by the name of Matthias Rich, blind, came, led by his Son, a boy about 12 years of age came to beg. He had an old certificate of respectability and of indigence dated in 1839. and signed by John Reed the former member of Congress from Barnstable County— He said that he had a family of several children to support, and no other means but the bounty of the charitable to assist him; which from time to time he went round to solicit, though it was a very mortifying occupation— Mr Tyler too came again this afternoon and resumed his volunteer task of varnishing all over the house every thing upon which he could lay his hand— I rode out this afternoon with Mrs Charles and her Son Charles— We stop’d at Mrs T. B. Adams’s and left a Letter from Mrs De Windt to her in reply to condolence on the decease of Mr Whittemore— The Letter announces also the birth of a Son to Mrs Van Wagenen, who was Julia the third daughter of Mrs De Windt— We then round by the Railway Stone Church. After our return, Mr Thomas J. Noyes with his brother came to enquire what had been done in Congress on the petition of their Grandmother Mary Pike for a pension; of which I had taken charge, 14. Novr last— Her husband was killed at Bunker’s hill— I told them that a Bill in her favour had passed the house of Representatives, but I believe had failed in the Senate—but not having with me the Acts of the last Session of Congress I was unable to answer the enquiry with certainty— I attended this Evening at the town hall an anatomical lecture by a young man named Lambert—chiefly against the compression of the chest, by straight-lacing—from 8 to 1/2 past 9—

2. IV. Friday.  Sun rose 4.25. clear and pinching cold.  I saw the sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house. I answered the Letters of Charles Sedgwick and Thaddeus Pomeroy, but continued idle with miscellaneous reading, and believing that I must prepare a Lecture for the next Autumn, meditated upon a biographical sketch of Lord Bacon of Nicholas Machiavel, of Ignatius Loyola and Blaise Pascal, either of which seems to afford a good subject for a moral and entertaining Lecture— But if this is ever to be carried into execution it must be preceded by much reading. I took up the life of Bacon in the first Volume of the Quarto Edition of his works, and read about an hour. I met Mr E. Price Greenleaf in my garden, and walked round with him examining my seedling trees.— I mourned the number of various kinds and ages apparently killed by the recent frosts after putting forth their foliage with cheering promise— Of the Baldwin Apple trees from Medford, two at least have holes of the borer worm two or three inches above the ground— Several of them bore largely last autumn, and we have now as many as a peck of them in sound condition, daily on the dining table. Of the Shagbark walnut there arein the Nurseryin the Garden andin the seminary which I have hope will outlive me more than a century— The peaches and button woods have a dreary and haggard appearance—many of them entirely dead.— Mr Greenleaf brought back a number of books that he had borrowed and asked for others—among which Montesquieu and Machiavel in French and Italian— This last I have not. but I found in the town’s library an English translation of Machiavel’s works, not including the plays; in 4. 8vo. volumes by Ellis Farneworth published in 1775— I looked especially for the Prince and found it with a translation of the Anti-Machiavel, by Frederic 2. king of Prussia, printed alternately chapter by chapter— Several of which I read—first the cunning Italian, and then the royal German-French commentator. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— He brought information of the arrival of our chests and trunks and boxes, ship’d at Georgetown in the brig Elizabeth Captain Baker, but fraudulently landed at Salem— He brought me also a Letter from Mr Savage, President of the Massachusetts Historical Society, with a vote of thanks of the Society for the Discourse on the New England Confederacy, and a request of a copy for the press. Mr Tyler was here varnishing— Ruth Turner to work— Elizabeth C. Adams to dine—and we rode to Milton after dinner.

3. IV. Saturday  Mr Tyler continues to favour us with volunteer varnishing—and this day wrought almost a metempsecosis on the full length portrait of my great grandfather John Quincy, at two years of age, painted in 1691. and left by his Son Norton Quincy, who died 29. September 1801— He brought me also a Boston Notion of this morning, containing a report of the celebration of last Monday; with seven columns of my discourse from the Notes of the Reporter— There are many mistakes, of the meaning; but I believe it scarcely possible that a more correct report of a speech nearly two hours long, should be taken from the lips of the Speaker.— I despatched 3 Letters of apology, for declining to deliver the address before the Berkshire County Agricultural Society next October— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came and returned more of the books that he had borrowed; and took from the Town’s library the 6. volumes of the works of Montesquieu in duodecimo and 2. volumes of Italian History. I read several chapters of Machiavel’s Prince, and the examen of the same by Frederic of Prussia.— I believe that a profound examination of both would form an instructive and entertaining occupation for this and the next Month—why should I not undertake it?— Machiavel, was a republican, Florentine Statesman of the 15th. Century— Frederic the 2d. a German Prussian King of the 18th. and Voltaire a French Man of Letters and universal Genius of the same age— Frederic wrote his Anti-Machiavel, while he was a Prince, and before he became a king.— He wrote in the French language, and the first edition of his work was published by Voltaire in Holland. The morality of Machiavel characterizes his Age and country; and is congenial to the doctrines of papal Rome at the time when Luther first raised the standard of religious reformation.— Machiavel was born 1469. and Luther 1483. and Ignatius Loyola 1491.— Comparing the Chapters of the Prince with the Examen of Frederic, the Royal commentator has greatly the advantage—but Voltaire in the posthumous Memoirs of his own life, charges Frederic with practising on the doctrines of Machiavel, however indignantly denouncing them in his youthful writings— The infidel spirit of the 18th. century is apparent in the treatise of Frederic, though more gauze covered in the second edition published by himself, than in the first published by Voltaire.— The cold weather continues, but while we were at dinner there was a heavy shower of rain, accompanied with distant thunder— It deprived us of the afternoon, and kept me at work, writing— At evening twilight however I walked up the hill, but the roads were so muddy that I was obligated to abridge my walk and come in— I shingled this day my seedling English Oaks to save them from the Sun.

4. III.45 Sunday.  Mr Lunt preached this morning, from 1. Corinthians 10.16. “The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not the communion of the body of Christ?” It was a communion day Sermon, and after preaching it he administered the communion, of which I partook— There is a peculiar solemnity in this religious rite, which in the most impressive manner admonishes every sincere Christian of his duties to God, and to his neighbour; and especially of the duty of goodwill to all mankind— There is something strange and mysterious in the history of the institution of the Jewish Passover—and of the substitution of this sacrament in its stead— On the night of the going forth of the children of Israel from Egypt, the destroying angel had smitten all the first born of the Egyptians— There was not a house but had a dead body in it: but the angel had passed over all the houses of the Israelites, and in commemoration of that double deliverance, on the very night of the Exodus, Moses commanded that their religious year should commence with that month, and that every family should annually sacrifice a lamb, and feed upon it in remembrance of that wonderful event. Subsequent regulations of divine appointment had prescribed that this annual festival should be held at Jerusalem, and 1500 years after the establishment of the passover Jesus went up to that city to keep the passover with his disciples— There it was, while at supper that he disclosed the secret of his own destiny, and considering himself as the paschal lamb, sacrificed for the sins and deliverance of mankind—he told his disciples by a figure of oriental imagery that the bread was his flesh, and the wine his blood, which they must annually eat and drink in remembrance of him— And now after 3300 years, the Jewish Passover is yet annually celebrated in the form of an annual memorial of the ignominious death and glorious resurrection of Jesus of Nazareth— And once in every one or two months it is repeated by Christians even of the purest and most spiritual denomination. Mr Lunt announced and prayed for one new communicant, Samuel White— After dinner he preached again from John 3.8. “The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh, and whither it goeth: so is every one who is born of the Spirit”— The spiritual nature of Christianity is a topic to which Mr Lunt very frequently returns— After Meeting I rode with Mrs Charles and her child Arthur to Germantown, and was reminded by the name of Palmer Street of the old General, once settled there.

5. IV. Monday.  The wind came round yesterday to the South and this morning when I rose before the Sun; thin clouds were scudding across the sky from South to North, followed by a dense fog, which soon cleared off, for a forenoon of high Summer heat— I took the opportunity to visit my seedling trees in the garden, nursery and seminary.— The exercise and the thermometer soon urged me back into the house. Of the multitude of English Oak acorns sown last October five or six have sprung up, the last week in May.— None since—and there as many more slender stalks, three or four inches high which came up last summer, and have survived the winter, and opened their leaves, but shew no manifestation of growth, the present Season— To keep these alive through another winter is my present ambition; but the black jack Oak is again winter killed nearly down to the surface of the ground— It is putting forth new shoots, but doubtful whether they will get headway to survive the next winter— The most extraordinary growth of the present year is that of my shagbark walnuts— Then the cherries, and the black walnuts; which seldom thrive here.— I had scarcely returned to my chamber when the wind shifted to the eastward and the afternoon and evening were cold and rainy— I answered a Letter from my wife, and before closing it received another from her, dated the first of this month, which will require further answer. I received also a Letter from William Hayden joint editor of the Boston Atlas, offering to publish in that paper, my Discourse on the New England confederacy; which I declined, having promised a copy for publication to the Society— I had also received last week a Letter from George Sullivan at New-York enquiring if I would deliver an Address before the American Institute of New-York, next November— I answered this day and declined. I resume the notice of the Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Third Series Vol. 1— Hutchinson papers, continued from the last Volume p. 1–152 Seven Letters of Roger Williams p. 159–178— Two Letters of Hugh Peters p. 179–180. Letters of William Hooke p. 181. and of John Maidston p. 185–198 to Governor John Winthrop of Connecticut— History of the Nanhiganset Country p. 209–228— Letter of John Haynes to John Winthrop p. 229.— 3 Letters of Henry Jacie to John Winthrop junr p. 235–245. Vol. 2. Memoir of French Protestants settled at Oxford 1686. p 1.–83. New England’s Salamander discovered by Edward Winslow p. 110–146. Cotton’s vocabulary of the Massachusetts or Natick Indian Language. p 147. Memoir of the Narragansett township. p 273.— Long Parliament p 323—

6. IV. Tuesday.  There was in the Night very heavy rain, with thunder and lightening which I neither saw nor heard—though I did hear the clock strike 3— I went to Boston this morning—with my Son, his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine.— On alighting at Dr Frothingham’s house I met my old friend Mr John Welles, who greeted me very kindly— He has just returned from an excursion Southward as far as Richmond in Virginia. On his way home he has been at pains to ascertain the cause of the universal blight which for the last two years has fallen upon the button wood or Sycamore trees— They were among the largest, soundest, most flourishing and longest lived trees of our forests; and the most easily propagated, for they grew from a twig or stake as well as from the seed— Last summer they foliated very scantily, and not till near midsummer— This Season they are but now beginning to put forth rare and stinted leaves; and look like one of Hayley’s old maid’s a blasted tree in the middle of a heath—or they sadden the rich foliage of a surrounding grove, like a spot of desolation in a circle of beauty. Mr Welles thinks he has discovered the source of all this mischief, in an insect scarcely larger than a musquito— I went into Dr Frothingham’s study, and had with him a literary conversation of about two hours— I spoke of my speculations upon the morality of the 15th. century—and the Jesuits—and he referred me to an Article in the 152 number of the Edinburgh Review July 1842—on the spiritual exercises of Ignatius Loyola: and Mr Edward Brooks afterwards lent me the republication of the number containing that Article— From Dr Frothingham’s I went and spent an hour with Dr George Parkman and his wife and daughter, and the revd. Mr Mason of New-York, who came as a delegate from the New-York Historical Society to the celebration of the New-England confederacy— I met in the Street Mr Buckingham, Editor of the Courier, and President of the Bunker hill Monument Association, who told me that the Directors hoped I should attend at the ceremony of the 17th. which is to be immortalized by an Address from Daniel Webster, and the presence of President John Tyler— I answered doubtingly. Doctor Parkman returned with me to Dr Frothingham’s door. We dined at Mr Edward Brooks’s, his father being the only other guest— At 1/2 past 4. Charles left us to go, by the Railway Cars to Worcester—to attend the great whig convention to be held there to morrow, to nominate whig candidates for the Offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the year 1844— I purchased a crockery ware pint pitcher, and a Turkish sponge. At 5. P.M. Mrs Charles and her daughter returned with me to Quincy—and I made up a fire again in my Study. And I wrote there two hours at the close of the Evening. Mr Minott Thayer delegate from Braintree to the Worcester Convention had called here on his way.

7. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 4.23.  I succeeded in reaching the corner of my Son’s house to see the first beam of the rising Sun— Mr John A. Green. Editor of the Quincy Patriot, brought me a small volume elegantly bound with my name on the outside binding published by Casserly and Sons 108 Nassau Street New-York: with a flattering, complimentary note from the publishers— The book is entitled A Memoir of Ireland Native and Saxon, by Daniel O’Connell M.P. Vol. 1. 1172–1660— These are Roman Catholic publishers; but I know not how to account for their extraordinary kindness to me— Mr Green had also a slip from a Berkshire Newspaper containing 4 Stanzas of poetry with my name as the author. He asked if they were mine— They were the Stanza’s 3–6. of Dermot MacMorrogh—Canto 2. Green intimated that he intended to republish them in the Quincy Patriot— I visited my seedling trees, and noted the first appearance of one more English Oak— I trimmed a young button-wood and took off a stake which I planted to ascertain if it will grow.— I answered at last a Letter, which has been waiting for an answer for 12 days. After dinner I rode with Mrs Charles and her boy Arthur to Mount Wollaston, and after we returned I had a visit from John G. Whittier. He had agreed to serve as Editor of the Emancipator during the absence of Mr Leavitt; but that engagement is cancelled and at the close of this week he returns to his residence at Amesbury— He spoke of the teeming projects of our Southern politicians for the annexation of Texas to this Union; and for the counter projects in Texas for the abolition of Slavery there— I told him my reasons for distrusting the sincerity of the British Government with regard to Slavery and Texas; the commercial interest and policy of Great-Britain, sympathising far more with our Southern than with the Northern States— Past Midshipman John Quincy Adams 2d. came in this Evening with his Sister Elizabeth— He has a short furlough and from the Razee Independence of the home Squadron, has been transferred to the command of the Sloop of War Decatur—ordered to the Station, on the Coast of Africa— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society Third Series. Vol. 3. Pathway to erect a plantation by Captain John Smith p 1–53. Plain dealing. by Thomas Lechford. p. 59.–128. Instructions to John Winthrop—Governor of Connecticut. Lion Gardener’s Relation of the Pequot War. p. 131–160. Relation of the Indian plot, p 161–164. Intrusion of Rhode-Island people on Indian Lands— p. 209. John Josselyn, two Voyages to New-England p 211–354. Chronological observations of America p 355–396.

8. IV. Thursday—  Sun rose 4.23.  I saw the Sun rise again from the S.E. corner of my Son’s house, but it went soon into a cloud which thickened the whole day and sprinkled rain in the evening. Mr Forbes of Milton called on me this forenoon and introduced to me a Mr Delano recently returned from China— He speaks doubtfully of the results of the late War of Great Britain against China. My Son returned before dinner from the whig convention at Worcester, where yesterday they first nominated John Davis as the whig candidate for Governor— Mr Davis positively and peremptorily declined the nomination; whereupon they nominated George N. Briggs for Governor and John Read of Yarmouth for Lieutenant Governor— There was a suspension of hostilities between the Clay and Webster fragments of the whig party, which are already bitterly exasperated against each other— Webster has undertaken to dragoon the whigs of this State from their allegiance to Henry Clay, whom he proposes to supplant, as a supplementary candidate for the Presidency; by a double coalition with John Tyler and John C. Calhoun— His first movements in this new system of policy, have demolished the prospects of Clay, and driven John Davis into retirement, but have gone near to demolish also Webster’s own party— The result thus far has been to throw the State into the hands of Marcus Morton and the radical democracy— This is but a step to that flagitious coalition which is to prostrate the freedom of this Union before its Slavery. What am I to do in this struggle? to flinch ingloriously from it? or to perish in fruitless resistance ag against it? Is it not a craven Spirit, that holds me still in suspense on this mighty movement upon the history of man. Miss Welsh came out with Charles from Boston— I took a ride with her and Mrs Charles and her this afternoon— We left her at Mrs Torrey’s and after a tour round the old roads in Braintree, took her up again at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I had in the morning a visit from Mr Joseph Graves of Brentwood in the County of Rockingham, New Hampshire— He said he was travelling this way, and called to see me, from mere curiosity— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society Third Series Vol. 5. Journal of the proceedings of the Congress held at Albany 1754. p. 5–14. Journal of the Treaty held at Albany in August 1775 with the six Nations, by the Commissioners of the 12. United Colonies met in general Congress at Philadelphia. p 75–100. Journal of Christopher Gist companion of Major George Washington in 1754— Journal of a Treaty held in 1793. with Indians Northwest of the Ohio. p. 109–176.

9. IV. Friday.  Heavy showers of rain in the morning, and cloudy remainder of the day. I received a Letter from my wife enclosing one from William S. Smith to Thomas B. Johnson— His condition is so critical, that his Sisters feared if the Letter should be communicated to him it might snap the attenuated thread of his life— Yet they did not dare to break the seal to ascertain its contents, and my wife enclosed it to me with a request that I would return it to Mr Smith, and intimate to him that if he has any application to make to Mr Johnson, it would be advisable that he should make it through me— I enclosed accordingly Mr Smith’s Letter back to himself and answered the one from my wife.— Mr Curtis came just before our dinnertime; and having dined before he left home abridged his visit. I agreed to meet him between 10 and 11 to morrow morning at my Son’s office in Boston— We have a final answer to give to Petty Vaughan of London who exacts a bond of indemnity from us for his own unauthorised transactions as a condition to his payment of a large sum in his hands, due to us as Executors of Ward N. Boylston’s Will.— There is also an account to be rendered to the judge of probate at Boston, for the settlement of the claim ofFuller, administrator of Moses Gill on the Administration de bonis non, with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston; and a proposal from the purchasers of the Tremont theatre to be considered— My Son went to Boston and returned to dine— After dinner, I rode with Mrs Charles and Arthur round the Braintree Meeting house square, leaving Miss Welsh at Mr John Greenleaf’s and taking her up as we returned. In the ride, I observed that the red Cedar trees have shared the fate of the button wood or Sycamores— They are all dying, and no one knows why— Multitudes of my Peach trees, are in the same condition. But what annoys me still more is the habit I am forming of wasting time on morning Newspapers—Garden, Nursery and Seminary forenoon visits; and siesta’s followed by an after dinner ride, and do nothing evenings This mode of life palsies the whole day—leaving me scarcely the two hours for the journal record, and one more for reading of Machiavel, and Ignatius Loyola—or to notice the Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Third Series. Vol. 6— Captain John Underhill’s History of the Pequot War. p 1–28. P. Vincents History of the Pequot War. p. 29 44 Sir Ferdinando Gorges’s description of New-England p. 45–94. Captain John Smith’s Description of New-England p. 95–140. Revd. Samuel Niles’s History of the Indian and French Wars p. 154–279. (unfinished) See the notice of this work, in the Letter from my father to judge William Tudor of 23 September 1818

properties.dateline: Quincy— Saturday 10 June 1843. Boston. Medford. Quincy.
properties.text: 10. IV. Saturday  Showery Night. Thick fog this morning, and Summer heat. After some hesitation I concluded to go— Rode to Boston with my Son, and Harriet Welsh, who is copying my Discourse on the New England confederacy of 1643. At my Son’s Office I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis and two of the members of the Church, purchasers of the Tremont theatre— The land on which the theatre stands was sold to its proprietors by Ward Nicholas Boylston, and it was part of the land on which the Boylston house was built fronting on school Street. The theatre fronts on Tremont Street and the portion of the lot sold by Mr Boylston was the back garden of the Boylston house. The present purchasers of the Theatre want a small additional grant for completing a passage way through from Tremont Street which they propose to purchase or to exchange for a four foot passage way opening upon School Street, no longer of use to them— We all went upon the ground and examined the premises— Several questions arose about the precise title and bounds of Mr Boylston. and of his conveyance to the proprietors of the theatre, which I thought required an examination of all the title deeds— Mr. Curtis undertook to look them up, and to answer the Committee men from the Church.— I found on looking over my file of papers relating to the demand by Petty Vaughan for a bond of indemnity, that the bond proposed by him was not among them, so that a further search for it must be made: and I am also to state an account for the judge of probate, to close the administration of Thomas Boylston Estate— This business being thus disposed of for the present, I concluded to leave the carriage at Boston and go to Medford by the Lowell railway cars— The Sun was out with scorching summer heat, and in walking to the depot, immediately after another half hour’s walk, I flushed my face almost into a fever— In 15 minutes we were at Medford, and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s with the members of the agricultural Society— While we were at dinner there was a gathering of thunder showers, which hastened us to the depot to which we were taken by Mr Brooks’s carriage at 6 O’Clock— There we waited till ten minutes before 7. when the Cars from Lowell half an hour belated took us up, and in fifteen minutes landed us at the depot in Boston. Benjamin the Coachman was there waiting for us with the Carriage and took us home to Quincy; through threatened thunder showers all the way, but only one slight sprinkling of rain— There was a drenching shower half an hour after we got home— Charles was quite unwell the whole day.
