Benjamin the Coachman was there waiting for us with the Carriage and took us home to Quincy; through threatened thunder showers all the way, but only one slight sprinkling of rain— There was a drenching shower half an hour after we got home— Charles was quite unwell the whole day.

properties.dateline: Quincy— Saturday 10 June 1843. Boston. Medford. Quincy.
properties.text: 10. IV. Saturday  Showery Night. Thick fog this morning, and Summer heat. After some hesitation I concluded to go— Rode to Boston with my Son, and Harriet Welsh, who is copying my Discourse on the New England confederacy of 1643. At my Son’s Office I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis and two of the members of the Church, purchasers of the Tremont theatre— The land on which the theatre stands was sold to its proprietors by Ward Nicholas Boylston, and it was part of the land on which the Boylston house was built fronting on school Street. The theatre fronts on Tremont Street and the portion of the lot sold by Mr Boylston was the back garden of the Boylston house. The present purchasers of the Theatre want a small additional grant for completing a passage way through from Tremont Street which they propose to purchase or to exchange for a four foot passage way opening upon School Street, no longer of use to them— We all went upon the ground and examined the premises— Several questions arose about the precise title and bounds of Mr Boylston. and of his conveyance to the proprietors of the theatre, which I thought required an examination of all the title deeds— Mr. Curtis undertook to look them up, and to answer the Committee men from the Church.— I found on looking over my file of papers relating to the demand by Petty Vaughan for a bond of indemnity, that the bond proposed by him was not among them, so that a further search for it must be made: and I am also to state an account for the judge of probate, to close the administration of Thomas Boylston Estate— This business being thus disposed of for the present, I concluded to leave the carriage at Boston and go to Medford by the Lowell railway cars— The Sun was out with scorching summer heat, and in walking to the depot, immediately after another half hour’s walk, I flushed my face almost into a fever— In 15 minutes we were at Medford, and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s with the members of the agricultural Society— While we were at dinner there was a gathering of thunder showers, which hastened us to the depot to which we were taken by Mr Brooks’s carriage at 6 O’Clock— There we waited till ten minutes before 7. when the Cars from Lowell half an hour belated took us up, and in fifteen minutes landed us at the depot in Boston. Benjamin the Coachman was there waiting for us with the Carriage and took us home to Quincy; through threatened thunder showers all the way, but only one slight sprinkling of rain— There was a drenching shower half an hour after we got home— Charles was quite unwell the whole day.

11. IV. Sunday—  The night was so warm, and finding the thermometer in my study at 70 with a thick fog, and a South wind, I invested myself in summer garments, and threw open my windows. But before I was called to breakfast the wind wheeled round to the Northeast the fog resolved itself into a heavy rain, and I resumed my broad cloth velvet and flannel cloathing— The rain continued so that I went morning and afternoon to Meeting in the Carriage, but in the afternoon I walked home Mr Lunt preached, in the forenoon, from 1. Peter 5.7. “Casting all your care upon him; for he careth for you.” The Doctrine of a special Providence seems to be congenial to that of guardian Angels; of Cherubim and Seraphim, and an innumerable company of Angels and Archangels— Ministering Spirits, intimated somewhat obscurely in all parts of the Scriptures, and blended with that of evil Spirits, the theory of which is organized by the poetical imagination of John Milton, so that my old Law master Theophilus Parsons used to say that he considered the Paradise lost, as a narrative of facts of equal authenticity with the Bible— But then if the universal cause, acts not by partial but by general Laws, in what sense can God be said to care for individuals? The argument of Mr Lunts sermon was to urge from considerations of fitness the probable conjecture of a protecting Providence, which is scarcely reconcileable with the existence of evil— To this belief of a special protecting Providence, that of retribution in a future world is indispensable— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text was from Matthew 13.31. “Another parable put he forth unto them saying, The kingdom of Heaven is like to a grain of mustard-seed, which a man took and sowed in his field: 32 which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.” In this chapter it seems as if Jesus felt it necessary to guard against the imputation of revolutionary designs in his ministry— He speaks of the kingdom of Heaven, in eight several parables in complex imagery, which even his hearers did not understand— He likens his doctrines to seeds and plants, with various results, and in one instance explains his meaning— His object in this parable is to admonish his disciples that they must not judge of the results of his husbandry from the smallness of the seed sown by him. It was perhaps necessary to convey these ideas in figurative language, to disarm the jealously both of the Jewish and of the Roman Institutions which were to be subverted and demolished by the kingdom of Heaven— But I can pursue these subjects no further. I finished reading the article in the Edinburgh Review upon Ignatius Loyola and his Associates, a bloated caricature portraiture of the men, but giving no idea of the Institution.

12. IV. Monday  Sun rose 4.22. Solstice yesterday.  So says the American Almanac of this year. The Massachusetts Register of the present year marks the Sun rise of this day at 4.28. and the first of the solstice to morrow or the day after— The Solstice of the American Almanac, begins on the 11th. and ends on the 19th.—9 days at 4.22.— The Solstice of the Massachusetts Register begins on the 14th. and ends on the 28th. 15 days at 4.27.— Both Calendars differ from themselves in other years— I saw the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house and found he had reached the extreme of his Northern declination as I had observed in June 1839. since which I have passed every month of June till this year at Washington— Passed Midshipman J. Q. Adams was here this morning to take leave—ordered to join the Sloop of War Decatur now at Norfolk, Virginia, under orders for the Coast of Africa, part of the Treaty Squadron of eighty guns— He is appointed sailing master of the Decatur— He was here again in the evening with his mother; and his Sister Elizabeth, and is to depart to-morrow— Charles Faxon a Tax collector of the town of Braintree, brought me a highway tax-bill of 1 dollar 96 cents which I paid, and Samuel White for my subscription of 10 dollars for the sufferers by the late fire of the Faxon and other houses— Mr Lanman a son of the late U.S. Senator from Connecticut Samuel Lanman, with Dr and Mrs Coit, Mrs and Miss Hubbard and a small child, all from Connecticut were here this afternoon about 5. minutes; for the single purpose of seeing and speaking to me— I fear they thought my reception of them cold— I rode with Mrs Charles over Milton hill— I answered a Letter from William Pitt Fessenden, a member of the last Congress from Portland Maine, who has been charged in an abolitionist address to the people of that State, with lukewarmness in the support of the right of petition. He wrote to me requesting my testimony, as to his course in the house on this subject. I have given him my testimony— The abolitionist charges against him are unjust—but zeal in support of the right of petition can do nothing in the Congress of the United States— I wrote this answer with great difficulty, much hesitation, and not a little imprudence in lifting up one corner of the curtain which covers the hideous reality of the Slave ascendancy in the Government of this Union— The double representation of the Slave owners in the House of Representatives and in the electoral colleges for the choice of President and Vice-President.— Semper ego auditor tantum?

13. IV:15 Tuesday.  My Son went to Boston, and returned to dinner; suffering with a severe cold and cough. The spell of idleness is yet upon me, and I have no hope of emerging from it— To answer Mr Fessenden’s Letter, I wanted the Journal of the U.S. House of Representatives for the second Session of the 27th. Congress; which was in the chest, which was sent round by water from Washington, and has at last arrived— I opened the chest to find the book, and with it found an enormous budget of Documents and pamphlets to be filed, assorted and bound—which took me not less than three hours to put into complete disorder— I went to the Bank and made a deposite there, but could not reach it before the Noon day bell had rung, when the morning business of the Bank is closed and the doors are shut— But the Cashier Bartlett’s Son came and received my deposit and balanced my book. The grass in my front yard and seminary was mowed— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, and after dinner I rode with her, and Mrs Charles and Arthur over Milton hill and bridge to Dorchester, returning by the upper bridge over the Neponset stream— Nicholas Machiavel, and Ignatius Loyola have fallen into a Mesmeric sleep, but I received this morning a Letter from Asa Walker and two others a Committee of Correspondence for a public meeting of the citizens of Bangor and vicinity, holden on the 27th. of last month, and at which a Resolution was adopted to observe the first of next August as the Anniversary of West India emancipation, by a public address and other suitable exercises—and the committee appointed to carry the resolution into execution, invite me to deliver the address— The temptation is almost irresistible, but must be resisted— My time is not yet come— How shall I answer this Letter? The same question is of more than daily recurrence. I have for example an invitation dated the 19th. of April from a Committee of the Directors of the Bunker hill monument association, to unite with them in celebrating the completion of that monument, by a civic and military procession, and an Address, by the Hon Daniel Webster— Upon this pageant has been engrafted another to bedaub with glory John Tyler the Slave-breeder, who is coming with all his Court in gaudy trappings of mock-royalty to receive the homage of hungry Sycophants under colour of doing homage to the principles of Bunker hill martyrdom. I answered this invitation, declining to attend, with a struggle between inclination and decorum, to suppress the most imperative motive for my absence, the disdain to be associated with the mouth worship of Liberty from the lips of the Slave-breeder. I succeeded but indifferently in veiling my emotions, and touched upon the martyrdom of Bunker hill only by transparent generalities, which will yet provoke censure.

14. IV. Wednesday  Alonzo Taft came this morning and enquired what had been done with a claim for reimbursement of money paid by him for his passage home from Gibraltar in 1825. when he had been discharged by Commodore Rogers from the Squadron commanded by him without provision for his passage to this Country— He reminded me that nearly two years since he had applied to me concerning this claim— That I had advised him to make a written statement of it fortified with his own affidavit, and such other testimony to the facts as he could procure, and send these papers to me, and I would attend to the claim at Washington. He said he had accordingly made the statement in writing and sworn to it— Had obtained the deposition of another man, and sent all the papers to me here at Quincy, since which he had not heard from me concerning his claim.— The whole subject had totally vanished from my Memory—and after a search of at least four hours I found only the entry in my diary of 7. October 1841. confirming the fact that he did apply to me on that day, and that I gave him the advice precisely as now represented by him— But neither in my diary, nor in my voluminous files of papers can I find a trace of the papers which he says he sent to me, or that I ever received them— I believe I never did— This incident admonishes me that my minutes for remembrance of all the claims to which my attention is due have been sadly deficient in system— Is it too late to improve it?— I received an invitation from Joseph T. Buckingham and 8 others Committee of Arrangements for the Directors of the Bunker hill monument association, to dine at Faneuil Hall on the 17th. and a Card of invitation from the city Council—to a dinner at the Tremont House to be given to the President of the United States on the 15th Friday both of which invitations I declined— I rode to Mount Wollaston this afternoon with Mrs Charles and her three younger sons Charles, Henry and Arthur— From the beach below the mount there is a full view of the Bunker hill column from top to bottom— The Revd. Charles Spear, an itinerant Universalist Minister came and sold me for a dollar, as a gift of friendship a duodecimo volume, of his composition on the names and titles of the Lord Jesus Christ—the fourteenth edition— He spoke of his poverty—of his self education of his pulmonary complaints which interdicted him from preaching; and intending a voyage to England where one edition of his work has been printed, he inquired with some solicitude whether it was held in Europe discreditable to an author to sell his own works— He said he was now preparing a great work on capital punishment— Miss Sampson is here working at her profession. I received a Letter of the 10th. from my wife—

15. III.20. Thursday— Sun rose 4:22.— Set 7:38. Or 4:27— 7.33  The first is by the rule of the American Almanac—counting from the first beam of the rising to the last of the setting Sun— The Massachusetts Register computes only the time when the whole disk is above the horizon; and there is a difference of 1 minute and 40 seconds between each of the two computations, allowing 3 minutes and 20 seconds for the rising, and the same for the setting of the disk— I was going to the gate for the afternoon ride in the carriage with Mrs Charles when Coll William H. Freeman came and detained me at home. He informed me that he is to be tried by a Court martial in about 3 weeks at Middletown in the State of Connecticut; upon a charge of scandalous conduct unbecoming an Officer and a gentleman; and the specification is for treating contemptuously his superior by a paragraph, in a Letter to the Secretary of the Navy— He read to me the Letter containing the obnoxious passage, and the Letter from the Secretary of the Navy informing him that he had determined to bring him to trial: and the Coll. asked me if I would assist him as his Counsel— I answered that I earnestly desired to do any thing in my power to befriend him— But that I had never practiced as an advocate before Courts Martial— Had long since ceased to practice in the Courts of civil jurisdiction, and apprehended I was not competent to do justice to his cause as his advocate— Besides which there might be doubts of the propriety of my appearing in that capacity— He did not press his request, but said he should want my testimony— I said I would cheerfully give that if it should be necessary for him, either by a deposition before the judge of the United States judge of the District Court at Boston or by attending in person before the Court martial at Middletown— He intimated his intention to apply to Mr Choate the Senator from this State in Congress to be his Counsel; and I thought he could not do better. Mr Armstrong came to invite me to go to his house on Saturday after the return procession from Bunker’s hill, and before that from the State house to the dinner at Faneuil Hall— I thanked him for his kindness, but I told him I did not propose to be present at any part of the celebrations of that day. The political device of turning the Bunker-hill monument address into a sycophantic tribute of homage to John Tyler is Webster’s, and Boston is of all the Cities in the world the spot to play it off to the greatest advantage— I saw the sun rise and set from Charles’s house. It rose clear and the day was fine the Sun had just reached the border of the western horizon, clear when a dark cloud came over the disk as it was descending and eclipsed his upper limb.

16. III.45. Friday.  Sun rose 4.22.— Set 7:38.  The Sun rose not quite clear but sufficiently so to mark the point of the horizon at which the first beam emerges, or rather at which the revolving orb of Earth brings him above the surface— I took an hour of exercise with my knife and handsaw, and examining my seminary seedling trees— The hay from the enclosure, mowed last Tuesday, was got into the barn just in time to save it from the heavy rain for which the clouds had been gathering all the morning and which continued till about 3 in the afternoon, when it held up, without clearing off: Charles went to Boston with his daughter Louisa Catherine, and returned to dine— This was the of the reception of the President of the United States by the city of Boston. He comes with his cabinet and a ridiculous parade of ostentation to attend the celebration of the completion of the Bunker hill monument; a costly pageant first got up by Joseph Tinker Buckingham President of the Bunker-hill Monument association and Editor of the Boston Courier, the most respectable of Websters Trumpeters— The corner stone of the monument was laid by La Fayette on the 17th of June 1825—on which occasion delivered an elegant Discourse— He is to deliver another— The object now is to glorify him— A formal invitation was sent to him last fall immediately after the completion of the monument inviting him to the performance of this service, which he then accepted; and the invitation and acceptance were published in newspapers all over the country— The invitation to the President and his Cabinet to attend is a political device of Webster’s own—a gull-trap for popularity—both for himself and for Tyler, by which he hopes to whistle back his whig friends whom he had cast off as a huntsman his pack, and who now threaten to hunt him like the hounds of Acteon— The reception of the President this day had all the appearances of cordiality, not withstanding a drenching rain to cool it— He is lodged at the Tremont house at an enormous expense to the city; was entertained there with a sumptuous dinner, by the City Council, and went to the theatre and to an evening party at the Postmaster Gordon’s house— I was invited to the dinner, but sent an excuse— Spent the day quietly at my house, writing to my wife and filing and assorting letters and papers, and making little progress even in disorder— Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society Third Series. Vol 7—published in 1838. Account of the Massachusetts historical Society, by Revd William Jenks D.D. p. 5–26. Post-Office Department 48–90. Model of Christian Charity by Governor Winthrop. p. 31–47.— D’Aulney and La Tour p. 90–121. Instructions to Randolph p. 129–138 Commission to Sir Edmund Andros p. 139–149 Papers relating to his Administration 150–195. Higginson Letters. 196–221. Colonel Quarrys memorial p. 222–242. List of Portraits in the Hall of the Historical Society p. 285–291. I am projecting remarks upon the majority and minority reports on the treatment of coloured Seamen in the Southern ports—

17. IV. Saturday.  Sun rose 4.22. Set 7:39.  This was the day of the great celebration of the completion of the monument on Bunker hill; and never since the existence of the three hills was there such a concourse of strangers upon their sides as has been assembled on the banks of “Majestic Charles” this day— What a name in the annals of mankind is Bunker hill?— What a day, was the 17th. of June 1775? and what a burlesque upon them both is an oration upon them by Daniel Webster, and a pilgrimage of John Tyler and his Cabinet of Slave-drivers, to desecrate the solemnity by their presence! And then a dinner at Faneuil Hall in honour of a President of the United States hated and despised by those who invited him to it, themselves as cordially hated and despised by him. I have throughout my life had an utter aversion to all pageants, and public dinners, and never attended one, when I could decently avoid it— I was a student at Cambridge when on the 17th. of June 1786. Charles river bridge was opened— The colleges were emptied on that day of the Students who flocked to witness the procession and the pageant— I passed the day in the solitude of my Study, and dined almost alone in the Hall. I had then no special motive for my absence— But now with the ideal association of the thundering cannon which I heard and the smoke of burning Charlestown which I saw on that awful day, combined with this Pyramid of Quincy granite, and Daniel Webster spouting with a negro holding an umbrella over his head, and John Tyler’s nose with a shadow outstreching that of the monumental column; how could I have witnessed all this at once without an unbecoming burst of indignation or of laughter? Daniel Webster is a heartless traitor to the cause of human freedom. John Tyler is a Slave-monger—what have these to do with the Quincy granite pyramid on the brow of Bunker’s hill?— What have these to do, with a dinner in Faneuil hall, but to swill like swine and grunt about the rights of man?— I stayed at home and visited my seedling trees; and heard the cannonades of the rising, the meridian and the setting Sun—and answered a Letter from the Revd. Joseph Emerson dated at New-London Connecticut making enquiries about a translation of Voltaire’s philosophical dictionary, published under the name of John Quincy Adams, and secretly circulating as he says, about the country, as my work— I saw the Sun set from the front of Charles’s house, at the extremity of his northwestern declination, and as I heard the cannonade salute of the closing day, and saw the smoke ascending from the side of the pyramid, the top of which was full in view; then came in forcible impulse to my memory the cannonade, and the smoke and the fire of the 17th. of June 1775— I waited to see the revolving fire of the Boston Light house kindled, and then returned to my peaceful home

18. IV. Sunday.  Sun rose 4.22. Set 7.39.  The Revd. Benjamin Kent now keeper of a school for girls at Roxbury preached for Mr Lunt this morning with a double text. Romans 7:24. “O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?” and Philippians 4.13. “I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.” The doctrine of the discourse was that the will of a perfect Christian fortified by conscience is omnipotent. That nothing is impossible for it to atchieve; and to elucidate the principle, he presented a parallel between these two passages from the writings of St Paul first in the epistle to the Romans in the agonies of despair and then four years later to the Philippians in the exultation of a glorious victory and triumph by the strength of Christ assisting him— The first written in the midst of the terrible struggle of his conversion, and while he was yet uncertain of its success. The last was written after his conversion was consummated, and his confidence in himself with the strength imparted to him by Christ his lord and master was unbounded. Upon this theme Mr Kent amplified and dilated until he reminded me of the story which I once heard Dr Franklin tell of a convent of monks who had a very inconvenient hill in front of their monastery, and upon their faith like a grain of mustard seeds being sufficient cast the mountain into the sea, set up a general onset of prayer to remove the mountain, which they perseveringly pursued till tired of the obstinate adherence of the mountain to its place one of the friars gave out that there was a mistake in the translation of the text, and that the true reading should be that with faith like a mountain it is possible to move a mustard seed— Mr Kent and Mr Lunt dined with us— They were both at the Bunker-hill celebration yesterday; which went off admirably well. Webster’s Oration was brilliant and eminently successful. Two hours and seven minutes— Suitable to the occasion, and often rapturously cheered— The dinner at Faneuil hall was also very well ordered and passed off agreeably.— The cheering of Webster was hearty and general—that of the President feeble and cold— Mr Kents text this afternoon was from Proverbs 16.32. “He that ruleth his spirit is better than he that taketh a city.” The Sermon was supplementary to that of the morning, upon the extreme importance and excellence of the faculty of self-controul Mr Lunt gave notice that the Revd. John Gregory would deliver at 5 O’Clock this afternoon a Temperance Lecture and Mr B. O. Tyler would exhibit his design for a family temperance pledge— Some incident already forgotten turned my attention lately to an enquiry into the scriptural notices of Angels, and I looked into Basnage’s history of the Jews—Book 4. chapters 9 and 10. where I found more than I looked for, and more than was very agreeable.

19. III.30. Monday.  Sun rose 4.22 clear— Set 7.39—  Visitors must account for the idleness of this day— I rose with a dull head ache; and the exercise of the morning consisted in sawing and whittling sticks for stakes. Two brothers named Adams, William van Bergen and Herman C. inhabitants of Coxakie and of Athens in the County of Green, and State of New-York on Hudson river, came and introduced themselves to me— They came from home to attend the Bunker hill celebration, and took the occasion to visit me, and to make some enquiries concerning their own lineage— Their grandfather Joshua Adams removed about eighty years ago, from Turkey Hill, in Hingham, to Egremont, whence their father some years after emigrated to the place where they now reside— There he settled as a practising physician, raised a family of children and died— They wished to know whether Joshua was a descendant from the Patriarch Henry, but I rather thought he was not— The passed an hour with me in conversation chiefly about the family, and after, they went away— Herman C. returned, and said he had a son, to whom he had given my name, about 7 years old, and he requested me to write a few lines of advice that he might keep as an autograph; and I promised that I would— Mr Stow is recorder of the City of Buffalo, in the State of New York He brought me recommendatory Letters from Millard Fillmore and from Genl. Peter B. Porter—the latter very kindly urging me to pay them a visit in that neighbourhood: to which Mr Stow added his own very friendly solicitations— I do not deceive myself by mistaking this earnest desire to hear me for any thing more than mere curiosity—but it is friendly, and claims my gratitude— I believe there is not a man in the world more unfit for self-exhibition at public meetings and banquet dinners— When I go to them it is with feelings of a culprit to punishment than of a victor to triumph— I told Mr Stow that I could not indulge the hope of ever meeting in public the people of buffalo, but should be ever grateful for their kindness and would pray for their prosperity. Mr William Cost Johnson paid me also a visit, with a Mr Chapman—a stranger. Mr Johnson came to witness the Bunker hill monument celebration, and leaves Boston to morrow Morning, returning to Washington— Miss Anna Henshaw with her brother Samuel came this afternoon, on a visit to Mrs Charles, and Mr Tyler to shew me the portrait of my great-grandfather John Quincy at two years of age, painted in 1691 and now refreshed with a coat of his varnish— I rode in the Carriage with Mrs Charles to Mount Woolaston, stopping at Mrs T. B. Adams’s to leave a Letter to her from her son Isaac Hull.

20. III.30 Tuesday.  Sun rose 4.23. Set 7:40.  Computation of the American Almanac exhibiting one minute of southern declination for the rising Sun, and one minute of continuing Northern declination for the setting sun— The length of the day remains 15 hours 17 minutes: the longest of the year. Another day absorbed by visitors— Charles went to Boston with his daughter, and returned to dine.— He brought the account of the decease this morning between 5 and 6. O’Clock of Hugh S. Legaré of South Carolina, Attorney General of the United States, and acting Secretary of State— He died at the house of his friend Mr George Ticknor, to which he had been removed the day before from his lodgings at the Tremont house— He had been invited as a member of the Presidents cabinet to the monumental celebration— The duties of his two departments prevented him from accompanying the President on his journey; but he left Washington so as to reach the Tremont house on Friday and was present at the dinner given to the President by the City Council at that house on that day— He was then much indisposed and the next day so ill, that he was unable to attend the celebration at the hill. His disease which was bilious colic continued increasing in violence, and inaccessible to all medical treatment till he expired. He was an able, and a very amiable man—by far the best of the Presidents present associates— Just as I was called to dinner, came in Doctor Goodale, a stranger from the Western part of the State of New York— He introduced himself, and asked numerous questions of whig politics, and particularly concerning the prospects of John Tyler at the next Presidential Election— There is no doubt he believes this idle pageant and personal courtesy will draw upon him over powering popularity— The experiment has in part succeeded, and its total failure is certainly not yet demonstrated. He visited Lowell yesterday, with a numerous train and was received with tolerable cordiality— Mr Alexander Marsh came to make enquiries about the family of that name— His father named Esek Marsh went from this town some seventy years ago, and took with him this person then a boy who seems to have had no communication with this town or with his relatives left here— I referred him to the two brothers residing between this and the Stone temple; but he appeared not satisfied with that, and inquired if I knew any thing of a family here by the name of Hamilton— Mr Edward A Newton of Pittsfield, and Mrs Newton paid us an afternoon visit. She is a daughter of my old friend the late Dudley Atkins Tyng, but I had never seen her before— There very urgent in the invitation of me to the agricultural anniversary at Pittsfield next October— Ride after they were gone with Mrs Charles and the baby to Milton.

21. III.40. Wednesday.  Sun rose 4.23. Set 7:40.— Day 15 h. 17 m  I saw the Sun rise and set—still at the solstice; clear the whole day, and the first unequivocal summer day we have had this Season. As I have given up almost entirely the exercise of walking, and believing as I do that strenuous exercise of the body is yet a necessary of life to me, I am devoting two hours of the morning, immediately after sunrise to labour for my seedling trees. I am ashamed that after fifteen years search for the secret of raising trees from the seed, I am as ignorant of it as before I began— I now despair of producing any useful result from my labours in this respect. But I have many trees at different stages of their growth, which I may cherish into useful trees. My most successful experiments have been in manuring the ground where the seeds are planted; and I am about to resume that occupation with another, sawing and cutting twigs for stakes. This is hard work and squeezes perspiration out of the skin, as from the peel of an Orange— It is wasted time but necessary exercise— Elizabeth C. Adams was here after breakfast, and then Deacon Spear, who proposed to me to visit my woodlots, adjoining to which Daniel Baxter has purchased a lot which did belong to the late Ebenezer Adams— I referred Deacon Spear to my Son to fix a day when we should all go and make this survey, and discuss vicinage with Mr Baxter— After dinner I was visited by the Revd Benjamin Kent, and his brother in Law, Mr Bradford who has resided some years in China, whence he returned about two years since— Mr Kent had mentioned to me, sundry relics from the combustion of Miles Standish’s house in Duxbury—an old rusty hinge and door latch—a piece of the floor burnt to charcoal a small fragment from what he thought a pane of painted glass— All which he dug out from the ruins of the house, for which he dug more than a century after it was burnt and found fifteen feet under the surface. He had also a small viol full of char’d wheat seeds of which he found a bushel at the same search— He gave me these relics, and left with me to examine it, a large volume with antient manuscript deeds and Letters, and three or four volumes of manuscript Sermons among which one volume containing several Sermons as early as 1680 by my great grandmother Quincy’s father John Norton Minister at Hingham— Mr Legare’s funeral took place at 10 this morning at Trinity Church; under which his body is deposited—and at 4 O’Clock this afternoon Mr John Tyler self Styled President of the United States with his Cabinet took the Cars of the Norwich Rail-road on their return to Washington—

22. III.30. Thursday. Sun rose 4.23. Set 7.40  A cloudless day of oppressive Summer heat. Two hours of the morning wasted in idle labour to keep alive the scanty remnant of my seedling trees— Nine tenths of the seeds that I have sown, have failed to come up, or perished— Of the remaining tenth—two thirds have been taken up and transplanted to my Sons grounds, or to those of Mr Robinson the Episcopal Minister— My record which I have kept from year to year of almost all my plantations, has fallen into inextricable confusion, from its very minuteness— Four fifths of the cherished seeds which came up and flourished for a time have withered and been extirpated so long that I have lost even the memory; while the Nursery gardens and Seminary, are now overstocked with seedlings which choak one another. I have trees now. Oaks, Apples, Shagbarks, pignuts, Ash, Maple and Cherry which will outlive centuries, unless cut down, uprooted or blasted by lightnings I take pleasure in watching their growth, and in the thought of leaving them to grow till my grand children shall remember me in finding shelter and shade under them. But I have never been able to impart my marotte to any one of them. If I could I have no doubt that my successor would have improved the art of planting and the Science of dendrology— Among the rest he would have discovered the folly of wasting time upon the cultivation of trees not suited to the climate—Apricots, Nectarines, Cork, Willow and live Oaks: and he would have found the art of cultivating pears, plums, and cherries in perfection which I have sought in vain— My Philadelphia Seminary maple, seed sown 1. June 1835 measures now 19 inches round the trunk, and is about 25 feet high— Shoots are putting out from the stems of seedling English Oaks of the third year, crop’d by the Scythe of the Mower in the Seminary, on the 13th. Mr Francis Tookey is a student at the Law School in Cambridge having been there one year and nine months, and has three months more to finish his term— He says he visited me, once before in 1838. of which I had no recollection— He asked me for an autograph, and I gave him my sign manual, on a small card engraving of Durand’s portrait— Mr Enoch Hunt was here towards evening when I was reading on the Settee in front of the house— He said he thought I should not be able to bear the fatigues of the next Session of Congress. Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society. Third Series Vol 8. 1843. Extract from the Chronicle of Bernaldez p. 5–69. Bartholomew Gosnold’s Letter to his father 1602. p. 70. Archer’s Account of Gosnold’s Voyage p. 72–82 Brereton’s Account of Gosnold’s Voyage p. 83–93 Tracts appended to Brereton p. 94–124. Rosiers account of Waymouth’s 1605 p. 125 Levett’s Voyage 1623 p 125. Savage Gleanings for New-England history— p. 243.

23. III.40. Friday.  Sun rose 4.23. Set 7.40 beclouded—  The declination of the Sun Southward is already perceptible since Tuesday last both morning and evening, though not marked in the American Almanac. I took off a limb from the black willow South of the bridge over the brook in the lane between my house and Charles’s and slip’d from it several twigs which I stuck down as stakes, to ascertain whether any of them will take root. This experiment I have heretofore made with full success both with willows, and button woods.— But the button woods and red Cedars are now perishing all over the Country no one knows why or from what cause— I had a new hinge put on to a tool shed in the garden, which was there in my fathers time, and kept the tools— The lower hinge of the shed door was broken I believe when I came into possession—the door could not be closed and a spade and two hoes have disappeared— It is close to a spot which I have found favourable for raising delicate seedlings the first and second years till they are fit for transplantation. I began the manuring of my plats. My Seminary teems with apple seedlings from two six feet high, pushing up their plumelets with unusual rapidity, but meeting with two enemies: the aphis, and a green maggot worm which arrest their growth. There are three black walnuts in the seminary, one in the garden, and one in the Nursery, growing all with the same rank luxuriance but for which I dread the trial of the winter— The two Pennsylvania shagbarks in the Garden have to undergo the same ordeal— The budded cherry leaves are covered with rusty spots, and every cherry has an ugly speck upon it. The wild cherry’s swarm this year— Mr Curtis came this morning, with a plan of the house in School Street, of the Estate of Ward N. Boylston, and the adjoining Tremont Theatre lot with the boundary title deeds— He inclined to cede to the purchasers of the Tremont Theatre a strip ten feet wide, across the Eastern end of the lot, as an equivalent for their surrender of a five feet passage way and the use of a pump and well.— I approved and promised my assent to this arrangement— Charles went to Boston with his daughter and returned to dine— He brought me the manuscript copy of my Discourse on the New England confederacy which Harriet Welsh had undertaken but some one else has completed— Fahrenheit till noon this day was at 84 in my chamber— Then came a cooling eastern breeze and in two hours the thermometer was down to 72. The evening was rather more than cool. Mrs Henshaw and her son Samuel came out and took tea here. After which I rode with Mrs Charles to the Saltwork beach behind President Quincy’s deserted house. Elizabeth C. Adams was here this Evening. I revised in part the copy of my discourse.

24 III.45. Saturday.  Sun rose 4.23. Set 7:40. Last of the Solstice  After an abridged excursion to see the rising Sun, and to visit and study my seedling plants and listen to the matinal minstrelsy of the bobalink, the spring-bird and the robin, with the chirping of the sparrow, and the new whistle of the quail, I think all the aerial music of this time and place, I returned to my library chamber, and revised the copy of my Discourse on the New-England confederacy of 1643, furnished me by Harriett Welsh, and which I made up and despatched by the mail to James Savage, President of the Massachusetts Historical Society, at Boston— In revising this Discourse I had the opportunity of examining it with cooler judgment than I had while composing it.— I was then somewhat disqualified by the hurry, agitation, and severe disposition under which I was labouring: with a keen apprehension, that my Catarrh would disable me from delivering it, and extreme anxiety that it would if delivered be tedious and dull to the auditory— It was on the contrary happily delivered, and with as much favour from the auditory as I could have expected or ought to have desired— It is now a historical document, and a political disquisition; to be published by the Massachusetts Historical Society, and will pass to posterity as one of my contributions to the labours of that Institution.— I would it were wiser—more philosophical—more profound— I would the faculty had been conferred upon me to enlighten my brethren of the human race; to improve their condition upon earth—to rule them by the energies of the Soul— Perhaps one of the sins for which I may have to answer hereafter to answer is that of repining at the scantiness of the portion of intellect which I was endowed— The day differed from that of yesterday. A morning less intensely warm, but no east wind at noon to chill the atmosphere— I received a new packet of proposals for repairing the mill dam of the Columbian Mills, with a Letter from Mr Frye, which I immediately answered— I received also, nearly a fortnight since an invitation from Bangor an invitation to deliver an anniversary address there on the 1st. of August the day in 1838 of the total emancipation of the Slaves, in the British colonies of the West Indies— After much hesitation and deliberation I began this day an answer to this invitation: and I was occupied almost the whole afternoon in a fruitless search for the bond of indemnity to Petty Vaughan, which he requires that the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to execute before he will remit the monies held by him and belonging to the Estate. Mrs Charles rode without me to Weymouth— After Sunset there was a threat of a thunder gust and shower, which evaporated in wind, and a mere sprinkling of rain. The Atlas of this day says that Websters regret at my absence on the 17th. was not spoken.

25. IV. Sunday.  Sun rose 4.24— Set 7:40  Mr Lunt and his wife are gone upon an excursion into the State of New-York. The Revd. Dr Kendall of Plymouth preached here for him—in the morning from John 1.18. [“]No Man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the father, he hath declared him.” It was one of the sacred doctrines of the Jews that no man ever saw God or could see him and live— His voice was often heard, and his angels were often seen— He was made perceptible by fire, as to Moses in the burning bush; and to Elijah when carried up in a chariot of fire— Moses had the hardihood to ask to see him, and he passed before him so as to shew his hinder parts—but it was only a storm of wind— By the incarnation God was made manifest in the flesh; and here the Messiah, said to be in the bosom of the father, it is further said had declared him— Dr Kendall’s argument was that the gospel of Christ was the manifestation of God. I invited Dr Kendall to dine with us; but he asked to be excused He said he was turned of seventy and never dined between the services and that what he most needed was repose— But that he would cheerfully walk home with me after the second service—in which of course I acquiesced. After dinner, the text was from Hebrews 11.5. “By faith Enoch was translated that he should not see death: and was not found, because God had translated him: for before his translation he had this testimony, that he pleased God.” The story and character of Enoch are among the most mysterious parts of the Bible— Scarcely any thing is said of him in the old Testament, except that which is noted in this passage of the Epistle to the Hebrews— That he walked with God, and was not because God took him; Why he was so privileged we are not told—nor how he was thus removed from Earth, exempted from the common law of human nature to die. St. Paul says it was by Faith; and because he pleased God. I scarcely can tell by what process it was, that Dr Kendall made this text the theme for giving a brief historical statement of the ministers of the gospel who were settled in the old Plymouth Colony before the commencement of the present century—of whom only two or three still survive. He is himself the only one still in office as Pastor of a Church, and he has now a colleague settled with him— He paid a tribute of friendship and of honour to the memory of the late Senior pastor of the Quincy church, who died very suddenly on theoflast, and he spoke reverently of Dr Henry Ware whose Ordination as Minister of the first Church at Hingham I attended in September 1787. and who is yet living, emeritus professor of divinity at Harvard University. Dr Kendall came home with me after the second Service—and after walking up the hill to see the Sunset from the front of Charles’s house, parted from us in peace.

26. III.30. Monday  Sun rose 4.24. Set 7.40  I continue my morning exercise, and observe the mysteries of vegetation upon my seedling trees— Among them is the difference between the plants whose growth is continuous through the summer—those which have but one term of growth of a few weeks in the Spring; and those which have two— This difference is remarkable in the Oaks— The black having but one; and the red two six weeks growths in a summer— On the 13th. instt Dennis mowed the grass in the seminary, and cropped the stem of a third year seedling of an English white Oak in Mary-Louisa’s patch—a lateral shoot has put out from the mutilated stem and is now in the process of opening leaves— The same thing is happening to a second year seedling in the garden, which I accidentally cropped about the same time.— But the English white Oak seedlings of this Season have ceased to grow and the most thrifty of them is not more than 4 inches high. The Philadelphia maple continues to grow the whole summer One in the Seminary and one in the Garden from the seeds sown by me 1. June 1835 are 17 inches in circumference and 20 feet high— About noon I met Mr E. Price Greenleaf in the Garden and he inspected with me all my trees— He cautioned me against trimming the trees after the 22d. of June; and he brought to my notice the depredations upon all my trees of insects and worms almost numberless— The thriftiest of my apple trees, in its tenth year and already bearing has half a dozen Gimlet holes just above the ground pierced by the borer— Another 14 years old and bearing freely has a worm in every apple. The Caterpillar and the Canker are angels commissioned for destruction. The beetle or dorbug nips the shoot in its prime, and invisible thieves in the darkness of the night strip the Oaks of their tender leaves, and yield them up to withering decay— The drought, the flood, the frost, the Sun, the gale, the blight, the field mouse at the root and the green louse or aphis at the germ, form such a host of foes, that it is as hard to raise a tree as a child— Charles and his wife went this afternoon to Hingham in search of a School for their two eldest boys— I continued without finishing my answer to the invitation from Bangor to deliver there an Oration on the first of August in celebration of the emancipation of Slaves in the British West Indies— This answer will be instead of the oration itself; but it is already too long and must be much longer to be worthy of the theme. I shall probably not send it after all, but I feel an irremissible duty to bear my testimony once more, before I go hence against Slavery. To select the time, the place and the manner is a subject of great consideration and must be neither precipitated nor too long delayed— My ideas are yet crude indigested and confused. I will begin to collect and assort them in this Letter, with the firm resolve to persevere in the pursuit. I began also this afternoon to read Dr Henry Wares Inquiry into the foundation Evidences and Truth’s of Religion—of which he sent me last year a copy, the receipt of which I have not yet acknowledged.

27. III.15. Tuesday.  Sun rose 4:24. intercepted. Set 7:40 crystal clear.  My Marotte gives me abundant exercise for two hours of the morning, and my only apprehension now is of its encroaching on my hours of labour. I received this morning a Letter from my wife dated last Friday in which she informs me that her brother is better, and she proposes to leave Washington to morrow and expects to arrive here next Saturday. Charles and his wife had already concluded to go up the hill to their own house to morrow— Charles went to Boston with his daughter this morning and returned to dine. His wife took her two eldest boys this morning to Hingham, and left them at a boarding school kept by Mr and Mrs Wilder— Mrs Wilder is a daughter of Nehemiah Parsons, whose wife was the only daughter of the old and faithful friend of my childhood and youth John Thaxter— I walked this morning with my Sons third son, Henry Brooks, to his school Mrs.Their youngest boy Arthur, an uncommonly beautiful and forward child was born 23 July 1841— A Mr Mill, originally from New-Hampshire, now attached to a college or high school at Crawfordsville Indiana came in near our dinnertime, having walked this morning from Abington— Charles White, the President of the College, he says is a lineal descendent from Perigrine White, the first born of New-England— Mr Mill said their buildings had been burnt down, and he was travelling to solicit contributions for re building them— I invited him to dine with us; but he was afraid of losing the afternoon stage to Boston, and declined— He made several enquiries to know if the college could obtain a collection of the distributable public documents to supply the place of those which were consumed in the fire— He was also desirous of procuring a complete collection of the publications of the Massachusetts Historical Society— And he spoke of the Representatives from Indiana in the last Congress, and particularly of Mr Lane, who was no favourite politician to him— Elizabeth C. Adams was here this afternoon. So intense was the heat that my afternoon was lost in idleness— I resorted two or three times to my hard bed, but could neither sleep nor repose— I read two Chapters of Dr Ware’s Inquiry into the foundation, Evidences and Truths of Religion; but I could neither understand nor take interest in what I read. I was obliged to lay the book aside, and had no spirit or impulse to take up any other. I was not able to get through one page of my Letter to Bangor— As Sunset approached we all went up and saw it from the front of Charles’s house in cloudless splendor descend beneath the horizon— There was a refreshing breeze and we sat under the portico, till the town curfew bell of 9. sounded our retreat— In my concert of birds the other morning I forgot to mention the black-bird, blue-bird, and swallow, all of which join in the chorus.

28. IV— Wednesday  Sun rose 4.25. Set 7.40 both beclouded.  My morning exercise becomes tedious unless I fix my attention upon particular plants of which I have now a considerable number in the critical state of uncertainty between life and death— The summer house Apple tree, the growth of which has been so cheeringly rapid, is doomed to death by the borer worm— The tree in front of my study window, under the brow eastward of the old horse chesnut; after suffering from the Scythe in 1834. and the field mouse three or four years later has now a stock in circumference about the size of my thumb and six feet high; and if duly guarded from its foes will form a valuable tree— Upon almost every patch into which I gradually year by year since 1834 divided the seminary I have now growing young seedlings of different kinds together with others transplanted all with the intention of finishing by raising one tree on each patch.— On many of them I have peach trees some of which have borne, and others but last summer were of the fairest promise. They are now little better than totally destroyed— I shall be compelled to uproot them all.— I have very few pears, and not one of thrifty growth—few and very unpromising cherries— Three black walnuts, transplanted in 1840 from the garden, and now for the first time seeming likely to live— One solitary shagbark walnut first hopeful this year—perhaps 20 English white oaklings whose fate is dubious— One beautiful Apple tree now six feet high and a strait stem alongside of a stunted, transplanted but yet finely growing Philadelphia maple. The multitude of these trees furnishes me occupation for two hours every morning merely to look at them— The result of all my labours for the cultivation of trees from the seed will probably be lost; but if I could inoculate my son or one of my grandson with my own fancy for seedling trees he would raise the most magnificent forest and the most delicious orchard that ever was known in New England— Charles and his family removed this day, up the hill to his house, and Louisa C. Smith, came out from Boston by Gillet’s stage, to keep house for me till the arrival of my wife from Washington— This day was intensely hot; so that although I finished the record of yesterday before Noon I could accomplish nothing further for the remainder of the day. I attempted in vain to finish my Letter to Bangor, and was equally unsuccessful in attempting to make progress in reading Dr Henry Wares Inquiry. I find it however work of profound interest, and have determined if it please the great disposer to read it in the spirit of the Inquiry itself— As a subject which it is one of the great duties of my life to examine and to penetrate to the utmost extent of the capacity which God has given me

29. III.30 Thursday.  Sun rose 4.25. Set 7:40. Fahrenheit 92  I had sown in 1840 Apple and Pear seeds in a short row between the Eastern door and gale under an old Althaea tree which must soon be taken away.— They came up but have been cropped by the scythe every Spring with the grass, from which the mower could not discern them—when I came out here the middle of May I could not discover the trace of one of them in the grass— Yesterday I found three of them, with leaves put out since they were cut down—perhaps I may save one of them. I received a Letter from my wife of the 26th. last Monday advising me that she had postponed her journey home for a few days, her brother being again worse, and Mrs Frye threatened with a fever.— I went into Boston and attended the stated monthly meeting of the Massachusetts historical Society. Charles and his wife went in with me— The meeting of the Society was at Noon. Before going to it I paid a morning visit to Mr and Mrs Abbott Lawrence, whom I found in the bustle of packing up for a voyage to England— They are to embark in the Steamer Acadia, to sail next Saturday— The Voyage is for his health; and he says he proposes to return next October— While there he intends to sound the Peel ministers about a reciprocity Treaty; and to consult with Edward Everett but he is not reconciled to the projects or present policy of Daniel Webster, and he thinks Webster’s great device of bringing Tyler and his gang here as bobs to his Bunker hill monument kite a very small concern— I went with Charles to H. Wilson junr. a Taylor and ordered a light waistcoat and pantaloons for summer wear.— The persons above named with Charles and myself constituted the whole meeting— Several presents were received, and votes of thanks passed— My Letter to the President James Savage, with the copy of my discourse was read and placed on the files— The discourse itself he said was at the Printers, and he promised to direct that the proof sheets should be sent by the mail to me for revisal— I returned to Mr Felt the books which he had lent me— At one; the meeting adjourned and with Charles and his wife returned to our respective homes to dine— Their daughter Louisa Catherine, dined with Louisa C. Smith and me— In the afternoon there was a light shower merely of rain, but the heat before and after was totally disabling to read or write— I discovered broken ground on the seedling spot next to the kitchen— I went up the hill at Sunset which was deeply beclouded, and sat in the front of Charles’s house, with a fresh and delicious breeze till the bell at 9. called me home.

30. III.30. Friday.  Sun rose 4.26. Set 7.40.  My Morning exercise encroaches too much on my hours of labour; and rising as I do at half past 3 in the morning I am called to breakfast almost before I have seated myself at the table for daily writing— This morning I discovered three more cropped apple-seedlings, in the range between the Althaea and the old horse chesnut tree— One of the crops is a mere steminches high without the trace of a bud or leaf upon it— I shall try the experiment if they can be revived, and hoed up partially the grass around them, watered the ground about their roots and gave them some refreshment of manure.— The cropd oakling in Mary Louisa’s patch has put out a new stem and fair leaves, but the tender fresh leaves of that in the garden next the kitchen, as well as those of the shagbark, have had the borders of their leaves scorched to a black cinder by one day’s heat of the Sun. Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine. The morning set in at high summer heat, and I expected a roasting day, but by 10 O’Clock there came a soft eastern breeze, which without obscuring the Sun cooled the atmosphere to a delicious temperature, and left me full power to read or write without interruption— Yet I read only a few pages of Dr Ware’s Inquiry into the foundation, evidences and truths of Religion— He begins with the foundation of religion—that is he begins by stating the temper of mind in which the inquiry should be pursued— The first section of the introduction is an argument to prove that religion is an interesting subject of inquiry.— The second that there is no reason for entering on the inquiry with a wish to find its claims without foundation in truth— These are preliminaries— Now that religion is an interesting inquiry, no one will deny who is capable of making and pursuing the inquiry at all. The desire of continued existence is planted in the nature of man— The brute creation cling to life as tenaciously as man—more tenaciously—for they never commit voluntary suicide—but they have no conception of what death is or of a state of existence after death— Man learns by experience as a witness and by tradition what death is—he sees that it is the extinction of his being— He has hopes and desires but no evidence of continued existence after death— Dr Ware’s first chapter therefore is with what evidence the inquirer ought to be satisfied on the subject.— That is—what he is to take for evidence, which is not evidence. All the Evidence is negative, and the only alternative for the inquirer is to abandon the enquiry and take his fate as it comes, or to put up with Faith as the substance of things hoped for and the evidence of things not seen.— The creation speaks for itself and discloses a creator or creators, one or more—no evidence to decide that question, but faith acknowledges only one God— I wrote two pages of my Letter to Bangor, and as Sunset approached I walked up the hill, and spent the evening under Charles’s portico, and in his Study. He told me Caleb Cushing proposed to visit me to-morrow.

1. III.30. Saturday.  Sun rose 4:26. Set. 7.10.  In ranging round my grounds every morning, not a day passes, but I meet with some new phenomenon of vegetation, the observation of which ought to be accompanied and immediately followed by examination and meditation— It never is, and however mortifying to my self-conceit it may be, I am constrained to confess that the faculty of combining ideas and brooding over them till they fructify, hasn if not totally denied to me, imparted in scanty measure.— I took John Kirk round my seedling nurseries this morning and shewed him the trees that are, and those that are not to be taken up— I have now from the acorn, the black, white, red, and chesnut Oaks of considerable size, besides the English white Oaks which bear acorns in profusion. None of the native trees have yet borne fruit— Our red cherries are now so far ripened that we had yesterday and this day tarts made of them— The trees throw up suckers which bear transplanting and are of rapid growth, but I have never raised a cherry, except the mazzard, or a plum from the stone— This day there was a very light easterly breeze which made the day comfortable. I wrote further upon my Letter to Bangor, but did not finish it— Read a chapter in Dr Ware’s inquiry. His second chapter is on the sources from which the proofs of Religion and its truths are to be drawn.— These are Nature, and Revelation.— “The being of God, including all his attributes—the moral government of God, and a future life of righteous retribution”— To these articles may be reduced, and in them included—[“]all that we know of religion by the light of Nature.”— Creation is indeed to the mind of man evidence of a creator—but is it evidence of his moral government— This is not clear— Still less is it evidence of future righteous retribution— The visible creation evinces order—but not moral government, or future retribution— In the progress of human reason man conceives the idea of justice; and the family relations teach sympathy— With the idea of God therefore is connected in one indissoluble chain those of power, justice and mercy; and from them are deduced those of moral government and future retribution— Still the continued existence of man after death is so contrary to all the evidence of the senses, that it must rest forever on the pillars of Faith— I have too long intermitted the monthly summary of my daily occupations— In the month of June just expired I have risen at an earlier average than 4— Go up the hill to see the Sunrise from the South-east corner of my son’s house with one of the most magnificent spectacles of nature in the scenery before me— I then loiter about my grounds two hours or more. Return to my chamber and receive the mail except on Sundays. Breakfast at 8. Read newspapers and Letters, and write till 1/2 past 2. dine—Siesta—ride with my daughter in the carriage—up the hill to see the Sunset— No Evening

2. III:30 Sunday.  Sun rose 4.27 Set 7:40. beclouded  A day of intense heat. Mr Lunt who has been with his wife upon a fortnights excursion into the Country returned home yesterday, and preached this morning from Ephesians 6 13 “Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.” The discourse was a very earnest exhortation, to resist all manner of temptation— It was a very serious and sensible dissertation upon a duty which every Christian is called very frequently called to perform— The Lord’s prayer supplicates the almighty not to lead us into temptation; which implies that temptation itself comes from the agency of God himself, and seems to imply that from the weakness and frailty of our Nature we are not able to resist a temptation when it comes.— The Scripture says that the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and in another place that the Lord gave the children of Israel Statutes that were not good. But if the Lord leads men into temptation, who can redeem them from it?— This is one of the mysteries for future solution— It cannot be accounted for here— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with me. Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from Psalm 101.1. [“]I will sing of mercy and judgment; unto thee, O Lord will I sing.”— The Sermon was a sort of critical and historical Essay upon the book of Psalms— A subject upon which there is much to be said— I would consider it first as the only model of Hebrew Lyric Poetry. 2. compare it with the Lyric Poetry of the Greeks and Romans. 3. It exclusive character devotional— 4. connected with the religious worship of the tabernacle and afterwards of the temple— The musical establishment of David connected with the composition of the Psalms. 5. The effect of music, vocal and instrumental, upon religious worship. 6. Peculiarly suited to the worship of one God— Creator and Preserver of the world— The adaptation of sacred music and Psalms, to Christian worship.— Mr Lunt gave out to be sung after the Sermon his 57th hymn, which is Watts’s version of the 33d. psalm—one of the poorest that Watts ever composed—in which he makes ways rhyme with grace, loves with proves, spread with made, and seas with place; all in three Stanzas— It ought not to have been admitted into his collection— There was a collection taken up according to the annual usage for the Sunday school library. The S.S. Westerly gale, burning hot blew till the going down of the Sun, and then came on a very light thunder shower Mr Degrand left us to return to Boston shortly before nine— I attempted a versification of the 33d Psalm but only accomplished it in part— The Great Western Steamer arrived yesterday at New-York from Liverpool, and brought News from London to the 17th. of June.

3. III.30 Monday.  Sun rose 4.27. Set 7.40.  The Sun rose beclouded, and the weather was nearly as warm, as last evening immediately after the shower which was very light— I visited my seedling trees and wasted two hours in digging round them, manuring the land; and coaxing the small ones to grow— In the meantime a fresh breeze from the Northwest swept off all the clouds and compelled me to resume my winter garments. Mr Caleb Cushing Commissioner Plenipotentiary to China, and Joseph Vance heretofore a member of Congress from the State of Ohio, and afterwards Governor of that State paid me a morning visit, before breakfast; and subsequently the Revd. Samuel K. Lothrop, with Mr Ezekiel Bacon of Utica New-York— Cushing’s visit would have surprized me, but that he had told my Son last Friday that he intended to make it— He has not made his Court to Captain Tyler in vain. His obsequiousness and sacrifice of principle lost him the favour of his Constituents who repudiated him at the recent elections, but Mr Tyler had more precious favours in his gift, and he has lavished them in profusion upon Cushing. He is to embark in a few days for Alexandria in Egypt—to proceed thence overland to Bombay; where he is to find the Steamer Missouri, which is to take him to Canton— Mr Vance has within a few years experienced also the fickleness of popular favour— He was originally a poor labourer, but rose by his eloquence to Congress and to the Government of the State, and then was dropped into his primitive obscurity— Corwin is such an other, with more talent but not with deeper root. Ezekiel Bacon can tell much the same tale— He was a member of Congress from Berkshire, Massachusetts at the time of Jefferson’s embargo. Afterwards moved into the State of New-York, and engaged deeply in her politics—but has been many years an invalid; retired altogether from public life, and writing verses in a sick chamber at Utica— My correspondence with him began in 1808. and I have several Letters from him with enclosed poetry within the last year— I had not seen him since I went to Russia, and did not know him even when named to me by Mr Lothrop till the course of conversation disclosed who he was.— Archibald Macon (his Surname I forgot[)] is a black man who says he has been studying Law these two years, and is raising a contribution to enable him to go to Hayti or to Jamaica. I rode to Milton this afternoon with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs Charles and her baby Arthur— I received this morning a Letter from my wife, with information that Johnson Hellen—his wife andchildren have been poisoned with Arsenic steeped in their coffee at breakfast by an Irishwoman— I finished this Evening my Letter to Bangor.

4. III.30 Tuesday  Sun rose 4:28. clear. Set 7:40 beclouded—  Independence day. 67—  I saw the Sun rise from the corner of Charles’s house and marked its bearing, in the centre of the valley between the two hills.— I took the usual morning range round my grounds with no new observations on my trees—save the appearance of 8 or ten seedling English Oaks within a circle of 6 feet round the spot in the garden where one of those trees had been set out and grew and bore last year many acorns— It was taken up last Autumn, and these seedlings are from self-planted acorns which had fallen from the tree, and were left unnoticed on the ground—  My only surviving Son, Charles Francis, delivered the annual Boston City Oration on the Anniversary of Independence; an incident of the most intense interest to me, it being this day fifty years, since I performed the same service to the town. At half past 8 this morning we left my gate, and went into Boston; alighting at the city Hall in School Street, where we found the Mayor of the City, Martin Brimmer; and the Aldermen, common council with the other City Officers were assembling for a procession— President Quincy and Captain John Percival were among the persons whom I met there— Soon after 10. the procession moved escorted by two military companies to Faneuil Hall, where for the first time this celebration was held. It has usually been at the Old South Church, and was there in 1793 when I performed— The order of performances this day was 1. Music. 2 An Ode, by a select choir of pupils of the public schools, under the direction of Lowell Mason 3. Prayer, by the Revd Mr Hague. 4. Selections from the Scriptures by the Revd. Mr Gray.— 5. Ode written by Mrs L. H. Sigourney. 6. Oration by Charles Francis Adams 7. Prayer, by the Revd. Mr Gray. 8. Hymn—To the tune of God save the king. 9. Benediction by Mr Hague. The Oration occupied one hour and a quarter in the delivery; and was received with great, repeated and long continued applause— The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, with a very respectable and highly intelligent auditory. There was a station assigned in the procession to the members of the Massachusetts delegation in Congress; in which I walked with Robert C. Winthrop. Neither Governor Morton nor any member of his Council was present.— About a quarter past one, the ceremonies were all over— I went with Charles and Dr Frothingham to his house, where our Carriage soon came and took Charles and me home to Quincy. Mrs Frothingham with two of her sons and two daughters, came from Boston, and dined at Charles’s— I dined with only Louisa C. Smith. The last time I had been in Boston on the 4th. of July was in 1809. I went up the hill at Sunset. Mrs Frothingham returned with her children to Boston— We witnessed the fireworks on the Common of Boston. No language can express the agitation of my feelings, and the remembrances of this day [symbols]

5. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 4.28. Set 7.39. clear  The morning was cloudy, and there were copious showers in the forenoon. But soon after the sky was swept clear with a Northwest wind rather cold than cool. In my morning visitation to my trees I still found something to observe. I took off a girdle of suckers round an old Russet apple tree in the lane between my house and Charles’s; and I tied to the old dead stem two shoots of a black Jack Oak which has been growing twelve years in the Nursery; which throws up every summer shoots four or five feet high, and die down almost to the ground every winter— I have thus nearly ascertained that the Cork, Willow, and live-Oak, will not bear this climate— I fear the blackjack, will share the same fate; but I hope the English white-Oak may be propagated by the Acorn to any extent. Of a dozen acorns from the nursery trees, which I sowed last October, in a row close to the kitchen garden gate, last Thursday I perceived that one was breaking through the surface of the ground, and now at the end of a week, the plumelet is about half an inch above ground in the form of miniature leaves— This morning I perceived a second and this afternoon a third of the same row piercing through the soil— I sowed about the same time last autumn a number of shagbark walnuts, not one of which yet appears. Probably the reason why so many seedlings from this hard nut are winter-killed the first season after they come up is because they come up so late in the summer that they have not time to harden into wood before the sharp frosts set in—and I propose a double experiment to see if the vegetation of them cannot be hastened or retarded; by sowing from the 15th. to the 20th of October 3 rows of one dozen each 1. of nuts in the shell. 2. of nuts with the shell cracked. 3. of nuts in the drupe.— Another experiment may be to sow one row on the 1st. of October and another on the first of November— I find a multitude of new hatched slug worms eroding the surface of my cherry tree and pear tree leaves— Fresh spurs are putting forth from button-wood trees and stakes which were apparently dead— There came a man apparently 60 years of age, in very coarse apparel with red hair and a weather-beaten face, who said he was a Virginia named Richard Bland Randolph— That he had received in 1798 a midshipman’s warrant from my father; had been one of the captors of the French frigate L’Insurgente; and had been dismissed from the service at the reduction of the Navy by Mr Jefferson in 1802. That he had now a petition before congress for prize money of which he had never lifted the first cent; that he had made himself odious in Virginia by expressing opinions in favour of abolition; and that he had not bread to eat— I rode this afternoon to Milton with Louisa C Smith, Mrs Charles, and her boy Arthur—

6. IV. Thursday—  Sun rose 4 Set 7.  I emptied this morning one of my flower pots; filled it with fresh earth from the garden and sowed in it the seeds of a Baldwin apple which had been kept sound through the winter, but which has been decaying since my return home on my library mantle piece—and with them I sowed one dozen red cherry stones of cherries just now ripe and which I picked from the trees— My last experiment to see if they will vegetate.— I leave my trees. My Son went this morning to Cambridge to attend a greek examination. At 10. O’Clock, I left home with his wife, and her Son John Quincy—we went into Boston, and dined at Dr Frothingham’s; meeting there her father Mr Peter Chardon Brooks— Immediately after dinner we proceeded to the depot of the Western Railroad, where after taking leave of Charles who had just come in from Cambridge, we started in the Cars at half past 3.— The weather was fine—clear sunshine yet comfortably cool— We passed through the towns of Natick, Southborough—Westborough, Worcester, Brookfield— Charlton and several others which I neglected to ascertain, and at a quarter before 9. landed at Warriner’s United States Hotel in Springfield 96 miles from Boston— Among our travelling companions were the Revd. Alexander Young, Minister of the New South Church, Boston; going by the way of Hartford and New-Haven, to preach two Sundays at New-York. Mr and Mrs Joseph Grinnell of New-Bedford and Mr Henry Sargent, going to visit his son, settled at Newburgh opposite to Fishkill landing on Hudson’s river— The Season is delightful. The face of the Country like the garden of Eden— It is the Season of hay-making and throughout our way, the mower with his scythe, the cocking of the grass, or the spreading it from the cock to dry, followed in alternate succession, and the atmosphere was charged only with varieties of fragrance— Fields of Indian corn, Rye, Potatoes and Oats interchangeably with pastures covered with grazing cattle, neat and comfortable houses and kitchen gardens and Orchards laden with ripening fruit, attested a genial climate a fruitful Season and a region of Peace, plenty and contentment— As the cars flew along from Boston till we passed through Natick the contrast of the Seasons crowded upon my observation between the present aspect of the country, and that which I witnessed last November when I went to deliver the Lecture, with the ice glazed road to Mr Wilson’s house, and the falling snow of the next morning as I returned to Boston— At Springfield we took our lodging for the night at Jeremy Warriner’s United States Hotel, one of the most elegant houses of public entertainment that I ever visited— This morning, I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and invited his daughter Mary to go out to Quincy, and pass a few days with her Aunt Louisa C. Smith till my return, but her health is so bad that she declined going from home.

7. IV:30. Friday  Mr Young departed at 7 this morning in a Steamer for Hartford— Mr Sargent disappeared in another direction for Hudson’s river. I rose with the Sun, and wrote in my bed chamber till breakfast time at 8. having no time to examine a narrative of an expedition to the Oregon territory in 1835, 36 and 37. by Dr Samuel Parker or the life of the Revd. Lemuel Haynes a Mulatto minister of the gospel, born in 1753 and deceased in 1833. of whom I had never heard before; but who was many years eminent as a preacher in Connecticut and the western part of the State of New-York. Books which I found on the table at which I wrote— After breakfast, Coll. Howard and Mr Ashmun called to see us; and accompanied Mr Brooks and myself with John Quincy to the Arsenal and the armoury. At the Arsenal we saw 30000 stands of arms, and were told that there were 150,000 ready for use in case of need— At the armoury Major Ripley went round with us, and we saw the various processes of making the gun barrels, and the black walnut gun stocks— I had seen these processes in 1828, but they are constantly making improvements in the manipulation of the musketry— They are now substituting the percussion lock and cap for the flint lock and pan—but Major Ripley told me that unless an appropriation should be very shortly made to repair or rather to rebuild the house over the water fall, in which they make the gun barrels and stocks he apprehends it will crumble into ruin and carry the workmen employed in it with it— On our return to Warriner’s we had a visit from Mr William B. Calhoun, and Mrs Grinnell was visited by her two Sisters Mrs Dalton and Mrs Bentley— We had a magnificent collation dinner, and at one O’Clock rode to the depot and resumed our seats in the railroad Cars— There was a light sprinkling of rain but the clouds gradually dispersed and the Evening was fine— Mr and Mrs Grinnell were still with us to Pittsfield 54. miles, through a country contrasting with that through which we had passed yesterday— A wild region of dark forests and stupendous rocks, through many of which deep cuts and inclined plains, have been made for the Western railroad, which has cost ten millions of dollars. At Pittsfield we quitted the railroad and bid farewell to Mr and Mrs Grinnell and our new acquaintance Mr Porter of Lee a member of Governor Marcus Morton’s Council—we took a Carriage and came in two hours to Lebanon Springs over a heavy mountainous road. Here we are to pass three or four days, for the sake of the baths, said to be salubrious. We expected to have met here my old Classmate judge Samuel Putnam, and Mr Caleb Loring of Boston, but were disappointed. They went away this morning— Mr Charles G. Loring is here with his wife, a daughter of judge Putnam, and a son and daughter—and Mrs Crowninshield another daughter of judge Putnam.
