8. IV:15 Saturday.  The Columbian Hall at the Lebanon Springs, the house at which we have taken our lodgings, is a Hotel kept by Hull and Bentley, with about 120 bed chambers on four low Stories of a wooden mansion with a wide piazza round three sides of the house on the second and third Stories— A large dining hall on the ground floor with a reading and bar room over which ascending a flight of steps there is also a large drawing room— The house is built on the eastern side of a high and steep hill, in the form of a half rectangle the short side of which fronts the street, and the long side a very extensive valley between two ranges of lofty mountains chiefly covered with Oak, chesnut, beech—birch, black walnut and especially sugar maple trees, interspersed with willows and sycamores of respectable size and stature but none of them very large or tall— The sumach, and locust are also very common among them.— On rising this morning and walking round the piazza, I was much struck by the successive lights and shades of the Sun rising in a crystal clear sky, gilding the tops of the mountains successively in proportion to their respective elevations piercing through interstitial passages between the hills into parts of the valley, and casting long dark shades of solitary trees in one direction before them—for three quarters of an hour the peaks of the mountains were taking one after another the golden tinge, before the sunbeam became visible from the piazzo, on which I was walking, and listening to the morning concert of the birds. This was very little varied by the spring and yellow birds, with the king-bird, wren, swallow and robin— None, but what I hear at Quincy, and no sound either of bobolink or quail.— I wrote till breakfast time at 8 and soon after with all our party, a Mr Aymer and two Ladies from New-York, and Edward, a son of Patrick Jackson I rode in two Carriages up the hills to a tower about 50 feet high on the loftiest summit of this neighbourhood, whence we had a range of prospect round the compass with a radius of fifty miles.— The line between the States of New-York and Massachusetts is on the road from Lebanon to the tower which is in Berkshire County, and whence parts of the States of Massachusetts, New-Hampshire, Vermont and New-York are visible at one view— Returning from the tower, at Noon, I took a bath: Water at 90. not warm. After dinner I had a visit from Mr Dunham and Mr Hayden of Pittsfield to invite me there; but I declined— Mr Dunham brought with him his daughter Helen Maria’s Album for me to write my name in it— We next rode, taking with us a small boy a son of Mrs Crowninshield, to the village of the Shakers, and visited a man named John Mantle, and a woman living in two rooms of one house, where they keep a small shop of Shakerism, at unconscionable prices. we saw also their dairy, and cheeses and cow-yard with two women, milking 25 cows— Returned, and after tea, spent the Evening on the Piazza, in converse with a cluster of Strangers.

10. IV.15. Monday.  I had a night not of undisturbed repose, which I attributed to the warm bath of last evening. But the discomforts of it soon passed away.— I went up on the Lookout on the top of the house, and saw the Sunrise above the Eastern hill tops, at 5 minutes past five— He was shining on the tops successively of all the surrounding hills for about half an hour before his first beam met my eye. A person by the name of Spelman came on to the Piazza, and spoke to me from outside of my chamber window— He said he belonged to Albany and happening to be for some days at Pittsfield, he had heard of my passing through that Town and that I was here.— And that never having seen me, and thinking it probable he might never have an opportunity of seeing me again, He took his horse this morning and came over from Pittsfield with the determination to see me, and thake hands with me; and having accomplished that purpose he would detain me no longer, and took his leave— After breakfast, with Mr Brooks, Mr Loring’s two sons, Edward, son of Patrick Jackson, and John Quincy, I rode in a Barouche to the tunnel of the Western rail-road, nine miles distant from Lebanon, through the valley stretching from the Southern end of Columbia Hall. The tunnel is a subterraneous excavation 40 feet wide and 200 feet long through a rock of solid marble, like that of the coal mine in Silesia or that of the catacombs at Paris except that they have no outlet, while this pierces through the rock from side to side forming an arch about 12 feet high with a mass of earth covered with a forest of trees over it— This is the most extraordinary achievement on the western rail-road; and is said to have been projected and effected, by an Englishman and work men in the compass of one year. The road to it is very good, partly through the valley between the two ranges of mountains cultivated on both sides with pasture and meadowlands, Rye, Indian corn, Potatoes, Oats, and very little wheat with scattered groves of Chesnut, black walnut, Sugar Maples—locust, Sycamore, Oaks black and white, hemlock and pine trees— We returned, reaching Columbia Hall just before one. We had expected a Letter from my Son, by the mail this afternoon; but were disappointed; we concluded nevertheless to depart at 7. to morrow morning; return to the Western rail-road, and proceed to Saratoga— The Daily Advertiser of this morning from Boston, brought the account of the Shipwreck last Monday of the Cunard Steamer Columbia, on black ledge, near Seal Island on the coast of Nova Scotia— Also the deaths of Washington Alston at Cambridge, and of John Holmes at Portland.

properties.dateline: Lebanon Tuesday 11. July 1843 Albany. Troy. Saratoga
properties.text: 11. IV. Tuesday.  My birth day—76.  We had been disappointed in not receiving a Letter yesterday from my Son, with intelligence from my wife at Washington; and we had strongly inclined to stay another day at Lebanon, to take the chance of another Mail from Boston— But Mr Brooks adhered to the determination upon which we had agreed, to start this morning at 7.— We accordingly did so—but I rose at 4 and completed the writing of my journal of yesterday which I had begun last evening, in time to pack up my trunk before breakfast— Just as we were about leaving the house, Mr Bentley delivered to me a Letter addressed to me, covering one from my Son to his wife, written on Saturday last, mailed at Quincy, and which came this morning by the mail from Albany— It eased us of much anxiety, and indicated that my wife proposed to come home this week— We took leave of Mr Crocker and rode in a carriage about 10 miles to Canaan a depot of the Western rail-road one mile east of the tunnel which we had visited yesterday. Here we waited nearly three quarters of an hour till the train of Cars from Boston and Springfield came up, in which we took our Seats and proceeded to Greenbush opposite to Albany, passing through Chatham and Kinderhoek on the way. We passed through the tunnel; but it was like leaping into a dark cellar, and in half a minute out of it again— We should not even have seen what it was, but for our yesterday’s visit— At Greenbush, we crossed in a Steam ferry-boat to Albany, and immediately passed into another Steamer came up to Troy, which we reached at one p.m. and where we stop’d at the United States Hotel kept by Mr Watrous— In the Cars at Canaan, we had found among the passengers, Mr and Mrs Nathan Hale, and their daughter Sarah a young woman about 20, afflicted with rhumatism; and Doctor Duggan of Quincy with Mr Edward Glover his Patient—going to the Springs for the same complaint. At Albany, now a city of 33000 inhabitants and Troy, distant from it but 7 miles, with a population of 25000 we met the crowd and bustle of a swarming hive of bees— After a short visit to Mrs. Dickinson; a meeting in the Street with Genl. Wool, and his nephew Lieutt. Goodrich, and visits from Mr Vail, the late member of Congress, and Mr Seymour the member elect from this district, at half past 3 we left Troy in the train of Cars for Saratoga, where after passing through Ballstown we arrived at 6 O’Clock p.m. We took lodgings at the Union, said to be more retired than the United States hotel—there being not more than 200 fellow travellers at the house.— Those at the other being much more numerous— At one of the depots on the way from Troy we had met Mr Richard W. Davis, one of the 4. re-elected members of Congress from the State of New-York— At the Union Hotel we met again Mr and Mrs Grinnell from whom we had parted at Pittsfield— Also Mr Richard Fletcher of Boston— Mr Asbury Dickens, Secretary of the U.S. Senate, here with his wife and family, a Mr and Mrs Huntington, whom I scarcely remember and of strange faces, numbers without number.

12. IV.15. Wednesday.  I have got into a great crowd of Strangers; a position always painful to me, and for which from a perpetual want of presence of mind, I am not fitted— After finishing the record of yesterday I walked out—took a tumbler of Congress water, at the spring and found it a very weak chalybeate, and walked along the public grounds to a hillock on the summit of which was a circular railroad wheeled round the movement bein effected by the person riding— Returning to the Hotel I met Mr Fletcher who conducted me to theSpring and Bathing house. Before and after breakfast many of the visitors at the house, strangers were introduced, neither whose names nor persons remain on my memory. Two gentlemen belonging to the village came and said many citizens of the place were desirous of paying their personal respects to me, for which they asked me to fix a time; which I did for 10 to-morrow morning. Mr Huntington proposed to me to go out with him and some other gentlemen to view the battleground between Gates and Burgoyne; and the place where the British army surrendered— Accordingly, eight of us went out in two carriages, among whom were Mr Grinnell, Captain Breese of the Navy, Mr Howard, a member of the Council of Massachusetts, a Mr Russell with two others 12 or 13 Miles, to Bemis’s heights, which our drivers had some difficulty in finding— On the way out we crossed the Saratoga lake in a flat ferry boat, and shortly before reaching the heights, we passed by a very small and mean looking hovel in front of which stood an old man, who the driver told us was a hundred years old— We turned back and enquired whether he had been at the surrender of Burgoyne— He said no—he was at that time stationed in Connecticut; but that he was a Canadian, born at Quebec one hundred years old last month— That on the appearance of the American army before Quebec in 1776 he joined them; was present at the death of Montgomery, and served in the American army through the whole revolutionary War— I perceived that he spoke English with a French accent and spoke to him in French, which he spoke with native familiarity— He said that on the death of Montgomery Carlton cried like a child— He said also that he had been with General Washington in the campaign through the Jersies, and spoke of a victory at Elizabeth town, at which 36 pieces of cannon, with 900 barrels of flour as many of rum, and as many hogsheads of wine had been taken— On the heights we found a gentleman farmer named Neilson, 54 years old, who told us his father had lived in the house where he now lives, and that Genl Poor and another had quartered in his kitchen— He had two maps, upon which he pointed out to us every position occupied by the several detachment both of Gates’s and of Burgoyne’s armies in the two actions of 19. September and of 7. October 1777 1777. We had with us the volume of Marshall’s life of Washington, containing the narrative of both those actions, and compared it with the positions pointed out to us, by Mr Neilson— He walked out with us to the house of a neighbouring farmer named Walker a native of Smithfield, Rhode-Island, but settled here these 38 years— Near his house stands a Bass wood tree, from 20 to 25 years old—apparently from an old stump, and surrounded by successers. It was under the original stock of that tree then old and large that the British General Frazier received his mortal wound.— Burgoyne had descended along the Southern banks of the Hudson river, till he came to the spot where the village of the Springs now stands, when he crossed the river to assail and disperse the force which was then assembling on the Eastern banks to meet him— Burgoyne had assumed his position in August and on the 19th. of September he made a general assault upon the American lines which extended down to the river— The battle began at two in the afternoon, and was -tinued until the darkness of night came on; when the two parties remained in possession each, of their own intrenchments as before— On the 7th. of October Burgoyne made his second attack, later in the day, and that also was terminated by the night when both parties again retired to their own intrenchments—but that day decided the fate of the War— A post had been assumed by a detachment of Gates’s army South and East of all the lines to outflank the British, and commanded by Coll. Morgan— A corps of the British army was despatched to force this position, commanded by General Frazier— They met and a conflict of 52 minutes ensued. Mr Neilson conducted us to the stone wall bounding the road, overshadowed by the Bass wood tree within the enclosure: stretching his arm over the wall and pointing to the spot where Morgan’s intrenchments had stood—here—said he—bloody work was done on that day— Then pointing to a knoll about 30 rods from the tree, he said, a rifle ball from that knoll, struck General Frazier and he fell. His corps discouraged by the loss of their leader, retired to their intrenchments, and the fortune of the day was decided— The next day Burgoyne commenced his retreat and reached a place now called Schuylerville distant from the heights about ten miles, pursued by Gates and his army—swelling by daily accessions of militia, till Burgoyne with about 7500 men left of his force, was completely hemmed in and on the 17th. of October surrendered by capitulation.— We took a collation at Mr Walker’s house. His son a youth of nineteen or twenty shewed us a guinea of 1775. and two Spanish pillar dollars, which he had dug or ploughed up yesterday on the field of battle— He had also many other waifs and derelicts of War which have been found from time to time under the same grounds—bullets—rifle balls; grape shot—part of a shoe-buckle—one broken skull, and sundry other human bones— He has a wife, two sons and two daughters whom we saw; and four other daughters married— We returned to the Springs about 5. p.m—walked to the circular rail-way and swung round it with John-Quincy— Visited Monsieur Edouarts collection of Silhouettes and spent the Evening in the drawing room—

properties.dateline: Saratoga Springs Thursday 13 July 1843— Caldwell, on Lake-George
properties.text: 13. IV. Thursday.  Though I rise at 4. O’Clock and improve as well I can the morning hours in writing I cannot find time for the daily record, and fall into arrears. There is always so much to record, that the difficult is in the selection, and the judgment in selecting right. At 6. yesterday morning I had been startled by the sound of a band of Music, close to the Congress Spring, within sight and hearing of my chamber window— They played a succession of delightful airs for the space of an hour, while at the same time a cluster of persons were coming and going to and from the Spring, under a shed, where three or four boys were drawing from the well tumblers, nested in tin cases the water, each of which was taken and quaffed by the successive visitors who drank and departed. This morning at precisely 6 the same Scene presented itself— I wrote and listened to the music till 7. and then went and took a warm bath Fahrenheit 96. at the Hamilton Spring. But that as I afterwards found was not the proper time for the bath; but at 11. or 12 before dinner. At the bathing house, placarded a notification signed by Chancellor Walworth andother citizens of the village, that I would receive at the Union Hall at 10. O’Clock, any visitors who wished to call on me— And accordingly from 10 to 11—about 500 persons, men women and children of both sexes and all ages came; were introduced to me by Chancellor Wolworth, Dr Freeman, Mr Putnam, the keeper of the house, or themselves— I shook hands with them all, and when the stream was drained, I addressed a few words of thanks to those of them who had remained in the drawing room where I had received them and they departed— At noon Mr Daniel D Barnard who had visited me last evening, and promised to come and go with me to return the visit of the Chancellor, did come, with two other Gentlemen, and as the chancellor had been with me, and requested me to dispense with the formality of returning his visit we went to the flat rock, or pavilion spring, where I took a tumbler of the water— Returning we stop’d at the United States Hotel, where Mr Barnard lodges and I took leave of him. At 2. we dined, and at 3. our party, with Mr and Mrs Joseph Grinnell, Miss Cornelia Grinnell, their niece and adopted daughter, and Miss Caroline E. Otté, Miss Grinnell’s Governess or companion, started in the Stage; with three cheers from a crowd of person’s who had assembled in front of the Union hall to witness our departure, and just before 9 in the evening, arrived at the lake house, in Caldwell at the head of Lake George 27 miles from Saratoga Springs. The road heavy and tedious, deep sand most of the way and high hills— At 18 miles from the Springs we stop’d to examine Glen’s falls, which are very considerable.

properties.dateline: Caldwell. Friday 14. July 1843. Ticonderoga. Lake Champlain
properties.text: 14. III.45. Friday.  Caldwell.— I was roused as daylight came on by the consultations of a tribe of Swallows nested on the edges of the roof of the portico fronting the east under my open chamber-window, who made a noise equal to that of the hum of men, on the royal exchange at London— I saw the Sun-rise, partially beclouded, over the mountain forests beyond Lake George We breakfasted at the lake-house kept by Mr Shirrell, and embarked, at a landing at the foot of the garden before the house— We parted from the landing, and shortly before noon at the head of Lake George, where it is connected by a small brook with Lake Champlain— We rode in Carriages, between two and three miles, to the ruins of the fort of Ticonderoga; but on alighting to survey them were overtaken by a heavy shower, which drove us from the ruined walls to an adjoining hotel where we stop’d and dined— Lake George is 34 miles long, and at two or three places from three to four miles wide; but on the average not more than one— Its course is between two ranges of lofty mountains, ascending from the border of the lake from 1200 to 2500 feet, covered with dark forests of Oak and pine, but of trees neither remarkable for height or circumference— On the sides of many of the mountains, there are frequent spaces of precipices of 150 or 200 feet perpendicular like the wall of a house or a fortress, some of them extending 800 or a thousand feet long of solid rock—and there are several hundred, they say 365 islands interspersed in wild confusion and infinite variety of form from one end of the lake to the other. Some of them have fanciful names—others, of their distance from the head of the lake, as 5 mile and 12 mile islands; and others from memorable incidents in the two struggles for the conquest of Canada in the seven years war and the war of the revolution— Of the fort of Ticonderoga, nothing but outer dilapidated walls remain— Here we dined and judge Burnet, an ardent whig and intelligent, well bred and well educated politician, introduced himself and several others to me and dined with us— At 3. O’Clock the Steamer Whitehall came and took us up at the landing— This was the lake Champlain Boat, Captain Lyon, of Burlington Vermont, substituted for the William Caldwell which had transported us over Lake George— In the Whitehall I metwho reminded me that he had been a member of the 26th Congress; and although I had then so little personal acquaintance with him that I did not now remember him; yet we now became very familiar with each other, and had much conversation especially as he had now with him a very pretty little daughter about 7 years old. He landed however this afternoon— Just at Sunset we reached Burlington in the State of Vermont, where Mr Brooks and Mr Grinnell, with the two young Ladies landed and took a ride round the town— I remained on board the boat where several of the inhabitants of the town, came and urged me earnestly to give them a day— Among them Heman Allen in the 23 and 24th Congresses and Mr Marsh, the nominated candidate for the present Congress

properties.dateline: Champlain. Saturday 15 July 1843. Montreal. St. Lawrence river.
properties.text: 15. IV. Saturday  The Steamer Whitehall Captain Lyon, is a beautiful boat, with a most obliging and intelligent commander. His wife, a handsome and pleasing woman was on board yesterday; but landed at Burlington, whence we in the Steamer about 9 last Evening proceeded on our voyage, passing by Plattsburg in the Night— The Captain insisted upon giving up his cabin to me, and I never passed a night in a more comfortable bed chamber. About one in the morning the boat was moored to a wharf at Champlain, in shallow water, opposite a small island, and hard by Rous’s point—the navigation of the lake being about there so obstructed by shoals, that the boats venture no further without daylight— We were to stop from one to four in the morning— Soon af- that I saw the Sun majestically rise, over Champlain, in the summer morning of a beautiful village, with the spire of a Church peering up from its surrounding trees— But the boat did not move, and by 5. O’Clock a fog arose and thickened till the Sun was lost in gloom for the space of three hours— I retired to my cabin and wrote till the Sun came out again; mean time the boat started, and passed by the ruined fort on Rous’s point, and the land mark of Latitude 45. the boundary between the United States, and the British Province of Canada, unseen by me. At the head of the lake the river Richelieu leads to St. John’s where it takes the name of the Sorel to pass into the St. Laurence— The passage from Whitehall at the foot of Lake George, where we landed yesterday, adjoining Ticonderoga, to St. John’s in Canada is 160 miles, which we traversed in 19 hours. It should have been in 16 or at most 17.— But our detention at Champlain by the fog belated our arrival at St. John’s at 7. or 8. till near 10. The railway cars had started at 9.—and the next train was to leave at a quarter before 2— Captain Lyon had dressed out the boat in all the colours he had on board. The 85th. regiment of British light infantry is quartered at St. John’s—we landed and went to the hotel kept by Mr Morehead— He introduced to us a Commissary of the army named Lister, and he soon introduced Major French the present commander of the Regiment. We visited with him the barracks; and the regular exhibition of the parade was made, apparently in compliment to us.— The heat was intense— The manoeuvres on the field, merely good—not of ideal perfection— Major French himself gave the word of command with adequate precision and accuracy. We returned to the hotel and dined. We invited Mr Lister to dine with us, but he declined. A quarter before 2 we took the rail-way cars 17 miles to La Prairie— Major French was at the depot, to take leave— From La Prairie a Steamer took us 9. miles to Montreal where we stop’d about 2 hours at Doolittle’s hotel: took a glance inside of the cathedral; embarked in the Steamer Queen Captain Roach, and started from the wharf at 6 in the afternoon for Quebec— Two Officers of the army—Coll. Gore, and Coll. J. Campbell introduced themselves to me, and Coll. Campbell gave me a Letter for Lieutt. Coll. Walker, Commander of the Royal Artillery at Quebec—

properties.dateline: Steamer Queen. St. Lawrence river. Sunday 16 July 1843. Quebec—
properties.text: 16. IV. Sunday  The distance from Montreal to Quebec on the St. Lawrence is 180 miles which we traversed in 11. hours— But soon after we left Montreal, the night came on and we saw no more of the Country. The Steamer Queen is a very fine boat, but met with an accident some time since and was sunk— She has been very lately raised, repaired and painted, the smell of which was very offensive— The hand or foot could scarcely touch anything without sticking to it.— There was another Steamer too, the Lord Sydenham, in competition with the Queen; and the pressure of Steam, for this race was excessive upon both— That upon the Queen at one time became alarming and they were obliged to stop the boat and let off the steam for the space of at least ten minutes.— The pinewood fire too threw out burning charcoal cinders in showers upon the upper deck, and made it at once dirty and uncomfortable. I had to myself however a good State room, with two berths but without a table, so that I could not write and did not open my trunk.— Before 10. I turned in and slept sound till day light— I rose at 4. saw the Sun rise from the upper deck, opposite the village and church of St. Nicholas, 15 miles from Quebec where we landed precisely at 5. O’Clock— The Ladies then rode, and the men walked up, like scaling the walls to Payne’s Hotel on the Square where the parade of the troops is held; adjoining the place d’Armes.— The first thing I did was to sally forth in quest of a barber— I found one, named Tessier, a native of Quebec, whom I finally prevailed upon with not a little difficulty to shave me.— At breakfast we met a gentleman named Frazier, a Scotch Presbyterian, who offered us seats in his pew in the Scotch church of St. Andrew; which Mr Brooks and I accepted— The preacher was a Dr Cook— His text was from Genesis 4.3. [“]And in process of time, it came to pass, that Cain brought of the fruit of the ground an offering to the Lord. 4. And Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock, and of the fat there of: And the Lord had respect unto Abel, and to his offering— 5. But unto Cain, and to his offering he had not respect.” We dined at one O’Clock, and at 2. attended the evening service of the English episcopal church for the troops of the garrison.— The several regiments were marched in full uniform accompanied by their Officers but without their firearms into the church, where the chaplain to one of their regiments the 68th. 81st. and 82d. read the evening prayers for the 5th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Job. 42.3. “Who is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I uttered that I understood not: things too wonderful for me, which I knew not.”— After Church I took a ride with Mr and Mrs Grinnell and Mrs Charles to the plains of Abram and in the Country round the City of Quebec, which is beautiful, and richly cultivated— Evening walk on the platform—
The Traveller’s own Book to Saratoga Springs, Niagara Falls and Canada—by S. De Veaux Buffalo. Faxon and Read 1841.

17. IV. Monday.  In our excursion yesterday afternoon we observed two monuments, upon which I stop’d to read the inscriptions.— The first is an obelisk 65 feet high, adjoining the entrance to the glacis of Cape Diamond fronting the river eastward— On the South side of the pedestal is carved in large relief the name of Wolfe—on the North side that of Montcalm. In the front are the two following inscriptions—  Mortem Virtus. Communem Famam Historia Monumentum  Posteritas dedit   and below  Hujusce Monumenti, in Memoriam Virorum Illustrium Wolfe et Montcalm Fundamentum P. C. Georgius Comes De Dalhousie, In Septentrionalis Americae Partibus ad Britannos Pertinentibus Summam Rerum Administrans; Opus per multos Annos Praetermissum (Quid Duci Egregio Convenientius?) Auctoritate Promovens. Exemplo Stimulans, Munificentia Fovens, Die Novembris XVâ A.D. MDCCCXXVII, Georgio IV. Brittaniarum Rege.  The first of these inscriptions is good: and the simple names of Wolfe and Montcalm at the opposite sides in good taste.— The second inscription is a newspaper puff in honour of Earl Dalhousie, barely noticing the names of Wolfe and Montcalm, but magnifying the Scotch Laird Governor General Dalhousie, into an egregious chieftain, with the word convenientius of very dubious latinity.— I could not help thinking of the famous specimen of the bathos— And thou, Dalhousie, the great God of War   Lieutenant Colonel to the Earl of Mar.  It is indeed highly creditable to this last Dalhousie, that he did accomplish the erection of this monument, but he should not have suffered this pompous panegyric upon himself to be inscribed upon its front in substitution of some brief but pathetic allusions to the illustrious rivals in life and death, themselves.  The other monument is on the plains of Abram— A plain stone broken column about eight feet high from the ground, with a small square basement surrounded by loose stones cemented together on a low gently rising mound with the words deeply carved on the shaft  Here  Wolfe Fell  Victorious.  It is a sad eye sore to monumental glory that this inscription is so defaced by the chipping off from the Letters of the word victorious, and from the name of Wolfe, that they are scarcely legible— A person present said this defacemt had been made within the last two years.  On rising this morning, I went out to the platform to see the Sun rise across the river— A solitary centinel was walking to and fro on his guard, and as I passed by him said in a low desponding tone—Sir—can you tell me what O’Clock it is?— I answered, half past 4. The Sun was then about ten minutes risen—on returning from the precipitous edge of the platform which looks down on the tops fifty feet below of a street of houses, I asked the centinel the name of a point across the river—he said he did not know. He had been here not more than a month, and came last from Jamaica. I passed on to the next Centinel at the wicket gate entrance to the glacis of Cape Diamond, and before the obelisk and asked him the name of the point— He did not know— It was point Levy—and at some distance beyond it was the Island of Orleans— After Breakfast an Irish waiter at the Inn shewed me the way to the residence, at the Artillery Barracks of Lieutt. Coll. Walker commander of the Artillery, to whom I delivered the Letter which Coll. Campbell had given me in the Steamer Queen on our passage from Montreal— Coll. Walker’s reception of me was not so cordial, as the gift of the Letter had been by Coll. Campbell— It was cold but civil, as I have often found the receipt of commendatory Letters— He invited me however to the Lunch at the mess-room at one O’Clock, but I told him I was going to the Falls of Montmorenci, and should not be back till later. He led me however to a spot in the garden, where there was a ladder by which I mounted on the glacis and had a beautiful view of the city below the rivers and country around and the distant mountains. He asked me if I had called upon the commanding officer of the city, Sir James Hope. I had not— On my return to Payne’s Hotel, I found a Barouche at the door, and immediately went with Miss Grinnell, Miss Otté and Mr Leupp, and Mr Brooks’s Coachman Perry, nine miles to the falls of Montmorenci— Mr Bowden with my Grandson John Quincy went separately in a Calèche, and returned an hour before us— After passing a clumsy wooden bridge over the river St. Charles, the road is a turnpike, lined with a continuous village of French cottages and chaumières, interspersed with a few handsome and costly houses surrounded by cultivated farms— The country has an appearance of general ease and comfort— The houses of one story, deep slanting roofs with Lutheran windows sometimes with a second set over them, built of wood or stone bare or plastered over with shingled or thatched roofs, and the sides of the houses sometimes of plank, perpendicularly laid— The population is generally good looking and healthy; but we saw several women in the kitchen garden adjoining every habitation, hoeing and digging the vegetables, and others with the men making hay.— About half way to the falls by the side of the road, was a column on a pedestal surmounted by a corinthian capital with inscriptions on three sides of the pedestal, imparting that the monument was erected by the inhabitants of the parish of Beauport in gratitude to the blessed virgin, for the success of the temperance reform in that parish—we viewed the falls first on the North side then on the South, and lastly on the river strand below; the descent to and ascent from which were so steep that the Ladies did not attempt it— We returned to the city about 3. p.m and I received visits from Coll. Walker, who agreed to accompany us at 9. to-morrow morning to the Citadel, and from the English Bishop of Montreal Dr Mountain— There had been cards while I was absent from L’Eveque de Sidyme, and sundry Priests—the Mayor of Quebec, and C. S. Bourne—a Stranger

18. IV:30. Tuesday.  Heavy rain all night and this morning, subsiding to mist and fog, then clearing up cool. Coll. Walker came at 9. with Major Cole the commandant of the Citadel— In consideration of the rain we agreed to postpone our visit to the citadel till one O’Clock, and then to meet the Officers there. In the meantime I had what I sadly want on this journey, leisure to keep along the record without running into irretrievable arrears.— When the weather held up I visited with Mr Grinnell the Roman Catholic cathedral, a very large and massive building where we found some enfans trouvés on their knees at their devotions— There are numerous paintings suspended to the walls, from the legends of the Saints, the subjects of which I did not understand; but some of them ludicrous as caricatures. All indifferent as works except one of the annunciation, which Mr Grinnell pointed out to me, as a good picture— There was one the virgin, a full length with her arms expanded, and streams of radiance from her hands like the tail of the comet last February— Sir James Hope the present commander in chief of the place called on me, and urged me with great earnestness to stay another day, and dine with him to-morrow— We had engaged for our passage in the Steamer Montreal at 5 this afternoon— Sir James was extremely polite, and profuse in his offers of service. At one we visited the citadel accompanied by Lieutt. Coll. Walker, on horseback, and received by Major Cole with very engaging attentions— The batteries of iron 32 pounders and brass 6 pounders are like those of other fortresses; but the prospects from the several bastions, were variegated beautifull and grand.— I went out in the barouche with Mr Grinnell and two of the Ladies, to search for the spot where Montgomery fell but could not find it— There are different traditionary accounts of it, some saying it was on the spot where now stands the Prescott gate, through which we passed. Others that it was close to the custom-house, near the spot where we landed from the Steamer Queen— We traversed the lower city upwards of a mile, along the margin of the river; not so rich as Pearl Street in New-York and more like wapping. At 3 we dined and at 1/2 past 4. left Payne’s Hotel and embarked in the Steamer Montreal, Captain Armstrong— While at the wharf, Mr C. S. Bourne, who had yesterday left a visiting card for me at Payne’s hotel came on board, introduced himself to me, and expressed his regret that the shortness of our stay at Quebec had deprived him of the opportunity of rendering me any service in his power there. He said he was a native of Virginia, and had somehow become a subject of Queen Victoria he supposed; but that his affection for his native Country was as warm, as it ever had been—was inextinguishable— That he was proud of being one of her Sons; and then he complimented me personally, and took his leave as the boat was about to start— She parted from the wharf precisely at 5.— There was on board as a fellow passenger a Philadelphia lawyer named Brown, a Son of the late novelist Charles Brockden Brown, who was introduced to me, and entered immediately into conversation with me, which with the intervention of half an hour for tea continued with deep interest till past 11. O’Clock, when Mr Grinnell called me up on deck to contemplate the rising moon and the firmament of Stars.

properties.dateline: St. Lawrence river Wednesday 19. July 1843. Montreal
properties.text: 19. IV. Wednesday.  I was roused this morning at early dawn, by the noise in the boat with she stop’d at the landing of trois rivières; but did not get up till after she had left that place and was again on her way— At Sunrise the weather was cold as with us is usual in the last fortnight of September I found on the promenade deck aft of the gate between the deck and cabin passengers two men lying stretched on the floor of the deck, without bed, blanket sheet or coverlet; and on the forecastle ten or twelve others in the same condition. They were all sound asleep— They rose successively between 5 and 6. Then shook themselves stretched their arms, yawned and were ready for the day. I could not but think what a useless and debilitating luxury are all beds and bedding: and incline to the opinion that it would be a great improvement in the education of children to accustom them to coucher sur la dure, but after traversing the deck up and down about 2 hours, I got chilled and retired to my berth in my State room—till just at 7. O’Clock the Steamer was moored to the fire stone wharf landing at Montreal— A man from Doolittle’s exchange Hotel immediately came on board and delivered to me a Letter from my Son to his wife— Mr Brown immediately left us to pursue his journey to the Saratoga Springs. We had hesitated whether we should not at once pursue ours to the Niagara falls, but concluded at last to pass one Night at Montreal. We took lodgings at Doolittles, and sallied forth for curiosities— Before I reached the Hotel I was accosted by Mr Frothingham, whom I had met in September 1840. in Nova-Scotia, and passed a day with him at Kentville, and now loaded us with civilities and attentions— Two Gentlemen, a Yankee by the name of Lyman, and a Scotchman, name not remembered, as a deputation from the Mercantile library association of Montreal, invited us to their rooms and urged me to deliver a Lecture to them this evening, which I declined. Another deputation from the New-England men settled at Montreal invited me also to address them which I likewise declined. Many of them visited me at the Hotel, of whose names I can give no account— We visited the convent of the grey Nuns, at once an Orphan and a Lunatic Asylum— A foundling baby not 3 days old was brought in, not an hour before our visit— Of the maniacs we saw more than enough— We visited also the parade of the 71st regiment of light infantry—Highlanders.— A part of their band of music were 6 pipers with their appropriate dress and feather— And we were visited after the parade by their commander Lieutenant Coll. England, and by Captain H. E. Austen.— Among our other visitors, were Mr Day a native of Connecticut, nephew of the President of Yale College and now a judge of the Court of Queen’s Bench in Canada— With him and Mr Frothingham, after dinner we rode round the mountain stopping on the way at Mr Frothingham’s house; a beautiful retreat about 2 miles out of the city.

20. IV. Thursday—  Mr Leupp and Mr Bowden, who have been travelling with us from Saratoga Springs left us at 9 this morning to pursue their journey to the white mountains of New-Hampshire— Mr Leupp is a young man, an adopted Son of the late Gideon Lee of New-York a former Member of Congress and of the Committee of Manufactures—a conservative Jackson democrat and Harrison whig.— He died within the last two years and left large property to his daughter, married to Mr Leupp— She also died last year at 23. with an infant, and he is a disconsolate widower travelling pour se distraire— Mr Bowden is younger a student of divinity at the episcopal seminary of New-York— They have been social and agreeable companions, and we, especially the Ladies, urged them to continue with us, and parted from them with regret.— My only visitors were the Mayor of Montreal and Doctor Beaubien a member of the City Council both French Canadians, extremely courteous in their regret that the shortness of our stay deprived them of the opportunity of displaying their hospitalities— I took a last walk round the Streets, and purchased as a lasting memento of Montréal a hatchet hammer— At Noon we departed in a Stage— Judge Day, called to take leave just as we entered the carriage— We came 9 Miles to La Chine a small village where we found a Steamer which took us 24 miles to the Cascades. In this boat we dined, and the ever varying beauties of the river, were somewhat modified by swarms innumerable of flies first met at La Chine— The Captain of the boat said they were called eel flies, and were very troublesome for about a month— They were of five or six different forms; one, the least numerous identical with the fish fly of the Potowmac— One a large ant with wings double its own length; two of the moth tribe one as large as the larva of a silk worm, the other that of the common moth. None of these except the last had the impudent familiarity of the common fly—none of them approached the person, but they were crawling about the decks and swarms of them were flying in the wake of the boat and in the air along the shores, all the afternoon till Sunset— At the Cascade, a Stage was ready, and took us 16 miles to the coteau du Lac, the whole distance on the bank of the river obstructed by a constant succession of foaming rapids against which steam itself cannot make head. From Coteau du Lac another Steamer took us after a magnificent Sunset 41 miles to Cornwall, during two hours of this passage we turned into our berths and slept. At 10 p.m, another stage took us over a heavy road of deep sand to Dickinson’s landing where we arrived at Midnight, having traveled by Stage and Steamer 102 miles since noon. Here we found the Steamer Queen Victoria at the wharf waiting for us, and Mr John Fine, who had come from Ogdensburg to invite me to spend a day there. Mr Fine had induced the Captain to make special arrangements for the accommodation of our party, and he gave up his own cabin to me for the Night— The boat is moored to the wharf and is to depart at 4 in the morning.

properties.dateline: Ogdensburg. Friday 21. July 1843. Kingston. Steamer Sovereign.
properties.text: 21. V. Friday—  I slept an hour beyond my time. And the boat had been an hour on her way when I awoke— The Captains cabin was comfortable enough for sleeping; but had no accommodation for writing, and I lost my morning.— The night and the whole of this day the weather was as if specially made for the enjoyment of travellers; but the morning was cold and the middle of the day more than comfortably warm— Just below Cornwall commences the line on the river St. Lawrence the Eastern side of which forms the Counties of St. Lawrence and of Jefferson in the State of New-York, while the western side continues the British Province of Upper Canada— On this Eastern side of the river stands about 60 miles from Cornwall stands the town of Ogdensburg—opposite to which on the British side is the town of Prescott. We reached Ogdensburg between 8 and 9 this morning, and our approach was greeted by the firing of 3 guns and the cheering of huzza’s from the wharf.— Fine said he had forbidden the guns; but the people would fire them— I was unwilling to land and go to the Hotel, and Mr Fine informed the people on the wharf that if any of them inclined to shake hands with me, I would receive them on the deck of the boat where I stood; and about 300 of them, men and boys, came, shook hands with me, and passed off. Fine then told me that there were a number of Ladies at the Hotel who could not come to the boat, and yet wished to see me— I went accordingly to the Hotel, where I found not more than a dozen Ladies, and perhaps an equal number of men, except Henry Van Rensselaer, member of the last Congress from this District, all Strangers to me. I shook hands with them all wished them well, and returned to the boat, to which Mr Van Rensselaer bore me company, and bade me there farewell. We parted from the wharf with three cheers and three guns— Mr Fine continued with us to the next stoppage of the boat at Morristown, where he took leave of me and landed. We soon after entered on the passage through the thousand Islands, and landed, half past 4. at Kingston at the head of Lake Ontario—110 miles from Dickinson’s landing— Here we found the Royal-Mail Packet Steamer Sovereign, of which to my great surprize my old acquaintanceElmsley is the Captain— She was to depart at 8 in the Evening, and in the mean time we took a Carriage and with the Ladies rode round the City first stopping at a Confectioners to take ice-creams— On our return there was a pause whether we should proceed in the boat; a company of nearly 200 Irish and Scotch emigrants having embarked in her, and occupying too much of her cabin— The Ladies went to a Hotel and took tea, and satisfactory arrangements being made returned to the boat— Mr Aylwin a Classmate of my Son Charles, assured me that the Governor General Sir Charles Theophilus Metcalfe would visit me if he knew I was here— We left the wharf at 8. P.M.

properties.dateline: Lake Ontario Saturday 22 July 1843 Niagara Falls.
properties.text: 22. IV.15 Saturday.  The night was calm and beautiful. Captain Elmsley had ceded to me his own cabin, but for the conveniencies of every kind and especially for writing it could bear no comparison with that of Captain Lyon of the Steamer Whitehall on lake Champlain— On rising therefore I went upon the promenade deck, and there beheld twenty-five women and ten or twelve children, all half clad, in ragged and tattered garments, stretched at full length on dirty rags and blankets, with here and there a featherless apology for a bed or pillow—all locked up in sound and quiet sleep.— The Sovereign, was cleaving at the rate of 12 miles an hour the glassy waters of Lake Ontario, close on the British shore of the lake, and a boundless expanse of waters on the other side— I walked upwards of an hour on the deck winding my way between these happy Sleepers, without disturbing them, till the mate came on deck, and speaking in a high tone of voice said come! come! tumble up! tumble up! when they awoke—started upon their bare feet, stretched their arms, shook themselves; packed up in the blankets or sheets on which they had lain,—each the sum total of her bedding, and went forward where was another company not quite so destitute of Scottish emigrants— The others were Irish— The town of Cobourg soon came in sight 110 miles from Kingston shortly before reaching it we passed by a Light house seeming to float on the Lake. It stands on a Rock the peak of which is just level with the surface of the water— The boat stop’d at Cobourg and again 7 miles beyond at Port Hope at each of which places several of the Scotch passengers with their luggage and furniture disembarked— Between 2 and 3. Afternoon we landed at Toronto, and after taking a ride round the town in which there was nothing remarkable to remember we again embarked in the Steamer Queen Victoria. At Toronto, Captain Elmsley’s wife a handsome and elegant woman, the daughter he said of a judge, as he was the son of another, and he introduced her to our Ladies— We left Toronto at 5. p.m. and crossed the Lake to Niagara and Queenstown whence the steamer passed over and landed us at Lewistown— The passage from Toronto to Niagara is 35 miles to Lewistown 7 miles more, and thence by a horse rail way seven Miles to Niagara Falls.— From Kingston to Toronto is 177 miles. We rode in the dark from Lewistown, and reached the Cataract house at the Falls at 9 in the Evening 438 miles from Montreal in 2 days and 9 hours. We found at the Falls, Mrs N. L. Frothingham, and three of her Sons, Octave, Francis andMr Silliman of New-York with his Sister, and multitudes of others.

23. IV:30. Sunday  Arthur’s birth day. 2.  I slept to the sound of the Cataract, and on rising this morning before the Sun I saw the foam of the rapids hurrying to the Falls, right under my window. We breakfasted at 1/2 past 7. with about 150. other visitors to the falls.— Immediately after breakfast General Peter B. Porter came over from his house nearly opposite our hotel, and insisted with so much cordiality on my removal to his house that I consented with great reluctance to part from my company for the time— The houses being so near together that it is little more than occupying a distant apartment of the hotel. I went over, and he introduced to me his daugter 19, his son and namesake 16. a student about to commence junior Sophister at Harvard University, now here in vacation before commencement— His brother’s Son, Peter B. junr. already a middle aged, intelligent active and respected man. Mrs Holley a relative visitor here; and Mr Kelly and Irishman apparently the General’s Secretary, or homme d’Affaires— I met here also Mr Stow, a Gentleman who some weeks since came to Quincy with an earnest invitation from General Porter to me to visit him, which I then declined, and expected never to be able to accomplish.— I enquired for a church to go to for public worship, and found there was a methodist, and a presbyterian church near the hotel, but that attendance at church was not fashionable among the visitors at the falls— But Mr Silliman had formed a party to go to the Tuscarora Indian Settlement 7 miles from the falls, and attend at their church service— General Porter took Mr and Mrs Grinnell and me with him in his carriage and we reached the church while they were singing just before the sermon— An orthodox Presbyterian Calvinist Missionary was the preacher, and in the pulpit which was like the bench of a judicial Court, he and an Indian Chief interpreter stood side by side— The text was from Lukethe parable of the Sower and the seed—the way side hearers and the Stony-ground hearers.— The Indian chief interpreted sentence by sentence, what was said by the missionary— A collection was taken up for a sick and destitute Old woman— The Missionary at suggestion of Genl. Porter announced and the Interpreter repeated that John Quincy Adams once President of the United States was present; whereupon I made to them a short address.— Then at the request of Genl. Porter they sang an English hymn and we departed— On the return we stop’d, and with Mr Grinnell, and Mr Silliman I went down the steps to the whirlpool—an arduous performance— It was between 3. and 4 when we got back to the falls— Dined at General Porter’s with his family and after dinner took a first view of the falls, at the spot at which they are approachable to the very edge of the precipice, and also upon goat or Iris Island. Then returned to the Cataract house, and was detained by visitors till 10 in the Evening when I came to Genl. Porter’s for the Night.

24. IV.30. Monday.  This morning after breakfast, General Porter, with his nephew and namesake, the judge’s son, took me, with Mr Brooks and Mr Grinnell to a farm house and farm owned by him on the brink of the river two miles above the falls, and to Schlosser a mile or more higher up, and in 1837. the Scene of that memorable transaction, the seizure and destruction by a party from the British side of the river, of the Steamboat Caroline, an incident, which brought us nearer to a British, border and civil war than any other since the Peace of Ghent. At Schlosser there is only a single house but a landing place at the rivers edge— In the middle of the river Navy Island, belonging to the British, and Grand Island, to the United States and part of the State of New-York, both covered with forests of primeval trees are so narrowly separated by the channel of the river, that they seem at Schosser to be one continuous island, and just below them commence the rapids rushing to the falls render the river impassable in boats— There is no trace of the tread of hostile feet remaining, and nothing noticeable on the spot, save its reminiscences. We stop’d at the general’s farmhouse and more solid and more costly lime-stone barn, which Mr Brooks thought would suit well at Medford, and John Quincy thought a very good house to live in— The house-wife of the place by a liberal distribution of dough gathered round us a populous tribe of Turkies, geese, ducks, and dunghill fowls among which the sable crested poularde family from Normandy were conspicuous. The soil of the farm is rich, but bound up in limestone of which the General has made durable and substantial Stonewall fences. The cultivation is in the process of défrichement, with a plenteous kitchen garden and a young orchard surrounded by fields of wheat, barley, oats, corn and potatoes, interspersed with lots of lofty, but girdled forest trees, and others bestudded with stumps standing like the pins of a vast bowling green— We returned to the Falls where Mr: Brooks and Mrs. Charles with her Son dined in family at General Porter’s; and after dinner with all our party we again visited the falls upon goat or Iris Island— There is a kitchen and fruit garden there through which I passed with General Porter; and I went to the top of the tower, built by General Porter at a point on the island whence the view of the falls is on this side the river most grand and picturesque— Returning again to the Cataract house several visitors at the falls were introduced to me and among them Mr Meyer, Minister of a Lutheran Church at Philadelphia, and his two daughters. I received a written invitation from Syracuse to stop and visit the people there. ProfessorMitchell of Cincinnati, came with two Resolutions, from the Astronomical Society of that place, inviting me to lay the corner stone of an Observatory which they are about to erect there: and with Letters from judge Burnet and Mr Pendleton urging me to accept the invitation— I asked Mr Mitchell for a short interval of time, to make up my mind, upon a proposal so strange to me; and so flattering that I scarcely dare to think of it with composure.

properties.dateline: Niagara Falls. Tuesday 25 July 1843. Lundy’s Lane. Table Rock.
properties.text: 25. IV.30. Tuesday.  This morning I delivered to professor Mitchell my answer to the Resolution of the Cincinnati Astronomical Society of the 18th. instt. inviting me to lay the corner Stone of the observatory which they propose to erect; and to deliver an Oration on the occasion— I have accepted the invitation, and promised to perform the duty; if in my power some day in the month of November next, to suit the convenience of the Society. This is a rash promise, and in faithfully analysing my motives for making it I wish I could find them pure from all alloy of vanity, and self-glorification. It is an arduous, hazardous and expensive undertaking, the successful performance of which is more than problematical and of the event of which it is impossible for me to forseee any thing but disappointment— Yet there is a motive pure and elevated and a purpose benevolent and generous, at least mingling with the impulses which in this case I obey, and upon which I may without irreverence invoke the blessing of Heaven as I do, for fortitude, energy and perseverance to accomplish what I have promised— Mr Mitchell after receiving my answer, took his departure to return to Cincinnati— Mr. Millard Fillmore and MrLove, heretofore members of Congress came this day, deputed from the City of Buffalo to invite me to visit that place, and Mr Fillmore delivered to me a similar written invitation signed by 13 citizens of Syracuse— I went this morning with Genl. Porter to Goat Island to bespeak a warm bath at the bathing house just above the single sheeted fall from which it borrows the stream that supplies the bath— They had then no heated water, but promised to have some ready for me this evening.— I then walked about an hour before breakfast with the General to re-inspect all the points from which the cascades and the rapids are seen to the best advantage— The sky was unusually clear, the Sun shining in cloudless splendour and the snowy foam of the spray reflected the burning beams in a constantly shifting rainbow adding exquisite beauty to the awful grandeur of the falling flood.— After breakfast, General Porter, with Mr Brooks, Mr and Mrs Grinnell, Mrs Charles and her Son, descended the steps to the ferry, and crossed the river in a small ferry boat over a placid and gentle stream scarcely conscious of the falling tempest so close above them— The ascent on the western side, of the river, though steep and rocky, is practicable, and we found at the landing two Carriages waiting for us, in which we ascended the heights, and rode first to view the scene of the Action at Lundy’s Lane on the 5th. of July 1814. in the last War with Great Britain— We then went to the Clifton house and ordered dinner— Then leaving the Ladies there we proceeded to the plains of Chippewa, where General Porter explained to us the movements on the battleground at that place, on the 25th of July 1814 of which day this is the anniversary— Returning we stop’d and saw the phenomenon of the burning spring and I drank a tumbler of its cool sulphuric water. Dined at the Clifton house— Visited the table rock and the cavern under it— Returned over the ferry. Warm bath— Evening party at Genl. Porter’s.

26. IV:30 Wednesday.  My wedding day. 1797.—  Since I left home, I have been able hither to, to employ two hours of the morning before breakfast in writing, and thus to keep along with the current of time in my journal— But now commences a succession of days so absorbed morning noon and night, that my record must run into arrears very difficult, if not impracticable to retrieve— This morning Genl. Porter took me over to see his brother the judge, who within a few months has been crippled by an accident in which his hip bone was broken, and he can scarcely rise from his seat. At his house I found four clergymen of different denominations who were introduced to me; but whose names escape from my memory.— After a tour in his garden from one corner of which there is a fine view of the falls, I visited with the General their Saw Mill where they were sawing planks— There was also a machine for sawing shingles, not working, but which had been seen and much admired by Mr Brooks. I enquired of one of the workmen, how long the saw which the machinery drives through the log in half a minute and turns out a plank. He said four months and was entirely worn out in that time.— The train of Cars leaves the Falls for Buffalo, at 2. P.M— But the Committee from that City had concluded to take me up from Schlosser in the Steamer Bunker Hill— General Porter took me in his Carriage to Schlosser, and there all our party met, precisely at Noon, the time which had been fixed, the Committee from Buffalo, with a numerous company of Ladies and gentlemen who had taken this opportunity for an excursion of pleasure, and all cordially greeted me and all our party. Here General Porter took leave of me, declining from indisposition the earnest invition of the Citizens of Utica to accompany me thither.— There was another Steamer the Cleveland with a company of Ladies and Gentlemen, equally numerous on a separate excursion, but joining us as in procession— The passage from Schlosser to Buffalo occupied four hours; the banks of the river on both sides presenting a succession of beautiful landscapes. Some of us landed on Grand Island, and inspected the pyramid announcing in Hebrew and in English the city of Ararat founded by Moses M. Noah— We dined in the Steamer: a cold water dinner, and at 4. O’Clock entered in beautiful Style, the harbour of Buffalo, at the entrance of Lake Erie— We were received by shouting multitudes at the landing. I was conducted in an open barouche to a Stage at the park received a complimentary address from Mr Fillmore, which was answered by me addressing the People— After this I rode round the City with Mr Fillmore and the Mayor, then to the American Hotel, and shook hands with some hundreds of men and women— Firemen’s torch light procession— Thunder Shower and Evening party.

27. Thursday IV.15.  The splendid evening party and supper at Buffalo last Evening was at the house of Genlwho had invited us the day before at the Niagara Falls— The Editor of a newspaper at Buffalo, who had been in the park when I answered the address of Mr Fillmore was so distant from me that he could not hear me, and requested me to write out my speech which was impossible. He then offered to come at 5 O’Clock this morning and take it down at my dictation, to which I agreed. He came accordingly precisely at 5 and wrote by my dictation till half past 7. It was a full report of my speech as correct as my memory could repeat what I said— Before breakfast I received a note from Frederick Whittlesey, Thomas Kempshall and Graham H. Chapin all three heretofore members, at different times of the house of Representatives of the United States—requesting an interview with me— They came as a deputation from the citizens of Rochester to invite me to visit that city; which invitation I accepted. At half past 8. A.M. we left Buffalo in the cars 35 miles to Batavia. Here they stopped to take in wood and water— Here a crowd were assembled with Phineas L. Tracy, heretofore a member of Congress, who introduced me to them— A platform in front of the door broke down from the weight of the pressure upon it, and one gentleman who had accompanied us from Buffalo was so much hurt that he was obliged to leave us. I was stepping from the platform into the house when the crash happened and just escaped falling through— From Batavia to Rochester is 32 miles— We arrived at Rochester between 2 and 3.—and found Guns firing, Bells ringing and an immense crowd of People— Shouting— Mr Brooks with Mrs Charles F. Adams, and John Quincy proceeded this Evening to Canandaigua— The first person whom I saw, before I alighted from the Car was Francis Grainger, who had come in deputation from Canandaigua, to invite me to stop a day there; and he brought me a kind and friendly invitation from Mr John Greig; late member of Congress chosen to supply Grainger’s place, when he was appointed Postmaster General, and who when Grainger retired from the Tyler Cabinet, resigned to bring him again into the house.— I consented to stop and dine to-morrow with Mr Greig at Canandaigua; to have an interview and hand shaking with the inhabitants; and then proceed on to Auburn in the Evening— With Mr and Mrs. Grinnell, Cornelia, and Miss Otté I remained for this day at Rochester. We dined at the Eagle Hotel— After dinner rode round the city, and to the cemetery of mount Hope, a copy from that of Mount Auburn superior to the original— At 6. p.m was the public meeting— The Mayor Isaac Hills, addressed me from a stage in front of a public building— I answered him by a speech; and Grainger being called out made a short one— Then came the shaking of hands— In the Evening I received the Ladies at the Eagle Hotel, and made them a short Speech. The firemen’s torch-light procession closed the day.

Tracy, heretofore a member of Congress, who introduced me to them— A platform in front of the door broke down from the weight of the pressure upon it, and one gentleman who had accompanied us from Buffalo was so much hurt that he was obliged to leave us. I was stepping from the platform into the house when the crash happened and just escaped falling through— From Batavia to Rochester is 32 miles— We arrived at Rochester between 2 and 3.—and found Guns firing, Bells ringing and an immense crowd of People— Shouting— Mr Brooks with Mrs Charles F. Adams, and John Quincy proceeded this Evening to Canandaigua— The first person whom I saw, before I alighted from the Car was Francis Grainger, who had come in deputation from Canandaigua, to invite me to stop a day there; and he brought me a kind and friendly invitation from Mr John Greig; late member of Congress chosen to supply Grainger’s place, when he was appointed Postmaster General, and who when Grainger retired from the Tyler Cabinet, resigned to bring him again into the house.— I consented to stop and dine to-morrow with Mr Greig at Canandaigua; to have an interview and hand shaking with the inhabitants; and then proceed on to Auburn in the Evening— With Mr and Mrs. Grinnell, Cornelia, and Miss Otté I remained for this day at Rochester. We dined at the Eagle Hotel— After dinner rode round the city, and to the cemetery of mount Hope, a copy from that of Mount Auburn superior to the original— At 6. p.m was the public meeting— The Mayor Isaac Hills, addressed me from a stage in front of a public building— I answered him by a speech; and Grainger being called out made a short one— Then came the shaking of hands— In the Evening I received the Ladies at the Eagle Hotel, and made them a short Speech. The firemen’s torch-light procession closed the day.
Committee from Rochester— Whittlesey, Kempshall, Chapin— Invitation.— Rochester to Batavia—

28. V:30. Friday  I had about 2 hours this morning to retrieve one day of arrears, which since I left Quebec have crept upon my diary, in spite of every possible exertion— The lapse of unrecorded time constantly reminds me of that irresistible current which hurries down and dashes over the cataracts at Niagara— So am I hurried down the stream of time, and day after day, turns over the precipice and is lost.— We breakfasted at the Hotel, and as were about passing into the Cars, Mr Isaac Mills, the Mayor of Rochester sent to our Ladies a basket of delicious black heart and white heart cherries, perfectly ripe, and of a size such as I have not seen for many years. Mr Grainger and Mr Jared Wilson accompanied us to Canandaigua whence they had been sent as a deputation to meet us— At the entrance of the town we met a cavalcade in military uniform, with a band of music and numerous carriages, all of which united in a procession of a full mile, with bells ringing and a firing of cannon, which left me in amazement to enquire of myself what all this was for— The procession however led me to the brick church, where Mr Francis Granger, introduced me to all the beauty and fashion of Canandaigua, in a highly complimentary address, which I answered as best I could in a speech full of inanity and gratitude— Shame-faced and awkward as I must always be in answering compliments to myself— After the speeches and shaking hands with all the men and women introduced to me in the church, I rode with Mr Francis Granger, whose brother John A. Granger was the Marshal of the day, to the house of his mother, with whom he resides, and where I found his daughter— Thence I went to the splendid mansion of Mr John Greig— A princely palace where I dined with a select party of his friends. He has a handsome library, and fine collections of paintings, engravings, antient coins and shells— Among the rest a volume of Italian engravings shewing the history of the art of painting from Cimabue to Raphael. Also a Volume of fancy Caricature Portraits, long before Hogarth— After dinner, and visiting, Mrs Gorham, widow of Nathaniel Gorham junr Mr Brooks’s brother in Law, and at whose house he, with Mrs Charles and her son John Q had passed the last night we proceeded in the Cars, to Auburn, accompanied by the Ex-Governor William H. Seward and another deputy from Auburn, with an invitation to me to stop there— At Geneva, and several other places on the road, crowds were collected to shake hands with me; to hear me speak a few words, and shout me onward— We arrived at Auburn between 9 and 10 at Night, and by the torch light procession of the firemen I was transported to Governor W. H. Sewards house for the Night.

29. IV:30. Saturday.  In the tumult of our arrival last Evening; in the darkness and the crowd I was separated from my remaining companions—Mr Brooks, Mrs Charles F Adams with her Son John Quincy, and Mr Brooks’s man Perry. They were landed at the public hotel, while I was taken to Mr Seward’s— Mr and Mrs Grinnell, with their adopted daughter Cornelia and her governess and companion Miss Otté, parted from us at Aurelius at the head of the Cayuga lake, near which they have relatives to visit, and we shall see them no more— Mr Seward requested his Lady to go to the Hotel, and urge Mrs Charles to come to his house; and she appeared willing to go; but I persuaded her to stay at home. Mr Seward’s father and mother were on a visit at his house; and both much indisposed— I soon retired to bed— This morning at half past 6. Mr Seward went with me to the Hotel and invited Mr Brooks to breakfast at his house, and to visit with us the State Prison both of which he declined— Mrs Seward visited Mrs Charles but did not please her— Mr Seward accompanied me in the inspection of the State prison, where I found Mr Ulysses F. Doubleday, an ex-member of the 22d. Congress, as Superintendent.— The system of prison discipline at Auburn discards the solitary cell altogether— The convicts work together at ten different mechanical trades; but they are not allowed to speak to one another— There are now 731 convicts there and they work as Tailors, Shoemakers, Weavers and other trades, but are not taught them as apprentices.— They appeared to be all industriously at work, and there was an admirable observance of cleanliness and order— With Governor Seward, the Committee from Auburn, who met me at Canandaigua and came thence with me consisted of judge Conkling, judge Miller, Luman Sherwood, P. H. Perry, Stephen A. Goodwin, James C. Wood, and J. S. Doty— The Committee of Arrangements at Auburn P. Bronson, U. F. Doubleday, Abijah Fitch, M. S. Myers and George H. Wood— After breakfast, this morning Mr Brooks visited Govr Seward and conversed with his father, who though yet very unwell came down. At 9. O’Clock, we went to the Presbyterian Church; where Mr Seward addressed and introduced me to the People; and I answered in a Speech of about half an hour.— Christopher Morgan a member of the 26th. and 27th. Congresses had come from Aurora to meet me, and invite me there, but I could not go— He came on with me to Syracuse—as did Mr Seward and others of the Auburn Committee; and the whole military company of the Auburn guards— The distance from Auburn to Syracuse is 26 miles which we traversed in one hour and 5 minutes— Repetition of Address answer and shaking of hands— A public dinner, with cold water and a speech and toast from Governor Seward, briefly answered by me— Here I met the Revd. J. P. Boyd Storer— Ride after dinner to the Salt Springs and Salt works—address and answer there.— At 6. returned to the Cars. Reached Utica at 10 in the Evening. Torch light to Alexander B. Johnson’s.

IV:45. 30. Sunday.  Mr Johnson first wife was Abigail Louisa Smith Adams; second daughter of my brother Charles, and of Sarah Smith, sister of Coll. William Stevens Smith of New York who married my sister— The first seven of the children named in the margin with the dates of their birth; were the children of my niece, and grandchildren of my brother Charles—besides which she was the mother of  John Adams. born 3. Octr. 1815. died 29. Novr 1820  Bryan. born 30. April 1819. died 30. Octr 1837  John Adams. born 28. Feby 1821. died 28. Augt. 1839.  My Niece died 4 July 1836.  Mr Johnson marriedhis present wife,—and by her has the two children last named  Mr Ezekiel Bacon called on me early this morning.— Though chairman of the Committee of arrangements for my reception at Utica, such was the confusion in the crowd and darkness of last evening, that he missed of meeting me. I was taken into a Carriage, and brought to Mr Johnson’s through a dense mass of population. I know not how or by whom— They brought me by the torch light procession of the firemen— From the porch of Mr Johnson’s house I thanked them for their kindness and I said I hoped and trusted we should all devote this day to the worship and service of almighty God; and that to-morrow, I should have the happiness of meeting again my fellow citizens face to face, when I should endeavour to find words to thank them for their kindness— Mr Brooks was also lost for some time in the crowd; and Mrs Charles though in the charge of William C. Johnson was so much alarmed that she actually screamed. John Quincy, in charge of Perry, got through without difficulty, and we were all received with kindness and cordiality by Mr Johnson and all his family— This morning, with Mr Brooks, Mr Johnson and Mr Bacon attended us to the episcopal church—where the minister Mr Proal read the morning service for the 7th. Sunday after Trinity and preached an excellent and elegant sermon from Revelation 6.2. “And I saw, and behold a white horse; and he that sat on him had a bow; and a crown was given unto him: and he went forth conquering and to conquer”— Whole family dinner at Mr Johnson’s. After dinner I went with Mr. Bacon to the Dutch Church—where Mr Knox preached from Proverbs, 14.9 “Fools make a mock at sin: but among the righteous there is favour.” The discourse was confined to the first clause of the text— At 7. in the evening, I went again with Mr Bacon to the Presbyterian Church, and heard its Minister, Mr Porter from Psalm 104.34. “My meditation of him shall be sweet: I will be glad in the Lord.[”] A very cheerful and cheering discourse upon the pleasures of sincere piety.
Revn. 6:2. 7th. after Trinity— Proal  Proverbs 14.9. Knox— Psalm 104.34— Porter—

31. IV.30. Monday.  I have concluded to stay till Wednesday Morning, on a visit to Mr Johnson and his family, and Mr Bacon, and the committee of arrangements for the publication thought it best to postpone that ceremony till 10 O’Clock to-morrow morning to give the opportunity for persons living in the neighbourhood of the city to come in and see the show— And this day was taken to visit the Trenton Falls.— But Mr Brooks’s patience could hold out no longer. He left Utica in the train of Cars for Albany on his return home, taking with him his Coach, driver Perry, and his grandson John Quincy— Mr Alexander Smith eldest son of Mr Johnson, whom we found here on a visit to his father is a practicing lawyer already of some reputation in the city of New-York— He was obliged to return, and left us also at 10.— We then went, a party in two Carriages, and viewed the Trenton Falls: distant 15 miles in a Northern direction from Utica, in the County of Herkimer— The party consisted of Mr and Mrs Johnson, their Sons, William, Charles and Arthur, and their daughter Sarah. Mrs Charles F. Adams, who went in a chaise with William C. Johnson—Mr Joshua A. Spencer the U.S. District Attorney for the Northern District of New-York and myself. The ride was extremely pleasant, and the country all around beautiful and fertile. But the falls belong to a person by the name of Shepherd. There is near them, also belonging to him, a house heretofore kept as a tavern, but now closed and uninhabited. The descent to the falls is as steep, and nearly as deep as that of the whirlpool at Niagara, and the wooden flights of steps, laid to facilitate the descent are rotting into spungy funk every step of which threatens to give way under the foot, and to pitch the traveller into the abyss— The falls of which there are seven within the compass of half a mile are each separately of not more than 40 or 50 feet in sheets of water perhaps 200 feet wide rushing down with terrific violence, and dashing over rocks in many cases turning corners with a force of friction which would seem sufficient to fire the rock— The passage between the two lofty and wood crowned ridges is like a ruptured chasm made by an earthquake, and the concave sides of a limestone wall descending to a level with the stream leaves an edge barely wide enough for the foot of the passenger to step along with the aid of an iron chain fastened to the side of the rock, and held by the left hand as he slides along but wherever the edge of the rock under foot is but a few inches wider the chain is intermitted and the pilgrim staggers along as he may— Within these few years two females, a child of Mr Thorn, the Croesus of New-York, and a Miss Suydam have fallen and been plunged into eternity while visiting this Scene for curiosity— Near the last of the falls there is a small shed inhabited as a dwelling house by a son of Henry R. Storrs, where we found a draught of spruce beer, and benches on which we disposed of the basket of Sandwiches brought with us from Utica.— We returned from this hovel in our Carriages to the uninhabited house, where we met Miss Van der Kemp, the daughter of the late Francis Adrian Van der Kemp and Miss Mappa a daughter of his associate.— They live with one of his Sons, in a small house where he resided in a village now called Russia, but which he called Olden Barnevelt— We visited them there; and returned to Utica, between 6 and 7. in the Evening well wearied and worn out— The visit to the Trenton falls is imminently dangerous— Yet the Johnson’s trip over it, like Rope dancers on a tight rope.
