1. V.15. Tuesday—  I received yesterday a Letter from Daniel Thompson, Benjamin Anderson, and Tucker Woodson, a Committee appointed by the coloured citizens of Utica, to wait on me, and return their thanks for my efforts, in protecting the right of petition, and promoting the abolition of Slavery, and proposing to come, if it would be agreeable to me, in the Evening. I accordingly received them about 8. O’Clock, and one of them addressed me in a short, but formal speech, modest and well delivered. I answered them with equal brevity: thanking them for their kind attentions to me; assuring them that I had no claim to gratitude from them for services in which I had performed no more than my indispensable— That I should still and ever be happy to serve them to the utmost extent of my power, and commend them to the protection of our common father and creator— My first visit this morning immediately after breakfast was to the female Seminary, where I was introduced to the assembled teachers and pupils, and addressed in behalf of the trustees of that institution by Mr Spencer in a manner so affecting that it made a child of me. It consisted chiefly of extracts which he read from my mothers published Letters of 19. August 1774. to my father, and of June 1778 to me.— I actually sobbed as he read, utterly unable to suppress my emotion— Oh! my Mother! Is there any thing on earth so affecting to me as thy name? so precious as thy instructions to my childhood? so dear as the memory of thy life? I answered, I know not what— My thoughts were all upon my mother— My heart was too full for my head to think, and my presence of mind was gone— At the close of his address, Mr Spencer presented to me, at the request of the Ladies 12 numbers of a monthly publication, from August 1842 to July 1843. called the Young Ladies Miscellany the original productions of the Utica female Academy— At 10. O’Clock the reception took place, on a stage erected in front of the Bleecker house; where Mr Bacon addressed and welcomed me in the name of the citizens of Utica: I answered him in a speech of about half an hour, sufficiently cheered for my hopes or wishes, but of mortifying inanity to myself— The shaking of some hundred hands then followed, and on my way, returning to Mr Johnson’s I stop’d and four Daguerrotype likenesses of my head were taken: two of them jointly with the head of Mr Bacon. all hideous— Then a visit to the dwarf. C. F. Stratton called General Tom Thumb. 11 years old—25 inches high; weighing 15 pounds. Dressed in a military uniform, mimicking Napoleon. Dinner party at Mr Johnson’s. Ride after dinner to the Lunatic hospital. John M. Niles, U.S. Senator from Connecticut is there. Thence we went to the York Mills Cotton Factory. where there was a crowd—a reception a procession, an address and speech; and a present of several pieces of the cotton cloth which I declined accepting. Elegant evening party and supper at Mr Johnson’s.

2. V. Wednesday.  I have ceased altogether writing in the morning before Breakfast; and having no other part of the day at my own disposal, my diary has already run ten days in arrear— At 7. this morning Mr Bacon came and went with me to the Shadow shop, where three more Daguerrotype likenesses were taken of me, no better than those of yesterday. They are too true to the original— At 10. O’Clock I left Mr Johnson’s house, and Utica; accompanied by Genl. Ostrum and Mr Seymour, who insisted in coming with me to Albany. Mrs Charles of all our original traveling party remains at Utica, proposing to move homeward next Monday, escorted by William C. Johnson, and his sister Sarah Adams, whom I have invited to visit us— I had received yesterday from Alexander C. Gibson, mayor of the city of Schenectady, by the hands of Alderman Benedict, and Recorder Harman, a pressing invitation to make a short stay at that place, and other deputations had come yesterday to Utica to give me like invitations to those places— An old German clergyman, was one of the deputation from Herkimer and reminded me with loquacious gratitude, that in 1822 when Secretary of State, I had been of some service to him in procuring for him a remittance from his native Country, of an inheritance which had there fallen to him in the right of his wife. 3. V. Thursday.  At ten O’ Clock this morning I met again the People of Albany, in company with Mr Barnard, who addressed and welcomed me in their name, from the stoop of Mr Gregory’s house facing the Capitol Park— There was no public building in the City capable of containing a tythe of the assembled multitude. I answered Mr Barnard’s address, by a speech of about half an hour, well received and of which the only fault which I heard found with it was that it was too short. To myself it was but the crowning proof how unfit I am for such occasions, and a lesson at once of profound gratitude, and humility— When the shouts which followed its close had subsided notice was given to the citizens that I would repair to the Governor’s chamber in the Capitol, and there shake hands with any one who would desire it— About 500 of them, perhaps one tenth of the whole number, went through this ceremony, after which there was a separate presentation to some 200 ladies assembled in the Senate chamber, and to whom I also made a grave, and not a flattering speech— After this I was conducted by the Committee of arrangements and viewed the public Offices of the State Government; and then in another building those of the City. Some of the most antient archives of the State, in the low dutch language were exhibited to me— Among the persons who now accompanied me was Mr Flagg, heretofore the Comptroller of the State. Mr Bouck the Son of the present Governor was among the individuals introduced to me last evening and again this morning— He presented to me his father’s compliments with his regret that he had been obliged to leave the city upon private business yesterday morning. Governor Marcy was among those who met and greeted me as was Mr Edwin Crosswell the somewhat celebrated Editor of the Albany Argus— Mr Van Buren himself is at the Saratoga Springs; as we were informed by Mr Isaac C. Bates who came from thence last Evening;—and proceeded on his journey homeward this morning— After a retirement of two hours to my chamber at Mr Barnard’s for repose, I met at his table a party of about 20. of his friends, among whom were the Mayor of the City and Mr Lansing—General Rufus King, a son of Charles King, Dr Potter, the Rector of the Episcopal church, at which Mr Barnard worships, and others. strangers, whose names I could not retain— After dinner we visited the mansion house of the Patroon, the late Stephen Van Rensselaer, whose eldest son of the same name resides there. He is now absent; but his wife, and her brother in Law and Sister Mr and Mrs Bayard received and treated us with great kindness. The house, about 2 miles out of the city, Garden and Green house are elegant and comfortable— We returned to Albany and the Evening closed, with a party of Ladies and gentlemen given by Mrs Barnard, and from which by a refinement of courtesy to me the Company retired at an early hour.

4. V. Friday.  At half past 6 this morning Mr Barnard took me in his carriage to the landing place in the city of Albany—whence the Steamboat crosses the river Hudson to take the Cars of the great Western Railroad to Boston— He crossed the river with me and took leave of me at the Cars— Mr George N. Briggs had come deputed with an invitation to me, from the inhabitants of Pittsfield; and I had received a written invitation from Mr Edward A. Newton, to take rooms during my visit to Pittsfield at his house— Mr Briggs and another of the deputies accompanied me. The distance from Albany to Boston traversed by the Western Railroad is 200 miles— Pittsfield is 52 miles and Springfield one hundred from Albany— The cars reached Pittsfield at 10 O’Clock in the morning— The road from Albany was the same we had travelled on the 11th. of last month, as far as Canaan where we then came from Lebanon Springs and returned to the train, we had parted from four days before at Pittsfield— We again came through the village of Kinderhoek, and again passed through the subterranean Tunnel.— We passed in sight of Lebanon, which I remembered with pleasure, and, and the spot was pointed out to me of the line which separates from each other the States of New-York and Massachusetts— Mr Newton’s carriage was at the depot in Pittsfield, and I was taken in immediately to his house— It was immediately crowded with visitors; till the citizens were informed that I would meet and exchange salutations with them at the presbyterian church at Noon— In the meantime the Berkshire County Medical Association, casually assembled here upon business of their own, came with their President—at their head—his honour Henry H. Childs Lieutenant Governor of this Commonwealth; who introduced them all to me, perhaps to the number of 120. and with them all I cordially shook hands— I found myself suddenly though not unexpectedly unwell, and retired for an hour of repose to a bed chamber. Mr Newton has among his pictures a portrait of my father upon which he asked my opinion. It was a copy, by his brother an eminent painter, who died in England, 3 or four years since, of one of Stewart’s portraits of my father— At noon a procession was formed to the Church and there Mr Briggs addressed and welcomed me, in a highly complimentary speech, which I answered with what ever of Spirit was left me, mortified, exhausted and ashamed— I then shook hands in the church, with all the men and women who presented themselves, after which we proceeded to the public house and partook of a plentiful cold water dinner— Among the guests to this were Mr HenryShaw of Lanesborough, and Josiah Quincy junr. now abiding at Lenox. Lieutt. Governor Childs presided, and after dinner there was a quantum sufficit of toasts of sentiments and of flabby Speeches— They were succeeded by a ride of 8 or 10 of the party to the female Academy where we were met by a procession of the Lady teachers and pupils—an Address, a Speech; and a song by the young Ladies— At 6. P.M. we took the Cars for Springfield and arrived there after 9.— There was no room for us at Warriner’s, and we put up at the American Hotel.— Mr W. C. Calhoun came in.

5. IV. Saturday.  I was very much indisposed all night—and rose this morning worn out, and exhausted. Mr William C. Calhoun had come in last Evening to arrange the reception which had been projected for me at Springfield— But the people had expected my arrival this morning, and by coming prematurely Calhoun said I had spoiled all the fun— The sight of me is no novelty at Springfield— They have seen me come and go time after time without exciting any interest or emotion: I thought a reception here would be flat and unprofitable, and concluded to make the best of my way home, by taking the morning Cars, and escaping from another repetition of a ceremony already satiated with repetitions.— Mr Calhoun after urging me without importunity to stay, insisted, if I would go, upon accompanying me as far as Worcester. Mr Briggs and Mr Pomeroy took leave of me, and at half past 6. departed in the morning Cars upon their return to Pittsfield, immediately after which I took my seat in the train for Boston, and among many other fellow passengers all strangers, met, my old pupil subsequent protégé, and now alienated friend Alexander H. Everett, a political outcast, the wreck of his own ill woven ambition, and the envious and vindictive craftiness of another man more cunning and unprincipled than himself— At Worcester Mr Calhoun took leave of me to return home, and I closed my journey alone.— I had often travelled between Springfield and Boston, and three times, since the opening of the railroads— The movements are so rapid that I am scarcely conscious of transportation from place to place— I had conversation upon topics of unimpassioned interest; as much as the jarring noise of the cars would admit and on recognizing the village of Natick I was reminded of my rides to and from that town in the frost and snow of last November, as well as of my passage through it with numerous friends on the 6th of last month. At a quarter before 12 we reached the depot at South Boston, and I parted from Mr Everett without a taking of leave on either side. I left my trunk at the depot and walked to my Son’s office N. 23 Court Street to enquire if he was in town—but neither he nor Mr Spooner was there— I next enquired at the stable where he keeps his horse. He was not in town— I returned to the depot, and had a long search for my trunk which had disappeared; but was at last found in the baggage office— I met Mr Peter C. Brooks junr in Washington Street, and passed by Mr Thomas Loring, who did not see me— I returned to the Stable; took there a hack; stop’d at the Railway depot and took my trunk, and came out alone to my home at Quincy, precisely one Calendar month from the day when I left it— I found the family at dinner. My wife—my Son John’s widow, Mary Catherine, and her daughter, Mary Louisa—

6. IV:30. Sunday  Rain all Night and all this day— We rode to Meeting both morning and afternoon and from Meeting. Communion day. Mr Lunt’s morning text was from John 6.56. “He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood dwelleth in me, and I in him.”— This was said in the Asiatic style of figurative language, and even when spoken shocked the multitude of his hearers in the synagogue at Capernaum, so violently that perceiving their astonishment and disgust he explained that he spoke the words in a spiritual sense—not withstanding which the Apostle says, “from that time many of his disciples went back, and walked no more with him.” Nor is it surprizing—The source of all figurative language is the analogy between the operations of matter and of mind. In the expression of complicated ideas, there may be points of close and luminous analogy between flesh and spirit, associated with other points of the most abhorrent opposition— The Asiatic or Oriental style, seizes upon one striking point of analogy, and totally suppresses or disregards all other points not harmonizing with it— The Attic or Grecian styles shuns all these complicated analogies, which mislead or confuse the mind, with incongruous ideas and contradictory associations.— It requires harmony of thought—not expecting that the similitude should run upon all fours; but forbidding the attempt walk upon one or limp lamely upon two— When Jesus told his disciples that they must eat his flesh and drink his blood, his allusion was at once to the sacrifice of the paschal lamb, to the institution of the passover and to its connection with the wheat harvest by the eating of unleavened bread— But taken by itself, the declaration that he came from Heaven, commissioned to renovate the nature of man, and that his disciples must begin by eating his flesh and drinking his blood—who could hear him without believing that he was either a maniac, or an impostor— A Canibal, and not a teacher come from God?— The apostles however adhered to him, and afterwards when he kept the passover, immediately preceding his crucifixion, he instituted the perpetual memorial of his death and resurrection, by repeating the same figure—by breaking and distributing the bread as his body, and presenting the cup as his blood.— This incident is not noticed in John’s Gospel but is related in the 26th Chapter of Matthew—the 14th. of Mark, and the 22d. of Luke— Mr Lunt administered the Communion, of which I partook in humiliation and prayer.— The text of the discourse in the afternoon was from Acts 5.1. [“]But a certain man, named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife sold a possession. 2. And kept back part of the price, and brought a certain part, and said it at the apostles feet.” Jesus Christ himself required of his disciples the devotion of all their property to the propagation of faith in him, and in his religion— After his death his disciples, by a common voluntary agreement began by holding all their property in common— But this could not last long, and this case of Ananias and Sapphira was no doubt intended to prove that human nature was not yet sufficiently purified for the practical establishment of this principle, as a permanent institution.— The crime of Ananias and Sapphira, was in the deception which they attempted, to practice; and not in withholding their property.— That the Apostle Peter declared was optional, and after awful example of punishment inflicted upon the fraud, the community of goods was thenceforward abandoned—

7. V:15. Monday  Franklin White a painter of portraits by trade had called on me, before I went upon my late journey, and requested me to sit to him for my portrait, which I promised to do—after my return— He came this morning and claimed the performance of my promise— And this afternoon he came again and took a sitting of an hour— Mr Samuel Copeland came also with two bills. Lewis Tappan was here with his wife and two daughters but the Ladies declined alighting from his carriage, and he stayed with me but a few minutes— The day after he was here on the 31st. of last May, he embarked for England, and has just now just returned— He attended the second World’s convention held at London from the 18th. to the 22d. of June, and gave me a brief and rapid summary of their proceedings— He said he had a Letter to me from Thomas Clarkson, and sundry papers containing full and detailed reports of the proceedings of the Convention— But they were at Brookline and he would send them to me— He was to go for New-York this afternoon— He said he had told Lord Aberdeen of my distrust of the British Government on the subject of Slavery, and particularly on the surrender of fugitive Slaves. He said Lord Aberdeen was startled at the suggestion, and utterly disclaimed all intention of suffering the tenth Article of the Ashburton Treaty to be made the instrument of reclaiming Slaves— This Article is a pattern example of diplomatic swindling— There is hope that its purpose may be defeated by the alarm of the English abolitionists and their remonstrances against it before the enact of it by Parliament as English Law.— A grosser fraud was never practiced upon nations than was intended by that article— The apologies for it, by Lord Ashburton, and by the British Ministers are lame and prevaricating—and from the statements of Mr Tappan, all my suspicions of the duplicity of the British Ministers, on the subject of Texas and Slavery are but too strongly confirmed.— The policy of the British Government is to cherish sustain and protect the institutions of Slavery in our Southern States, and in Texas, and their task is to do it by humbugging the abolitionists in England into the belief that they intend directly the reverse— Richard C Greenleaf was here with a young man from New-York named Stalknecht an emigrant from Germany, but who has made his way so well in this Country that he has a subordinate Clerk’s office under the Supreme Court of the State of New-York, and is said to be paying his addressed to Mary, the daughter of Mrs Lucy Dawes. Isaac Hull Adams and Francis Frothingham were also here— The weather was dull and gloomy the whole day, and I paid only a transient visit to my garden Nursery and seminary of seedling trees— Enough hower to discover the ravages by the blazing Sun, and the protracted drought, which has burnt up all vegetation here since I left it flourishing on the 6th of July.

8. IV:30. Tuesday.  Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. Mr and Mrs. Leman were here this morning before 7 O’Clock; and they breakfasted with us— Mr Leman is 70 years of age and I perceived he was labouring under great agitation— He had taken from Mr Curtis and Mrs Alicia Boylston, a Lease of a lot of land in Charlestown, for five years to expire in Novr. 1844. upon which he has erected a building to serve at once for a dwelling house and a Carpenter’s shop. But he gave me a mortgage of the house as security for the timber and planks of which it was built, and now the mortgagees, are making demonstrations and preparations for removing the house, and he is in fear of being turned out of house and home— He has flattered himself with the hope that the house having become a fixture to the soil was real estate and could not be removed without previous process of law; and I countenanced him at first with in that opinion. but recollecting afterwards that a Statute of the Commonwealth gives to the tradesmen working on a building, a lien upon the materials of which it is built, I feared he was leaning upon a broken reed, and advised him to consult with Mr Curtis, and Mr A. C. Spooner—my Son’s associate in the office. N. 23. Court Street to devise some means of extricating him from his perplexity— After Breakfast he wandered with me round the garden and Nursery and took sundry twigs of trees for keepsakes; and took leave My Son gave me a check on the Merchants Bank for 700 dollars, which I deposited in the Quincy Stone bank here, and I settled 2 bills of Samuel Copeland— Isaac Hull Adams and his sister Elizabeth were here— There was a Letter from Mrs Charles F. Adams to her son Henry, from Utica; doubtful whether she would leave that city as she had intended yesterday.— I received also a Letter from C. Oscanyan dated 31. May at Constantinople. He is a native of that city; whence, I know not how, he came to this Country; resided here several years, and married an American woman in New-York— The object of the Letter is to solicit the appointment of Dragoman to the American Legation at the Ottoman Porte— A Sinecure vacated by the decease some months since of Commodore David Porter— Oscanyan was an acquaintance of some of the younger members of my family, and used to visit occasionally at my house, but he is sadly out of his reckoning in applying to me for influence to obtain for him a diplomatic appointment— We had this day two or three thunder showers so that I was much confined to the house, and the contrast between the perpetual motion, the ever gathering crowds of people—the greetings and salutations, and huzzas of the multitudes, with the rapid travelling alternately by Stage, Steamer and railway, and the dark and sullen quietude of my own house thus confuses me and keeps an unseizable cotrarion in my head—a buzzing tintinnabulum which will end in distraction or lethargy— I struggle to recover my self possession and the controul of my thoughts.— They are yet in a whirlwind.

9. IV. Wednesday.  Showery day, which still detained me from visitation of my grounds, and from exercise abroad— Mr William Barry was here with a bill for four years subscription to the common school journal. He asked me if I recollected that in the summer of 1809 just before I embarked for St. Petersburg, the hatters of Boston applied to me to draw up for them a memorial to Congress— I remembered it well— He said he was the person who made the application to me— It is noticed in my Diary of 26 June 1809., but the name of the person applying is not reported and I did not now remember that it was Mr Barry.— Isaac H. Adams was also here and Franklin White the painter to whom I gave a second sitting of an hour— It must be extremely difficult for any painter to take a favourable likeness of me now—for I cannot sit five minutes or three or even one, with out, falling into a doze— This propensity which I have long observed grows upon me to such an extent, that I ought to be deeply alarmed at its progress—for its termination may overtake me every day, and every hour of my life— It benumbs every faculty of my body and soul. It portends a moment of Sleep from which there will be no awaking upon earth, and of which I am in constant expectation— When I ask myself why I do not make immediate and effective provision for instantaneous departure whenever that summons shall come, I have no answer to make other than the frailty of my nature— This irresistible spell has made it impossible to take a good daguerrotype likeness of me, and it baffles though not in equal degree the skill of the portrait painter, who cannot give life or animation to a countenance all the muscles of which are all the time lapsing into slumber— It deadens alike all the faculties of the mind, and is a continual warning to me of the decays of my powers native and acquired— Shall I ever take it?— This evening I visited Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf my neighbours each four score years of age— I requested him to mention to their son E. Price, that I wished to see him— My time is now almost entirely consumed in bringing up the arrears into which my journal had fallen in the course of my month’s excursion; and with the most intense exertions, I cannot recover more than one day in a day. Many of the Newspapers have reported the proceedings at the places, where I was received with honorary notice— It began at Saratoga Springs on the 12th. of July— I escaped it not without difficulty at Burlington Vermont— Then after a suspension of one week in Canada, the display was recommenced at Ogdensburg and continued to Pittsfield in Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

10. IV. Thursday  I rose at four, but the cloudy sky restrained me from sallying forth to observe the rising Sun. At five, I saw a man walking to and fro in the yard fronting my windows between the gate and the porch, without knocking or ringing the bell at the door; and on going down found it was Daniel Leman, the man from Charlestown, but this time without his wife— He came on the same business as before, in terror of having his house taken off over his head. He remained here two hours complaining of the hardness of his fate which was neither more nor less than inability to pay his debts.— Mr Curtis was afterwards here and we concluded to purchase the mortgage on the house, and leave him in possession of the house till the expiration of his lease; leaving him in the interval time for preparing to depart or for procuring the means of paying his rent— Leman’s son was here in the afternoon anxious for the relief of his father, and I informed him of the manner, in which Mr Curtis and I proposed to effect it— Mr Wilder and Mr Hearsey, are a Committee of the Proprietors of the first social Library in the South parish of Hingham; and called on me to enquire if there was not a joint Resolution of Congress, by which that Society are entitled to receive a copy of the diplomatic correspondence published by Congress— I looked over the volumes of the Laws, but could find no such resolution I promised however to make further enquiry, and if I should find they have the right I will take care to procure the books for them— A person by the name of George Piggott came from Boston to make enquiry after Martha Cumming a woman who served as cook, while I was absent, and took a leave of absence for a week and has never returned— Piggott says she boarded at his house, and has gone off in debt to him— She had left her trunk here; but we did not think ourselves authorised to let him have it— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came, and examined some of my stocks of seedling Apple trees— This is the season for that operation, and Mr Greenleaf usually performs it for me. He promised to procure some buds of excellent apples, and to come and bud the trees next Tuesday afternoon, if by that time he can get the slips— I received this morning by the mail the Bangor Courier of thecontaining my Letter of 4 July last to Asa Walker, Charles A. Stackpole, And F. M Sabine. It is announced as a Letter from John Quincy Adams on Slavery—with a statement that it was read at the Meeting on the 1st. of August and without one word of comment upon it— I have expected the publication of this Letter, and expect to be held to severe responsibility for writing it— Before my lamp is burnt out, I am desirous that my opinions concerning the great movement throughout the civilized world for the abolition of Slavery should be explicitly avowed and declared— God grant that they may contribute to the final consummation of that event— There are sundry errors of the press, and of the manuscript to be rectified, and to which I must attend.

11. IV:15. Friday.  Rain all Night, and almost the whole of this day. Confined of course to the house, and gave a somnolent sitting to Mr Franklin White, who said he should want only one more. My Son went to Boston in the Stage, and while we were at dinner returned home, with his wife, William C. Johnson, and his sister Sarah Adams, named after grandmother, my brother Charles’s wife.— They left Utica Wednesday Morning. Came that day to Albany. Yesterday to Springfield—and landed this day noon at Boston. We went up and spent the evening with them at Charles’s house I received also this morning, forwarded from New-York by Lewis Tappan; a Letter from Thomas Clarkson, of 2 July 1843. at Playford Hall near Ipswich Suffolk in England—with a printed prospectus for the publication of the proceedings of the Anti-Slavery convention held at London, from the 19th. to the 20th. of June last.— A printed address signed by Thomas Clarkson, in behalf of the British and foreign Anti-Slavery Society; dated 7. July 1843. to Lord Aberdeen, and earnestly remonstrating against the annexation of Texas to the United states— The British and foreign Anti-Slavery Reporter of 14. 21. 28 June and 12 July and the morning Chronicle of 14 July. These contain a full exposition of the proceedings of the second World’s convention, at which no very conspicuous person attended excepting Lord Morpeth— His Speech to the Convention on taking the chair, was firm, moderate and discreet— The Resolution honorary to me which he offered, and which was unanimously adopted, is an indication of personal respect for my character beyond the Atlantic which ought to fill my soul with humility and with fervent gratitude to God— These events occuring at the same period with the manifestation of kindly feeling towards me, from the people of the State of New-York, and with the invitation from Cincinnati to lay the corner stone of their observatory, seem temptations of prosperity too great for frail human nature to resist or to bear with impunity. I pray for the calmness and sensibility suited to justice and to the true estimate of worldly honours.— And I received a Letter from Mr Andrews the young lawyer from Texas who visited me the day before he embarked with Mr Tappan for England— He is encouraged in the hope of accomplishing with the aid of British influence the abolition of Slavery in Texas— But I perceive nothing as yet to relieve the deep distrust which I would fain discard if I could, of the British ministerial policy with regard to Slavery in Texas and in our Southern States— Her interest is to sustain and cherish Slavery there, and there is too much reason to surmise, that in the conflict between policy and principle, Slavery with bear off the palm.

12. IV. Saturday.  Sun rose cloudy.— The return to a sedentary life from a month of great and constant agitation, excitement and over exercise forms a trial of the Constitution— It seems as if a hurricane had passed over my spirits; and now, when they have been a whole week settling down into the ordinary quiet current of rural Summer life, exercise is necessary to save them from falling into Syncope— My time for exercise is from the hour of rising till breakfast; and if I miss it then the day is very apt to slip through without it— For exercise I am obliged to resort to my garden and seedling trees— I emptied a seedling pot into Mary Louisas Seminary plot, where there is now a seedling Apple stock—An Englis Oak and a shagbark walnut, all of the third year— When Mr Curtis was here day before yesterday, I agreed to meet him in Boston next Monday Morning, to execute the deeds of exchange with the purchasers of the Tremont Theatre— Also to meet Mr Fuller the administrator of Moses Gill junr. and endeavour to come to a settlement, at the probate office with him. And further to prepare a Letter to Petty Vaughan at London to be sent by the Acadia to sail for Liverpool next Wednesday— Mr Curtis dined with us and returned home immediately after dinner. This day there were visits from Mr Lunt, and Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham with whom I agreed to go upon our usual annual fishing party from Cohasset, next Thursday. Isaac Hull Adams and his Sister Elizabeth William C. Johnson, and his sister Sarah were here, and the latter is to stay with Mary-Louisa, while upon her visit here— We received a Piano from Boston, upon hire by the week. The Boston Courier of this morning republishes from the Bangor Courier my Letter of 4 July last to the Bangor Committee for celebrating the anniversary of the emancipation of Slaves in the British West India Islands; with all the errors of the Bangor, and several more. Not a word of comment upon the Letter is in either of the papers— I expected the publication of that Letter; and wrote it for the purpose of exhibiting in as brief a compass as possible my principles, feelings and opinions, relating to the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade throughout the world— I meant it as a note of defiance to all the Slave-holders, Slave traders and Slave breeders upon earth. As the experiment of Summons to the whole Freedom of this Union in its own defence, I sent it forth alone, to try its Fortune in the world, and made it purposely bold and startling, to rouse if possible both friend and foe— The two publications without comment, give no promise of a rally for the support of Freedom. As yet there is no hostile notice of it abroad— It may remain altogether unnoticed, which is the worst fate that can befall it—for if I can but raise a controversy by it—that is; an adversary worthy of being answered, it shall be if my life and health will admit, a text book for future enlargement and illustrative for the whole remnant of my toilsome days.

13. V. Sunday.  Dr Frothingham preached, in exchange with Mr Lunt. His morning text was from Psalm 27.3. [“]Though a host should encamp against me, my heart shall not fear: though war should rise against me, in this will I be confident.” The turn of mind of Dr Frothingham is so original that from the enunciation of his text it is impossible to foresee what will be the purport of his discourse— You perceive it as he proceeds and when he comes to the close, you perceive an unbroken chain of close argument, of beautiful order, of lofty moral principle, and of pathetic sentiment pervading the whole composition— In this Sermon, after some general remarks on the character of David, and the prevailing spirit of his Psalms, he analysed the sources of his confidence, not in his own prowess, nor in the efficacy of the means in his own hands for extricating him from the troubles with which in his long and eventful life he had been surrounded, he drew from the text a lesson equally profound and impressive of unwavering confidence in the goodness and mercy of God; enlarging upon the independence with which it endowed the human character of time—of space of good or evil fortune, and even of one’s own errors and imperfections. There is a purity, an elevation, a grandeur in the elemental composition of a man whose confidence in God is thus inextricably rooted, which raises him to the level of angelic nature, and which adapted to the contingencies incidental to the ordinary course of human affairs, touch the heart until it overflows at the eyes: which it did with me this day, mastering all power of resistance. Dr Frothingham dined with us— His Son Octave who is about graduating at Cambridge was with him, but dined with his aunt Charles My Son himself and William C. Johnson dined with us— The text this afternoon was from Acts 23.11. [“]And the night following the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good cheer, Paul:”— There was a close analogy between the subjects of the two discourses; the incidents in the life and adventures of the Apostle Paul, being eminently suited to illustrate the efficacy of a stedfast confidence in the overruling Providence of God— Immediately after our return from the afternoon meeting; Mr and Mrs Eliot of were here— Mrs Eliot, returning from a visit to her son and daughter at Saint Louis Missouri since last March. Then came Mr Degrand from Boston; and in the evening Mr Beale, Charles and his family. Elizabeth C. Adams and John, and Fanny Foster— A considerable company. Degrand brought out as usual a budget of Newspapers, and among them the Daily Advertiser of yesterday, containing copied from the Pittsfield Eagle, a report of my reception at Pittsfield, the closing scene of that series of receptions and processions which from the borders of Canada to my quiet retirement at home, have signalized the month of my recent excursion as among the most memorable periods of my life.

14. IV. Monday.  Sun rose 5.5. over the barn on the top of the distant hill.  Walk over the hill after observing the hazy Sunrise. I met a man, taking his morning walk; who accosted me, and said he had recently removed from Boston to this place for health and comfort— His name is Brummett, and he keeps a milleners shop— I observed this morning numerous ant holes on the ground with a circle of the soil surrounding each hole thrown out by the ants under the ground— I received this morning 4 copies of the Massachusetts Eagle of 10. August, published at Pittsfield and Lenox—containing reports of my reception at Pittsfield, and also at Albany— I went alone in the carriage to Boston, and called on Mr Joseph B. Felt 15. Warren Street to enquire about my discourse delivered before the Massachusetts historical Society on the 29th. of May last. When I left home on the 6th of last month it was in the printers hands—and I had revised two half proof sheets of it; and my Son afterwards revised the remainder. But I have heard nothing of it since my return— Mr Felt knew nothing about it, but promised to enquire of Mr Francis C. Gray chairman of the printing committee— I left with the Seal-engraver Mitchell the Carnelion stone of Captain Robert C Buchanan, to have the Johnson arms and his cypher engraved upon it according to his directions— At my Son’s Office, Mr Curtis and I as Executors and Trustees of Ward N. Boylston, executed indentures of exchange interchangeably with Timothy Gilbert, Thomas Gould and W. S. Damrell, in behalf of the purchasers of the Tremont Theatre— Mr Bowditch attended as their Counsel. I promised Mr Curtis to prepare a Letter to Petty Vaughan, to be forwarded by the Steamer Acadia, the day after to-morrow— Mr Curtis has purchased the mortgage of the house at Charlestown occupied by Daniel Leman, and leaves him for the present in possession. I met Mr George B. Fuller twice at the Probate Office; and was ready to render my account as Administrator of Thomas Boylston; and to transfer to him the Bank shares for the payment of the debt due to the Estate of Moses Gill—but he was not ready for the production of his account, nor to state the amount of his claim as Gill’s administor against the Estate of Thomas Boylston— The judge therefore postponed the further consideration of the case till next Monday. I called at the Emancipator Office, and enquired of Mr Alden the publisher whether he intended to republish my Letter to the Bangor Committee on Slavery— He said that nearly the whole of it was in type and struck off, on the first page of the paper to be published next Thursday.— He gave me a copy of the paper which I promised to revise. I returned home to Quincy to dine; and after dinner received visits from two black men, named Lewis Nelson from New-York and Peter Avery from Boston— The impression left by the two men was very different— That of Avery quite favourable— I was up till past midnight, writing to Mr Alden, and pointing out the errors of the prose and manuscript, in my Bangor Letter as printed in the Emancipator.

Damrell, in behalf of the purchasers of the Tremont Theatre— Mr Bowditch attended as their Counsel. I met Mr George B. Fuller twice at the Probate Office; and was ready to render my account as Administrator of Thomas Boylston; and to transfer to him the Bank shares for the payment of the debt due to the Estate of Moses Gill—but he was not ready for the production of his account, nor to state the amount of his claim as Gill’s administor against the Estate of Thomas Boylston— The judge therefore postponed the further consideration of the case till next Monday. I returned home to Quincy to dine; and after dinner received visits from two black men, named Lewis Nelson from New-York and Peter Avery from Boston— The impression left by the two men was very different— That of Avery quite favourable— I was up till past midnight, writing to Mr Alden, and pointing out the errors of the prose and manuscript, in my Bangor Letter as printed in the Emancipator.

15. V. Tuesday  Rain all the morning: confined me to the house. Mr Franklin White had been here on Saturday, but found himself so unwell that he could not take a sitting at that time, but agreed to come again this day— He came accordingly: took a fourth sitting of an hour, and finished the portrait— He is a timid, unobtrusive man, who in the performance of menial services for Harding himself a third rate portrait painter, acquired the talent of taking likenesses in Oil colours: but he can scarcely claim to be called an artist. This is about the 45th. time that I have sitten for my pictures, and I question whether another man lives who has been so wofully and so variously bedaubed as I have been— There is no picture of my childhood but from the age of 16, when I was caricatured it crayons by Mr Schmidt for four ducats, down to this my 77th year, when Mr White has lampooned me in oil, scarcely a year has passed away, without a crucifixion of my face and form, by some painter engraver or sculptor— A miniature, in a bracelet for my mother, painted at the Hague in 1795 by an Englishman named Parker, now in the possession of my Son John’s widow— Copley’s Portrait of 1796.— Stuart’s head of 1825. And Durand’s of 1836. painted for Mr Luman Read, are the only ones worthy of being preserved, with the Busts by Persico, Greenough and Powers— The features of my old age are such as I have no wish to have transmitted to the memory of the next age— They are harsh and stern far beyond the true portraiture of the heart; and there is no ray of intellect in them to redeem their repulsive severity— Mr White stretched the canvas over the frame of the portrait of Edward Boylston, which Mr B. O. Tyler had loosened to spread over it a coat of his varnish. Mr Tyler himself was here— He had written me a long and absurd Letter, proposing to me to lend him several hundred dollars to set him up in his varnishing trade and also to get up an engraving of a family temperance pledge, the sale of which is to make his fortune— I declined his proposal: desired him to spread no more of his varnish upon my house or upon any thing in it; and advised him to wait for the application to him from other persons wanting his varnish rather than to worry every one into the use of it against their will— This advice was not precisely the most palatable that could have been administered, but it was the best that could be given him— My garden has been this year so much neglected that we have not the common vegetables, Peas and Beans— Carrots and Beets; but must purchase them— I spoke of it to Kirk and enjoined upon him better husbandry for the next year.— Young evening party with music of the Piano and songs.

16. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 5.7. First clear since my return  In my morning excursion to see the rising Sun, I met again Mr Brummett— For morning exercise I waste time in labouring on my seedling trees— Proof daily heaps itself upon proof of how useless these labours are, for want of orderly system, and ultimate purpose— I emptied a seedling pot, and weeded and manured 5 apple stocks in a row at the opening of the seminary gate, where I have proposed to raise, one apple tree that shall stand One of them is now 6. feet 6 inches high with a stem nearly straight to the top. Two others are from 3 to 4 feet high: and two not over 9 inches. All the seeds sown at the same time.— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded 10 seedling stocks in the seminary thicket. 2. Harvest 2 Rohan, 2. Spitzenberg 2. Amory and 2. Rhode-Island sweetings— Also 4 Spitzenberg on Fanny’s row—and 5 in the Orchard. Deacon Spear was here this morning and proposed to me to fix a day when I would go with him into the woods— I told him I would go upon any day convenient to my Son, who is to go with us—and desired to agree upon it with him.— On my return home from Canada, I found among the newspapers on my table one with the title of Boston Investigator—devoted to the protection and development of infidel principles: Vol. 13. No. 13. Wednesday August 2. 1843— It had apparently been sent to me for a scurrilous article on the 2d. page entitled, Another specimen of Christian Criticism; being a knavish commentary upon the Revd. Joseph Emerson’s Letter to me, and my answer respecting the translation of Voltaire’s philosophical Dictionary—imputed to me because the title page announces it as printed and published by J. Q. Adams— The Article now states that it was published in 1836. at the investigator office and purports to be with additional Notes both critical and argumentative by Abner Kneeland— This man was an avowed atheist, and preacher of atheism; of which his translation of Voltaire’s dictionary was one of the gospels— He was shortly after convicted upon an indictment for blasphemy—imprisoned, and soon pardoned. His Atheist church was broken up, but it seems his weekly atheist Newspaper still continues.— Two or three days since I received an Octavo weekly Journal Edited by G. Vale at New-York 5. Augt. Third series Vol. 1. N. 18. The Beacon—seventh year— A co-adjutor of the Boston Investigator in the propagandism of the atheistic church— In this paper there is an Article headed Voltaire and J. Q. Adams, containing my letter of 17. June 1843 to Mr Emerson, with one from him to the Editors of the New-York Observer, requesting them to publish it. The correspondent of the Beacon, extracts them from the Journal of Commerce, without noticing the offensive fraud of palming upon me the act of printing and publishing these excrements of Voltaire but with a malignant imputation of false pretences in my remarks upon the base and filthy infidelity of Voltaire— These periodical publications, the Investigator, and the Beacon indicate the pertinacity, with which this little atheistic club, pursue their will of the wisp over the low, swampy lands of Christendom.

17. IV— Thursday.  At 5 this morning, my son and William C. Johnson breakfasted with me. We took up Isaac H. Adams at his mother’s, and alighted at Mr Loring’s house in Hingham at 20 minutes before 7. We met there Mr Parrot, a member of the State Legislature from Boston, and Mr Theodore Parker the heretical minister of Jamaica Plains— They were going to breakfast. After which I left my Carriage, and went in a Carry all with Mr Loring and Revd. Mr Charles Brooks to the cold Spring at Cohasset— Here after waiting about an hour for a boat; and clams for bait we embarked in a sail boat with one man, one oar, and a pitcher of cold water for our only stores, and sallied forth in quest of fish for a Chowder dinner— Mr Barnes was Captain and the boatman was mate and crew— The sportsmen were Coll. Lincoln, Mr Wing, collector of the port of Cincinnati Ohio, Mr. Parker the pious reprobate, Professor Charles Brooks recently returned from a four years search after natural history in Europe—Revd. Mr Waterson, and William C Johnson, with myself— As usual we cast anchor, or lay to and drifted in five or six different places, and caught upwards of one hundred fine haddock but scarcely any thing else— One large mackerel—one hake; two or three small rock cod, not worth naming and there or four perch—as many sculpins and pollock to throw back into the sea— The day was supremely beautiful, but before noon some of us began to crave refreshments and we had nothing but cold water— Mr Barnes became impatient to go in— Our clam bait gave out; and it fell calm, making it doubtful whether we should get in before Night: A Mr Richardson in a row boat of his own gave us a small additional supply of bait, some lemon juice, pears an Orange, Crackers and Claret wine; all which was unsatisfactory to the craving of the hungry. I staved off the call to go in about 2 hours, in which we caught about 70 of the haddock and then yielded, our bait being again exhausted. We went in after two, and the landsmen had already dined upon the chowder.— A second table was however got up for us and we fed— After dinner my companions and some others went out for a second fare— I staid and loitered under the shed in conversation with a motley group of 25 or 30 strangers till past 5. when we returned to a tea and evening party of Ladies and Gentlemen at Mr Loring’s, till Charles came and said if I intended to return home this Night it was time to go. We came immediately home; and I received a note from Benjamin’s father; informing him that his mother was dying.

17. IV— Thursday.  At 5 this morning, my son and William C. Johnson breakfasted with me. We took up Isaac H. Adams at his mother’s, and alighted at Mr Loring’s house in Hingham at 20 minutes before 7. We met there Mr Parrot, a member of the State Legislature from Boston, and Mr Theodore Parker the heretical minister of Jamaica Plains— They were going to breakfast. After which I left my Carriage, and went in a Carry all with Mr Loring and Revd. Mr Charles Brooks to the cold Spring at Cohasset— Here after waiting about an hour for a boat; and clams for bait we embarked in a sail boat with one man, one oar, and a pitcher of cold water for our only stores, and sallied forth in quest of fish for a Chowder dinner— Mr Barnes was Captain and the boatman was mate and crew— The sportsmen were Coll. Lincoln, Mr Wing, collector of the port of Cincinnati Ohio, Mr. Parker the pious reprobate, Professor Charles Brooks recently returned from a four years search after natural history in Europe—Revd. Mr Waterson, and William C Johnson, with myself— As usual we cast anchor, or lay to and drifted in five or six different places, and caught upwards of one hundred fine haddock but scarcely any thing else— One large mackerel—one hake; two or three small rock cod, not worth naming and there or four perch—as many sculpins and pollock to throw back into the sea— The day was supremely beautiful, but before noon some of us began to crave refreshments and we had nothing but cold water— Mr Barnes became impatient to go in— Our clam bait gave out; and it fell calm, making it doubtful whether we should get in before Night: A Mr Richardson in a row boat of his own gave us a small additional supply of bait, some lemon juice, pears an Orange, Crackers and Claret wine; all which was unsatisfactory to the craving of the hungry. 18. IV:15. Friday.  Among the persons introduced to me yesterday, were two persons from Kentucky named Scott and Andrews, who urgently invited me to visit Louisville next November when I go to Cincinnati, and Mr John B. Flint a Son of the former Minister of Cohasset, heretofore a merchant in Boston, and now an inhabitant of Louisville.— He asked me if I had received a Letter from him written yesterday giving me such an invitation, with one introductory of himself from Dr N. L. Frothingham— I had not received them—but they came this day— Of the company last evening was Mrs Parsons the daughter of my early and long-lamented friend John Thaxter, and Mr and Mrs Wilder daughter of Mrs Parsons. My two Grandsons John Quincy and Charles Francis are now at school in charge of Mr and Mrs Wilder.— A son of Nathan Rice was also of the party; and a Grandson of General Benjamin Lincoln; who told me that he had a considerable collection of Letters from General Washington and of my father to General Lincoln: some of them highly interesting.— Of many of the persons introduced to me, both at the cold spring and in the evening I cannot retain even the names— Mr Smith the preceptor of the Academy and Mrs Smith were there, and the three daughters of Quincy Thaxter himself now deceased—The Revd. Joseph Richardson my immediate predecessor as representative of the Plymouth District in Congress was one of the party at the spring— This morning my Son and William C. Johnson went to Boston, and returned to dine with us as did Isaac Hull Adams, who with the three girls had made a party to Squantum.— I called at the Quincy Patriot Office to enquire if the publisher John A. Green intended to republish my Letter to the Bangor Committee. He had it already marked on the Emancipator for publication next week; together with my Letter to Mr Alden, correcting the errors of the press, published with the Letter in yesterday’s emancipator. I spoke to Mr Green for 100 copies of the Bangor Letter, folded in octavo form, and he promised to send me the proof sheet for revisal next Tuesday or Wednesday. President Quincy was here with Mr George T. Bigelow. They had been attending a meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge— I made sundry enquiries of Mr Quincy respecting the erection of the Astronomical Observatory at Cambridge, and the subscription for procuring a telescope of the first class for its use— I want especially the names and purposes of the instruments to be procured—their cost— The time when it is expected they will be received The persons now employed upon astronomical observation and calculation, and what is expected to be the annual cost of the whole establishment— Mr Quincy promised to communicate to me the correspondence on the subject; and inviting me to commencement next week, to shew me the present condition of the building— I fear my own want of perseverance in the pursuit of these enquiries— Afternoon visit from Mr and Mrs Vernon of Kingston Rhode Island—

19. III.30 Saturday. Sun rose 5.11. Set 6.55.  I had the summer house cellar cleared out in the Spring for the reception of seeds and nuts and acorns. But while I have been absent it is overgrown with grass and weeds, upon which I operated this morning partially with the hoe— And I filled a seedling pot with earth from the ditch halfway up the hill for an experiment— The third year English Oak in Mary Louisa’s patch is Sun killed: and another has just come up in the adjoining southerly patch— A person by the name of Mann accosted me this morning while I was at work, and told me that he lived over the brook west of my neighbour G. W. Beale’s, and could supply me with chickens whenever I may want any— My Grandsons John Quincy and Charles Francis Adams came home as usual on Saturdays from school at Mr Wilder’s, Hingham— Coll. Benjamin Loring of Boston with Mr Jo. K. Meredith a young man from Virginia came with a Letter of introduction from Mr Thomas Loring, merely to see me as a curiosity— A party of our double family Isaac H. Adams, William C. Johnson, Fanny Foster. Sarah A. Johnson, and our Mary Louisa Adams, went to Medford to visit Mr and Mrs. John Angier and returned this evening— Mr E Price Greenleaf came this afternoon and budded for me 4. seedling Apple stocks including that in front of my library window with Hingham slips received this morning from Mr Loring and 5 pear stocks. 3 caplimonts and 2 Dix’s. 1 in the Seminary thicket, and 4 in the orchard. I went this evening to the town Hall, and heard an Anti-Slavery Address of about an hour delivered by Wendell Phillips; an intimate friend of my youth was his father John Phillips afterwards the first Mayor of Boston.— I had heard much of Wendell as an Abolitionist enthusiastic Orator, but had never seen or heard him. He was now introduced to me by one equally a stranger to me, but who introduced himself—named J. W. Pendleton. Mr Phillips spoke to me about his fathers intimate acquaintance with me; which I confirmed; and assured him of the respectful and affectionate memory that I retain of him— He said he was so young when his father died that he had but a faint recollection of him; but that a friend of his who had known him had told him if his father had lived to this time, he would not have followed the course which he does— I said I thought that was probable; the great characteristic of his father having been prudence and discretion in the avowal of his opinions—and boldness that of Wendell himself— His address this evening was extemporaneous, and very handsomely delivered— Its topics were censure upon the church for coldness or lukewarmness to the cause of anti-slavery, and a fervid argument for the total and immediate abolition of Slavery throughout the world— Mr Pendleton walked home with me.

Sunday. 20. IV.  Rain, nearly all night—and Lightening this morning. Mr Lunt preached this morning from Psalm 91.2 “I will say of the Lord, He is my refuge, and my fortress: my God; in him will I trust.” Confidence in God— The same subject treated by Dr Frothingham last Sunday Morning, differently, but still well treated by Mr Lunt— He said that in order to judge of the expediency or duty of reposing confidence it was necessary to consider the attributes suited to inspire confidence of the object to be confided in. And these were transcendent in God beyond all else— These attributes were 1. His power—Omnipotence— 2. His wisdom 3. His goodness. 4 His unity. 5. The gift of Revelation— Upon each of these attributes he dilated as separately and in combination sources of confidence— He then alluded to the antient doctrine that the Gods take no interest in human affairs as a great and pernicious error destroying all confidence in God; and he glanced without dwelling upon a modern error equally destructive of confidence in God—the supposed existence of a rival or antagonist power to that of God; sharing with him in the government of the world; defying his power and disabling his goodness and outwitting his wisdom— God he said had no such rival or antagonist. After expatiating upon the inestimable value of this confidence in God to the happiness of man, he reminded his auditory that it was a trust forfeited by Sin, from which whether of commission or of omission it was incubent on every man solicitous for his own comfort and happiness to abstain— No greater calamity could befall a man than to lose his confidence in God— It was the enjoyment and consolation in this life, and the unwavering hope of a blessed immortality— The afternoon text was from Psalm 55—the latter part of verse 19.— [“]Because they have no changes therefore they fear not God.” The tendency of change in human affairs to inspire devotion, and of continuous prosperity to induce presumptuous indifference to the will of God, was connected in the Sermon with the recent death of Mrs. Locke, a young woman of 23. daughter of Josiah Nightingale— Prayers were requested for him and his family; and for the husband Locke— The youngest daughter was also prayed for being weak and low— I made this day a special effort of attention to the two discourses, with barely tolerable success in the morning, but with signal failure from drowsiness in the afternoon.— Buffon considered Genius, as consisting of continuous application— There is something else. But involuntary slumber is a physical and mental infirmity under the operation of which observation and reflection are suspended.— Does Genius ever sleep? I wrote my two pages in the leisure of the day—but I sleep when I would not, and cannot sleep when I would— I seem to myself often an Idler; but I believe I tax my physical nature for toil beyond its endurance— Charles and his wife, W. C. and Sarah A Johnson passed the Evening here.

21. IV:30. Monday.  I went to Boston this morning in Gillett’s Stage Mrs Foster and her daughter Fanny. Richard C Greenleaf and his wife were of the passengers. Met Dr. Frothingham, Mr Richard Fletcher, and Dr Francis Parkman in the Street— And met Mr George B. Fuller at the Probate Office— He was not ready with his charge as administrator of the second Moses Gill against me as Administrator of Thomas Boylston— He has no evidence but that which I must furnish to support the charge, and the case was therefore again postponed till next Monday. At Brooks’s hard ware shop I purchased a spade which I mark as an epoch because it is to dig for exercise. Call’d at the Emancipator Office and saw Mr Leavitt who returned in the Steamer Hibernia, from his Mission to the World’s convention for the abolition of Slavery— I had very little time for conversation with him but he said without hesitation that from all the observation he could make, he believed the suspicion and distrust of the sincerity of the present British Ministry, and especially with regard to the abolition of Slavery, which I had disclosed to him was well founded— He thought Lord Aberdeen at least lukewarm in the anti Slavery cause.— State policy controuls the abolition Spirit. At Mitchell the Engraver’s shop I took back the Seal with the Johnson arms. Captain Buchanans cornelian was at the jewellers to be set.— By gross negligence I left my Umbrella, borrowed from Mrs C. F. Adams at Elm Street N. 9.—the house whence the Quincy Stage departs. Second Call at Dr Frothingham’s— I had enquired of him where the words laudator temporis acti were to be found— He traced it to Horace’s Art of Poetry, and verse 173.— And Milton’s old man eloquent is in the Sonnet 10. to the Lady Margaret Ley— I had requested that Gillett’s Stage which leaves Boston at noon would call for me at Mr James H. Foster’s which was done at half past 12. I was there in waiting for it, and saw Louisa and Mary Foster. I returned in that Stage to Quincy, and got home at 2. Dr Frothingham had given me a note for Mrs C. F. Adams to notify her that Thomas and Frank Frothingham were coming to dine with her, but when I went up the hill to deliver the note they were already there— They came over here after dinner, but I did not then see them.— While I was from home this morning, Mr and Mrs John P. Kennedy of Baltimore were here with Mr Robert C. Winthrop, who left an invitation for me to dine with him tomorrow— There were also here while I was from home Mr and Mrs Brayton, and another Mr and Miss Brayton, all from the neighbourhood of Utica, and visitors merely for looking at the curiosity— Having all the after part of this day at my disposal, I was able to make up the record of one day, and save it thus from a relapse into new arrear, but not to make any progress in redeeming the past.

properties.dateline: Quincy. Tuesday 22 August 1843. Boston and home
properties.text: 22 IV. Tuesday.  Heavy rain in the night— Mr P. C. Brooks had invited our whole family party to dine and pass the day with him at Medford but the prospects of the day were so inauspicious that the Ladies first gave up the project, and then Charles and W. C. Johnson did the same— They went with me to Boston, and returned home before dinner.— I called to enquire at Mrs Frothingham’s and then at James H. Foster’s for the missing Umbrella without success—of Gillett at N. 9. Elm Street with no better fortune; but he promised if it should be found to send it to my house— I saw Mrs Foster, and her daughters Elizabeth and Louisa.— At noon, attended the Meeting of the Massachusetts historical Society— Thinly attended— James Savage President. Dr Charles Lowell, and Joseph Willard Secretaries. Joseph B. Felt Treasurer. John Davis, Nahum Mitchell Revd. Samuel Ripley, A H. Everett and George Bancroft with R C Winthrop constituted the meeting. The death was announced of two members of the Society since the last meeting. Dr Homer of Newtown, and Dr W. P. Greenwood of the Stone Chapel Boston.— Dr. Codman was appointed to prepare an obituary notice of Dr Homer and there was some suggestion of a similar appointment for Dr Greenwood— Dr Lamson was mentioned; but it was concluded to pass the subject over to a day of fuller attendance— An answer was received from a Doctor Bliss of Oxford England, accepting an election as a corresponding member of the Society— An application was read in behalf of the Wabash college in Indiana, for a copy of the publications of the Society. After some discussion the subject was referred to the publishing committee for consideration— I entered on the Book of persons proposed for membership the name of Dr. Nathaniel L Frothingham, to succeed Dr Greenwood— But the nomination is to be made by a standing Committee— Adjourned, just about 1. judge Davis invited me to dine with him next Tuesday, which I accepted— Mr Winthrop invited me to dine with him at half past two— I had an hour and a half on hand and two objects to secure— One to communicate to the publishing Committee the special reasons for electing Dr Frothingham in the place of Dr Greenwood— The other to get from the printer 200 copies of my Discourse on the New-England confederacy of 1643.— I walked to Mr Felts and found him at dinner. I desired him to mention to the nominating committee the special relations which existed between Dr Greenwood and Dr Frothingham, who is now, and has been for months preaching to Dr Greenwood’s congregation—and the obligation of the Society to Dr Frothingham for the use of his church, and for taking a part in the celebration of the 29th. of May. Mr Felt acknowledged the force of the reasons, and promised to report them to the Committee— He also informed me, that the printer of My Discourse was Mr Bolles whose printing Office was over the Bookseller’s shop of Little and Brown in Washington Street. I went there and ordered the 200 copies of my Discourse to be sent to Bigelow stable, Hawley Place where my Carriage was, and it was done. I dined with Mr Winthrop—Miss Winthop and Miss Tappan were there—Mr and Mrs John P. Kennedy. William Minot, Dr. Warren, Dr. Palfrey, and Josiah Quincy junr were there— Miss Winthrop is just engaged to Dr Warren— I came home in a continual flood of rain, alighting at my gate as the darkness of Night was setting in.

23. IV. Wednesday—  Commencement.  I attended at Commencement—the first time since 1831. Left home at half past 7. with my Son, and William C. Johnson, went through Boston, and reached the tavern opposite the Presidents house at 9— Intending to pass the night at Cambridge, I applied for a bedchamber, but was informed that they took no lodgers. Precisely as we alighted, the Governor Marcus Morton arrived preceded by an Escort of Cavalry; attended by three Aid de Camps in full military uniform; and followed by the Lieutenant Governor, Dr Childs, and several members of the Council. The whole procession enlivened by the noisy music of the brass band— They proceeded immediately to the new Gothic Stone cloister to which the Library has been transferred, on the ground floor of which were assembled the President and faculty of the University, members of the corporation and overseers, and visitors invited or uninvited of all denominated— The President soon invited the members of the board of overseers into a side room, and there proposed in the name of the faculty 66 youths for admissions to the degree of bachelor of Arts— He read over their names, and the Governor put the question to the board who manifested their assent in the usual way; that is by holding up their hands— He went through the same process for conferring the degree of Master of Arts— After which the procession was formed and marched to the new parish church, and after a very short prayer by professor Walker, the Salutatory Oration was pronounced by Octavius Brooks Frothingham— Among his salutations was a very flattering one to me—my title to which if contested I should have been puzzled to vindicate. Then followed on the list of performances 14 disquisitions 9 Dissertations 6 English Orations 1 Greek and 1 Latin Oration and a Poem, besides an English and a valedictory Latin Oration by candidates for the Master’s degree. About one third of the list were omitted: yet the performances were protracted to a sitting of nearly 6 hours— No conference—no forensic no dialogue— The bachelors English Oration by Horace Binney Sargent Son of Lucius Manlius— The Master’s English Oration by Joseph Henry Allen who visited me last fall at Quincy— The Latin valedictory, by William Goodwin Russell of Plymouth—jocular with much graceful action. The President then conferred the degrees first of bachelor then of master— Then Doctors of Medicine and then bachelors of Law closing with the honorary Doctors of Divinity— I dined at the College Hall. Visited with my Classmate Samuel Putnam the chambers of Sargent, of John Lowell, and of Frothingham and spent the rest of the afternoon and Evening at President Quincy’s— My Son and William C. Johnson took the Carriage to Boston, and returned this evening to Quincy.

24 IV:30. Thursday  I wrote this morning two hours by Lamplight, and met at breakfast the whole Quincy family; with the addition of Mr Waterston, father of Anna Quincy’s husband— Immediately after breakfast I attended on President Quincy’s study the meeting of the judges of the Boylston prize-declamations. There were 19 names entered in competition for the 5 prizes 5 of the junior Class 6 of the Senior and 8 of the graduated Class— 5 however of the candidates did not appear— Among the judges were judge Putnam, Leverett Saltonstall Charles Loring, Mr Gould, Mr Rogers, and Dr Alexander Young— The declamations occupied about 2 hours, and were on the whole superior to any that I had ever heard on these occasions before— We returned to the Presidents Study, and balloted for the two first prizes at once— I voted for Ladd and Boyden— Only one had a majority and that was Dexter— His piece was a farcical Scene of Boz Dickens’s Pick wick novel, and his merit was that of a comic actor, Ladd had a strong vote on the first ballot, and a majority, on the second— But the only vote given for Boyden on the first ballot was mine, and before the vote was taken for the three second prizes, I stated my reason for wishing to assign a prize to him, which was that he alone had selected the Latin of Cicero to speak and had spoken with articulation accent emphasis, modulation and pause not inferior to any of the rest— Mr Gould objected that his pronunciation was not correct, and that he had missed the quantities, of several words— I thought that a venial Offence for a scholar fitted out of Boston, and at the first ballot for the second prizes Pike had 5 and Boyden 7. of 11. votes— At the second ballot Means had 6. and this completed the distribution— We returned to the Meeting house and Mr Quincy announced the names of the successful competitors, with a general encomium upon all the performances as unusually good.— Immediately after this I went with Mr Quincy, Mr Samuel A. Elliot and Mr Pierce the Astronomical Tutor, and saw the spot where the Observatory is to be erected.— Craigies Summer house— Found the cellar dug, but not lined with Stone— The Meridian line is fixed and it is expected that the Tower will be completed before the next Spring— As we returned we met the procession of members of the Φ.B.K. Society, passing from the chapel to the meeting house and joined them. Mr George S. Hillard delivered an admirable Oration, and the Revd. Chandler Robbins a short Poem— I dined with the Society in the dining hall of the College—toasted and speechified— Retired early with Mr Quincy and visited the Panorama of Athens.— Took leave of Mr Quincy’s family—called on Dr Waterhouse and returned through Roxbury home.
