25. IV:40. Friday  Last evening soon after my return home, Mr Marchant a painter from New-York called on me, and enquired if I had received a Letter from a Committee of the New-York historical Society, requesting me to sit to him for my picture. I said I had; but that having been immediately afterwards been absent from home a month, and under some uncertainty whether it was the wish of the Committee that Mr Marchant should come here to paint the portrait, or wait till my passage through New-York, I had hitherto delayed answering their Letter. He said he had now come to take the time that might suit my convenience for the work— Mr Marchant had already painted my portrait in November 1840. at New-York— But as I could then give him only three sittings in two days, he was not satisfied with his own work, and wishes to do it over again— He had now with him a miniature copied from his former picture, but our Ladies thought it bore No resemblance to me. Mr Marchant is at present engaged in painting certain portraits at Providence, and will come the week after next to take mine— This morning I made my morning excursion for observation and exercise but saw not the rising Sun intercepted as he was by a dense fog— But upon inspecting the self planted seedling wild cherry on the hill, I saw a white knob, thrusting itself up through the surface of the horse manure that I had gathered round the tree— It has put forth three or four plumelet leaves, while I was absent on my journey. So have many of the English Oaks— Mr Samuel Lewis of Cincinnati Ohio brother brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Joshua Leavitt— Mr Lewis was formerly the Superintendent of common schools in the State of Ohio, and is an abolitionist— He expressed high gratification, at my engagement to visit Cincinnati next November— I conversed freely with him upon the subject of Slavery, but told him that I shall probably feel myself interdicted from discoursing or perhaps even speaking about it at Cincinnati— I received a Letter from Philadelphia signed Joseph Hedges, covering a sealed Letter, not directed, and requesting me to forward it to Daniel Webster—alledging that it is on business and that the writer does not know Mr Webster’s Post Office address— Without directing the Letter I enclosed it to him at Marshfield. Mrs John and Mrs Charles F. Adams with their two daughters and Sarah A Johnson visited Boston this afternoon; took tea with Mrs Frothingham, and returned— My Son and William C. Johnson came home the evening of Commencement day, and yesterday morning took the Steamer took the Barnstable; to pass through Sandwich to Wood’s hole, and thence to New Bedford— On visiting again this evening the wild cherry seedling on the hill, I found the fungus mushroom or toadstool with its dark cap opened like an umbrella over a white stem four inches long.— I am not yet recovered from four successive days of dissipation.

26. IV:30. Saturday.  I commenced this morning my operations with the spade, experimental for health and for cultivation— Filled seedling Pot N. 1. with earth from the ditch, enriched and planted in it 12 cherry stones— The Quincy Patriot of this day has my Letter to the Bangor Committee correctly printed— I received yesterday a Letter signed Samuel M Pond President, with 2 Secretaries dated Portland 22. August. and containing a vote of thanks to me for that Letter, from a meeting of the friends of universal Liberty in the State of Maine— Mr N. E. Johnson is the Editor of the New-York Evangelist a weekly religious public journal somewhat inclined to abolitionism— He was at the late Liberty meeting in Portland— Mr Whiton has some connection with the Anti-Slavery press in Boston, but I know not exactly how— Mr Quincy Thaxter was here this afternoon with his son a boy of 5 years old named John Quincy and with his Sister Anna Thaxter— She came to invite my wife and our Ladies to a tea and evening party at Hingham; but my wife is again so ill that she has taken to her bed; and none of the other Ladies incline to go without her— Mr Thaxter in right of his wife has a claim for a portion of the Estate of William Otis, and brought with him sundry documents recently received from the Island of Cuba, in the Spanish language, taken to authenticate the genealogy of Mrs Thaxter in descent from Nathaniel Otis one of the brothers of William— I offered him any services in my power to recover his claim and he left all his papers with me to be presented to Mr Lewis Johnson the Administrator of William Otis, when I go next to Washington. Charles’s two boys came home from Hingham— At Sunset I walked up the hill to Charles’s house but was belated for seeing the Sunset.— As I passed by the seedling wild cherry I saw that the mushrooms or toadstool had shot up its stem till it became top heavy, broke down and turned black as a sooty chimney— Mr Edward Brooks junr came out from Boston to take tea with Mrs Charles, and I went to the town hall, and heard Wendell Phillips deliver a second Anti-Slavery Address.— He spoke without Notes, as all the Lecturers now do— His argument was the incumbent duty of every abolitionist is to trample under foot the article of the Constitution which requires the surrender of fugitive Slaves.— He assumes the position that this is null and void; as a compact contrary to the Law of Nature and of God— He thanked God that he was not a citizen of the United States—and goes the extremest lengths of the abolitionists— After his lecture he came and spoke to me, and . . . I told him I could not concur in his doctrines— He took me home in his Carry all.— His auditory was small.

27. III.30 Sunday— Saw Sirius—risen at 4.  Mr Motte was a Classmate and chamber mate of my dear and lamented son George— He is a native of South-Carolina, born of Episcopalian parents; educated at Cambridge, and afterwards for an Episcopalian clergyman— His studies led him to the unitarian faith, and the congregational forms— He was for a year or two Minister of the unitarian church at Washington; and afterwards of the South Congregation, Washington Street, Boston— His talents are respectable, and his life and conversation blameless.— But his defect of character is want of energy— He travelled a year or two in Europe with the consent of his congregation for the restoration of his health, and returned to them again— But his manner of preaching is not attractive— It is languid and lifeless, and the substance of his discourses, though sensible and intelligent has no charm to redeem the dulness of a languid and listless delivery.— His congregation insensibly grew weary of his ministrations hardly knowing why— They drop’d off one by one from his Society— Those who remained became uneasy and discontented, till by mutual consent they agreed to part. He took his dismission in kindness and charity, and they elected in his place a young man named Huntington, at whose ordination I assisted last October.— Mr Motte continues to preach as occasion calls, and has now a summer residence at Cohasset— His Sermon this morning was from 1. Corinthians 15.45. [“]And so it is written, The first man Adam was made a living soul; the last Adam was made a quickening spirit. 46. Howbeit, that was not first which is spiritual, but that which is natural; and afterward that which is spiritual 47. The first man is of the earth, earthy: the second man is the Lord from heaven. 48. As is the earthy, such are the earthy: and as is the heavenly, such are they also, that are heavenly.” Here is a multifold repetition of one idea—the distinction between matter and spirit; but Mr Motte made it the foundation of an enquiry into the nature of the enjoyments of Paradise, and why there is so much lamentation at their having been forfeited— Mr Motte dined with us, and his afternoon Sermon was from 2. Corinthians 4.18. [“]While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen: for the things which are seen are temporal; but the things which are not seen are eternal.” substantially the same subject as that of the morning.— And I found it impossible to follow the preacher into any train of impressive argument. The day was to the feelings the hottest of the season—Sultry and scorching. Towards sunset there came up a long though not very severe thunder shower— This evening I completed the recovery of the 12 days of arrears which had accumulated in my diary, in the month of my journey to Canada and the Falls of Niagara and of Trenton.

properties.dateline: Quincy Monday 28. August 1843. Boston and back
properties.text: 28. II.50— Monday  I rose before three this morning, an hour earlier than my regular time, supposing that to have arrived at 40 minutes past 3 I saw Sirius about 10 minutes risen— I mark the 10th. of August as the day, and 40 minutes past 4 as the time of his emerging so far from his conjunction with the Sun that the Egyptian shepherds would have discovered him.— One of the obstacles to my morning labours now is the moisture of all grass covered ground, on which whether from dew or rain I cannot tread without getting wet-feet, from which no leather boot or shoe affords protection. The bare foot or the Sabot is the proper chaussure of the practical farmer.— This morning, after a long and fruitless search for the papers which I had prepared in 1839 for ascertaining the amount of the claim of the Administration of Moses Gill on that of Thomas Boylston, I was obliged without finding them to go into Boston and attend the probate Court. Mr Fuller was not there— I told the judge that I had not found the papers, but would as soon as possible either find them, or make out from the correspondence a statement of the amount as I had done before— I called at the Store of Mr Curtis’s son in State Street, to enquire if he was in town; and to inform him that I wished to see him at my Son’s Office— I went twice there and desired Mr Spooner, if Mr Curtis should come in to inform him that I should be glad to see him there to-morrow— I called at the Emancipator Office, where Mr Leavitt had a large volume Class B. of paper laid by the British Government, before Parliament relating to the Slave trade in 1842. He says there are three more such volumes Class A. C. and D—which he expects to receive by the next Steamer.— There came up a heavy shower, and I purchased an Umbrella—the first volume of the Lives of the Queens of England by Agnes Strickland, and the Hymns of the Nursery of England; which I gave to Charles’s son Henry— As I was standing at the door of the Booksellers shop Dr Frothingham in passing by stop’d and spoke to me. At Mr James H. Foster I saw Mrs Foster and Louisa. Mary was quite unwell and kept her chamber. The Quincy Stage took me up there and landed me at home before 2.— As we were sitting down to dinner Mr P. Bronson of Auburn, New-York called to see me— He had already called this morning with his nephew Mr William Blake of Boston, just after I had left home in the Stage— Mr Blake returned to Boston— Mr Bronson remained to see me before his departure to return home— He was to go in the Stage this afternoon to Hingham: thence in the Steamer to Boston, and there to take the Cars of the Great Western Railroad to Albany.— Mr Bronson was one of the Gentleman, who with Governor William H Seward accompanied me from Auburn to Syracuse. I received this morning a Letter of the 21st. instant from Genl. Peter B Porter at Niagara, with a copy of one of 8 June last from him to Governor Bouck.

properties.dateline: Quincy Tuesday 29 August 1843 Boston and back.
properties.text: 29 III.50 Tuesday.  To keep up the current of my diary, I omitted the morning excursion to my garden and grounds. at 10. I rode with Louisa C. Smith to Boston, and left her at Mr James H. Foster’s. Visited Mr Robert C. Winthrop— Mr and Mrs Kennedy left the city yesterday morning for the Saratoga Springs. I spoke to Mr Winthrop of the removal by John Tyler of Levi Lincoln, from the Office of Collector of the Port of Boston; and the appointment of Robert Rantoul junr. in his place; and enquired whether the merchants of Boston would not as a body take some notice of this dirty trick of the accidental President. He said he thought it would be very proper, but although Mr Lincoln is universally allowed to have discharged in exemplary manner the duties of the Office; there is little sympathy with him in the public mind on this occasion. At my Son’s office I found Mr Spooner, Mr Flint of Louisville Kentucky and Mr. Nathaniel Curtis. Mr Flint who proposes to depart to-morrow on his return to Louisville, urged on me again the acceptance of his invitation to me to visit that city, when I go to Cincinnati next November, but I told him it was exceedingly doubtful whether I shall be able to go even to Cincinnati, and if I do, whether I can extend my journey further.— I left him however with an assurance that I will come to Louisville if I can— I requested Mr Curtis to look over his papers to see if he has not among them some memoranda of the amount of the Gill claim on the Thomas Boylston administration— He shewed me a proposal from the present Tenant of the School Street house, that it be taken down, and a new one built on the site, for which he shall take a lease for 5. or 10 years at a rent of 1000 dollars a year— We discussed and referred it for further consideration. I signed a duplicate of the Letter of the 15th. instt. to Petty Vaughan. President Quincy passing in his chaise in the Street, stop’d and spoke to me. I had received from him this morning sundry papers relating to the observatory.— He recommended specially Professor Peirce to my attention— Going to visit Dr George Parkman I met him in the Street, and went with him to his house where I saw Mrs and Miss Parkman, a Miss Brown and Alexander H. Everett— The Doctor walked with me to judge Davis’s house. There I dined with his daughters Mrs Goodwin and Mrswidows Isaac P. Davis and his wife, Professor Peirce, and Tutor Lovering.— We had much conversation on Astronomy— I urged the judge to get up an Astronomical Society in Boston— At 5. pm the carriage came: I took up Louisa C Smith at Mr James H Foster’s and we returned home. Mrs Charles spent the Evening here. Revised the Letter to Bangor
