30. V. Wednesday.  Spading one hour— Loosened the ground round the Apple seedling in front of my Library window— Deacon Spear was here to speak of the payment of my annual tax-bill—Town and County— A deduction of 4 per cent for payment on or before the first of September— My Son has the bill— We expected his return home this day; but he did not arrive— Captain Josiah Bass’s Son has four lots of woodland 50 acres in all, which he wants to sell, but names no asking price. I required that the precise quantity of the land should be ascertained, and the price specified—after which I promised to go and look at the lots.— Mrs. Martha is the widow of Lemuel Burrell, a Seaman on board the Macedonian frigate, and died in the service at Norfolk, Virginia— She has received the widow’s pension 5 years 72 dollars a year; but it was stop’d last January when she received 12 dollars as a final payment— She is in great want of a renewal of the pension, and desires to petition Congress for it. I advised her to petition jointly with as many other widows having the same ground of claim as her own, as she could find out, and I promised to present the petition and give it all the support in my power. She is a daughter of Joseph Beale heretofore of Squantum, and lives now with her daughter, wife of Richard Newcomb of this town— Mr Peirce Perkins professor of Astronomer at Harvard University, and Mr Bond, Observer for the observatory, which is to be came from Cambridge and dined with me— Mr Bond brought with him some papers additional to those which President Quincy had sent me— The successors of Frauenhofer at Munich are Merz an Optician, and Mahler a Mechanician— The price of the duplicate of the Pulkova Telescope is 42000 German florins, or 16800 dollars— On their Catalogue for sale there is a graduation of the prices of Refractors of inferior power—of 30,000. 22000. 15000— 8000. 4800. 2200. 2000 1500. 900. and 750 florins— And a multitude of other mathematical and optical instruments the most costly of which is the Heliometer charged at 15000 florins. Of this there is one at Pulkova— The mural circle is the next dearest astronomical instrument, after the Refractor. Its chief use is for making catalogues of Stars, and it requires two observers to be constantly occupied at the same time— They do not propose to procure at present a mural circle, or to make that Class of Observations at Cambridge— The Perkins professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics is a new institution at Harvard, and Mr Peirce has been this year appointed the first professor.— Mr Bond left with me two pamphlets—one in French F G. G. Struve’s report of his observations of double Stars, with Frauenhofer’s great Telescope at Dorpat from 1824 to 1837. Struve being then Director of the Dorpat Observatory.— The other is an Additamentum, in Latin, dated 2. Octr. 1839. when Struve had been transferred to the new Observatory at Pulkova; and with which there is appended a disquisition on the annual parallax of the Star [symbols] Lyrae— I collected from this interview much desultory information which I must tax my memory to retain, but which I cannot record. I took them up to Charles’s house to shew them the prospect— Met there Mr and Mrs Edmund Quincy on a visit from Dedham— Edward Brooks junr. and Thomas Frothingham came out afterwards and spent the Evening with us.

31. II.30. Thursday.  Spading and hoeing 2. hours— The Pear tree first bearing in the centre of the garden next the red cherry tree, is a bergamot— I took up the diseased peach tree close to the fence at the kitchen garden gate— In attempting to trim the wild cherry seedling up the hill, I cut off the stem itself close to the ground.— Broke up the ground sloping down from the tool box towards the orchard— Deacon Spear was here again enquiring for my Son, and about paying to Lewis Bass, collector of the town and County tax, to-morrow to save the deduction of 4 per cent for prompt payment. My Son had not then returned from his excursion, with William C. Johnson to Barnstable, Provincetown, Sandwich, Wood’s hole, Nantucket and New-Bedford— But they got home before dinner, and were here this evening.— President Quincy called on me and said he had been to the grave yard to see to the repairing of his monument of his father and mother— It has been erected about 40 years, and I wrote the epitaph engraved upon it. It is already dilapidated, in consequence of its exposure to Sun, rain, frost snow and mischievous boys— The cemetery has been much neglected, but more care of it is now taken— Mr Daniel Greenleaf called in and said that the tomb of the Ministers of the parish had been opened to deposit there the remains of the late Pastor Peter Whitney, who died on thelast and that the coffin of Norton Quincy was there placed on that of Anthony Wibird the immediate predecessor of Peter Whitney— But there was no inscription on the Stone of the name of either. That of Mr Wibird was now to be carved on it, and Mr Greenleaf enquired if I should wish to have that of Norton Quincy added to it. I said I should; and requested Mr Greenleaf to say to Mr Lunt that I would see him on the subject. I had further conversation with Mr Quincy concerning the observatory, and he is to send me some other papers accidentally omitted when he sent me the others— I read the french pamphlet report of Struve to the Minister of public instruction and President of the Russian Imperial Academy of Sciences Ouvaroff, containing the narrative of his observations upon double stars at Dorpat from 1824 to 1837. It is full of very interesting information, leading as usual to multitudes of further enquiries which I shall never have time to pursure—for see now the distribution of my time, through this month of August since the 5th. when I came home.

1. Optical Institute of Utzschneider and Frauenhofer at Munich  Optician Merz— Mechanician Mahler.  Largest Achromatic Refractor of 21 feet focal distance 14 feet inches opening—parallactically mounted, with an hour circle of 17 inches diameter, from Second to Second in time, and a declination circle of 24 inches diameter, from 4 to 4 Seconds through the Verniers divided on a silver Limbus— The Spyglass has an achromatic seeker of 42 inches focal distance—34 lines of opening— All necessary coarse or fine movements are in every case in perfect equilibrio followed through one hour with centrifugal Pendulum of the daily motion of the earth and has six usual astronomical oculars of 140— 226— 336— 504— 756— and 1200 magnifying powers, together with a repeating Lamp-micrometer, with 9 separate Oculars from 148 to 2000 magnifiers, and then 2 Ring micrometers, and 2 Sunglasses. 42000 florins.  Quincy 1. Septr 1843.for W. C. Johnson.  Plymouth County Towns  8th Congressional District of Massachusetts  Extracts from the Diary of J. Q. Adams

1. IV:30. Friday.  Sudden change of weather last Evening from sultry dog day heat with swarms numberless of musquitos to a chilling Northeaster— Spading and hoeing two hours— The English acorns planted last October continue to come up from the ground one after another so late in the Season that the stems cannot acquire a consistency to survive the winter without protection from the frost. Summer and winter are equally fatal to them— And for this I should discover a remedy.— A man by the name of Butters came as a mendicant with a recommendatory Letter from Mr Ripley the minister of Waltham. His apology for beggary was that he had lost his property and must raise 150 dollars to recover it. He said he had got nearly the whole, but wanted a few dollars more and enumerated sundry of my friends who had given him 5 dollars each. I thought one quite as much as he deserved— George W. Hardwick brought honey in the comb for sale 25 cents a pound.— Charles and W. C. Johnson went to Boston and dined at Dr Frothingham’s— Mrs Charles, and the three girls went also, and got home just in time to hear the 9 O’Clock bell— I called this evening on Mr Lunt the minister and spoke with him of the inscription to be made on the ministerial monument of the name of Norton Quincy, who was buried in it— He promised to attend to it— Struve’s report on double stars was published by order of the Russian Academy of Sciences says that stars of the 6th. magnitude can be seen with the naked eye, and none below the 12th magnitude can be seen by the most powerful Telescope— The bright star of Lyra, Vega is a double star and Struve observed its annual parallax— There are two classes of double stars, optical, one behind the other, and physical—stars composing a solar system with Satellites— The observation of the double stars give by their changing distances furnish the means of ascertaing the parallax of the brightest of the two Stars— Herschel in 1780 and 1800 was the first of double stars in 1813 Struve began the observation of them at Dorpat— In 1824. The great Telescope, the masterpiece of Frauenhofer was received and from that day the observatory of Dorpat took the lead of all others for the observation of double stars. The multitude of observations is almost as surprizing as that of the Stars. There are only 120 nights in the year when observations can and only 80 when the micrometrical observations can be pursued with large magnifying powers.— With a magnifying power of 1000. the 100th. part of a second is a discernable quantity— The Mira Ceti or whale wonder changes from a Star of being of the 2d. magnitude till is diminished till it disappears— There are stars of all the colours of the rainbow— There are triple and quadruple stars— The distance of stars of the 6th. magnitude is estimated at 16 millions of times the distance of the earth from the Sun.

2. IV.5 Saturday  Sun set 6.30—  Spading and hoeing two hours. Planted in seedling pot N. 2. filled with garden earth and manure a green gage plum stone— Rain in the night. Kirk and Dennis broke up and manured most of the seminary plats which I had not cleared out— Mr Lunt called on me to enquire of the time of the birth of Norton Quincy of which I had told him I thought I had a record; but on making search I found it not, though I had of his marriage in 1746. Mr. Lunt spoke also of his design to prepare and deliver a course of Lectures upon English Literature; and supposing I was one of the directors of the Lowell Institute intimated a wish that I would propose him as a candidate for the appointment, to deliver his course there—and asked for the use of books in my library which he may want in the prosecution of his work—which I very cheerfully promised—as well as to do any thing else in my power to serve him; though I have no connection with the Lowell Institute— I saw the Sun set from Charles’s porch— I made up a parcel of 25 of my printed miscellanies and gave them to my brother Charles’s grandson—William C. Johnson and gave him two others for his brother Alexander to whom I had promised my argument in the case of the Amistad captives.— The search for scattered pamphlets and other nameless absorptions of time stole away my morning hours—and dinner came before my record of yesterday was completed. After dinner the labour of writing is too drowsy, and my tribute to the address for Cincinnati was of only one page— Mr Beale was here this Evening. I received a Letter from President Quincy, enclosing sundry Letters from Astronomical observators to Joseph Cranch, London, and one from him to Professor Peirce, all written in 1842. and relating to Astronomical Instruments and their makers.— Of these more hereafter  Struve.  His catalogue of double stars, discovered by the great Telescope of Frauenhofer in the space of 2 1/2 years 120000 stars of magnitude from the first to the 8th and a little beyond; of which 3112 were physical double—and of these only 340 were on the list of Herschel and 447 on a former catalogue of Struve, before Frauenhofer’s great refractor was made. Struve considers the double Stars as Solar systems with planetary Satellites like those of our own Sun— The relative movements of these double stars are ascertained, and he gives a list of 7. whose periods of revolution in their orbits are from 43 to 573 years— The deepest impression left on my mind by these observations of Struve is the immense increase of visual power conferred upon mankind by the invention of these new instruments, which may be called Titanic Telescopes.

3— IV:45. Sunday—  Visited my grounds— Two hours— Heavy dews and wet feet. Discovered a swarm of black oak caterpillar worms clinging round two twigs of the 13 years old shagbark walnut tree at the bottom of the Nursery. Cut off the twigs and consigned their occupants to the fire. Heard Mr Lunt this morning from the Genesis 49.4. “Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel.” This was an admirable discourse, on stability of character— The sentiment thus expressed in the English Bible is incomparable as a maxim of morals, but is not a correct translation of the original. Charles Thomson’s translation from the Septuagint, mutilates the thought, and substitutes little better than nonsense in its place— Mr Lunt began by relating the occasion upon which the words were spoken, by Israel on his dying bed, in what is called his blessing upon his children.— It is rather the prediction of the future fortunes of their descendants— The lot of Reuben the first born was any thing but a blessing— It is reproach for more than instability. It is a charge of criminality and a declaration that its punishment shall be visited on the descendents of Reuben by the forfeiture of his right of primogeniture. Mr Lunt merely glanced at this view of the subject— His Sermon was a comment upon the sentiment that instability of character is fatal to all excellence.— He pointed to the sources of stability the consciencious estimate of right, and religious faith— I believe that a loose faith is the surest indication of wavering integrity, and can have no confidence in the honesty of a philosophical unbeliever— Immediately after my returning from the morning meeting, Mr Degrand came in from Boston—dined with us, and kept me in attendance till 10. in the evening. Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from John 15.5. I am the vine, ye are the branches: He that abideth in me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit: for without me ye can do nothing— The argument of this discourse was that the Christian religion is addressed more to the heart than to the head— That it deals little in abstractions—that it personifies all the virtues, and that all its efficacy depends upon the personal character of Jesus Christ, without whom his disciples can do nothing.— He incidentally gave a side blow to the transcendental doctrines of Ralph Waldo Emerson and the scarcely disguised infidelity of Theodore Parker, which is shaking the faith of the sons of the New-England Pilgrims— It had been advertised in the Quincy Patriot of yesterday that Edmund Quincy woul deliver a Lecture upon Slavy in the town Hall at half past five O’Clock this afternoon— I went with De Grand and found that his wife, and their Son Edmund, a boy of 5 years old were with him. I invited them all to take tea with me after the Lecture which they did. The Lecture delivered without notes was about an hour and half long and very reproachfull. The auditory about double the numbers of those at the Lectures of W. Phillips.

4. IV.5. Monday.  Heavy dew and wet feet— Two hours— Planted in seedling pot N. 2. 12 mazzard cherry-stones— Mushrooms coming up in abundance— Mrs Kirk has raised double flowered Althaea’s, from slips which she brought from Washington the winter before last. Some of the flowers are now in bloom— She says an Apple tree slip which she stuck into the ground has taken root— My Son, his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa; with William C. Johnson and his sister Sarah, made a party and went to Medford and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s. Charles and William returned soon after dark, but it was past 9 when the Ladies reached home— Charles’s three elder sons dined with us— The day was excessively warm and sultry, which partially disabled me for writing on my astronomical address, and I expended three hours in a search for papers which I did not find— I read the first book of Bailly’s history of antient astronomy, and Charles brought me from Boston the Number of the North American Review for April 1825. containing the Article of Dr Bowditch upon modern Astronomy.— Bailly fixes on the year 3890. before Christ for the invention of the sphere by Atlas, and marks that period as the commencement of the study of Astronomy.— In the Atlantic Nation. He considers Uranus as of the same nation—and that Fohi in China, Thaut or Mercury in Egypt—Zoroaster and Belus in Persia and Babylonia cultivated the science about the same time— He gives for the duration of the globe to the Christian Aera,  The Persians, preceding the Chaldeans instituted the canicular year of 1441 years 3209 years before Christ.  The Chinese have the record of an eclipse 2155 years before Christ—2500 years before Christ occurred the conjunction of the 5 planets on the day of the new moon. A minister of Hoang-ti named Yu-Chi discovered the pole-star and made something like an Orrery, and Fo-hi himself was an eminent Astronomer— Made a Zodiac and constructed Astronomical tables— Fohi flourished 2952 years before Christ— Bailly says he believes that these facts cannot be false— The tartars have the same pretension and extend to the same period— But neither Fohi nor Uranus nor Atlas was the inventor of Astronomy They received it from the Atlantic Nation— The Chaldean Saros of 223 lunar months and the luni solar period of 600 years came from that people— The invention of the Zodiac must have preceded the deluge— Astronomy was cultivated 1500 years before the flood, and is now upwards of 7000 years old—

5. III.30. Tuesday  Sun rose 5.29. Crystal clear—  Heavy dew—wet feet— The hottest night of the year. Devoured all night by muschitos, and compelled to rise before my time to escape from them— The loss of the Night’s repose infected the industry of the day and the astronomical address lingers mournfully along— I filled experimentally the seedling pot N. 3. and spaded round the Apple tree by the side of which the seedling white maple perished in the drought. I took to the Book binder Gill the 17th volum of my Diary, from 1. Jany. 1842 to 8. July 1843 to be bound. The old Mitchell’s map was there and I left directed how it was to be repaired for preservation. I met sundry boys gathering wild cherries from my trees along the road on the hill— They said they had permission— Harvey Field was here, renewing proposals for the purchase of lands from my Penn’s valley farm, but shy of making offers. I desired him to stake out the ground which he wanted, with Deacon Spear, and to name the price he is willing to give for it; and promised then an answer— I received a Letter from Mr Frye, with enquiries whether of Mr T. B. Johnson’s funds of which my Son is the Agent and Trustee the sum of 3500 dollars can be withdrawn to be invested in a mortgage of George Boyd’s house and land in Michigan to save his wife and children from being turned houseless into the Street or the woods— I took the letter to my Son and had some conversation with him about it.— He finally took the Letter, and said he would answer it— Mr Lunt was here this Evening. He has been to Hingham, and through Mr Jairus Lincoln obtained the following extracts, from the town records of that place John Quincy of Braintree and Elizabeth Norton of Hingham were married October 6. 1715.— Norton Quincy was born Oct 27. 1716. This supplies the dates of two events which I have long been desirous of ascertaining— The entry in chief Justice Sewall’s Diary of 5 pounds lent to John Quincy, with the present of a Psalm book for his mistress is of Octr. 4. 1715. as now appears only two days before his marriage— I am daily receiving Letters of invitation to visit places on going to or returning from Cincinnati which embarrass me exceedingly. This day two from Samson Mason and one from H. Hedrick to Springfield, Clark County Ohio.— One two days since from Joshua R. Giddings, apprizing me that they are taking measures to invite me to Jefferson, Ashtabula County, Ohio. Besides the invitation already received from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania—there has been a meeting of the inhabitants without distinction of party and Resolutions adopted to invite me as the guest of the city— I have received also Letters from Mrs Alicia Boylston, Elisha H. Allen, James T. Austin, Caleb Hartshorn—James Eaton of Malden, (to deliver a Lecture) and Frederick T. Tiffany (to be re-elected chaplain of the U.S. house of Representatives) requiring immediate answers, which I procrastinate— I made out to write this Evening to Mr Joseph Grinnell, enclosing to him the 5 dollars bank Bill, received from General Peter B. Porter at Niagara Falls for him.

6. IV:45— Wednesday—  Sun rose 5:30.  Work about my grounds—gathered a quart of wild cherries from the seedling tree opposite the kitchen window in the garden, and steeped them in three bottles of New England Rum. At 8 O’Clock Deacon Spear came and I went with him and my Son, in my own Carry all to visit my grounds on the Penn’s valley farm— I stop’d to see my kinsman Josiah Adams, four score years of age, and now for the last nine months paralytic and bed-ridden— His brothers Ebenezer and Thomas have gone before him, and he lingers along, a few days more— I found since I was last at his houseyears ago a road laid out from just before his house, to the house that was my brother’s in Braintree, and it runs through my lots between my native spot and the lawyer’s common so that I know the places no longer. Since the death of Ebenezer Adams, Daniel Baxter junr. has purchased at auction for 45 dollars an acre, the lot that belonged to the 2 brothers. 16 Acres, between my Druid lot and lawyers common has changed the face of it by Tillage, and now proposes to buy 8 acres of mine or to sell me his 16 acres at 75 dollars an acre— My land borders on the road: his lies back, which shews his astuteness in the proposal to give or take— We made our way through a narrow and tangled path across the lawyer’s common; where in 1829 I sold off the burden of Pine and hemlock wood, and which is now thickly covered with a growth of black, white, and scrub oaks, with a portion of white birch, white and pitch pine and sundry others— From the South side of lawyer’s common I walked with my Son round by Capen’s house to the new road where Deacon Spear met us with the horse and carryall which he had gone back to fetch— Here we met Daniel Baxter junr. and Mr Totman all wanting to purchase parcels of my land bordering upon the road, but shy of offering any specific price for what they want except Mr Baxter’s offer like the exchange of shields between Diomed and Glaucus. I told them all I must take time for consideration. I returned home with Charles, and at two O’Clock William C and Sarah A. Johnson left us, went into Boston, and took the Cars of the Western Railroad to Utica— Mrs. Charles with her baby Arthur to see and consult Dr. Bigelow. Mary Louisa, and Louisa Catherine went to Boston with them and saw them off— Then came back about Sunset— We shall miss William and Sarah very much— Before Sarah went away, she asked me for some lines to enter upon her Album; and I gave her two Stanza’s upon smiles.— I sent the Letter to Mr Grinnell of New-Bedford, and answered the Letter from Mr James T. Austin requesting an introductory Letter to Europe— I have no familiar acquaintance there. These avocations arrest almost entirely the progress of my astronomical address, for which I find no leisure either to read or to write.

7. IV. Thursday  Cloudy and cold— Two hours of hoeing, to prepare my grounds for seedling Stones, seeds nuts, and acorns. Planted a row of cherry stones across the centre of the Summerhouse. Mr John Woods of Hamilton Ohio about 20 miles west of Cincinnati, a member of Congress from 1825 to 1829. came with a recommendatory Letter from Mr Corwin to Governor John Davis, which he shewed me— There is a great water power in the town of Hamilton, and Mr Woods has visited the manufactures at Lowell with a view to ascertain the most effective means of managing water power for the establishment of manufacturing mills. He is a member of a company formed there for the purpose of prosecuting this undertaking and is now about to return home— He wrote here and left with me a Letter stating that he had been requested by the Citizens of Hamilton and Roseville, Butler County, Ohio to invite me to visit them on my tour through the State, which invitation I accepted if it may be in my power— The State of Ohio is in the hands of the most unbridled democracy— My promise to go to Cincinnati was rash, and unadvised and has already involved me in engagements to visit places where I shall not be welcome— And my arrears of correspondence with the preparation of an Address oppress me to distraction— The Letters lent me by President Quincy are 1. from Joseph Cranch 30. Rosoman St. Clerkenwell London on Septr 2. 1842 to Professor Benjamin Peirce, Cambridge—with enclosures from J. Challis Professor at the Cambridge Observatory: Mr Brisbane at Greenock. S. Henderson, Observatory at Edinburgh. G. B. Airy, Astronomer Royal at Greenwich two. T. R. Robinson, Armagh and J. F. W. Herschel, Collingwood, all eminent astronomical observers. The Letters are all advisory, and inclining to have the object glass and perhaps the mounting done at Munich— The proposals of Troughton and Simms to construct an equatorial for £1250 Sterling. Other Letters are from George Merz opticus 30 June 1842 and 19 June 1843 from Professor Airy 30 June 1843. speaking of a plan of the Pulkova observatory in the Astronomische Nachrichten of Schumacher N. 290 and mentioning the doubts of the durability of the famous German glass— There is a Letter from Le Rebours at Paris the mathematical instrument maker proposing to construct an equatorial 9000 francs— Merz says that a parallactically mounted Refractor is good only at the place for which it is made, and cannot without great modifications be used elsewhere— He claims payment of one third of the price in advance— The instruments bespoken for the Washington Observatory are a Pulkova Titanic equatorial—of 16 feet focus and 12 inch object glass— 2. A transit for the Meridian 7 feet focus. Another for the prime vertical to be made by Repsold at Hamburg 4. a five feet mural circle 5 a 3 feet transit circle,—and a set of magnetic and meteorological instruments— Cambridge is to have only the Titanic.

8. IV. Friday  Lazy labour in the morning; not sufficient for bodily exercise. Second quart of wild cherries from the young garden seedling steeped in New England Rum— I received this morning Letters 1. From James J. Lawn and 4 others a Committee of the Mechanics Lyceum of Baltimore, inviting me to deliver a Lecture there next Autumn in going to, or returning from Cincinnati. 2. from William G. Webster son of the late Noah Webster. New-York 6. Septr. 1843. proposing that Congress should purchase a manuscript etymological synopsis of his father’s Dictionary, and requesting me to make the application to Congress for the family. 3. from F. C. Hells Septr. 2. 1843. Augusta, Georgia, kindly dissuading me from presenting abolition petitions. 4— From William F. Channing, son of the late Dr. William Ellery Channing, Newport 6 Septr. 1843. asking for any Letters I have received from him, and any other assistance that I can give him in collecting his fathers works for publication and a memoir of his life. 5. From H. F. North—New Britain Connecticut 4. Septr. 1843. for an autograph. 6. From Emily Rushbrook Lewis. 26 Augt. Rock Mills South Carolina, for an Autograph—and 7. from Belinda Anderson 30. August 1843. Union, Erie County Pennsylvania, enclosing complimentary Stanzas in blank verse, and asking for an autograph— All these Letters ought to be answered speedily, and I have made a note of them to see how any of them I shall or can answer at all— I did answer a Letter from Elisha H. Allen of Bangor, Maine, which I intended to do in three lines, and which like a creeping plant spread out into three pages.— I find it easier to write a long Letter than a short one— I answered also a Letter from William F. Lockwood the Editor of a newspaper in Elyria, Ohio— William Jagger visited me this afternoon, and occupied full two hours of my time.— He is still meddling with politics, beyond his depth; but he says that he recovered a verdict upon the libel suit brought against him, and proved by the testimony of judge Anderson, of Virginia that Tom Benton stole money at chapel hill of at least 3 persons besides himself. Deacon Spear came here yesterday with a message from Harvey Field—who wants 32 acres of it and thinks that 5000 dollars would be an adequate price for it— My time is so absorbed by daily avocations that for several days past I have been able to write only one page a day of the address: and even to do that I am obliged to write from ten in the Evening to near Midnight. I was shocked to see in a newspaper of this day an account of the death of Graham H. Chapin one of the Committee who brought me the invitation from Rochester to Buffalo—

9. IV. Saturday  Sun rose 5.33— set 6.23—  Change of weather to cold. Spading an hour and a half despatched Letters to Elisha H. Allen, about his votes on my trial in 1842 and to Caleb Hartshorn thanking him for a copy of the Life and Speeches of Henry Clay by Daniel Mallory, in two Volumes recently published— I received this morning four extra newspapers. 1. The Philanthropist of 30. August 1843. Cincinnati 2. The Herkimer Journal of 6. Septr. 3. Albany weekly Patriot of 5 Septr. all containing my Letter to the Bangor Committee; and 4. The Christian world of this day, with an account of Lewis Tappans late visit to England, with frequent references to me, and particularly the statement that Mr Tappan told Lord Aberdeen, that I had less confidence in the present British administration, with regard to Slavery and the Slave trade than in their predecessors. Lord Aberdeen vehemently disclaimed all diminution of zeal against Slavery and the Slave trade; but Mr Leavitt has come home convinced that my distrust of the present British Minsters is well founded.— William Jagger came again this morning to enquire for a public document relating to the amount and value of the public Lands— I made a search of at least half an hour for Levi Woodbury, Secretary of the Treasury in 1841. I found and lent it to Mr Jagger; but he sent it back to me in the course of an hour. The time I lose in searching for papers, and in enduring idle and unwelcome visitors is consuming— That of drowsy exhaustion and worn out lassitude is equally distressing. This afternoon there came a man by the name of Jonathan Underwood, an inhabitant of Parma, Monroe County, New-York about 20 miles from Rochester— He is traveling about the country for his amusement and called to see me out of mere curiosity having missed of seeing me, when I was lately at Rochester— I sat with sad civility, but he kept me two full hours, plying me with questions about men and things chiefly on politics, and to which I answered by little more than monosyllables. Mr Thomas Loring called to apologize for delaying the summons for a second fishing party from Cohasset, which he had promised. His engagements have absorbed his time— He spoke of someday next week, but I desired him not to give himself any trouble or inconvenience, not being overburdened with leisure, myself for the party— I had a long conversation with my Son—urging him to undertake the improvement of my Lands in Quincy by farming, and by preparing the location for house lots— I have neither time, knowledge nor sagacity for the undertaking myself.— I made out a list of the members in the Legislature of the Commonwealth from all the towns of the present eighth Congressional district, and also of the 13 towns in the County of Plymouth, which were of the 12th. Congressional District, under the census of 1830. and are not in the District for which I have now been elected—and I took from my son a minute of the political complection of them all. He and his wife were here an hour this evening. I was again up till midnight writing a page of my address.

10. IV.15 Sunday. Sun rose 5.34. clear.  Mr Lunt preached this morning from Mark 10.15. “Verily I say unto you, whatsoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, he shall not enter therein.”— The affectionate attachment of Jesus Christ to little children is one of the peculiar characteristics of the Christian religion— A century later the Roman Poet Juvenal had said maxima debetur puero reverentia, and that noble sentiment like many others of the same poet, betoken the silent influence of Christianity spreading over the heart of man, while it was yet proscribed and persecuted by the Roman Emperors— The Affection for children was a part of that doctrine of universal benevolence which pervades the new Testament, and which is ever one and the same— It is remarkable that Christ gave no instructions to children— His apostles taught them nothing but obedience to their parents and guardians, and the parable of the prodigal son teaches only to the parent the lesson of forgiveness for transgression— The virtues of children are docility, simplicity, credulity, and sensibility to kindness— This he says is precisely the temper in which the gospel must be received or it cannot be received at all.— He took them up in his arms, put his hands upon them and blessed them— There was more teaching in that action than there would have been in a volume of discourse— Mr Lunt’s Sermon was eloquent and pathetic; but for the last two Nights, between three and four hours of sleep each night have been my portion— Scattered Spirits, dull and slow conceptions flagging attention and a torpid state of body sinking unconsciously into slumber; follow me through the day, and steep my senses in forgetfulness. These are the decays of nature, and are continual admonitions to prepare myself for the time at hand. Mr Samuel K Lothrop Minister of the Brattle Street Church in Boston preached this afternoon; from John 16.32. last part of the verse: “and yet I am not alone, because the Father is with me[”]— Mr Lothrop’s manner is in perfect contrast with that of Mr Lunt, and yet is very pleasing. He began by remarking that there is among the generality of mankind a decided aversion to being left alone—and then he descanted upon the peculiar inconveniences of being left alone— Some of the views which he presented of this thought were striking— He referred to the desertion of Jesus by all his disciples, and to the awful but all sufficient consolation and support which he derived from the consciousness that his father was with him—and he solemnly exhorted his hearers to remember that the same trial may await themselves; and they must be prepared to meet it alone, but having the father with them— Mr. and Mrs G. T. Bigelow and Charles Miller were here after Church, and Mrs Phineas Foster towards Evening.

11. V:30 Monday  First fire for the Season in the dining room, and the Summer has departed. My morning labours, for the first time this Season were irksome—third quart of wild cherries from the garden seedling to steep in rum. Planted 18. Bergamot pairs in a row, in the small nursery at the northern corner of the garden, and a row of steeped mazzard cherries in the Summer house cellar— Of the seedling Apple stocks transplanted from the Nursery to the orchard there are several flourishing and deserving attention which I have neglected— The seedling English White Oaks, self planted under the trees, are so numerous that all question of their reproduction is removed; and now remains only to devise expedients for saving them and the shagbarks from the winter frost— Harvey Field was here and spoke of that portion of my land which he proposes to purchase; but we cannot agree upon the terms— He offers me five thousand dollars for 32 acres for which I ask 20000— He proposed to sell me his dwelling house and about 20 acres for 10000 dollars, and I told him I would bargain with him if I knew where to find the money to pay for the purchase— Mr Andrew Ernst of Cincinnati, Ohio, paid me a visit with his wife, a daughter of George A. Otis of Boston— Mr Ernst is by birth a German, but came to this Country, a child, more than 40 years since— He says that when his father settled at Cincinnati there were but three houses in the place; it is now a city with 60000 inhabitants— He speaks our language so entirely like the people of our Western section, that not withstanding his name I had not a suspicion that he was born a foreigner, till his wife mentioned it— There was an earnestness and warmth in his manifestations of kindness to me which is never shown by natives of my own Country— There is a consciousness of equality and often of superiority, which interdicts all appearance of obsequiousness in our native Americans, even when they come as beggars— Mr Ernst asked to visit my garden and nursery, and took some nuts, acorns and flower seeds, because they grew in my garden— And he and his wife both invited me to stay at their house when I come to Cincinnati— My time is frightfully shortening to make my preparations for that journey. I answered Mr W. G. Webster’s Letter, and offered to present his memorial asking Congress to purchase the Synopsis of his fathers great dictionary, if he concludes to send it— I intend if possible to write one Letter every day for the next six weeks. But in preparing my astronomical discourse I am much distressed for want of time to read with attention Bailly’s history of antient Astronomy; and Goguets chapters on the same Science— I want 6 months for Bailly’s book alone— In the history of Grecian Astronomy I find the names of Thales Anaximander and Anaximenes all of Miletus— I look for them in the Dictionnaire Historique and find accounts of them, worthy of meditation. Thales was the first of the wise men of Greece, and like Moses, though 800 years later learnt his wisdom from the Priests of Egypt— He founded the Ionic school of Philosophy. He was never married saying when young that it was too soon, and when old that it was too late

12. IV.45 Tuesday.  Sun rose 5.36. Frost  A tolerable Night’s rest, in consequence of which I suffer less from lethargy, and am able to apply rather more time to labour— I worked an hour with the hoe and spade, the best of all exercise, but which I shall be obliged in a very few days to relinquish— I received a Letter from Mr Frye at Washington informing me that the repair of the Mill dam is finished— He has agreed to pay 1000 dollars for it, and the next heavy rain will sweep it away. This the third Letter that I have received from Mr Frye since I returned from my excursion and which I have neglected to answer But this morning I received a Letter from Nathaniel Cross of Portland, Maine, enquiring what had become of his petition to obtain indemnification for injuries and losses sustained by him at Matanzas in the Island of Cuba, while exercising the functions of Consul of the United States at that place. He was here about this time last year and then told me his pitiable story. His consular agency was merely temporary committed to him by the regular Consul, a title not recognized by the Government there— His petition was presented at the commencement of the last Session by Mr Fessenden, and was referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs— I believe they made no report upon it, but it was discussed more than once in Committee, and they were unanimously of opinion that it could constitute no claim against the United States. Mr Spencer Warfield of Millville in this Commonwealth, called to see me for mere curiosity, and in the afternoon Dr. Ward Nicholas Boylston called on me— He came to enquire for an answer to a Letter which I received on the 3d. of this month from his Grand mother, which has perplexed me much— Mr W. N. Boylston, by his Will directed that he should be buried at Princeton, and provided for the erection over his remains, under a building which he proposed to give to the town on certain conditions.— He was accordingly buried, there, but the town has not complied with the conditions of the grant— Mrs Boylston has purchased a tomb in the cemetery at Mount Auburn, and wishes to have the remains of her husband deposited there. Her Letter to me was to enquire my opinion, whether she could not by Law have them taken up and removed, without consulting or considering the dispositions or desires of the people of Princeton. I doubt if there is any human Law applicable to the case; and still more whether under the circumstances she could cause the body to be removed without the consent of the People of Princeton. I requested the Doctor to say so to her, and to advise her in my name to do nothing without first attempting to obtain their consent.

13. IV:30. Wednesday—  My Fahrenheit 40. Sharp frost.  Spading and hoeing perhaps for the last time this Season— The laborious exercise that I have used in the four months since the 16th of May when I came out to Quincy has been greatly conducive to the restoration of my health, but the cold weather will master me: and I fear the consequences, if I undertake to meet it with defiance— I answered the Letter of A. H. Lawrence of Washington, proposing to take on lease or purchase my square 592 in that city; and four Letters of Mr Frye which I had hitherto left unanswered— Also the Letter of James J Lawn, and 4 others a Committee of the Baltimore Mechanics Lyceum, inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them, which I declined— But this effort to retrieve the arrears of my correspondence absorbed the time for keeping up the diary and protracted my evening till close upon midnight— Mrs Margaret Wade a widow of a revolutionary soldier 78 years of age and a claimant for a pension was here, with Mr and Mrs Litchfield, all of Scituate— Mrs Wade said she had been here five years ago with a Mr Bailey, since dead— I had forgotten the fact, but find it recorded in my diary of 4. October 1838. The law limits the right of pension to widows married before the 1st. of January 1794. Mrs Wade was married in June of that year and failed to obtain her pension for that reason— She wishes now to renew her claim and to have her old petition called up, or if necessary to have a new petition presented for her— I promised to call up her old petition if to be found on the files of the house, and if not to write to her that she may prepare and forward a new one— My own list of petitions presented at the 3d Session of the 25th Congress, I could not find—and upon the House Journal of that Session I find only a petition of the heirs of Edward Wade. Deacon Spear was here with a modified proposal of Mr Daniel Baxter to give 100 dollars an acre for 2 acres of my land adjoining his, or to take 70 dollars an acre for his land adjoining mine— I declined taking his offer of 100 dollars an acre for mine, and authorised Mr Spear to offer him 60 dollars an acre for his, which he purchased at auction for 45 dollars an acre— Mr John E. Fuller and his wife were here— He is an agent for trading in old books, and brought with him a number of showy and costly luxuries with splendid engravings of very insignificant personages— I had no use for them, but he offered me a copy of Walton’s Polyglott Bible in 8 folio volumes for 150 dollars, which tempted me almost beyond resistance— It is part of the theological library of the quondam professor John G. Palfrey which he is selling off— Mr Marchant the painter came and took a sitting for my portrait, and dined with us.

14. V.15. Thursday.  Fahrenheit 40.— Frost.  My spading is rather abruptly terminated, having by over eagerness of labour, yesterday morning rubbed off the skin from a spot on the fore finger of the left hand, which is now sore and disabled for labouring at all. How often is over labouring thus checked and rebuked— I dallied however two hours this morning with my time— Miss Susan Tufts called at the gate this morning riding on horseback with Mr Ellis; to enquire of the health of our Ladies. Mrs John and Mrs Charles F. Adams, with Mary Louisa went to Boston and returned to dine, bringing out with them as a Visitor to Mrs Charles, Dr. Bigelow’s daughter— Mr Henry Bowers of Scituate with his son George William Bowers was here. He is the nephew of the late Mrs Cushing, widow of judge William Cushing of the Supreme Court of the United States— She died in 1834 at New-York, and bequeathed by Will to Mr Bowers two small profile portraits in crayons, one of President Washington, and one of my father, and both excellent likenesses.— They were painted from the life at Philadelphia, about the year 1797. Mr Bowers brought and left them with me, asking me on returning them to write him a line expressing my opinion of them as likenesses, and giving the name of the painter if I knew who he was— To the likeness of both I can very fully attest, but I know not who the painter was. Mr Marchant came, dined and took tea with us; and was employed the whole day and evening upon my portrait: painting from the life in two long sittings before and after dinner, and the remainder of the day copying from the portrait which he painted of me at New-York in 1840— He was suffering all day with a severe headache— I answered a Letter from Mr William Lincoln inviting me in the name of the Worcester County Agricultural Society to attend their Cattle Show, Ploughing match and exhibition of manufactures on the 9th of next Month— I cannot spare the time and decline— My Son was here, and I had a long conversation with him on the project for laying out in house lots a part of my lands brought upon the street by the new roads. He is averse to having any dealings with Harvey Field; and lukewarm if not cold to any undertaking to convert the land into house lots— I think I shall give it up altogether— This was the third successive day of weather of more than autumnal cold— We have fires in the dining room and middle parlour, and my patience this afternoon was starved out— I made a fire in my library and sat up writing till midnight.

15. IV.30 Friday—  Fahrenheit 60 75.  The temperature of the air had been relaxing all night and the thermometer at daylight this morning was at 60.— The dampness was extreme, and brought me its usual accompaniment a rhumatic head ache. I strip’d my wild cherry tree of a fourth quart of its fruit, and barely finished when it came onto rain and there was a succession of heavy showers through the day; growing warm all the time to 75 degrees. I marked this morning a shoot coming out from the stem of the wild cherry seedling which I carelessly crop’d sometime since— Some of my self planted English white Oak seedlings are still putting forth their plumelets— But the Ash, horse chesnut and shag bark walnut have long ceased to vegetate for this year. Mr Marchant was here all day, dined and took tea with us, painting half the town from the life and the remainder copying from his old picture— He made me sit, time and again, morning and afternoon— I answered a Letter from Mr Thomas M. T. M’Kennan of Washington Pennsylvania, inviting me to stop a day at his house, going or returning from Cincinnati next November— I accept the invitation conditionally, if I go to Cincinnati at all— I received the Peoria Register of the 1st. of this month: a whig, Clay newspaper in the State of Illinois— It admits the election to Congress for one of the Districts of that State of another Editor of a Newspaper named John Henderson, who in his canvas said— I desire to be elected to Congress in order that I may meet and indignantly hurl back the infamous slanders of John Quincy Adams— This may answer for a counterpart to my late receptions in the western part of New-York— I wasted again much of this afternoon in a fruitless search for papers, and dipped into Mitford’s history of Greece for his account of the Grecian Philosophers; but found it extremely meagre. Bailly on the other hand is copious, but I cannot snatch the time necessary for reading him— My Son, his wife and Miss Bigelow passed the Evening here and Miss Bigelow played delightfully on the Piano. I drudge on from day to day with one page of my astronomical address, and this evening completed my task at 11 O Clock— If I should intermit the labour but for one day, it is doubtful if I should ever resume it— I should certainly not be ready for the performance of my promise— I see by the Newspapers that at the Convention of whigs of Norfolk County at Dedham last Saturday the 9th. among their Resolutions, they appointed a Committee consisting of Benjamin F. Copeland of Roxbury, Josiah Brigham of Quincy, and Tileston of Dorchester, to invite me to meet and address the citizens of the County, some time before the election.

16. IV. Saturday  Summer has returned, and the Thermometer has been part of this day as high as 80— Mr Marchant was again here almost the whole day; and took half a dozen sittings, of about half an hour at a time, from shortly after breakfast till evening twilight— He dined and took tea with us; and finished at last the portrait— My wife and all the family think it far better as a likeness than that which he painted in November 1840— I see it is more laboured and finished; but the likeness is not so strong— Mr Lunt came, and borrowed from the Adams library, Wartons history of English Poetry 3. Volumes 4to. He also mentioned that he had received an invitation from Dr Gray’s Church at Jamaica Plains, to our church to the ordination of a young man named Allen, a son of Mr Allen of Northborough, Dr Gray having resigned his pastoral Office; and Mr Lunt enquired if I would be willing to go with him as a delegate from the Quincy Church, to which I readily assented— Mrs T. B. Adams was here this afternoon with her Sister Mrs. Nehemiah Foster and her Son Isaac Hull. Mrs. Adams and Hull returned last Evening from their visits to Cedar Grove and Newburgh and Utica— Elizabeth returned to New York city and remains with Mrs Bartlett. About Sunset a young man, son of Coll. Vinson of Dorchester came with Miss Bradley to view Mr Marchants new Portrait of me— Charles and his wife spent the evening here, together with Miss Bigelow who played charmingly on the Piano— I was up again till past midnight to write a page of my astronomical discourse— I answered a Letter from Mrs. Alicia Boylston, and I read a few pages of Bailly’s history of Antient Astronomy. His theory of an antedulivan People highly civilized, and possessed of the Science of Astronomy, very nearly if not quite equal to the progress of the time when he wrote, has scarcely a shadow of historical fact to sustain him— I cannot but suspect that it is merely a device to discredit the cosmogony of the bible, and especially the mosaic account of the deluge. He professes throughout the most profound reverence for the scriptural history but he takes no notice of the confusion of tongues after the flood and insists that one great people destroyed by the deluge had made all the modern discoveries in astronomical Science including even the laws of Kepler and the gravitation of Newton— There is indeed no doubt that in the Grecian School of Pythagoras, the Copernican system had been broached that the Sun was the centre of the world and the planets bodies revolving round him.

17. IV:30. Sunday—  Sun rose 5:41. Set 6.9—  Mr Gannett (I believe Dr. Gannett) minister of the federal Street church in Boston and sometime a colleague of the late Dr W. E. Channing preached here, this morning from Romans 1.16. [“]For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation”—omitting the remainder of the verse—“to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.” Mr Gannett enjoys a high reputation as a preacher. He must therefore abide a severer scrutiny than others— The text did not promise much— It was well for St Paul standing before hosts of inveterate foes, Jews and Gentiles; to say he was not ashamed of the gospel of Christ; and to assign for it the reason that it is the power of God unto salvation— But for a protestant divine of this age, and in this Country should boast that he is not ashamed of the gospel of the Christ, has a ludicrous aspect— Who is ashamed of it?— But it is not at this day the power of God unto Salvation first to the jew and also to the Greek— That stage of its existence has passed away; and I could not see the useful application to the present times or the sentiment in the text— The Sermon did not much relieve me. Mr Gannett dined with us; and when we returned from meeting we found Mr and Mrs. A. J. Downing of Newburgh at our house. They dined with us—visited at my Sons and at Mrs T. B. Adams’s—took tea at Mrs Edwards Miller’s, and returned this evening to Mr Benjamin Guild’s at Brookline—whence they are to depart tomorrow afternoon to return home. Dr. Gannett’s afternoon sermon was from Luke 9.23. “And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.”— This discourse made amends for the deficiencies of that of the morning.— It was perhaps not better but more suited to my taste— The Christians daily cross; dwelling with great emphasis on the word daily— There is in this excellent morality. The argument was that the Christian is called to suffer and to act in the performance of duty every day— The profound conviction of this and vigorous exertion for the fulfilment of the duty, constitutes the Christian, and the pattern of the perfect man— There is no more useful sermon than this. Two men calling themselves Luther and Eaton, professing to come from Fall river, and to be going to Brighton stop’d here and said that they had come so far out of their way for the sole purpose of seeing me— Their looks were not prepossessing. Mr Lunt returning from Boston brought me a Letter from judge John Davis, with Middleton’s celestial Atlas— I examined it with Mary, and found it more convenient for recognizing the constellations and fixed stars than Bode’s Uranographia which is too unwieldy for convenience.

18. IV. Monday.  Another change of weather to high summer heat, and swarms of moschito’s more annoying than I ever knew them— I met last evening a man who accosted me and said his name was Joseph Burrell a son of Peter Burrell who formerly lived with my father. I remembered that in the autumn of 1779. my mother sent me on horseback to Weymouth, where I took up behind me a ragged boy named Peter Burrell, and brought him to my mothers, where he lived a year or two as a waiting boy. He is now 79 years of age, and father of this Mr Joseph Burrell, who spoke to me of propagating apple trees by slips or twigs— I made preparation for doctoring an apple-tree in the alley beyond Charles’s house, surrounded by Weeds, Blackberry vines and suckers— It will make me a week’s hard labour for exercise— I cut out the cores of 12 bergamot pears from the new tree, and planted them in a row immediately behind my sentry box for my tools. Mr Frederick Taft of Uxbridge a revolutionary soldier 85 years of age was here with his son Ezra Taft of Boston. The father is going to Braintree and Randolph upon genealogical researches: the minister of the Church in the south precinct of Braintree, now Randolph, having been of the name of Taft— This Gentleman called to see me from mere curiosity and sympathy— Mr Nathan Crosby came with an annual subscription book for contributions to promote the cause of Temperance, but I did not subscribe— Messrs. B. F. Copeland, Tileston, Brigham and Richardson came this afternoon, and communicated to me the Resolution adopted at the Norfolk County whig convention at Dedham, on the 9th. of this month, appointing them a Committee to wait on me and invite me to address the citizens of the County of Norfolk, at some time before the election. I accepted the invitation and agreed to meet them at Dedham on Thursday the 26th. of October at 10. O’Clock— I requested however that notice might be given to the 5 towns in the County of Middlesex and the 4 in the County of Plymouth of the meeting; with an invitation to attend it, which they said should be done— Mr Tileston spoke to me of a historical Society at Dorchester of which I have been elected an honorary member, which I have neglected to acknowledge. Commodore Pearson of the Navy was here— He had a claim to promotion which he says in consequence of his absence at sea was overlooked in Jany 1829. and although it was laid before me, through the then Secretary of the Navy Samuel L. Southard it has never been restored. Mr Cummings came with an invitation from the Pic Nic of Ladies on the Hancock lot next Wednesday at half past 1. O’Clock— He gave me also an invitation from the Quincy Lyceum to deliver a Lecture before them, in October which I conditionally promised.— I wrote Letters 1. to Albert Gallatin, introductory for Mr Marchant 2 to President Josiah Quincy, for a meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams temple and school fund on Wednesday—and 3. to judge John Davis to thank him for the loan of Middleton’s celestial Atlas.

19. III.45 Tuesday.  In search of laborious exercise I undertook this morning with my Spade, hoe and Saw to clear out an apple tree close to the wall in the ally leading over the hill, beyond Charles’s house— It is overrun with suckers and the ground over its root is hard bound almost as stone, and covered with blackberry vines; unapproachable— With my spade and hoe, I broke up the ground; about one half surrounding the trunk and took off a couple of the suckers nearest to the surface of the ground— It was a sweating work of two hours; the remainder of which I left for to-morrow— The wild cherry seedling that I crop’d off some time since has put out two or three buttons, and close under the crop two leaves.— And this morning for the first time I saw 2 pears on the sucker tree near the dwarf apple tree. It is a bergamot and must be at least 25 years old— I thought it never would bear— Mr Nathan Crosby called on me again, with his Son Stephen Moody Crosby; whose mother is the daughter of my brother Thomas’s Classmate Stephen Moody, recently deceased— He came again to my son’s house for his contribution to the Temperance funds— Mr Thomas Loring came to renew the proposal for another fishing party. I agreed to meet him at his house on Thursday Morning at 7. O’Clock, if the weather promise to be fair; and if not, either of the following days Friday or Saturday.— I find it impossible, taking three hours of exercise a day, to write the page of Journal, two or three short Letters, and even one page of the Astronomical Discourse—and having yesterday written three short Letters, I was last night, spell bound, and physically unable to write more than three or four lines— This day I made an effort and got through my journal page by 11. but then fell to searching for files of Letters and papers, which took up the time till dinner— I received a second Letter from Mr Giddings, with one of the same date (13 September) from him, James M Bloss, and Gaius N. St John, as a Committee of the People of Ashtabula County, Ohio inviting me to visit them on my way to or returning from Cincinnati— This afternoon I answered the invitation and the Letter from Giddings; but it left me in the evening only the power to finish the page I had begun yesterday of my discourse. In the distribution of my time, it is distressing to be so exceedingly straitened for hours to read; and I feel it cruelly now—when I want to compress a history of Astronomy into a discourse of three hours delivery. My task is to turn this transient gust of enthusiasm for the Science of astronomy at Cincinnati into a permanent and persevering national pursuit which may extend the bounds of human knowledge, and make my country instrumental in elevating the character and improving the condition of man upon Earth— The hand of God himself has furnished me this opportunity to do good— But O! how much will depend upon my manner of performing that task? and with what agony of soul must I implore the aid of almighty wisdom for powers of conception, energy of exertion and unconquerable will to accomplish my design.

20. IV:10. Wednesday  Finished clearing out the crab apple tree in the alley over the hill; and took off two or three more suckers. Planted sundry pears in the summer garden cellar, and picked a pin of wild cherries from the kitchen seedling to steep. The return of the warm weather makes it again agreeable to work on the ground and in the open air before Sunrise— The heavy dews constitute an objection, and require coarse pantaloons, and heavy shoes— At noon was held at my house the annual meeting of the supervisors of the Adams temple and school fund— All the members present— President Quincy came from Cambridge. Mr Thomas Greenleaf, Mr Beale and my son all attended. Mr Greenleaf made a report on the state of the Treasurer’s accounts, which was accepted and the same Committee was appointed to examine the Treasurers accounts of the present year to be reported at the next annual meeting— There are no rules established for the transactions of this corporation—and at my motion a Committee consisting of Mr Greenleaf, Mr Beale and my Son was appointed to prepare, and report rules at the next annual meeting.— The principal rule needed is a provision for regular annual meetings. Hitherto there has been no such provision—the yearly meetings have all been called at my instance and held at my house. Mr Greenleaf and Mr Beale were also appointed a Committee to examine and report upon the condition of the Library given by my father to the town of Quincy— There is danger that unless one regular annual meeting of the corporation is held, and an annual examination of the condition of the provided for by standing rules, the library will be lost by dispersion or perish by the depredations of rats mice and moths. A duty devolves on me, and on my Son by continued and persevering attention to prevent the gift of my father to the town of Quincy, from perishing by neglect, and ultimately if in our power to carry it into full execution— The members of the corporation, Mrs C. F. Adams with her daughter Louisa and Henry, Miss Bigelow, and Mr. Lunt dined with us, and we made it so late before dinner was over, that I did not attend the Pic Nic of the Ladies of Quincy at the Hancock and Adams lot— President Quincy brought me from the University Library the 4. volumes of Bailly’s history of ancient and modern Astronomy. Mr John B. Kirkham was here this evening. He said he came expressly from Springfield to invite me to deliver a Lecture for the Lyceum there this Autumn— After some hesitation, I promised if it should be in my power to deliver a Lecture or an address at Springfield on Wednesday the 1st. of November, and the thought occurred to me of making my expedition to Cincinnati itself the subject of that Lecture.— This suggestion pleased me so much that I began and wrote one page of such a Lecture; but it kept me up till past midnight—lost me a second day for the astronomical discourse, and agitated me too much. Miss Bigelow gave us a delightful evening of performance on the Piano.

21. IV. Thursday.  The excitement of the invitation last Evening from Springfield, of the design formed in consequence of it with the engagement previously undertaken by me to address the People of Norfolk County on Politics, on the 26th. of next month, and the thoughts which rushed upon me in connection with these manifold engagements was so great that I was not conscious of sleeping a wink the whole night— I rose convinced that I had not slept a moment— But I heard the Clock strike 12 and 4. The intermediate hours 1. 2. 3. I did not hear and when it struck 4. I was expecting to hear it strike 1.— I slept therefore between two and three hours, believing all the time that I was wide awake: a state of existence bordering I fear upon insanity; and which I contemplate with some alarm. I rose however at 4. and after an hour occupied in washing scrubbing and dressing, I went up the hill and roused my son, came back and roused the cook and coachman of my own family. Benjamin tackled with one horse— I returned to Charles’s house to see the Sun rise, on this the equinoctial day; but there was a thick border of haze just over the eastern horizon, and the rising sun could not be seen— My son drove me in the Carryall to Hingham; whence we went with Mr Thomas Loring and Mr Quincy Thaxter to Mr Nicholls’s house at Cohasset— And thence with a small row boat, we went under the lee of a rock and fished for pearch about 3 hours— We caught a bucket full, with a due proportion of Pollock, flounders and one Tautaug—at half past 12 we returned to the shore, and then with Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 90 to Mr Loring’s house at Hingham— There we had a dinner of Chowder and fried pearch. Mr Baker and Mrs Quincy Thaxter with a baby girl 8 months old were there.— Mr Baker gave me Charles Willmer’s American News-Letter of the 5th. of this month, containing Queen Victoria’s speech on proroguing Parliament in person—after which she went to visit the king of France at the Chateau d’Eu. At 4 O’Clock we left Mr Loring’s house at returned home, with the Sun in our faces all the way. We reached home at 5. O’Clock, but I was so heated, so weary, and so heavy with the sleepless drowsiness of last night that I was disabled for all useful toil, and could not even write the journal of yesterday I found on my table, a Letter from judge Burnet and from professor O. M. Mitchell of Cincinnati, requesting me to fix the day for the ceremony of laying the corner stone of the Astronomical observatory there; and proposing Tuesday the 7th. of November. Also a Letter from W. B. Read of Philadelphia reminding me of a conditional engagement which I had contracted last May, to deliver a discourse upon some historical subject, before the historical Society of Pennsylvania, next November. I had already received a Letter of the 15th from Edward Armstrong a similar Letter he is the Secretary of the Society— When I promised professor Mitchell at the Niagara Falls to go to Cincinnati next November I totally forgot this engagement to the Pennsylvania Society; and it now comes upon me with grievous pressure and I know not what to do— This Evening was partly clear, and with Middleton’s celestial Atlas, I pointed out to my two Granddaughters Mary Louisa and Louisa Catherine most of the Constellations visible in the hemisphere now over us from the setting Scorpion to the rising Bull—and I verified the Star Fomalhaut.
