22. III:45 Friday  Sun rose 5.46. Crystal clear, Set 6.  I finished the trimming of the Apple tree in the alley on the hill beyond Charles’s house, and took off a bush of suckers.— The shoot from the cropped seedling wild cherry has put out a third leaf— I rubbed off an incipient leaf from a bud below. I first observed yesterday emerging from the soil the leaves of a seedling English white oak, in the row four of which came out about the 1st. of July. I suspect that the difference in the time of subterranean vegetation before they come up depends upon the depth at which they are planted; and that the safest from the fatal hand of frost may be those which go over the second winter before they come up.— The self planted on the spot in the garden where the tree was taken up last fall, have four out of the 16. a third spindle shoot now expanding leaves, and the tallest of them is 12 inches high, and the leaves have yet time for full developement before the frost will set in and suspend all vegetation for the winter— From this size down to two inches high I have every variety of the English white oak seedling of the present year. George Newcomb came to enquire concerning his petition in behalf of the owners of the Schooner Rosanne, and after about an hour of search I could find nothing about it, either in the Journal of the last Session of the house, or in my own minutes or diary. So I must turn it over for further enquiry— I completed the Diary of the day before yesterday and of yesterday, and wrote two Letters—one in answer to W. F Channing, enclosing a Letter to me, dated September 1841. from his now deceased father Dr W. E. Channing, complying with W. F. Channing’s request that I would send him any Letters that I had received from his father; of whose life he is preparing a Memoir, and one to James Eaton, Secretary of the Lyceum at Malden, declining an invitation to deliver an introductory Lecture before them. I was proceeding to write another Letter when I received a note from Robert Gourlay, more than 20 years since an agitator in Canada scarcely less terrible than Daniel O’Connell is in Ireland now— The British Government of the Province then seized and transported home to Scotland, and broke up his revolutionary movement; since which I had scarcely heard the sound of his name till I received the day before I left Washington last May, a Letter from him dated at Boston, with an enclosed small pamphlet and expressing a desire for an interview with me. I did not answer it but this afternoon received a note from him, repeating the wish for an interview and enclosing another pamphlet; I answered that I would receive him immediately and he came— But he had nothing to say to me, except that he was now going to Canada to claim of the Legislature indemnity for his past persecutions. Mr and Mrs Grinnell, with Cornelia and Miss Otté took tea here. The Young Ladies are now returning from Cayuga lake to New-Bedford.

23. IV:5. Saturday.  My morning exercise was light—a second pint measure made 5 quarts of wild cherries, picked from the seedling in the garden opposite the kitchen window, to steep— Curiosity enquires how this little sapling bears the fruit in profusion which five full sized trees could scarcely equal— What is the philosophy of bearing trees? what proportion do they bear to the barren, and what is the cause of barrenness? Mr John N. Bernard came as a mendicant with a subscription book and not many names— He is the son of a comic actor of the old Boston company to whom I was indebted for many pleasant and cheerful hours. He himself he says followed the Sea— Was wild and extravagant; and disregarded his fathers wise precepts and prudent counsels— At last he broke his knee, and was crippled since which he has been unable to go to Sea, and to earn his living in any way— For two or three years he has been itinerating round the country, throughout New-England and delivering Temperance Lectures— But the excitement has passed away, and the people will no longer hear his Lectures on Temperance— He is compelled therefore to appeal to the charitable for assistance, and his appeal is not always in vain— While we were at dinner, Mr Philbrick a teacher in the Roxbury high School came with a youth named Augustine Reed, a candidate for a Cadet warrant at the Military Academy at West Point— He had certificates of competency from M. A. D’Wolfe Howe, episcopal and George Putnam congregational minister at Roxbury, Samuel H. Walley junr and Dan Leach a teacher at the school—all which he left with me. I promised to cause his name to be entered in the book of Candidates at the War Department, and to deposit his certificates with the entry— And I explained to him that no Cadet Warrant can issue for the 8th. Congressional district of Massachusetts, till a year from next March and then he must be designated by the Member of H.R.U.S. from this District in the next Congress— My wife, with her two daughters and Louisa C. Smith went to Hingham, visited Mrs T. Loring and the Misses Thaxter, and brought home Mrs Charles’s two sons John and Charles— I wrote Letters to Edward Armstrong Secretary of the historical Society of Pennsylvania, requesting to be released from the engagement to deliver a historical Lecture before them next November; and I glanced over the Astronomische Nachrichten of Schumacher—Altona August 1826. where I found a notice of the life of  Joseph Fraunhofer.  Born at Straubing in Bavaria 6. March 1787. His father was a glazier and destined him to his own trade. In his 11th. year he lost both his parents— His guardian bound him to Weichselberger a Glassmaker in Munich for 6 years without charge and without compensation. Neither his father nor Weichselberger allowed him any schooling. After many misfortunes and obstacles he became connected as optician with the mathematical institute of Reichenbach Utzschneider and Liebherr, and there acquired his fame as an unrivalled maker of Telescopes. He died on the 7th of June 1826—aged 39.

24. III.30. Sunday.  Sun rose 5.48 clear Set 5.56.  Mr White of Dedham preached this morning from Proverbs 3.17. [“]Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are Peace”— The discourse was upon the pleasures of religion, but I was in a lethargy and unable to listen with attention— There was a great change last evening in the atmosphere to sultry damp, the effect of which upon my body was to produce a dull heavy headache, and a sluggish sulky rhumatic uneasiness all over me. I went to bed soon after 10 and to sleep— I awoke at the stroke of the clock with an excruciating cramp in my right leg— I supposed the clock was striking 4. but it struck 12— My cramp passed off but the head ache remained— I slept no more, but lay and heard the clock strike 2 and 3. during which the relieving perspiration came on. At half past 3. I rose, dressed. wrote a page of my astronomical address and as Sun rise approached went up the hill and saw it from the Eastern corner of Charles’s house— I returned and wrote with the interval for breakfast till the second bell for meeting was ringing whereby my indispensable days work was done; but I was in a state of torpor the whole day— The weather was of the very hottest of the Summer. Mr White dined with us and preached after dinner from Mark 6.20. [“]For Herod favored John, knowing that he was a just man, and an holy.”—omitting the remainder of the verse— The discourse was upon the duty and the blessing of an holy life. An excellent theme, but I had the malady of not listening as in the morning; altogether involuntary, and the unfailing consequence of a headache and sleepless night.— I had barely returned home from afternoon meeting, when Mr Degrand came in from Boston, with his nephew named Oxnard, a young Frenchman from Marseilles, and Mr Clapp senior editor of the Boston evening Gazette who took tea and spent the Evening with us. Mr Degrand took my Letters to Edward Armstrong and W. B. Reed, to put into the Post-Office at Boston. Extreme lassitude disabled me for writing and drove me to bed soon after 10  Fraunhofer.  While he was an apprentice at Weichselberger’s, the house fell in, and buried him under its ruins. He was dug out of them alive, the king of Bavaria having repaired to the spot, cheering the workmen who dug him out by his presence and his exhortations—and upon his deliverance gave him 18 ducats— With part of the money he purchased a machine for grinding glass, and made experiments with it in the leisure of holidays, without success. He resorted to Treatises upon Optics, but found they required previous elementary mathematics, for the acquisition of which he was obliged to steal holiday hours out of his masters house, for in it the use of Books was interdicted to him— He had been very imperfectly taught even to write— In despite of all these obstacles and discouragements, he persevered indefatigably in pursuit of the science of optics with the unconquerable will which cannot be disappointed.

25. IV Monday—  Showery, Foggy, Misty. Rainy—  A pattern day— After a night of sound sleep I awoke free from head ache— My washing, scrubbing—dressing took an hour of gentle exercise— Then two hours with the Spade and hoe to clear the ground about the stump of a mazzard cherry tree on the hill, eastern side of the alley opposite Charles’s gate; and to enlarge the plat round a seedling mazzard in the Seminary. This is hard and ungrateful work— The rest of the day with the intervals for breakfast, dinner, tea, and an hour of relaxation with my family and Charles, and about two hours of wilful idleness, a waking substitute for sleep was employed on my daily labour and produced. 1. The page of yesterday’s diary— 2 A page and a half of Astronomical discourse. 3. An Answer to Cyrus Curtiss, President of the Franklin Library Association at Hudson New-York, declining to deliver an introductory Lecture before that institution next October or November, and 4 my name, autograph on a card engraving of my portrait by Durand, directed to Elwood Evans age 14 years at Philadelphia— This is all and O! how small— But I wandered into Cerisier’s Tableau of the history of the United Netherlands—into Potter’s Grecian Antiquities— In search of Ludwig’s German and English Dictionary; and all for enquiries not one of which was satisfied.— In tracing the history of Antient Astronomy, especially that of the Grecian schools I get entangled in details of speculative opinions held by numerous individuals most of whose names are scarcely remembered, and they dog my progress so that I shall be hard put to it to get rid of them— But how shall I collect in a focus all the rays of human intelligence gathering to shed light on the Science of Astronomy?— The Pythagorean square of the hypothenuse—the polarity of the magnet—and last of all the telescope—the glass lens! which brings me again to  Fraunhofer—  With the remainder of the king of Bavaria’s donation, he purchased of his master the last half year of his apprenticeship, and sought to earn his livelihood by engraving visiting cards— This proved but a precarious resource, till by a lucky chance, Utzschneider engaged him as an Optician— Here was the field for the display of his powers. His first labours were the making of objective glasses for astronomical observatories. In 1809. Utzschneider erected with him and Reichenboch the optical institute at Benedictbeurn. In 1811. he introduced a new and improved mode of melting glass. In 1818 he undertook the whole direction of the establishment. Of his optical discoveries he communicated an account to the Bavarian royal Academy of Sciences, and published a French translation in Schumacher’s periodical. One of his theories was first published in the 3d. number of the Nachrichten. His Telescopes surpassed any that had ever been made before. The largest yet known was made for the observatory at Dorpat. He left another of the same power nearly finished— A larger one of 12 inches aperture was begun.

26. IV. Tuesday  The day was occupied like that of yesterday, and with similar progress, and growing anxiety. I worked an hour and a half at the mazzard cherry-tree stump in the alley on the hill nearly opposite Charles’s house; light clad in raw cold weather, to warm myself by labour— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. E Price Greenleaf came this afternoon and looked over the last budded seedling Apple trees in the seminary, most of which have taken— But he found a worm at the root of the tall seedling at the seminary gate; and one at the root of that near the Summer house cellar— I planted in flower pot N. 3. the core of a Bartlet pear and a row of rotten pears and peaches in the garden and orchard corner— I had an afternoon visit from Dr Duggan, whom I had not seen since we parted at Saratoga. His wife’s uncle, Daniel Glover, then his Patient, derived no benefit from the Springs, and soon after came with him home and died. The Doctor is a man of smooth speech, smiling face, and courteous demeanour: always extremely observant of me but not much my friend. He gave me to understand that he had made at Saratoga many minutes for Letters to Green the Editor of the Quincy Patriot, for publication; and had specially intended in those Letters to do me honour. But he had himself been very sick at Saratoga, and had not entirely recovered since his return; and having been much and painfully engaged in attendance, on his relative Mr Glover, till his death, and on the administration of his affairs since his Letters had not been published— Charles and his wife passed the evening here with their daughter Louisa Catherine. Mr Brooks goes to New-Bedford to-morrow.— I answered the Letter of enquiries from Revd. Henry F. Harrington of Providence, R.I. and declined the invitation of Philip W Lowry, J. Cohen and E. J. Dubois, Committee of the mechanical library association of Baltimore, to deliver before them a Lecture in October or November coming. I received Letters 1. from John A. Parker of New-York, with the Evening Post containing his petition to Governor Bouck, to sue the States of Pennsylvania and Illinois for their debts to him. 2. From Ezekiel Bacon of Utica, with an Oneida whig, and a Utica daily Gazette containing a narrative of his recent visit to the falls of Niagara. The papers are of the 17th. instt. 3. A Letter of sharp rebuke from Arthur St. Clair Nichols, at the Havana 1. Septr. 43. charging me with calumny for saying at Auburn that the Roman Catholics worship the Virgin Mary— 4. A Letter of invitation from Alexander Hay, Mayor of Pittsburgh and 19 others, and yesterday— A Letter from Stephen B. Tompkins and 8 others, 19. Septr. 43 White plains, West Chester County New-York, inviting me to the anniversary celebration of the Battle there, 28. October, and to deliver an Address—

27. IV:30. Wednesday.  A change comes over my whereabouts, if not over the spirit of my dream— I had my journal of yesterday written when I was called to breakfast, and that was all that I could accomplish—and rising at four, it is all that I ever can accomplish— From breakfast till 1. p.m. I was constantly occupied, with the interval of a visit from Mr Minott Thayer, with a young man named Ides, in packing my small black trunk for a journey to New-Bedford—to be gone two days. Such a mountain must I make of a molehill. My astronomical Discourse, and my address to the people of Norfolk County, are forcibly suspended, and I could barely find time to read Mr Bacon’s report of his late visit to the Niagara Falls and to answer the enquiries of the Revd. Benjamin F. Harrington of Providence. At one, we dined and at a quarter past 2. I left home with Louisa C. Smith who alighted at Mr James H. Fosters in Boston, and my granddaughter Mary-Louisa, who was on a shoping excursion, I stop’d at Mr Edward Brooks’s where I found him and his family and Mrs Peter C. Brooks at dinner— It was but a quarter past 3. I made a short visit to judge Davis and found him with his three daughters a grand daughter and a great grand daughter.— I had a short conversation with him upon Middleton’s celestial Atlas, and hurried back to Mr Edward Brooks’s, at whose door his father was stopping in to my Carriage and we drove to the depot of the New-Bedford Railway, which we reached on the stroke of four; step’d into the Car and were off, with scarcely time to greet Mr Grinnell who was waiting for us there— At half past six we alighted from the cars and step’d into Mr Grinnell’s carriage at New-Bedford— They call it 55 miles. It may be 50— The road is half the way the same as that to Providence; but the movement is so rapid that there is scarcely time to count the towns we pass through on the road. There was a cavalcade of firemen with lighted torches at the depot who escorted us to Mr Grinnell’s house, and a crowd of boys followed us shouting to the great consternation of Mr Grinnell’s horses; to no small personal danger and great annoyance of us all— Yet it was meant in honour to me, of which I was duly sensible in gratitude to him who disposes of the minds of men. Numbers of visitors course in to Mr Grinnell’s in the course of the evening among whom the selectmen of the town, the chairman of whom Mr Congdon, told me that they would come to-morrow at 12 O’Clock and take me to the town hall and introduce me to the citizens of New-Bedford—

28— V:30. Thursday  I slept till the day dawned upon my chamber from the east, and without losing time I saw the Sun rise in glory, fronting my windows. I wrote with assiduity till breakfast time at 8 and finished the diary of yesterday. After Breakfast, Mr Grinnell took Mr Brooks, and me in his Carriage first to see his father a very neat clad and gravely dignified old man, who told me he was just ten years older than myself being just turned of his 86th. year. He has enjoyed sound health till within two or three years but is now infirm with rhumatic complaints.— Our next visit was to Mrs Russell mother of Mrs Grinnell, an old Lady of 82. also of the Society of Friends. She lives in a large square wooden house which has been removed from a street different from that on which it now stands— And our third visit was to Mr and Mrs Arnold in the same hourse where we met an evening party in September 1835. The year after which they went to Europe, and travelled three years— Their house was then graceful and comfortable, and furnished with elegance, and at great cost— It is now embellished with many articles of exquisite luxury from Italy, that it is like a second princely palace.— Mr Arnold was not at home, but Mrs Arnold received and treated with a profusion of flowers and of fruits—grapes, pears and peaches— We returned to Mr Grinnell’s at 12 and found waiting there the selectmen, Congdon, Howland and Kempton, with whom I went in a Carriage to the town Hall, a new store, and spacious building.— There on the platform where the Selectmen have their Seats Mr Congdon addressed me in a speech carefully composed and handsomely delivered, of about 20 minutes—and introduced me to the Meeting composed entirely of men— I answered him in a speech of half an hour, like all the other extraordinary and extemporaneous speeches that I have been doomed to deliver a source to me of deep mortification from the consciousness, how flat and impotent is every effort of mine of this kind—and I was on this occasion more than usually dull— After the speeches came the shaking of hands for a half an hour— I met there unexpectedly Dr Thomas Robbins of Mattapoisett. Mr Brooks and Mr Grinnell went to the Hall, but did not come up to the platform— The Select men returned with me and left me at Mr Grinnell’s where there was a small party of 12 to dine— The Revd. Mr Peabody and Mr Arnold were of the company— Discussion upon theatrical entertainments— At 4. O’Clock the Selectmen came and took me to Mr Howland’s where a considerable number of Ladies had assembled, and received my very respectful salutations. Mr Grinnell came with Mr Brooks came and took us to ride over the river and round the town of Fairhaven. We returned to Mr Grinnell’s where there was a large evening party; Ladies and Gentlemen to meet us.

29. V:15 Friday.  A cold and hoarse sore throat is one of the sequences to my speech at the town hall yesterday. Yet I had a good night’s rest and awoke this morning with the dawn well advanced. I saw the Sun rise glorious in front of my window but had no time, but to dress and pack my trunk for departure. At a quarter past six we breakfasted—then took leave of Mrs Grinnell and the young Ladies— Mr Grinnell took us in his carriage to the railroad depot, and accompanied us to Boston— The train started from the depot precisely at 7. and we landed at the depot at the bottom of the common in Boston at ten— In the cars I met a young man named Elliot, son of Mr and Mrs Elliot of Washington, and Mr Durfee (Nathan) a representative in the Legislature of the Commonwealth from Fall-river in 1841— At the depot in Boston I parted from Mr Brooks and Mr Grinnell; stop’d at the shop of Mr Mitchell, Seal engraver and took the Seal ordered for Captain Buchanan— I found my Son at his office, and Mr Spooner came in while I was there— I hurried to Mr William Bowditch’s in Otis place. Neither he nor his wife was at home, and I had no small difficulty in obtaining, but did obtain access to the library. I was an hour and a half intensely engaged in searching for the volumes of Schumacher’s Astronomische Nachrichten, containing the accounts of the erection by the Russian Emperor Nicholas of the Astronomical Observatory of Pulkova— I found two of them at last—Volumes 11. and 13.— Numbers 264. August 1834. and 290. 291. 292 18. Novr 1835. I took out the Books and entered my name as the borrower. I next called upon judge Davis, and had a further conversation of half an hour with him. He lent me the companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas, and also, a Mercator’s map of the Starry heavens comprehending the whole equinoctial and terminated by the polar Circle, published many years ago by William Croswell, a college associate of judge Davis. This is an aid to the study of the constellations of which I had never before heard. At one O’Clock I met by previous agreement with my Son, him and his daughter Louisa Catherine, at Dr Frothingham’s where the Carriage was at that time ordered. Neither the Doctor, nor Mrs Frothingham was at home— But we met there at the time— Benjamin, the driver was punctual to the time with the Carriage, and we came home to Quincy to dine— I came home, burdened more than I ever was before, but with spirits too much dissipated to resume at once the broken thread. A Mr Fuller of Newton with his wife a daughter of William Jackson, returning from an excursion to Plymouth, called to see me for curiosity— Mr Marsh teacher of a school at Milton came with a subscription paper for a contribution to purchase an apparatus for lectures on Natural philosophy: to cost 500 dollars. I went up the hill at Sunset to see Mrs Charles but she was out on a visit to Mrs Lunt— She and Charles afterwards came and spent a short evening here— I could accomplish nothing more than the diary of yesterday though I began with Mary Louisa, the companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas, comparing the book with the maps; and both with the real spangles in the skies which were never arrayed in brighter splendor than this Evening. I recognized several old acquaintance among the constellations.

30. IV.15 Saturday  Sun rose 5:55 clear. Set 5.45.  Light frost. I wrought with my spade and hoe upon the hill; but found work which can only be done with the plough— The mornings are becoming so cold, and the pressure of my indoor work so excessive that I must henceforth renounce my excursions before sunrise, or limit them to a quarter of an hour. My visitors this day were Lovell Childs; a young man who said he resided at Andover; had some business in this part of the country, and came to see me, from mere curiosity— Next P. Emory Aldrich of Prescott, Massachusetts, William Baker of Newark, Ohio and Daniel D. Atchison of Lexington Kentucky, Students at the Law-school in Cambridge, told me that they came to Quincy to see me and the quarries.— After a short conversation they asked for my autograph— I wrote my name on 3 visiting cards with the date, and asked them, much to their amusement, for their autographs in return; which they gave me, all on one sheet of Letter paper— Then a young man, named George Warren, came from Boston with a recommendatory Letter from William Hayden senior editor of the Atlas, and accompanied by another young man named Turner, to invite and urge me to deliver a Lecture before the mercantile library association, which I was constrained to decline— Mr Lunt was here this evening, wanting to borrow Eliot’s biography for some notice of the death of Leonard Hoar sometime President of Harvard College— The book was at my Son’s up the hill— Mr Lunt found it there, but not what he wanted in it— I strip’d the remainder of wild cherries from the garden seedling, about half a pint, but a full quart had been borrowed while I was at New-Bedford— I picked up a dozen English white oak acorns fallen from the trees; but they all floated. Five or six that I gathered sunk and are plantable— I bought in a wool clad worm with the twig and leaf on which I found him— Charles’s sons John and Charles were brought home from Hingham, and Miss Sampson was taken home to Braintree this afternoon. I read in Schumacher’s Astronomische Nachrichten N. 264. August 1834. the first notice of the Pulkova observatory; and made some further progress in reading Bailly’s history—but not half a page in writing my own address; though I wrote myself more than once asleep.— Charles and his wife were here in the evening. I read with Mary Louisa two Sections of the Companion to Middleton’s celestial Atlas—comparing them with the maps and with the stars in the sky— The Mercator’s map of Croswell is not of much use— I was compelled by mere heaviness of spirit to retire to bed immediately after ten.

1. IV:15. Sunday.  Sun rose 5.56. beclouded. Fahrenheit 50.  I walked up the hill to see the Sun rise— There was a thin border of cloud at the horizon, intercepting the first sunbeam; then a strip of clear sky from which his effulgence radiated for a transient moment, and then a thick body of cloud extending all over the sky, under which he disappeared, and was no more seen this day— I allowed myself but 20 minutes of morning walk and before I got back to my table there was a sprinkling drop by drop of rain over my head. It increased to a moderate calm steady rain which continued the whole day till Evening when it freshened to a North eastern breeze and copious showers— I rode morning and evening to and from meeting. Mr Lunt preached in the morning from Luke 7.47. [“]Wherefore, I say unto thee, Her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much; but to whom little is forgiven, the same loveth little”— This is a mysterious part of the personal history of Christ— It follows immediately after the performance of many of his most stupendous miracles—the healing of the centurions servant— The raising from the dead of the widow’s son; and the answer to the messengers from John the baptist with the enquiry, art thou he that should come— After all this, a Pharisee invites him to his table—and while there; a woman, Luke says, a Sinner came in with a box of precious ointment, with which she anointed the feet of Jesus, kissing them and wiping them with her hair— The pharisee secretly taxes Jesus with keeping bad company, and of course being no prophet but an impostor. Jesus detecting his suspicions, tells him the parable of the two debtors and makes him acknowledge that the debtor to whom the most was forgiven will love the most—then compares the woman’s kindness to him with that of the pharisee himself; declares that of the woman much the best; and then because she loved much, her sins, which were many, were forgiven— Here are many sins forgiven for personal adulation; and the kindness of the pharisee roughly buffeted because it was not so obsequious as that of the woman— The other three Apostles tell the story with entirely different circumstances.— With them Simon is not a pharisee, but a leper— The woman is Mary, the sister of Martha and of Lazarus.— She is not mentioned as a sinner, nor are her sins forgiven; but Judas the Traitor, blames her for wasting the precious ointment, and she is justified by Jesus— This Mary passes somewhat dubiously for Mary Magdalen, but Luke does not name her. Mr Lunt was severe upon the pharisee. So is Massillon— I do not exactly see why— Mr Lunt administered the communion, and prayed for Mrs Lee, who died of a Typhus fever this afternoon. She was the daughter of the late Mrs Anthony W. Baxter who died last Winter. A family sadly broken up— Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from 1. Thessalonians 5:23 [“]And the very God of Peace sanctify you wholly: And I pray God your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.”— He detained the members of the Church and read the Letter of invitation from the church at Jamaica plains, to the ordination of Revd. Joseph H. Allen the 18th. He proposed me as the delegate to go with him which was voted.

2. IV.45. Monday.  The rain continued till after I rose this morning and the thermometer having risen to 56 there was thick fog, and lightening without thunder. In the course of the morning the sky cleared away. I am compelled to surrender the hours before breakfast to my preparations for the west, with drawing them from the service of bodily exercise and planting. Yet my progress in the labour before me is so slow that I shall certainly not be ready for the pledged address at Dedham—the Lecture at Springfield and the Discourse at Cincinnati—besides the unexpected and sudden calls to speak, which keep me upon the rack— Last evening and this morning I wrote two Letters to Alexander Hay, one as chairman of a Committee of 50 citizens from a meeting of Friends of Liberty at Pittsburgh Pennsylvania, and the other as Mayor of the City of Pittsburgh—both being invitations to me to visit that place on my way to or from Cincinnati.— A gentleman beggar by the name of Francis Sanderson paid me a transient visit. Isaac H. Adams dined with us, and assisted my granddaughter Mary Louisa in making up the Memorial of my July tour to Canada, and the Falls of Niagara—in many respects the most memorable period of my life— It consists of the Newspaper reports of the complimentary receptions which I met at Saratoga—Ogdensburgh; the Falls, Buffalo, Rochester, Canandaigua, Auburn, Syracuse, Utica, Herkimer, Little-falls, Schenectady, Albany and Pittsfield; which I pray God may not have turned my head. I have gathered the articles containing the notices of my progress—the addresses made to me and my answers, and now have the slips pasted into an old book for Wedgwood’s copying press, which I have had these 50 years and never used— Among my troubles now is the multitude of Letters that I receive from day to day and have neither leisure, time, nor even often the ability to answer— This day 1. from Lysander Spooner, with a pamphlet upon Constitutional Law, relative to credit, currency and Banking. 2 From Theodore S. Fay U.S. Secretary of Legation at Berlin, 13. August 1843. with an enclosure from John D. Hiester, and 3 other papers relating to the claim of Dr Flügel, U.S. Consul at Leipzig, 3. From T. A. Howard Rockville, Indiana 23. Septr. 1843. with perplexing enquiries concerning periodical journals. Howard was a worthy democratic member of the 26th. Congress 1. Session, from Indiana. 4. From Samuel Howard, and 2 others—Committee of Clay club. N. 2 New-York, Switzerland County Indiana 12. Septr. 1843. asking my opinion on a curious contested election question. I cannot answer these Letters. I called this afternoon at Mr Josiah Brigham’s shop to see him, but he was gone to Weymouth— At my son’s request I endorsed his note for 2400 dollars.

3. IV.45. Tuesday.  Sun rose 5.58 Crystal clear. Set 5.48.  Mr Brigham called on me this morning and I told him that having found it necessary to set out upon my journey to Cincinnati earlier than I had intended, I wished to change the day for my address to the inhabitants of Norfolk County, and of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, from Thursday the 26th. of this month to Tuesday the 24th.— And I requested him to give notice of this change to the other members of the Committee; and in the Newspapers of the District, which he very cheerfully promised to do. He thought the hour we had agreed upon was 11. in the morning, and I now agreed to fix that as the hour; but 10 was the hour upon which we had agreed, and I should not have consented to change it— I have a fearful weight upon my mind to prepare at once for Dedham, Springfield and Cincinnati, to keep my Diary in the current of time, and not to neglect entirely my correspondence— I receive so many Letters, and upon subjects so multifarious, that even the memory of receiving many of them escapes me, and I propose now to endorse and file them first chronologically; and alphabetically at the close of each month— I answered last Night and this morning Letters from judge Burnet and professor O. M. Mitchel of Cincinnati; promising if practicable to reach that city by the 6th. of November; the 7th. being the day named by Mr Mitchel for the ceremony. I wrote also. 1. to John B. Kirkham of Springfield apprizing him, that the day of my departure from home is changed from the 1st. of the next to the 25th of the present month, when I hope to reach Springfield in time to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at that place. 2. to John F. Lamb, at Frankford near Philadelphia, declining a renewed invitation to deliver a Lecture there. 3. To Charles J. Ingersoll, Philadelphia, who has twice transmitted to me these invitations to lecture at Frankford.— I return his courtesy with a lot of the same article. In political intercourse it may often be our duty to respect a man whom we cannot esteem; and in the encounter of partizan hostility we must make large allowance for the possible injustice of our own prejudices and prepossessions. I received this day Letters 1. From T. A. Howard, Rockville Indiana 23 Septr 1843. Another political adversary, asking good offices for a literary institution. Can I deny, or withhold them? 2. From T. B. Wakeman—New-York—with a printed circular notice of the 11th. annual Fair of the American Institute at New-York and a skein of black sewing silk. 3. From Albert Wright, superintendent of common schools, Washington County, New-York, 28 Septr 1843. who is to write upon physical education, and asks for my experiences— How shall I answer him?— There was this afternoon a very sudden thunder gust; and a beautiful double rainbow. Walk up the hill— Mrs Charles and the two Louisa’s.

4. IV.15. Wednesday.  Fahrenheit 46.  I devoted this day to labour and made my record of yesterday before breakfast— I thought I should have a long morning for writing, but Mr Curtis my Co-Executor of the Will of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston with Mrs Alicia Boylston his widow came, and informed me, that last Wednesday Mrs Boylston, who resides with her son at Providence Rhode-Island had a severe fit of palsy, which may be hourly expected to terminate fatally. That her right side is wholly impotent and she is speechless, though still in full possession of her mind. The event of her decease will impose upon him and me immediate and complicated duties, which will require our immediate and most assiduous attention— We read carefully the Will over together. The three Co-Executors are also constituted joint Trustees for the management of the Estate, real and personal, for the payment of sundry annuities, rents and profits, and of sundry bequests to take effect on the decease of Mrs Boylston— The Trust is almost a perpetuity, and the will requires that on the decease of either of the Trustees the survivors shall nominate a person to be appointed by the judge of Probate as the third Trustee, so that there may be always three, during the continuance of the Trust— A life estate was given to Mrs Boylston, in all the real Estate, but the moment after her decease the Trust attaches to it all. We agreed 1. That in the event of Mrs Boylston’s decease, we must immediately nominate a third Trustee for the appointment by the judge of probate, and that it shall be my Son, if he will consent. 2. That from the moment of Mrs Boylston’s decease accounts must be opened by the Trusts with all the Estates specifically devised, and with all the annuitants and beneficiaries 3.— That the option must be offered to Dr Ward Nicholas Boylston, to occupy the Princeton Estate, and to Thomas Boylston to occupy the Roxbury Estate; in which case the management of them will devolve upon themselves respectively; and if they decline occupying them they must do it in writing to be kept of record in the probate Office. 4. That an inventory should be taken of all the property, with which the Trustees will be chargeable from the day of Mrs Boylston’s decease—and a list of all the persons to whom they will have bequests or annuities to pay. 5. That they must take possession of all papers relating to the Execution of the will or the trusts, which have been hitherto in the possession of Mrs Boylston— Mr Curtis has received also from Petty Vaughan, by the Acadia, yesterday arrived one copy of the bond to be executed by us which he left with me. The other copy is to come by the Great Western. I promised to go next Monday to Boston, with an account for settlement between the Administrations of Thomas Boylston and Moses Gill, of which Mr Curtis promised to give notice to Mr George Fuller— I called at Mr Brigham’s shop, but he was gone to Boston.— I left at the Aurora Office a notice for publication to-morrow.

5. IV:30. Thursday.  Though I intermitted the morning excursion before Sunrise, and devoted the whole day to labour I was yet unable to complete my record before breakfast, and then the hours slip’d away: the noon bell rang, and my page was scarcely finished when I was called to dinner. The Quincy Aurora of this day has the notice that I left at the Office yesterday, that I will address the People of the County of Norfolk and of the 8th. Congressional district of Massachusetts on Tuesday the 24th. of this Month at 10. A.M. at Dedham— There is also a separate notification by the Norfolk County Committee to the same effect— I called at Mr Brigham’s shop, and agreed with him about the hour, and said it would be important to me to come home that day to dinner to have half the day to prepare for my departure the next morning. I then called in at the Quincy Patriot Office and requested the republication in that paper on Saturday of my notification in this day’s Aurora; which was promised.— Green the Editor of the Patriot is convalescent from a Typhus fever, but was not at the office— On my way, finding the grave-yard open, I went in, and saw the improvements they are making there. A strong cemented wall, with an iron gate and railing have been recently placed as a fence fronting the road—the old tombstone of the parish ministers has been rebuilt by the Ladies of Quincy, and the range of excavated tombs, with the names of their owners is carried round 3. sides of the square— But not a trace is to be found either of John Quincy or of Anna Fiske his mother—nor of John Quincy’s wife, all my ancestors. My Son was there with Deacon Spear; consulting about some inscription; and some improvement upon the family tomb, which belonged to my father, and where his remains, and those of my mother were at first deposited— My Son came home with me, and I proposed to him in the event of Mrs Boylston’s decease, that we should nominate him for appointment by the judge of probate as the third trustee in place of Mrs Boylston, to execute the trusts created by Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will— He asked my advice, and I advised and earnestly intreated him to accept the trust. He read over the Will and made no objection to my proposal.— He brought me a deed of a small strip of land for ten dollars to be conveyed to Ebenezer Adams, which I and my wife signed and sealed— I closed Letters to Miss Aricartha Miller at New-York, declining to deliver a Lecture; and to the Revd. Henry Jackson of New-Bedford in answer to enquiries about my eyes but I found not one half hour to write a Letter for this day— After dinner I read some pages of Bailly and some pages of Adam Smith’s History of Astronomy without ascertaining as I wanted the origin of the existing Zodiac, and Grecian Constellations— I bethought myself of Dupuis’s Origine de tous les cultes and supposing I might find there what I wanted, I borrowed the 11 volumes from the town Library and they engaged me till day light failed— Charles and his wife were here till the curfew, and I wrote till the clock struck midnight.

6. IV:45. Friday.  Sun rose 6.2. clear. Set 5.35. Fahrenheit 40.  Another day of intense and agonizing labour dissatisfied with my own work and disheartened All confidence in myself lost and ready to despair of assistance, whence alone it can come— Major Thomas Adams came, and asked me for a Letter of introduction to governor Lincoln, whom he proposes to visit, to invite him to come and address the whigs of Quincy, upon electioneering topics. He said Mr Choate the U.S. Senator had advised him last week, at Dedham to apply to Governor Lincoln; and upon Adams’s objecting that he thought Mr Lincoln would not come, answered “yes he will.” How this came to be known to Mr Choate, he did not say; perhaps he assumed to say it without authority, to escape from the importunity of Mr Adams, to prevail on him to come and discourse electioneering politics to the whigs of Quincy. I told Mr Adams that I would give him a Letter of introduction to Mr Lincoln. Mr. Robinson the episcopal clergyman of this place, Mr Howe the Minister of that church at Roxbury, with Mrs Robinson and Mrs. Howe, with Messrs. Snow, Cutler, Bent, and another, all episcopal ministers, paid us a morning visit all together— They are here at an annual convention of ministers of that church, I believe recently instituted, and this is one of many indications of the aspiring and domineering spirit of the clergy of that church, who at this time are taking a desparate lurch backwards into the arms of the Pope— We were all invited to spend this evening at Mr Lunt’s—but my wife, Mary Catherine, her daughter Mary Louisa, and Louisa C Smith are all afflicted with severe colds, and my time is so totally absorbed in the work before me that we all sent excuses— I ransacked Goguet, Bailly and Dupuis for the origin of the Zodiac, Constellations and Milky way. I consulted also the Abbé Banier’s Mythology, and Fables of the Antients explained from history, and this reading swallowed up the day till dark— Then after half an hour for tea, I sat down by lamplight, and wrote till half past 11. wrote without intermission, driving like Jehu till the two pages for the day were completed. Trash which I shall not have assurance to deliver, and probably not even to print. Mr John A. Green, came this afternoon and took my acknowledgment and that of my wife to the deed of about 1200 square feet of land to Ebenezer Adams which we executed yesterday

7. IV.45. Saturday.  Sun rose 6.3. Fahrenheit 52.  The whole hemisphere was covered with watery clouds, excepting a small strip of clear sky along the eastern horizon of the width of one third of the Sun’s-disk; the cloud ranging over it and bordering the horizon beneath it— The Sun was therefore about one third risen, when his first beam was visible; and when full risen the central third part of his disk shone bright, while the upper and nether sections of it were beclouded. As he rose there fell a few drops of rain which immediately held up, and a calm cloudy day succeeded till about 4. in the afternoon when it began to rain very gently and continued with light and scanty showers all the evening— Charles’s two Sons, came from school at Hingham. Isaac H. Adams was here this forenoon and my Son spent the Evening with us.— I went up the hill at Mrs Charles’s request to settle the notice to be given to William C Johnson of the time when he may expect me to arrive at Utica, on my way to Cincinnati— He had intimated a disposition to go with me, if I should desire it— Mrs Charles wrote to him about ten days since, inviting him in my name to go, and has received his answer that he will go— She is now to write to him that he may expect me at Utica on Friday the 27th. of this month, and must be ready to start with me at moment’s warning any time after Thursday the 26th. I had no interruptions this day, and yet wrote not one line of my discourse, the work that hangs most heavily on my Spirits— In the historical summary of the Science, which I have introduced into the address, I have come to the period of the Arabian Caliphs, and am preparing for the transition to the modern Astronomy to Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Galileo, Descartes and Kepler the precursors of Newton, upon all of whom I must bestow a transient glance— Smith’s History of Astronomy, furnishes some hints, but absorbs much time— For the Arabians not having Ockley’s history of the Saracens which I want, at hand I must put up with the 52d. chapter of Gibbon, which I hunted up, and pored over— I plunged also further into the turbid anti-Christian stream of Dupuis, and recurred to Dacier’s life of Pythagoras in the first volume of the Bibliotheque des Anciens Philosophes— This mass of heterogeneous reading absorbed the day, and bore with such pressure on the brain, that when evening came I was compelled by overpowering lassitude to desist—looked with my granddaughter Mary Louisa into Bode’s Uranographia for sundry stars which I see every clear morning, and which I now find are in the body of the great Bear—and lost my day. John A. Green Editor of the Quincy Patriot, told me that he attended a convention of the Liberty party last week at Dedham. That they agreed upon an address to the People, which would be published in the Patriot as it is, and that they ordered 2000 copies of it to be printed separately with my Letter to the Bangor Committee on the back of the sheet.

8. V.15 Sunday.  Stormy Night, and day. Doctor Convers Francis, Professor of Pulpit eloquence and the pastoral care at Harvard University preached, this morning from Revelation 2.7. “He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches.—[”] There is something so original, in Dr Francis’s manner of treating his subject that I cannot follow the links of connection between his text and his discourse— There was commentary upon the words of the text, the meanin of which is rather obscure—he finally expounded them to mean a Message from the holy spirit to the Christian churches— The argument was intricate; and its drift not very obvious till it came suddenly to its conclusion—namely that whatever might be the doctrines preached in the name of the spirit none were genuine but such as led directly to the improvement of mankind in practical morality, virtue and benevolence— I did not expect that this would be the peculiar axiom, drawn from that text— Neither could I perceive the flaw in the thread— The first hymn which the Doctor gave out to be sung was 536. of Mr Lunt’s Christian Psalter— My hymn for sabbath morning.— There are in that collection 22. Psalms and hymns of my composition; but the exultation of heart that I felt on hearing it read and sung as a part of the devotions of the day was preposterous and I own sinful vanity. I pray God to suppress in me, all pride at any manifestations of human applause that I may have recently receive, and to dispose me in the sincerity of my Soul, to see in them only lessons of humiliation— Dr Francis dined with us and preached this afternoon, from 1. Corinthians 15.10. [“]But, by the grace of God I am what I am”; another text which I should not have selected as peculiarly copious of instruction. But perhaps the perfection of the art of preaching consists in extracting a large nut from a small shell. The Doctor’s lesson was that all Christians should consider themselves to be what they are, by the grace of God; and it is doubtless the duty and the joy of a virtuous man, to live with God always in his thoughts Dr Francis gave notice that from this time for the winter the morning hour of meeting will be half past 10. and the afternoon a quarter before 2— My most urgent labour necessarily lags behind— I consulted Sotheby’s Georgics, for the line. Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas. Tis Book 2. verse 490.

9. IV:15. Monday.  I was at last forced to lay aside for the day my most pressing occupation to make up my accounts as Administrator de bonis non, with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston, for the judge of Probate— And an Account with George Fuller, Administrator on the Estates of the two Moses Gills— To complete the settlement there is also an account with the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to be made up, but that may be deferred to another day.— The morning till 10 was consumed in preparing the two Accounts, and then I went in to Boston, with Louisa C. Smith, my Son, and my grand daughter Mary-Louisa.— Called at Robert C. Winthrop’s, but he was not at home— At the probate-Office, where I met Mr George Fuller. I exhibited my Account N. 3. as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, to the judge; and I had now the Office copy of my account N. 2. settled in November 1839. Neither the original nor record of which could be found at the office at the Courts which I have attended within the last year; and the want of which has hitherto prevented the final settlement of the account with Fuller.— The Account with him and the Account of Administration were inspected by the judge and by Mr Fuller, who agreed to settle the account with him, as drawn up by me; but afterwards asked me to let him take the account with him, to which I assented and he took it— I met Solomon Lincoln the U.S. Marshal who piloted me to the Office of Mr Bassett the Clerk of the U.S. Courts, where I borrowed a copy of the Acts of Congress of the last Session. At my Son’s Office I met Mr Curtis, who informed me that Mrs Alicia Boylston died at Providence R.I. at 2. O’Clock yesterday afternoon— Mr Sherman Leland the judge of probate for the County of Norfolk keeps an Office in Boston, and at our request came to Charles’s. We presented an application to him nominating Charles Francis Adams for his appointment as the third Trustee under Ward N. Boylston’s will in the place of his widow, now deceased— The judge said he would hold an adjourned Court at Roxbury next Saturday, and then make the appointment— Mr Curtis had the second copy of the bond of indemnity to Petty Vaughan, received by the Great Western arrived on Saturday at New-York. I took it with me— I met De Grand in State Street, and he went with me to N. 33. Chatham Street John D. and Moses Williams, where I ordered a cask of Claret and a cask of Teneriffe wine. Returning we went into the new-Merchants Exchange, where I met Mr Green the past and future Postmaster— At 1. we rendezvous’d at Mr James H. Fosters, and came home to dine. Charles’s sons John and Charles dined with us, and afterwards went to Hingham. He was here this evening.

10. IV. Tuesday.  The sky was not wholly cleared off this morning so that I could not see the Sunrise. I was able therefore to devote the morning till breakfast to the Diary, and just finished it in time— I may therefore lay it down as a general rule that rising at 4. I can close the record of the day before, to breakfast at 8. and I can do no more— But then the disposable part of the day is gone— I hoped I should have a long day for progress on the Astronomical Discourse; and leisure for my correspondence. I was bitterly disappointed— Orin P. Bacon, Postmaster at the Neponset Village with his Uncle Asa Bacon, an inhabitant of the State of Vermont, and his Son Washington Asa Bacon, a settler at Detroit in the State of Michigan, paid me, together a morning visit— I went into my garden to visit my trees and plant some whole peaches and pears, nuts and acorns, but was called back to Mr Brigham to agree upon arrangements for the meeting at Dedham this day fortnight when I am to address the People of the County of Norfolk, and of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— Mr Brigham will go with me—to start at 1/2 past 7. A.M—reach Dedham at 9. Hold the meeting at 10. and return home to dine immeditely after the address— We agreed also upon other details of arrangement. I went a second time into my garden and Nursery, and was recalled again to a visit from Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, and the Revd. Doctor Pierce of Brookline— A visit of courtesy and civility— Coll. Perkins is close upon four score— My acquaintance with him commenced at the ordination of Henry Ware at Hingham in September 1787. Since which he has been prosperous in life and is now one of the wealthiest men in this country— I finally planted my pears and peaches promiscuously in a row, by the gate between the garden and Nursery, but without order or selection of seeds.— The morning was gone and I was called to dinner— It was scarcely over when Mr Cummings of the Quincy Lyceum came to enquire, if I could deliver a Lecture there this day fortnight at 1/2 past 7. in the evening— I told him I was engaged to deliver a Lecture, precisely at that time, at Springfield 100 miles from this place— As there is no day between this and then, which would suit the Quincy Lyceum, Mr Cummings thanked me for my former services to them, and released me from any engagement for the present Season— My Son went to Boston, and attended the funeral of Mrs Alicia Boylston at Mount Auburn and returned home to dine— John Lane Boylston, his two sons and three daughters, and Mr. Curtis were there— The extreme pressure upon my time prevented me from attending; much to my regret— Charles brought home and gave me a Boston Morning Post of this day containing a Letter from Duff Green at London dated the 18th. of September last, somewhat concerning me, and which I am to consider whether I should notice it or not. The print being too small for my eyes, I took it, with my grand-daughter Mary Louisa into my Library, and she read it for me.

11. V. Wednesday  Sun rose 6.8. clear— Fahrenheit 40.  Rising an hour later than my time, precludes the making up of my record before breakfast, and that throws it back upon the noon tide bell; and excepting the walk up hill to see the rising sun, and the visits to the wood house I superseded all athletic exercise. I received a Letter from Mr Henry Clay, with a kind and cordial invitation to Kentucky,  and to Ashland his house, on the occasion of my approaching tour to Cincinnati— And the invitation is extended equally to Mrs Adams— I receive it with a full sense of the generous and friendly feeling of Mr Clay; but under equal embarrassment whether to accept or to decline it— I had intended not to protract my journey beyond the absolute necessity required for the performance of the duty which I have engaged to perform; and that becomes more formidable as I approach the day of performance. Even now it brings me to the borders of distraction— There are numerous reasons why I should not step beyond the State of Ohio, and my deliberate judgment is that I should adhere to that determination— Yet there are considerations of great weight prompting to my acceptance of the invitations to Kentucky, and especially that of Mr Clay— I must wait for Counsel.— Deacon Spear and his son Charles were here with his brother in Law, Mr Crowell from Londonderry in New Hampshire— The Deacon left with me plans of two lots of woodland, parcels of the 600 acres and adjoining my lots there, which Mr Josiah Bass junr offers for sale—with an appraisement by Lewis Bass high above its real marketable value.— After dinner we had a visit from Mr and Mrs Loring of Hingham— Mr Loring urged me warmly to deliver an address to the whigs at Boston upon the public Lands; about which he said the People were very much in the dark.— But I have already undertaken more than I can perform.— This afternoon I undertook to gather and pack up in chests all my files of Letters received since the 3d. of March 1829. when I retired from the President’s house to Meridian hill— I packed in the rough chest received last Spring from Washington, all the files from 1829. to 1837. inclusive; and they fill the chest— They are yet not complete, and need a thorough new packing; for which I hope to have time and leisure and resolution hereafter— The files from 1838 to this time will require a second chest. Mean time my day was consumed my spirits worn out and my soul cast down to the nervous affections of second childhood— An alarm of inflammation in the eyes, suddenly supervening yesterday and this day aggravates my anticipations; and the necessity of suppressing my emotions before my family, does not alleviate them— Charles and his wife were here this evening— I gave Abby, a card portrait autograph, such as one I gave last week to Mrs Sarah Morton— I snatched a half an hour to read some pages of Dr Bowditch’s Article on Modern Astronomy, in the North American Review and wrote two pages by setting up till Midnight.

12. IV:10. Thursday.  Sun rose 6.9. clear, fog below. Fahrenheit 36.  A tolerable night’s rest, that is to say of four hours dissipated most of my nervous fantasies, but not the soreness and inflammation of my eyes; but my washing and dressing with making of my fire, providing my chamber with firewood for the day, and tripping up the hill to see the sun rise occupied a large hour and a half of the morning.— The sun rose crystal clear and Charles house on the hill was surrounded by an atmosphere equally clear; while all the low lands around, and my own house were covered with a thick fog— Returning from my walk my fingers were pinched with cold so that I could not write— I read therefore, part of Dr Bowditch’s Article upon modern Astronomy in the North American Review of April 1825. without finishing it— A valuable Article to which I must if possible again recur— But this delayed my diary page of yesterday till dinner time— My wife, Louisa C. Smith, Charles and his wife went to Boston, and returned home to dine— Mean while I had visits from Mr John P. Robinson the Episcopalian Minister of Christ Church in this town; with Mr Wells, teacher of a school at South Boston and eleven of his boys— After that Friend Crane of Canton, a man born in 1776. and to whom the Christian name was given in pursuance of a resolution long premeditated by his father— He came to see me from curiosity merely. Towards Sunset Coll. Josiah Quincy junr called; having come out from Boston to look at the beautiful place which has been desolate all this summer because there is too much solitude at Quincy for his wife. His son Samuel was with him— My Son brought a bond to be given by him to the judge of probate for the county of Norfolk, and to which Mr Nathaniel Curtis are to be the sureties, and myself, upon his appointment by the judge, as the third Trustee, for the execution of the Trusts created by Ward Nicholas Boylston’s will in the place of his widow; now deceased— Charles and myself signed and sealed the bond, and Louisa C. Smith, and my son John’s widow, Mary Catherine signed as witnesses—which they did also to my execution of the two copies of the bond of indemnity and release which have been received from him recently by the Acadia and the Great Western— I continue my endeavours for the assortment of my papers; but receive daily more Letters than I am able to answer— I have this day one from S. P. Hildreth and 25. a Committee of the Inhabitants of Marietta in the State of Ohio 3. Octr. 1843. an invitation to visit that place on my tour to Cincinnati—and one from John A. Watkins, Rodney, Mississippi 19. Septr. 1843. a very earnest exhortation to me to prevail upon Congress to erect a monument to George Washington, to cost half a million of dollars.— My work upon the Astronomical Address was postponed as usual from hour to hour till after the curfew and then the heavy drowsy head and smarting eyes so languidly performed their offices that it was with extreme effort I got through one-page devoted to Kepler.

13. IV:15. Friday.  An uninterrupted and yet an inefficient day—  Charles went to Boston and returned to dine—  Great part of the day was consumed in packing up my files of Letters from 1838 to 1842 inclusive in one of the rough hewn chests from Washington, which they fill.— All the files from 1829. to the close of the last year are now packed in these two chests but it would require a week of time to repack them in perfect order, and they might very advantageously be decimated for preservation, and nine in ten of them committed to the flames. I found upon the files sundry papers which I have long been searching for in vain Among them the bond of indemnity and release to Petty Vaughan, which has been so long missing: five of my son Charles’s quarterly accounts, and the statement of the Gill claim on the Administration of Thomas Boylston’s Estate, which I drew up in June 1839. and which had so unaccountably disappeared.— I received this day Letters 1. from Samuel N. Sweet. 7. Octr. Rochester New-York, with a narrative of my visit to Rochester, by a youth named John C. Chumasero, and some enquiry of my opinion concerning a book upon elocution of which he is the author and presented me with a copy when I was there— 2. From Hiram Teal and Co. 30 Septr. 1843. La Fayette Indiana, with enquiries concerning a petition to Congress which they say they sent to me last winter, but of which I have no recollection. 3. from Edmund Quincy, Dedham 12. Octr. an exceedingly cordial invitation to his house on the 20th. when I am to address my Constituents of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, in that town— 4. from the late judge John Davis. Boston 12. Octr: enquiries and remarks upon Astronomy, with much highly interesting matter— All these Letters require answers, but where shall I find to write them.— I finished reading this day Smith’s posthumous fragment history of Astronomy to the time of Newton, and Dr Bowditch’s Article on Modern Astronomy in the North American Review of April 1825.—both excellent summaries—the Article taking it up, where Smith leaves it, and the two forming together a complete and very useful abridgement of the history of the Science from its origin down to 1825.— Dr Bowditch confines himself to mere matter of fact; indulging far less in philosophical speculation than the man of Scotland.— Bowditch’s Review is precious for the selection of topics which the modern Astronomers have chiefly discussed; and for the list of the recent Astronomical writers whose works he recommends with favourable notice. Among them is a History of ancient Astronomy in 2. 4to. Volumes Astronomy of the middle ages in 1. and of modern Astronomy in 2. by Delambre which I have never seen— Charles brought me a message from Mr Nathaniel Curtis requesting me to prepare a Letter to Petty Vaughan to be sent with the bond of indemnity, by the Acadia Steamer the day of whose departure will be next Monday. I accordingly wrote the Letter.

14. IV:10. Saturday  The Misses Maria, and Elizabeth Rebeca Nicholson daughters of Commodore Samuel Nicholson, a naval officer of the War of Independence came from Dedham, where they reside to consult with me, concerning a claim for arrears of pay due to their father for a term of 13 Months, during which he was under arrest upon trial by a Court Martial— He was honourably acquitted of the charges, but his pay was suspended while he was under arrest and was never restored— In 1836. These Ladies petitioned Congress upon this claim Their petition was presented by William Jackson, and referred to a Committee— It was afterwards in the charge successively of John Reed and of William S. Hastings— There was another petition by their sister Mrs Rogers of New-York, for herself and them, for the same claim, and Mr Talmadge the Senator from New-York, has advocated the claim in the Senate. Theron Metcalf of Dedham drew their petition, and with it were sundry papers to support the claim which have never been returned to them— They have heard that they were mislaid and could not be found. They shewed me a copy of their petition which I read— They are I take it both of the last century and totally destitute— I advised them to prepare a new petition, referring to the former one and to the proceedings of Congress upon it. To send me the new Petition, which I promised to present and to call up the old one with its vouchers— Mr Lunt called and gave me a minute of the birth of Daniel Quincy 12 Septr. 1650. and of John Quincy, 5. April 1652 (he died 14. Augt. 1674) and of the death of Henry Adams 8. October 1646. which he took yesterday from the Boston town records. He agreed to go with me next Wednesday to the ordination of Mr Allen at Jamaica Plains— to leave here at 1/2 past 11 O’Clock A.M The council are to meet at 1 p.m. The ordination service to commence at 2. and tea after it is over— After dinner Isaac H. Adams and his Sister Mrs. Angier were here— Also Dr Fisher of Dorchester and Mr Edward Jarvis who said that they proposed to memorialize Congress, to demand a revisal of the returns of the last census especially with regard to the number of persons returned as insane. From these returns it is made to appear that there is an immense disproportion of insane persons, of the free coloured class, over every other portion of the population. The Slave-mongers are building upon it a systematic argument in support of Slavery. Mr Jarvis has published in the Boston Courier an Article, proving that the census returns have been falsified to give this appearance to the facts.— He believes that the falsification of the Document was made at the Department of State, and therefore proposes this memorial to demand the revisal of it— I told him that if they would send the memorial to me I would present it—

15. V:15. Sunday.  Sun rose 6.12. Set 5.20 Fahrenheit 34.  White frost. Chilly day. Just before meeting this morning, a Card was brought to me from French’s tavern, with the name engraved on it of Aaron Ely Hovey, with the word Mrs in pencil mark prefixed to the name, and From Washington citty D.C. underneath—and on the back of the card “Please call after church. I want to see you on particular buisness” in pencil, without signature. Mr Smith, a young man recently settled as a colleague of Dr Francis Parkman in Boston was the preacher. His morning text from Romans 1.28 [“]And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient.” After meeting I went over to French’s tavern, and enquired if there was a lady there who wished to see me— George French said yes, and shewed me to a chamber up two pair of stairs, where was a mean looking woman, in a decent mourning dress. To shew me who she was she exhibited two certificates of good character and conduct one by the name of Vinsen, and the other signed by a minister of a church at Saybook in Connecticut attesting her admission as a member of the church there in 1836. She then told me a long story of her living at Washington from 1822 to 1828. of her subsequent marriage with Mr Hovey and of their poverty and destitution— She wanted money.— I asked her if she lived with her husband? Sometimes.— But he had been for a long time unable to obtain employment— Did they live at Saybrook?— At Westport— I refused to give her money, with some expression of indignation that she, a member of the church should come here to demand money of me.— I asked if she had not written to me, making the same demand— She said she had. She asked if I would give her enough to pay her expenses back? I said not a cent—and left her.— When I got home I found Mr Smith the Minister and Mr Degrand from Boston, who dined with us. While we were at dinner Mr Grattan the British Consul came and took my acknowledgment of my signature and seal to the Bond of indemnity and release to Petty Vaughan. With him was Mr Reed, one of the late Commissioners from New Brunswick at the negotiation of the Ashburton Treaty— They declined staying to dine and Mr Grattan borrowed my cloak to return to Boston— Mr Smith’s afternoon text was from Hebrews 12.14. [“]Follow peace with all men, and holiness without which no man shall see the Lord.”— We hand company at tea and in the evening as above in the margin— Mrs Charles gave me a note to her from Mary Ann Bigelow and I received a note in pencil from Mrs Hovey.

16. IV:15. Monday.  A pattern day. When I rose, the sky was beclouded with lucid spots in the East, but about five, it began to sprinkle and rained in copious showers with short intervals the whole day and evening: Fahrenheit 52. I finished my Diary minutes just in time for breakfast, and by snatching every leisure moment, wrote 3 pages of Astronomy, to make up for the lapse of the two preceding days in which I had not written a line— And I closed the day by writing an answer to Mr Henry Clay’s invitation to visit him at Ashland, his residence in Kentucky— This is I believe the maximum of performance in writing in the space of one day for the rest of my life.— But I received with the mail this morning a letter from Mr Frye to my son, which supposing it to relate to the affairs of Mr T. B. Johnson, of no urgency, I left on my table, till evening twilight came on, when I took it up the hill and delivered it— My wife on leaving Washington to come here had left in charge with Doctor Hall Mr Johnson’s attending physician, in the event of an unfavourable change in the symptoms of Mr Johnson’s disease, to have notice of it immediately conveyed to her; and Mr Frye says that Dr. Hall, in concurrence with Dr Thomas and Mrs Smith requests him to give that notice.— I received also Letters 1. from David A. Bokee and 3 others committee of the whigs of Brooklyn, who are proposing to hear a course of political lectures this Season, and invite me to deliver the introductory. 2. from John L. Sibley—Assistant Librarian of Harvard University, making enquiries concerning the books that I have given to that Library— Also concerning the books given by my father—donations, he observes which never have been sufficiently acknowledged— He enquires also concerning the titles annexed to names in the triennial Catalogues; upon which I am not well informed. 3. from Lewis Johnson, Washington 11. Octr. 1843. with an enclosure for John Otis— My daughter Mrs John Adams has undertaken to make a copy for me of the Discourse prepared for delivery at Cincinnati on the occasion of laying the corner-stone of the Astronomical Observatory at that place. I have projected an address of 48 pages which would take 3 hours in the delivery. 45 pages of it are written, and I want at least 25 more, to fill up the Outline—but I have not the time, and must close abruptly leaving perhaps the most important part of what should be said unnoticed My wife on the advices received this day from Washington, of the dangerous state of her brother, thinks of going off immediately for Washington, and if she goes, I have promised to go with her— It disconcerts all my arrangements, but duty admits of no alternative.

17. IV. Tuesday.  Sun rose 6.14. Fahrenheit 40.  Clear sky—whereupon I went up the hill and saw the Sun rise, and consequently could not finish my daily record before breakfast— Calisto was perpendicular to the horizon from my Northeastern window tail downwards, Benetnasch so far above the horizon that I assume Arcturus rose at 5. but I did not see him— At 5 the dawn is so far advanced the bright stars of the Bear herself have faded almost out of sight, and those in her paws are no longer visible.— They do not indeed properly belong to the Bear any more than Asterion or Chara.— My only domestic interruption of the day was to see the disposal of 280 bottles of common claret wine from the cask purchased last week of John D and M. Williams in my cellars.— I have taken this occasion to have the cellars themselves cleared out, which was needed; and which I have too long neglected. I had upwards of 200 of the bottles of claret deposited in the arch under west-end of the house and 6 dozen in the Arch under the East-end— In the central cellar I found 5 boxes of wines brought in 1829 from Washington, and took out of one box 12 bottles of Vin de la Nerthe packed up at Tain—choice Hermitage— I must give it away. Mr Brigham called this afternoon, and enquired from the Norfolk County Committee whether I could furnish them with a copy of the address I am to deliver at Dedham next Tuesday— I told him that would be impossible— That I have little or nothing written— That I shall have time to write little or nothing, and that a great portion of my address must and will be extemporaneous— I agonize at the thought, and it haunts me day and night.— But I said I supposed there would be reporters there from the Boston Newspapers; and they must put up with their reports; for I shall not have even time to revise them— He said he believed the Committee would employ a reporter— I told him I might perhaps be obliged to go off to Washington the day after to-morrow, in which case it will be impossible for me to deliver the address at Dedham; and if it should be so, I must rely upon the Committee to give notice to the People of the District in time to save them from being disappointed— As I lost the light of day to write, I went over the hill to Mr Lunt, and notified him that I might be prevented from going with him to morrow to the ordination at Jamaica plains— My wife seems strongly inclined to go immediately to Washington; and have promised if she goes to go with her— Mr Lunt’s father was at his house— Charles and his wife and daughter Louisa were here this evening— Their boys do not go again to Hingham.— I wrote this evening till past 11. Three pages this day; and filled my 48th. page.

properties.dateline: Quincy. Wednesday 18. October 1843. Jamaica Plains. Quincy.
properties.text: 18. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 6.15. Fahrenheit 32  In the Southern aspect of my front door, I took the thermometer up the hill, and at the Northwestern corner of Charles’s house as the Sun rose it stood at 28.— The average difference between the two expositions is about 4 degrees. Returning from my Sun rise walk I met Benjamin Andrews our coachman, with the morning mail from the Post Office, in his hand.— On giving me the Letters and Newspapers, he took from his pocket a Letter addressed to Charles F. Adams, which he observed was from Washington and had a black seal— The superscription being in the hand writing of Mr Frye, I opened it and found it dated the 14th. at 7. in the evening and announced that Mr Thomas Baker Johnson, my wife’s only brother died that same evening at 10 minutes before 6. and that it would be necessary to inter his remains before any of the family could reach Washington. I wrote immediately to Mr Frye, enclosing a copy of Mr Johnson’s Will, and authorising him to do every thing necessary for its execution till I come— My wife not thinking it necessary to hasten her departure for Washington, my own arrangements remain undisturbed— Mr Richardson of Braintree was here anxious about an appropriation for the Boston Custom house, to the building of which he says he and his company have delivered by contract stone to the amount of 30000 dollars, for which they are unpaid.— Mr Lunt, came before 11. and again at half past 11. and went with me to Jamaica Plains, to attend the Ordination of Joseph Henry Allen as Pastor of the third parish in Roxbury. The Council met at the village Hall at 1. O’Clock P.M. The proceedings there were short and unanimous; and at 2. they proceeded to the meeting house where the services were performed in the following order—Voluntary—Ordination—Anthem—Introductory prayer by Revd. F. T. Gray—Selections from the Scriptures by Revd F. D. Huntington—Original hymn—Sermon by Revd Joseph Allen of Northborough, father of the youth now ordained— The text was Hebrews 13.8. [“]Jesus Christ, the same yesterday, and to day, and forever.” Original hymn— Tune Priscilla. Prayer of Ordination by Revd. Edward B. Hall of Providence R.I. Charge by Revd. Thomas Gray D.D. the Pastor of the same church who has just resigned his office. Right hand of fellowship, by Revd. John Fothergill Waterhouse Ware of Fall river: a son of Dr Henry Ware junr. recently deceased. The address to the Society, by Revd. George Putnam of Roxbury, and the concluding prayer by the Revd. Nathaniel Hall of Dorchester— Then, what is called an Ascription sung by the choir, and the benediction by the newly ordained pastor— All the services were good and well performed— A collation at the village Hall before and after the service— No other beverage but cold water and cool tea. The services closed a quarter past 5— We had called at Dr Gray’s house. Mr Lunt came home with me. We landed at 1/2 past 6. and I wrote till 11.
